DOC.HEAD: Jury Recommends Death for Convict Found Guilty of Furlough Murder
DOC.TEXT: A jury Thursday recommended execution for a convict who murdered his ex-wife while on prison furlough last year. Alan L. Matheney, 39, stood quietly as Lake County Superior Court Judge James E. Letsinger read the recommendation of death in the electric chair. Letsinger, who must make the final decision, set sentencing for May 4. The same jury Wednesday rejected Matheney's insanity defense and convicted him of murder and burglary in the March 4, 1989, beating death of Lisa Marie Bianco. The jury deliberated for more than four hours Thursday before issuing a recommendation. Had jurors not elected to recommend death, they could have urged a prison sentence of up to 60 years for murder and 20 years for burglary. Matheney's mother, Martha Matheney, showed no reaction to the decision as she sat in the back row of the courtroom. The victim's father, Eugene Bianco, said he was pleased. ``It's a just sentence for the crime he committed,'' Bianco said. ``I hope it doesn't drag on for years.'' A death sentence would automatically be appealed to the state Supreme Court. Bianco said his grandchildren still have nightmares about the night Matheney broke into their home, armed with an unloaded shotgun, and threatened their mother. Matheney chased Ms. Bianco into the street and beat her outside a neighbor's home. ``The kids miss their mother more, and they wish Mr. Matheney was no longer their father,'' Bianco said. Letsinger extended a gag order on attorneys until sentencing. St. Joseph County Prosecutor Michael P. Barnes cited the order and declined to comment. Defense attorney Scott L. King, however, held a brief news conference outside the courthouse and said he would argue for a prison term. The state proved two circumstances _ burglary and lying in wait _ to justify the death penalty, county deputy prosecutor John D. Krisor said earlier. The slaying sparked a furor over officials' failure to notify Ms. Bianco, 29, of the furlough for Matheney, who had been serving an eight-year sentence for assaulting her in 1987. The state's furlough program was suspended and later reinstated with tightened restrictions.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Awards $2.7 million to Family of Aeromexico Airliner Crash Victims
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge awarded more than $2.7 million in damages Wednesday to the family of a father and son who perished when a small plane collided with an Aeromexico jet over Southern California in 1986. It was the second case to result in a damage award to relatives of people killed in the disaster, which claimed 82 lives. U.S. District Judge Manuel L. Real ruled the family was entitled to $2,733,666 in compensation for economic and personal losses due to the deaths of Joe Guzman, 45, and his son Robert, 18. Joe Guzman's daughter Reann, 5, was awarded $427,254 of the damages. The Norwalk truck driver and his son were on the Aeromexico jet returning to Los Angeles from a fishing vacation in Baja California when the jet collided with a small private plane and crashed into suburban Cerritos. The death toll totaled 67 people in the aircraft and 15 people in the neighborhood 20 miles southeast of Los Angeles. In the first case, a different judge awarded about $1.3 million to a San Jose man who lost his wife and son in the crash. Dozens of similar cases to determine damages are pending. The lawsuits are based upon the decision of a federal jury that last April blamed the crash equally on the government, through the actions of an air-traffic controller, and on William Kramer, the pilot of the small plane.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets for First Time Admit Responsibility for Katyn Massacre
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with seven grafs to UPDATE with Jaruzelski scheduled to visit Katyn on Saturday, Poles were interned in 1939. Picks up penultimate graf `The killings...'
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union for the first time has admitted responsibility for the massacre of thousands of Polish prisoners in the Katyn forest during World War II, the British Broadcasting Corp. reported Friday. Until now, the Soviet Union has blamed the 1940 massacre of 15,000 Polish Army officers and soldiers near the western town Smolensk on Nazi Germany. The formal admission of guilt coincides with the three-day state visit of Polish President Wojciech Jaruzelski, who is scheduled to visit Katyn Saturday. The acknowledgement of responsibility for the slaying has been one of the conditions for improvement in relations between Poland and the Soviet Union. A BBC World Service radio news bulletin quoted Radio Moscow as saying recently discovered documents determined the crime was carried out by the Soviet NKVD, predecessors of the KGB secret police. The BBC quoted the official radio as describing the massacre as one of the worst outrages of the Stalinist era in the Soviet Union and said Radio Moscow expressed deep regret for the atrocity. The Katyn area, where the bodies of more than 4,000 Polish offiders were found in a mass grave, changed hands as the war progressed, first being under Soviet control and then Nazi control. The victims were prisoners of war captured in the Nazi-Soviet partition of Poland at the start of the war. The Poles had been interned after the Soviets invaded Poland in 1939. The killings eliminated some of most talented officers in Poland, and for years has been a source of deep resentment for Poles who until August were under Communist rule. The government is now under rule of the Solidarity tradue union movement. The crime was first disclosed in 1943 by the Nazis, who attributed it to the NKVD.

DOC.HEAD: Culture Minister Says New U.S. Visa Rules Will Harm Foreign Artists
DOC.TEXT: Culture Minister Jack Lang has denounced a new U.S. immigration rule, saying it will soon be easier for foreign artists and performers to work in Moscow than New York. Lang was referring to a regulation, which took effect Feb. 26, requiring foreign artists who wish to work temporarily in the United States to show ``proof of their commercial success or international fame'' to obtain the desirable H1 visa. ``Under the new rule, Vincent van Gogh would be denied access to American territory,'' Lang told reporters at a news conference. ``The ruling means that as far as cultural exchange is concerned, Moscow is more accessible than Los Angeles or New York,'' he said. A second category of visas, called H2s, are issued on a regular basis to ordinary alien workers. But Lang said the procedure for obtaining them is much slower and more complicated, making it difficult for performers to arrange their schedules. The U.S. Embassy in Paris issued a statement saying no laws concerning H1 or H2 have been changed. ``The new regulations issued on Feb. 26 were simply a clarification of existing laws. There has been a long tradition of cultural exchange between France and the United States and we trust that a continuing spirit of cooperation and mutual respect will resolve any problems that may arise,'' the statement said. In a recent commentary in Billboard magazine, American immigration lawyer Jeffrey Gabel said there were fears in the United States that the new rule would hinder foreign artists who are not superstars. ``The effects of this action could narrow the chances of foreign artists and entertainers and their support staffs to enter the United States,'' Gabel wrote. Lang cited several examples of artists _ famous in France but not superstars in the minds of U.S. immigration officers _ who have been denied H1 visas. They include film maker Elie Chouraqui and the rock group ``Niagara,'' which was forced to cancel performances in Baltimore, Chicago and Washington this year after failing to get visas. Lang said Niagara's musicians were asked by immigration officials to ``show proof of their usefulness to the American public.''' Chouraqui, Lang said, received a visa only after weeks of waiting and the intervention of Lang, Paris Mayor Jacques Chirac and finally, Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America. Lang called the new rule ``unacceptable'' and urged the United States to modify it as quickly as possible to ``ensure the free circulation of artists worldwide.'' ``In France, all artists are welcome,'' he said during Tuesdays news conference, adding that French work permits for foreign artists are ``simple, rapid, certain, free, and almost automatic.'' Lang said he would discuss the issue with his colleagues at the May 13 meeting of European Cabinet ministers. He urged the formation of a Franco-American committee of artists to promote freedom of movement.

DOC.HEAD: Ailing Marcus Aurelius Doomed to Indoor Life _ For Now
LaserPhoto NY8
By FRANCES D'EMILIO
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Marcus Aurelius and his noble horse are back on the Capitoline Hill but the triumph was bittersweet _ pollution has forced the gilded bronze statue to abandon its glorious marble perch above the heart of Rome. The 1,800-year-old statue was removed nine years ago for cleaning and shoring up. It was taken from the Campidoglio, the municipal square crowning the Capitoline, one of Rome's seven hills. There it had rested upon a marble pedestal, designed by Michelangelo, the Renaissance genius who also laid out the square. After six years of examination, analyses and fund-raising, experts wielding lasers, scalpels and brushes began actual restoration in the spring of 1987. The team brought back some shine to the imperial toga and saddle, but it was soon clear that no technology existed to protect the treasure from the ravages of pollution and vibration in traffic-filled Rome. Tests also showed that the weather is too humid for the 19-foot-high monument. So the restored Stoic emperor and his steed could not return to the spot Michelangelo chose for them. Instead, they were installed Wednesday in a room, its temperature and humidity carefully controlled, in one of the palaces atop the hill that houses the Capitoline Museums. In abandoning outdoor life, Marcus Aurelius has illustrious company. In Florence, the gilded panels on the east entrance to the cathedral's baptistry _ a door so beautiful Michelangelo thought it was fit for paradise _ are destined for specially sealed chambers in a museum. The four gilded bronze horses on the facade of St. Mark's in Venice were installed inside the church after restoration. Research is under way for a coating that would protect the Marcus Aurelius statue from the corrosive atmosphere and allow the emperor to take his place again in the square. Meanwhile, the city is debating whether to put a replica atop the pedestal. Anna Sommella, director of archaeology for the Capitoline Museums, says leaving the pedestal empty could remind the public of the price it is paying for polluted air. ``A remedy must be found for the square and for all of Rome,'' she said as she watched workers unload Marcus Aurelius off a truck and push the upper half of the two-ton monument slowly into the museum. Past city administrations have tried with little success to limit traffic in the historic center. Current Mayor Franco Carraro, a Socialist, was clearly ill at ease when asked what he could do about the problem. ``We can't go backward. Even if we remove traffic, there are other kinds of pollution, heating fuels, industry. We can't be utopian in facing the problem,'' said Carraro. Romans would rather brave the four daily rush hours and inadequate parking than risk chancy public bus and streetcar service. Recurrent discoveries of underground relics have defeated ambitious subway plans. Moving Marcus to the museum from the Central Restoration Institute at San Michele, a former monastery across the Tiber from City Hall, created its own traffic jam. Two flatbed trucks transported the statue. The emperor, his arm outstretched, led the way. His horse, one front leg suspended in a graceful curve, followed. The public will be allowed inside the museum to see the statue as of April 21, the anniversary of Rome's founding. Legend has it that when the statue's gilding disappears, Rome will cease to exist. Most of the gold coating, cleaned in restoration, has been added over the centuries in previous restoration; only a few specks are original. The work is the only known large equestrian statue surviving from ancient imperial days. Others were destroyed after Christianity came to Rome. Historians believe Marcus Aurelius' statue survived because it was mistakenly identified as representing Constantine the Great, the Christian emperor. It was originally placed near the Lateran palace, which had been a papal residence. Pope Paul III ordered it removed to the Capitoline Hill in 1538.

DOC.HEAD: Astronomers Name Four Asteroids After Beatles
DOC.TEXT: Astronomers used to name asteroids after classic Greek and Roman figures. Times change. Two Lowell Observatory astronomers have named four asteroids Lennon, McCartney, Harrison and Starr. Brian Skiff and Edward Bowell have been Beatles fans for years. So the names seemed natural for the asteroids, discovered in 1983 and 1984 during a photographic survey of the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter. ``We thought it would be kind of nice to honor people who don't usually get recognized in space,'' said Bowell, a native of England. He said most asteroids now are named after eminent astronomers or scientists, although Harvard Observatory astronomers in Massachusetts named one after rock guitarist Eric Clapton. Bowell said asteroid finders have the right to name their discoveries, abiding by a code which permits almost any name except those of politicians or religious figures. Skiff and Bowell have named about 250 asteroids, including Shakespeare, Michelangelo, and Sagan (for Carl Sagan). The newly named asteroids range from five to 10 miles in diameter, which is typical, Bowell said. They are among 4,461 asteroids whose positions are accurately known.

DOC.HEAD: The Land of the Free _ Not Anymore
DOC.TEXT: Give us your tired, your poor, your huddled masses _ but make sure they have $3 to park. Free parking for people heading to the Statue of Liberty will become history in May, when the fee takes effect at the ferry lots in Liberty State Park, said Bernard Hartnett, chairman of the park's Public Advisory Commission. The exact date for the change was not set. The plan will affect 550 car spaces and 20 bus spots at the park, Hartnett said this week. The fee for cars will be $3, and commercial buses will pay $20 for a space. School buses and visitors with a state park, handicapped or senior citizen pass will be exempt. A ferry runs from a dock near the parking lot to the statue in New York Harbor. The National Park Service says 426,308 people took the ferry out to the statue in 1989. The advisory commission said the revenues will be used to build another parking lot next to a science museum at the 800-acre park.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhotos NY14, NY7
DOC.TEXT: Reports of the death of Garry Shandling's character on the final ``It's Garry Shandling's Show'' are premature. The last show's theme is death _ Shandling's, specifically. And though the lead character is killed off, in the tradition of television series endings, there is a surprise. In its inevitable style, ``It's Garry Shandling's Show'' ends with Shandling talking right to viewers at home. ``People always say, `Is it your show or is it your life?''' Shandling says to the camera. ``This is just a show.'' The final episode of the show, which made its debut four years ago on the Showtime cable network, is slated for telecast on June 1. ``We both made this decision a long time ago,'' co-creator and producer Alan Zweibel said during a taping of the final show Tuesday. ``It's time to try something else.''

Producer David L. Wolper was given France's highest civilian commendation for his work on the 100th anniversary celebration of France's gift to America, the Statue of Liberty. The Legion of Honor was conferred by French President Francois Mitterand, who was among the guests at the opening ceremonies of Liberty Weekend in 1986, it was announced Wednesday. Gerard Coste, France's consul general in Los Angeles, will officially present the honor May 2 as part of a celebration marking Wolper's 40 years in show business. Wolper has filmed productions in France, most recently the miniseries ``Napoleon and Josephine,'' and produced the acclaimed TV series about the adventures of French oceanographer Jacques Yves Cousteau. Wolper also won the Cannes Film Festival's highest honor, the Palm d'Or, for ``The Hellstrom Chronicle'' in 1971 and the Cannes Television Festival's Grand Prix for ``The Making of the President 1960.''

Britain's Princess Diana is on a private visit to Nicker Island in the British Virgin Islands. Photographers caught the princess lying on the beach Wednesday being covered in sand by her two sons, Prince Harry, 5, and Prince William, 7. This is Princess Diana's second visit to the British Virgin Islands in as many years.

Kurt Masur, a leader in the democracy movement in East Germany and a conductor of the Gewandhaus Orchestra of Leipzig, has been named the New York Philharmonic's music director. The orchestra announced Wednesday that Masur, 62, will replace Zubin Mehta, who told the Philharmonic in November 1988 that he would leave as music director after the 1990-91 season. Masur's appointment is for five years and begins in the 1992-93 season, the Philharmonic's 150th anniversary season. He will conduct for 14 weeks that season and spend four weeks in New York in other activities. For the 1991-92 season, Masur will be ``music director designate,'' Stephen Stamas, chairman of the New York Philharmonic Society, said at a news conference. Stamas said he believes Masur will ``maintain a healthy interest in what is going on in Germany, while his interests will be largely musical.'' Masur was born July 18, 1927, in Brieg, Silesia, now in Poland. He studied at the music college of Leipzig. From 1960 to 1964 he was senior director of music at Berlin's Komische Oper and from 1967 to 1972 was chief conductor of the Dresden Philharmonic. Stamas said that Masur will remain principal conductor of the Gewandhaus Orchestra through the 1993-94 season, its 250th anniversary, and will maintain some association there.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Doctors Who Profit From Tests Order More
DOC.TEXT: Doctors' decisions to give tests or take X-rays depend in part on how much money they make on them, a study today says. The research supports the widely held but hard to document idea that doctors' own financial interests play a role in determining the kind and amount of care they give their patients. ``As in most professions, money matters,'' said David Hemenway, a Harvard School of Public Health economist who directed the study. The report, in today's New England Journal of Medicine, measured what happened when a chain of walk-in clinics changed the way it paid its doctors. Instead of a flat hourly wage, doctors could earn a percentage of all the fees they generated. With this financial incentive, they boosted the number of tests and X-rays they performed by about 20 percent. The study was conducted in 1984 and 1985 at Boston-area offices of Health Stop, the nation's biggest chain of walk-in clinics with 80 centers in six states. Nationwide, about 4,000 of these clinics have opened in the past decade. They specialize in quick care for routine health complaints, such as sprains and colds. Dr. Mark Shankman, Health Stop's chief executive officer, contended that the study was too small and flawed to draw conclusions. But he agreed that financial incentives can influence the way doctors work. Patients' needs differ, and doctors honestly disagree over how much _ or how little _ care is enough, especially when an extra test or two may rule out some remotely possible problem. The new study suggests that when such uncertainty exists, doctors may pile on the tests if they also profit from running up the bill. ``There is a lot of leeway in what you can do,'' said Hemenway, ``and when there are financial incentives, some physicians change a little how they behave in their practice patterns.'' During the period studied, doctors were still guaranteed payments of $28 to $32 per hour, depending on their age and experience. But if their patients' bills were high enough, they received part of the gross receipts instead of their hourly pay. They had the opportunity to keep 24 percent of the first $24,000 of their patients' monthly charges and 15 percent after that. The researchers compared the behavior of 15 doctors during three-month periods before and after the bonus system. Overall, they performed 23 percent more X-rays and 16 percent more tests after they became eligible for bonuses. Their total charges per month, adjusted for inflation, grew 20 percent. Seven of the 15 doctors regularly earned bonuses, and their pay rose 19 percent. The study did not attempt to learn whether patients benefited or suffered from the extra medical care. ``The implication is that part of the way doctors make decisions is the way they are paid,'' said Suzanne B. Cashman, a co-author of the study and a health services researcher at the Boston University Health Policy Institute. Shankman cited several shortcomings in the study besides the small number of doctors reviewed. Among them: _Even before the bonus system began, the chain had a profit-sharing program that provided a financial incentive to do more. _A widely used sore throat test became available during the study period, and this could have accounted for some of the additional testing. _One of the doctors studied had a sharp increase in X-ray use because he transferred to an office where he concentrated on occupational medicine, which requires frequent X-rays to diagnose work-related injuries. The latest study is part of a much larger examination of medical practices, patient satisfaction and physician attitudes at Health Stop. ``A lot of them said they didn't like it because of the pressure for money, money, money,'' said Hemenway of former and current Health Stop doctors. ``They felt it was a problem.''

DOC.HEAD: Voters Fickle in Judging Candidates' Past Drug Use
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Ann Richards overcame allegations of drug abuse to win the gubernatorial nomination in Texas, but analysts say voters can be fickle about judging politicians with drugs in their past. Age, sex and the drug of choice all may have something to do with it, they say. And so can the candidate's opponent. Accusations of drug abuse and related character attacks so dominated the four-week Texas gubernatorial runoff between Ms. Richards and state Attorney General Jim Mattox that one commentator said the contest had sunk from the gutters to the sewers. But the same issue created few ripples in Massachusetts, where 11 politicians last month admitted they had tried marijuana. And similar admissions appeared to play no role in the losing 1988 presidential campaigns of Democrats Bruce Babbitt and Al Gore. Just last week, the Senate approved Timothy Ryan as the nation's chief savings and loan regulator after senators displayed little concern that he had tried marijuana and cocaine while in law school. In Texas, Mattox pursued Ms. Richards relentlessly on the drug issue after she refused to say whether she had used illegal drugs. ``Did she use marijuana? Or something worse, like cocaine? Not as a college kid, but as a 47-year-old elected official sworn to uphold the law,'' Mattox asked in one television ad. Later he alleged outright that Ms. Richards, the state treasurer, once had a cocaine addiction. But by the end, he, too, was fighting off drug use allegations. Still to be seen is whether the drug issue will dog Richards in her general election contest against Republican Clayton Williams. Analysts say there are many potential difficulties, starting with her age. At 56, she is substantially older than the generation usually associated with and excused for experimental drug use. ``Anything you did before 25 is to be forgiven,'' even if it was only 10 years ago, said Democratic consultant Tony Podesta. ``But if you indulged your drug fantasies when you were 47, it sounds a lot different.'' The issue also is harder to overcome for women, analysts said, because people generally tolerate freewheeling behavior more easily in men than in women. In Ms. Richards' case, they note, the allegations also contrast sharply with the grandmotherly image she tried to project in her ads. The particular drug at issue also matters with voters. William Schneider, a political analyst at the American Enterprise Institute, said occasional or infrequent marijuana use, ``if not forgiven, is at least understood'' by voters, but cocaine is a different story. ``If it was only marijuana, she would have said so,'' Schneider said. Richards, a recovering alcoholic, told voters she had used no ``mood-altering'' chemicals in the past 10 years, but refused to say what, if any, drugs she had used previously. Ms. Richards won anyway, but analysts said the Texas race was a flawed test of whether voters will be forgiving of past drug use. Charles Cook, editor of Cook's Political Report, cited Mattox's attack-dog style, his failure to release his income tax returns and the last-minute allegations that he had smoked marijuana. ``It wasn't a situation where you had allegations about drug use by one candidate and the other candidate seemed pure as the driven snow,'' Cook said. ``Both candidates ended up with high negatives'' because of the drug issue, said Jill Buckley, a Democratic communications consultant. Buckley and others said voters found Ms. Richards the less offensive candidate because she started the race with a reputation for decency and there was a sense she was being unfairly hammered on drugs. In contrast with Texas, Ryan's law school experiments with marijuana and cocaine, recounted in a leaked FBI report, were all but ignored when the Senate confirmed him last week to head the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision. Senators were quick to condemn the leak and defend the nominee _ mostly on the grounds of his age, which is 44. Whatever Ryan did ``ended 17 years ago,'' said Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan. ``If he is to be held up to that standard, then we are going to wipe out a generation of men and women who are about that age, who may have experimented at one time or another with some type of drug.'' Podesta said some of the same dynamics were at work in Massachusetts when a crowd of politicians _ including a senator, two congressmen and five candidates for state office _ confessed to past dalliances with drugs. The public appeared to respond with a mass ``so what.'' ``You have a younger generation of politicians, a more liberal social atmosphere heavily influenced by the academic community,'' Podesta said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Refuses to Recognize Lithuanian Independence Declaration
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is refusing to recognize Lithuania's breakaway government, fearing a replay of 1956 when the United States rooted for Hungary's uprising but stayed on the sidelines as Soviet tanks crushed the revolt, his spokesman says. Bush, in a meeting with Baltic-Americans on Wednesday, rejected their plea for U.S. recognition of Lithuania as independent from the Soviet Union. The Baltic-Americans told the president that Lithuania is only the beginning of Soviet troubles. They said separatist movements will be boiling over in Latvia and Estonia by the time Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrives here for his summit with Bush at the end of May. ``The Latvians will be declaring independence in two weeks. Estonia is in the same process. By the time we get to the summit, we will have a situation in all three republics which is comparable to what is happening today'' in Lithuania, said Ojars Kalnins of the American Latvian Association. But White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush's policy on Lithuania ``is the correct one and it does not involve recognition.'' He said the president wants to ``avoid taking actions that would inadvertently make Lithuania's task more difficult by inflaming the situation.'' Bush, he said, mentioned Hungary in 1956 ``as an example of the situation that he wanted to avoid, a situation in which the United States supported the protest there and the movement there, and then the Soviet Union put it down by force and we were unable to do anything in support of our convictions.'' ``And he indicated that he did not want to precipitate a situation in which that would create the use of force or that ... similarly would cause us to be unable to act,'' Fitzwater said. The president has consistently voiced support for Lithuania's independence move because the United States never officially recognized the Soviet Union's 1940 annexation of the three Baltic republics. But even as he has warned Gorbachev that a crackdown or repression in Lithuania would harm a range of U.S.-Soviet relations, Bush has refrained from harsh criticism in favor of repeatedly calling for dialogue and peaceful resolution. Bush also has pointed out that Gorbachev deserves credit for allowing the democratic reforms in Eastern Europe and changes within the Soviet Union. He said as much to the Baltic-Americans on Wednesday, crediting Gorbachev's policies with allowing ``the atmosphere whereby Lithuania could consider its future in a different light because of glasnost (openness) and perestroika (restructuring),'' said Fitzwater. The Baltic-Americans said they were disappointed that Bush was unwilling to recognize the government of Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis or to give ``de facto'' recognition, a step short of official recognition. Mari-Ann Rikken of the Estonian-American National Council characterized the president as looking ``to find a way out, a way out of the Soviet Union for the Baltic states that will not result in a cataclysm for the Soviet Union and that will not result in a blood bath for the Baltic states.'' Fitzwater said Bush ``pointed out in forceful terms that the United States approaches this problem with many ramifications to consider.'' Lithuania and Hungary are not exactly parallel situations. Lithuania is trying to secede from the Soviet Union, while Hungary was an independent country under Soviet influence. Its government was seen as a Soviet puppet, and when anti-communist revolts began in 1956, the Soviet Union quickly and violently quashed them.

DOC.HEAD: US Moving Toward Easing Some High-Tech Export Curbs
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is preparing a proposal to ease restrictions on sales of high-technology items to the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe, but the changes likely will not go far enough to satisfy Western allies. Commerce Undersecretary Dennis Kloske, who supervises export control activities, said Wednesday there was growing agreement in the administration over the actions needed to provide Western technology to the struggling economies of Poland, Hungary and other former communist bloc countries. The administration is conducting a review, and recommendations on what changes can be made without jeopardizing national security should be presented to President Bush by the end of this month, Kloske said. ``There is an emerging consensus inside the administration that the changing developments in Eastern Europe will allow for a significant level of streamlining'' of export controls, Kloske told business executives attending a U.S. Chamber of Commerce trade seminar. Speaking to reporters later, Kloske said the administration strongly believes the Soviet Union should not be allowed access to the same level of technology being offered to other East European nations. The administration also is insisting that Eastern European countries sign agreements that guarantee that the high-technology products would not fall into Soviet hands. Such agreements also would provide for on-site inspection by Western officials. Kloske said the new governments of East Germany, Poland, Hungary, Czechoslovakia and Bulgaria have indicated a willingness to adopt enforcement programs to meet U.S. demands. U.S. allies, especially West Germany, believe the administration is still being too restrictive. The allies have been pushing for even more liberalization on exports to Eastern Europe and many believe the Soviets also should be allowed access to Western high-tech products as a way of supporting President Mikhail Gorbachev's economic reforms. But Kloske said the situation in the Soviet Union was still too volatile. Other administration officials have said the Soviet crackdown in Lithuania may have strengthened the administration's bargaining position. ``The Soviets are not going to receive preferential treatment overnight or any time soon,'' Kloske predicted. Sales of high-technology products to the Soviet Union and countries in the Eastern Bloc are regulated by the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls. The 17-nation COCOM group is composed of America's West European allies and Japan and Australia. COCOM was created during the Cold War to make sure that technology with military uses did not fall into communist hands. The United States has lately found itself isolated in the organization, resisting demands for much swifter relaxation of export controls. The Paris-based COCOM is scheduled to take up rules changes again during a June 7-8 meeting and Kloske said that session could well decide the fate of the entire export review process. ``If we cannot reach agreement in June, we begin to run a serious risk that the allies will begin shipping (to East Europe) on their own,'' he said. The administration is reviewing a proposal that would provide Eastern European countries with the same level of technology that is now being sold to China in the areas of computers, machine tools and telecommunications equipment. Earlier this week, the Soviet Union made a strong bid to the West to rethink its position on blocking Soviet access to the technology the country needs to modernize its economy. Stepan Sitarian, a deputy Soviet premier, told a conference in Bonn, West Germany, that the Soviets would be willing to agree to inspection procedures so the West could verify that high-technology equipment was not being used for military purposes. Kloske said the administration might be willing to consider liberalizing technology shipments to the Soviets in ``clearly civilian, non-strategic areas'' such as agriculture or textiles.

DOC.HEAD: Events in Eastern Europe Chilling Arms Control Talks, Experts Say
DOC.TEXT: Arms control progress is being chilled by the collapse of the Soviet position in Eastern Europe, the unsettling prospect of a united Germany and unrest in three Baltic republics, four specialists say. Assessing last week's inconclusive talks between Soviet Foreign Minister Euard A. Shevardnadze and Secretary of State James A. Baker III, the arms control advocates agreed there was ``little progress and some regression'' on key issues in strategic and conventional talks. ``I think the main reason has been the shock effect of the events in Eastern Europe and East Germany on Soviet thinking,'' former arms control negotiator John Dean told reporters. While the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, or START, talks should have no logical connection with events in Eastern Europe, ``there's bound to be something of a psychic impact,'' Dean said. The negotiating climate also has been complicated by the U.S. suggestion of moving quickly to ban mobile, land-based, multiple-warhead missiles, the experts said. ``To open up the MIRV (multiple-warhead) issue now means there will not be an early START treaty,'' said Spurgeon Keeney, president of the privately funded Arms Control Association. President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev open their summit meeting in Washington on May 30, but Keeney said: ``There is no chance there will be a (START) agreement by the time of the summit and the main problem now is if there can even be an agreement in principle by then.'' But Keeney and the others gave Bush high marks for continuing to emphasize the importance of reaching agreements with Moscow despite political pressure for him to more aggressively support Lithuania's recent declaration of independence. Also addressing the arms control issue were Paul Warnke, former director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, and Jack Mendelsohn, the Arms Control Association's deputy director. Keeney said that while both Bush and Gorbachev clearly want arms control agreements as quickly as possible, an apparent earlier consensus on how to deal with such strategic weapons as air-launched and sea-launched cruise missiles now appears to have been premature. The Soviets are raising serious questions on how to verify each side's declarations about the nature of such weapons, including their range and whether they are armed with conventional or nuclear warheads, Keeney said. Warnke said he believes the consideration of a ban on multiple warheads on missiles should await a second phase of the START talks. ``If we do want START I, we shouldn't throw this particular wrinkle in,'' he said. Warnke said there has been ``a toughening in the Soviet position'' overall. Some suggest this is due to ``the Baltic chill'' caused by Soviet efforts to quell the independence movement in Lithuania and the simultaneous moves toward independence in neighboring Estonia and Latvia, he said. ``The state of superpower relations does have an impact on negotiations,'' Warnke said, and added: ``There is speculation that the Soviet military is taking more of a role out of concern over the concessions their negotiators have made to date.'' But he said others feel the Soviets are just employing ``good negotiating tactics'' as the START talks near their end. Dean said there also has been a recent slowdown by the Soviets in the Vienna talks aimed at reducing conventional forces and arms in Central Europe. Progress on most issues is ``hanging fire'' and there is major difficulty on the issue of reducing Soviet and Western aircraft, said Dean, who now is arms control adviser to the Union of Concerned Scientists. Soviet negotiators have not been receiving fresh instructions, Dean said. He said reasons for the delay include Soviet leaders' preoccupation with other issues, the hardening of Soviet positions and ``the collapse of the Soviet position in Eastern Europe and in East Germany.'' Keeney said part of the blame may rest with unrealistic U.S. expectations after a series of Soviet arms control concessions. ``While it may be correct that the Soviets have dug in their heels, it's also true that the United States had reached the conclusion that the Soviets would accept any reasonable proposal we put forward,'' Dean added. ``That may have been unreasonable.'' Mendelsohn suggested there may be little progress on reducing conventional forces in Central Europe ``until the Soviets know what will happen'' in a united Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Uncover Genetic Details From 20-Million-Year-Old Tree
DOC.TEXT: Researchers have uncovered details of a gene from a magnolia tree that lived in Idaho about 20 million years ago, by far the oldest plant or animal tissue ever to yield that information. The genetic material came from leaf samples that were exceptionally well preserved by an ancient lake, researchers reported today in the British journal Nature. Such analysis can shed light on the relationships between extinct species and their present-day descendants, helping researchers construct the scientific equivalent of family trees. The new report demonstrates ``an opportunity to take a new technology and apply it to the study of ... classical problems in biology,'' said study co-author Michael Clegg of the University of California at Riverside. He did the work with postdoctoral student Edward Golenberg and others at the university, and scientists at the University of Georgia in Athens, the University of Idaho in Moscow and the DNAX Research Institute in Palo Alto, Calif. The leaf samples, from an excavation in the panhandle area of northern Idaho, were from 17 million to 20 million years old. The oldest material that previously had yielded to similar genetic analysis was human brain tissue about 7,000 years old, recovered from a bog in Florida, Clegg said in a recent telephone interview. Genetic material, called deoxyribonucleic acid or DNA, was extracted from leaf samples and a part of it was duplicated repeatedly using a technique called polymerase chain reaction. Researchers determined its chemical makeup, and found that the DNA was from a gene that acted as a blueprint for part of a particular plant protein. ``The fact that we could do it once probably means it can be done again'' with materials from other sites, Clegg said. The leaf samples were exceptionally well preserved, having fallen into a cold lake that rapidly silted in. The cold and the low amounts of oxygen available helped preserve the leaves, he said. It is unclear how many other sites could offer such well-preserved specimens for DNA analysis, he said. But the new report suggests the Idaho site itself may provide ``an extraordinarily well-preserved assemblage of fossils'' that could yield an abundance of information, much like the famed La Brea pits, said Karl Niklas, botany professor at Cornell University in Ithaca. The La Brea pits in Los Angeles are one of the world's richest known sources of Ice Age fossils. Clegg said DNA work has begun with other leaves from the site. The site contained remnants of more than 100 species of plants. Perhaps half were preserved in somewhat the same way as the magnolia leaves, and DNA might be recovered from some of them, said study co-author Charles Smiley of the University of Idaho. The site also contained 30 to 40 kinds of insects, some of which still had their original colors, and four kinds of fish, he said. But it is unclear what their potential for DNA analysis would be, he said. Niklas said that if other remains from the same site could be made to reveal genetic details, it would reveal ``an unique slice through time, based on DNA analysis ... That's an extremely exciting possibility.''

DOC.HEAD: Experimental AIDS Drug Reaches Fetus, May Prevent Infection, Study Suggests
DOC.TEXT: An experimental AIDS drug injected into two pregnant monkeys reached their fetuses, raising hope that it might block AIDS virus infection of human babies by their mothers, scientists said today. If used early enough in pregnancy, it might ward off perinatal AIDS infection, said study co-author Daniel Capon of Genentech Inc. of South San Francisco. The drug reached the fetuses about as easily as a human mother's natural proteins do as they build up disease resistance within babies, researchers said. The drug, called a CD4 immunoadhesin, has shown promise against the AIDS virus in the test tube, but its effectiveness in people is not yet known. The standard AIDS drug AZT can also reach fetuses, crossing the placenta ``quite well,'' said James Balsley of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases. Researchers are testing AZT's safety in pregnant women and plan to test whether it can block perinatal transmission of the AIDS virus, he said Wednesday. Some 1,734 cases of acquired immune deficiency syndrome in infants who were infected by their mothers have been recorded by the federal Centers for Disease Control. Scientists do not know details of how babies are infected, but many infections appear to happen during pregnancy, with some during birth. A child born to an AIDS-infected woman runs a 20 percent to 40 percent risk of being infected by the mother, studies suggest. The new work is reported in today's issue of the British journal Nature by Capon and others at Genentech, and Jerome Groopman and colleagues at Harvard Medical School and New England Deaconess Hospital in Boston. The immunoadhesin they studied is a man-made hybrid of parts of two natural proteins. One protein, called CD4, is found on the surface of some cells in the body. The other protein, an immunoglobulin, plays a key role in the body's disease-fighting immune system. The new study and previous research show that in the test tube, immunoadhesins can block the AIDS virus from infecting cells, and can trigger the killing of infected cells while leaving healthy cells alone. To test the drug's ability to cross the placenta, researchers injected two rhesus monkeys near the end of their gestational periods with immunoadhesins and then infused more drug for 24 hours before performing Caesarian sections. Blood from the newborns contained about 3 percent of the concentration of immunoadhesins that their mothers' blood had, researchers reported. Other experiments have shown that natural maternal immunoglobulins reach human fetuses at about the same rate, study authors said. With maternal immunoglobulins, Capon said, the fetal level builds up over time. A similar accumulation of immunoadhesins might occur if the drug is given early enough in pregnancy, he said. Gwendolyn Scott of the University of Miami School of Medicine, who is studying perinatal AIDS virus infection, called the immunoadhesin idea ``an exciting concept in terms of perhaps another way that perinatal transmission might be interrupted.'' Questions about safety of the fetus would have to be studied, she said in a telephone interview.

DOC.HEAD: World Ozone Pollution May Rise Over 30 Years, Study Suggests
DOC.TEXT: A projected increase of up to 50 percent in average global concentrations of the pollutant ozone over the next 30 years would make little difference in U.S. cities with an ozone problem, a scientist says. About 100 areas in the United States fail to meet federal standards for ozone levels, including essentially all major cities, according to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. But the projected global average increase would have only a minor impact on American cities because local pollution is the main cause of their ozone troubles, said scientist Brian Ridley of the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colo. Ozone is a form of oxygen that plays a Jekyll-and-Hyde role in the atmosphere. At high altitudes it shields Earth from solar rays that can promote skin cancer. But near the Earth's surface it is a pollutant that irritates sensitive lung tissues and harms crops. Low-altitude ozone is created by nitrogen oxides and hydrocarbons that come from automobile exhaust and industrial sources. Ridley was commenting on a study in today's issue of the British journal Nature that projected an increase of 21 percent to 50 percent in average global levels of low-altitude ozone by the year 2020. He also cautioned that such projections are uncertain because of lack of scientific knowledge about such factors as the distribution of nitrogen oxides in the atmosphere. The increase dealt with concentrations at the Earth's surface, over land only, study co-author Adrian Hough said in an interview. He and Richard Derwent did the projections at the Harwell Laboratory in Didcot, England. Hough said local ozone control measures may have to be more stringent if the projected increase takes place, because local ozone readings reflect this background level as well as local pollution. One projection focused on latitudes typical of the central United States. It found a rise in annual averages from about 30 parts per billion today to perhaps 35 parts or 45 parts per billion in the year 2020, Hough said. Under EPA criteria, an area fails to comply with the ozone standard if it exceeds 120 parts per billion for more than an average of once a year over a three-year period. Hough said the main factor behind the calculated rise in overall global ozone is increased emissions from industrialization and automobile use in developing nations.

DOC.HEAD: Student Loan Defaults Drop Slightly
DOC.TEXT: Education Department officials are reluctant to predict a new trend in student loan defaults, but trade school officials are claiming some credit for a 1.7 percentage point drop in the rate. ``Our problem with student loan defaults is too serious for hasty judgments about trends in the default rate,'' said Leonard L. Haynes III, assistant secretary for postsecondary education. The figures for fiscal year 1988, the latest available, are encouraging but not yet decisive, he said. ``We want to evaluate these data thoroughly before we draw any conclusions,'' Haynes said. Education Department data show the overall default rate dropped to 15.6 percent in fiscal year 1988 from 17.3 percent in 1987. In fiscal 1986, the default rate was 21 percent. For fiscal 1988, 385,000 borrowers who were supposed to begin repaying defaulted on a total of $1.07 billion in loans, while 2.46 million borrowers entered repayment on guaranteed student loans totaling $9.23 billion. In 1987, 2.23 million borrowers entered repayment, while defaulted loans due that year totaled 398,000. Larry Oxendine, acting director of policy and program development for the department, estimated the total of all defaulted loans at about $10 billion. The government has lent about $90 billion during the 25 years of the program. Stephen Blair, president of the National Association of Trade and Technical Schools, said a ``quick scan'' of the department data shows a significant drop in the number of defaults of trade school loans. Trade and other proprietary schools have been blamed in recent years for the spiraling student loan default rates. Some have been accused of using unscrupulous recruiting tactics to lure students to the schools just so they can get the federal money. ``We began a major national initiative four years ago (to reduce loan defaults at private career schools) and out of that we believe the reduction is due in part to our efforts,'' said Blair. Haynes said many factors contributed to the reduction in the overall default rate, including increased school default prevention efforts, a dramatic increase in the number of Supplemental Loans to Students entering repayment, plus technical changes in the calculations. According to Haynes, more than half of the total reduction came through excluding foreign schools or those with fewer than 30 borrowers, as well as institutions that are defunct, unaccredited or have withdrawn from the program. Of the 5,226 institutions tracked by the Education Department, more than 70 percent had default rates under 20 percent, Haynes said. Schools whose former students' default rates are above 20 percent must establish default management plans approved and monitored by the department. As an institution's default rate goes higher, additional measures are required, including a 30-day delay in release of loan funds to first-time borrowers and pro-rata tuition refunds. Beginning in 1991, schools with default rates above 60 percent are subject to expulsion from the federal student aid programs. Roberta Dunn, deputy assistant education secretary for student financial assistance, said 1,127 institutions with default rates of between 20 percent and 40 percent submitted management plans last year that were eventually approved. An additional 482 schools have rates higher than 40 percent. Institutions with defaults of 70 percent or higher include Tom Nolan's Chrysler Academy School, Decatur, Ill., 75.9 percent, defaults totaling $175,322; Cannella School of Hair Design, Chicago, 73.4 percent, $420,440; Stevenson's Academy of Hair, New Orleans, 75.8 percent, $108,057; Cambridge Technical Institute, Dayton, Ohio, 81.5 percent, $8,282,384; and Eason's Institute of Technology, San Antonio, 79.5 percent, $737,442.

DOC.HEAD: Maoist Guerrillas Black Out Capital, Policeman Killed
DOC.TEXT: Minutes after Shining Path guerrillas knocked out power to the capital once again, a Lima policeman was killed in a car bombing. Dozens of explosions were heard throughout the city immediately after the power was cut Wednesday night. The blackout affected cities and towns along 560 miles of the coast. The car bomb that killed the policeman exploded on one of Lima's main avenues in front of a private club that police frequent, Lima's top radio station reported. Almost simultaneously, six people were injured in a blast at the downtown offices of the University of San Martin, next to the Lima Election Board, the station reported. Four people were arrested immediately after the attack. A police spokesman said details of the bombings were not available. Witnesses said fires in the shape of the hammer and sickle were burning in the mountains outside blacked-out Lima. Guerrillas of the Maoist-inspired Shining Path frequently bomb power pylons, leading authorities to devise elaborate means for protecting them that have included high fences and land mines. The bombings and blackout came three days after the first round of presidential elections. The elections sent novelist Mario Vargas Llosa and political newcomer Alfredo Fujimori into a runoff that will probably be held in early June. The Shining Path had announced plans to sabotage the elections, and security was heavy, but little violence was reported in the capital over the weekend. More than 18,000 people have been killed since the Shining Path began its armed insurgency in 1980, the government says.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Soldier Charged With Premeditated Murder
DOC.TEXT: The Army says an investigator will decide whether a murder charge lodged against a paratrooper in connection with the Panama invasion should be forwarded for a possible court-martial. First Sgt. Roberto Enrique Bryan, a member of the 82nd Airborne Division based at Fort Bragg, N.C., faces a charge of premeditated murder of a Panamanian man and three counts of aggravated assault, Army spokesman Maj. Joe Padilla said. It is the most serious action taken by Army officials against a soldier in the aftermath of December's U.S. invasion of Panama, Padilla said. The charges are expected to be referred to an investigating officer, who will recommend whether the case should be forwarded to Maj. Gen. James H. Johnson Jr., commander of the 82nd Airborne. Johnson will decide whether a court-martial should be convened, Army officials said. Under the Uniform Code of Military Justice, the maximum penalty for premeditated murder is death or life imprisonment, dishonorable discharge, forfeiture of all pay and allowances and reduction in rank. Bryan, 42, was born in Panama and was sent there with the 82nd Airborne in the Dec. 20 effort to oust Panamanian dictator Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Padilla said. The soldier is not being held in detention and is being represented by a military lawyer, the spokesman said. Bryan was the senior enlisted man in his unit, a headquarters company. Such units were deployed to Panama to handle such things as supply and organizational matters, Padilla said. The spokesman said Bryan is charged with the murder of an unidentified Panamanian man, allegedly ``by shooting him with an M-16 rifle on or about Dec. 23'' at or near Madden Dam, which is outside Panama City. The three other charges allege aggravated assault against unidentified Panamanian men at the same location. One case involved a man who allegedly was struck in the hand with the butt of an M-16 rifle on or about Dec. 20, one man who allegedly was struck in the head with the butt of an M-16 on or about Dec. 20, and a man who allegedly was struck in the back with a section of rubber hose on or about Dec. 21, the Army said. Although Padilla said he could not comment on the circumstances surrounding the incidents, the Army Times newspaper reported earlier this month that the shooting occurred after a skirmish at a roadblock when a group of Panamanians were stopped in a car and someone threw a hand grenade at the soldiers. The U.S. soldiers then fired on the car, killing some of the occupants. The remaining occupants surrendered, got out and were taken prisoner, but one of the prisoners allegedly was shot and another severely beaten, the Army Times reported. The publication is an independent weekly. The charges came about as a result of an investigation by the U.S. Army Criminal Investigation Command, Padilla said.

DOC.HEAD: Cancer Drug Studied in Sickle Cell Disease
DOC.TEXT: Doctors hope to reduce the complications of sickle cell disease by prompting the body to produce a substance that it ordinarily stops making after birth. The experimental treatment involves the drug hydroxyurea, a medicine approved for treating melanoma and some other forms of cancer. Sickle cell victims make defective hemoglobin, the substance in red blood cells that carries oxygen throughout the body. In the new treatment, doctors induced the body to make fetal hemoglobin, which ordinarily is present in large quantities only before birth. But the treatment only slightly reduced anemia, a common complication of sickle cell disease. The doctors cautioned that more study of the drug's long-term effects and hazards will be necessary before they know whether it will play a role in treating the ailment. The study was conducted by Dr. Griffin P. Rodgers and colleagues from the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases and Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine. It was published in today's New England Journal of Medicine. In seven of 10 people given the drug for three months, levels of fetal hemoglobin in red blood cells rose by two to 10 times. This resulted in a 25 percent reduction in the tendency of their hemoglobin to polymerize, or form long fibers, which gives the red cells a distorted shape. The doctors speculated that if they could achieve a 50 percent reduction in the tendency to polymerize, they could significantly reduce the complications of sickle cell disease. In the United States, the disease is most common among blacks, where it occurs in about one of every 1,000 people. Doctors are also studying the possibility of using the cancer drug to treat thalassemia, another inherited blood disorder.

DOC.HEAD: More West Germans Want Quick End to 45-Year Stationing of U.S. Troops
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's call to remove tens of thousands of American troops from West Germany has been matched _ or surpassed _ by the increasing eagerness of West Germans to see them go. Once scorned as ``anti-Americanism,'' the wish to see the massive U.S. military presence sharply reduced has picked up the support of two state governments. ``Before, people were reprimanded for saying such a thing out loud,'' says Hans Jacobs, deputy mayor of Bitburg. He says ``now the time has come'' to plan a future with a far smaller number of U.S. troops. Bitburg, home to a U.S. Air Force base, is also the town where former President Ronald Reagan made a bitterly criticized visit to a German war cemetery in 1985. Jacobs says he looks forward to a possible civilian use for the air base and less noise from fighter jets screeching overhead. ``Tourism would also pick up if there weren't so many troops around,'' he said. Jacobs says the 13,500 Americans there outnumber West Germans. President Bush's proposal to withdraw 57,000 of the quarter-million American soldiers stationed in West Germany has sparked political wrangling over which areas should be the first to see substantial withdrawals. The activities of U.S. and other NATO troops have led to numerous protests in recent years, especially as resistance grew to ``low-level'' training flights. The roaring flights wake children, shake houses, scare cows and generally make life miserable for those in the training areas. Frequent military maneuvers also chew up farmers' fields and lead to massive traffic jams on already crowded highways. Many West Germans have long chafed at such a massive U.S. troop presence as an obstacle to full national sovereignty, and the collapse of Communist regimes to the east now has them feeling less threatened than ever. West German officials are even eyeing a U.S. pullout as a way to open housing for hundreds of thousands of immigrants from Eastern Europe. The Social Democratic mayor of Frankfurt says he hopes to turn a huge military shopping area into a city housing development. On Tuesday, Munich's Sueddeutsche Zeitung daily newspaper reported that environmentalists have demanded the closing of a huge Army practice range near the Bavarian city of Regensburg. They want it turned into a nature preserve. Hesse state Gov. Walter Wallmann has made an outright appeal for the removal of U.S. troops from Frankfurt and nearby Erbenheim. In a letter last week to Chancellor Helmut Kohl, a fellow Christian Democrat, Wallmann said the American facilities are needed to keep up with ``European competition'' in economic areas. The Hesse governor told Kohl, a fellow Christian Democratic, that he would even like to have the sprawling Rhein-Main U.S. Air Base outside Frankfurt turned over to the West Germans. Wallmann's bluntly worded letter would have been unthinkable just months ago from a member of the West German party with the closest ties to Washington. Frankfurt is jockeying to become the home of the central bank of an economically integrated Europe, thus attracting even more business to the glittering financial center. The city's mayor, Volker Hauff, would like the Americans to give up a huge shopping area, which includes a bustling Burger King restaurant, to turn the site into a city housing development. Carl-Ludwig Wagner, the Christian Democratic governor of the western state of Rhineland-Palatinate where Bitburg is located, is also seeking U.S. troop cutbacks. Wagner has presented a list of 12 military U.S. bases and facilities for possible closure. Most West Germans accept that U.S. troops will be stationed in their country for some time, and many West Germans warn that the financial impact of pullouts from smaller areas could be especially severe. In Rhineland-Palatinate, U.S. bases contribute from $2.6 billion to $4.1 billion annually to the state _ once one of West Germany's poorest. About 68,000 American troops and 75,000 family members are in the state, and 21,500 West Germans are in the employ of the state's U.S. military facilities. NATO commander John R. Galvin has been making TV commercials for the U.S. military to try to calm concerns about the future of U.S. forces in West Germany, according to a military spokesman. ``There's a lot of rumors,'' said Army Maj. David Compton of the U.S. military headquarters in Stuttgart. He said Galvin still has not made any formal troop cutback plan.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T to Begin Service to Albania
DOC.TEXT: The American Telegraph & Telephone Co. will begin its first phone service from the United States to Albania next month. The Albanian link will leave Vietnam, Cambodia and North Korea as the only major nations without telephone service with the United States, AT&T spokesman Herb Linnen said Wednesday. Albania's hardline communist government began allowing calls from Albania to go through on March 24, Linnen said. He said operator-assisted calls from the United States to Albania will be put through starting sometime in May, depending on Federal Communications Commission approval, and direct-dial service will begin in the fall. Linnen said AT&T also has a petition before the Treasury Department to allow formal negotiations with Vietnam for the first phone service with that country since the end of the Vietnam war. He said Vietnam, which has no diplomatic relations with the United States, has shown a willingness to resume phone service in preliminary talks with AT&T representatives. AT&T needs a license for the formal negotiations because of the U.S. trade embargo against Hanoi. ``When we see countries that cannot be reached from the United States, our objective is to start up service, regardless of whatever political situations that exist,'' he said. ``We have nothing going on right now with Cambodia and North Korea, but clearly our objective is that since they are not served, we want to be able to do that in time,'' said Linnen. Albania, on the coast of the Adriatic Sea north of Greece, has not gone through the governmental reforms seen in other Eastern European communist nations, although there have been growing demonstrations for change.

DOC.HEAD: Money Can Grow on Trees, Small Woodlot Owners Advised
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department says small-scale farmers who have woodlots on their property sometimes don't realize that money does grow on trees. And if you want to start from scratch and wait 15 to 50 years, depending on the region, newly planted trees eventually can return a profit. Experts say at least 6 million people own woodlots averaging 40 to 50 acres. They make up about one-third of the nation's 348 million acres of private timberland. The woodlot possibilities are described in a fact sheet by the Office for Small-Scale Agriculture, which is operated by USDA's Cooperative State Research Service. Previous topics have included sheep, goats, mushrooms, foliage plants, herbs, wildflowers, herbs specialty vegetables and ``exotic'' livestock such as ostriches, llamas, alpacas, water buffalo and European fallow deer. ``Many can improve their land management,'' the report said. ``This fact sheet is intended mainly for them rather than for others who may want to try to get into the business.'' But there are newcomers to woodlot management, including many farmers who are planting trees on more than 2 million acres under the government's Conservation Reserve Program. The program offers initial planting assistance and annual rental payments to farmers who agree to take highly erodible cropland from production for 10 years and protect it with grass and trees. A number of other federal and state programs, along with private efforts, are directed at woodlot improvements. Most woodlot farmers ``don't fully manage their operations'' and timber growth generally reaches only 50 percent to 60 percent of potential, the report said. Good management means getting each acre to produce the maximum annual growth possible, and to replace harvested trees. ``Owners with already established woodlots often have immediate income potential,'' the report said. ``Sometimes, however, the return covers decades.'' One example cited by the USDA agency was reported in the American Tree Farmer, official publication of The American Tree Farm System, which has certified 65,000 tree farmers on 91 million acres. Nels Hanson, president of the Washington Farm Forestry Association, told about a couple, Lula and Vern Johnson, who bought their 40-acre Washington farm for $102 an acre, including a six-acre patch of 40-year-old Douglas fir trees. Between 1949 and 1987, as money was needed to clear and plant understocked areas, they logged and thinned the stand. When the stand of Douglas fir was sold to the Weyerhaeuser Co. in 1988, it had 660,000 board-feet of lumber and brought nearly $382 per thousand, or $252,000. ``Not everyone can find a timber investment to match that,'' the report said. For those wanting to start a long-term timber program, unused areas along streams or creeks often good sites. The exact species of trees would depend on local growing conditions and advice from foresters. ``The South produces salable lumber products in 15 to 25 years,'' the report said. ``In the North and West, it usually takes 30 to 50 years. In the South, final harvests usually take place in 30 to 40 years and in the North and West about 60 to 80 years.'' The report added, ``Fairly intensive management is required to produce sawlogs in those time frames.'' For free single copies, write to: Howard W. Kerr Jr., Program Director, Office for Small-Scale Agriculture, Cooperative State Research Service, Room 342-D, Aerospace Building, USDA, Washington, D.C. 20251-2200. Or telephone 202-447-3640.

Government weather watchers say much of the drought across the Great Plains has been eased since the first of the year. A weekly weather and crop report Wednesday by the Commerce and Agriculture departments said last month was ``mild and wet across much of the United States.'' Historically, it was the 10th warmest and 35th wettest March on record. However, the report said ``unusually dry conditions'' prevailed over the Northeast, Northwest and West last month. ``Rainfall during the past three months has erased the moisture deficit accumulated in late 1989 across most of the primary hard red winter wheat region'' extending from southern and western Nebraska to the Texas panhandle, the report said. Statewide precipitation figures for January, February and March showed wet conditions extended through Alabama, Arkansas, Iowa, Kansas, Louisian, Mississippi, Missouri, Oklahoma and Texas. For Alabama, Louisiana and Oklahoma, it was the wettest first quarter on record. But in contrast to the wetness of southern and central states, the report said the West had ``unusually dry rainy season'' and that October through March ranks as the third driest such period on record. ``There were 130 tornadoes across the continuous United States in March 1990,'' the report said. ``This is the second highest figure for March since 1953.''

Private exporters have told the Agriculture Department the Soviet Union has bought an additional 175,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices for delivery through mid-May under a long-term grain supply agreement. F. Paul Dickerson, general sales manager for the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said Wednesday the wheat was sold by three private companies, which will receive subsidies under the department's Export Enhancement Program, or EEP. Dickerson reported the subsidies at an average of $34.13 per ton, or about 93 cents per bushel. The EEP arrangement allows private exporters to sell wheat and other designated commodities to specified countries at reduced prices in order to meet foreign competition. The exporters then collect free government surpluses of grain or other products as bonuses, or subsidies. Dickerson said the latest wheat was sold by J. Aron & Co., 100,000 tons; Union Equity Cooperative Exchange, 50,000; and Mitsubishi International, 25,000.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese-Peruvian Promises Changes Political Panamora in Peru
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Maneuvering his fenderless Volkswagen through Lima's dusty streets, taxi driver Segundo Flores Gutierrez explained why he has become an ardent supporter of presidenital candidate Alberto Fujimori. ``He'll bring us Japanese money, technology, ethics. We'll be totally Orientalized.'' But others believe Fujimori, 51, is just another Peruvian with little to back up his claims that he can capitalize on his Japanese heritage to rebuild the nation's faltering economy. The son of Japanese immigrants was virtually unknown to Peruvians a month ago. Now he's favored to become the next president after forcing front-runner and celebrated novelist Mario Vargas Llosa into a runoff. Vargas Llosa was hoping for a majority in Sunday's balloting but received just 32 percent of the vote. Fujimori, with less than 6 percent voter support in the polls a month ago, soared to second in a field of nine candidates and won nearly 30 percent of the vote. Now Vargas Llosa is considering bowing out and giving Fujimori the presidency. Fujimori made a strong showing by raising the hopes in millions of voters in this impoverished nation ravaged by a decade-old insurgency by the Maoist-inspired Shining Path. Part of his appeal is that he has never held political office. ``Fujimori is new and independent. Our other politicians are all used up, exhausted,'' said a candy vendor who supported Vargas Llosa until three days before the election. Vargas Llosa is also new to politics, but was faulted by voters for his affiliation with traditional right-wing parties. Analysts say he also was too frank in detailing his plan for harsh austerity measures. People who know Fujimori best say he is a natural politician. He speaks English, French and German as well as Spanish and Japanese. He was No. 1 in his graduating class of agricultural engineers in 1961. He did post-graduate work at the University of Wisconsin and the University of Strasburg in France. But he attended high school in a working-class neighborhood, and his immigrant father fed the family by working as a tailor and a night watchman. That background gives him a common touch that he has used with Peru's poor. ``He's a consummate politician, an absolute expert at manipulating people'' says an administrator at the National Agricultural University, where Fujimori was as rector from 1984 until last year. The administrator asked not to be identified by name. Fujimori has said that as a Japanese-Peruvian, he would be better able to attract Japanese aid to Peru. That claim has irritated Japan's ambassador to Peru, according to diplomatic sources. Many professors at the National Agricultural University say that as rector, Fujimori relied solely on Peru's bankrupt government instead of seeking foreign aid for the school. ``He never made any contacts with international groups that support agricultural research,'' one professor said. A member of the administration, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, said: ``How can he claim that he'll attract Japanese money to Peru? There's not a single yen in this whole university.'' Lima's large Japanese community has been somewhat surprised by Fujimori's campaign, which has played on the Peruvian stereotype of Japanese as being honest and hard-working. ``His popularity is very surprising,'' said Juan Iida, publisher of a Japanese-language newspaper in Lima. ``We didn't even know who he was.'' Many in the Japanese community says Fujimori's values are more ``Peruvian'' than Japanese and some who have worked with him question his ability to resurrect Peru's shattered economy. Former colleagues at the university, for instance, criticize his management of the school. At one point, they say, 200 of the university's milk cows dried up for lack of food and water. Critics say Fujimori was ultimately responsible for ensuring proper care for the cows. Supporters say the national government was at fault because it withheld funds. The same accusations are made about four laboratory buildings that stand half-finished in the middle of the university's campus. Fujimori himself appears to have no doubts about his chances of being elected president and governing the nation of 22 million. Even while barely a blip on pollsters' charts, he confidently predicted to anyone listening that he would win the election. Along with their four children, Fujimori and his wife, Susana Higuchi, run their own three-acre farm, of which the candidate proudly speaks when claiming he will revitalize Peruvian agriculture. But even if Fujimori cannot increase the yield of Peru's farms _ now strangled by drought, rebel fighting and a poor economy _ or attract Japanese help, some Peruvians still support him. ``The Japanese are the most patient people in the world,'' a waiter in a Lima restaurant said. ``They know how to live on rice and water, and before long that may be just what Peruvians will need to learn.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Rejects Two-Alliance Proposal by Soviets
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration says a Soviet bid to make a united Germany a member of both NATO and the Warsaw Pact is an unacceptable formula for neutrality that could lead to future instability in Europe. President Bush firmly believes that German membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization alone is ``the best guarantee for long-term peace and continued stability,'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Wednesday. ``That Germany should be a member of NATO and the Warsaw Pact is another formula for neutrality,'' Fitzwater said. ``It is a status that we believe, the Germans themselves and their neighbors believe is undesirable,'' he said and added: ``We strongly support full membership of a united Germany in NATO. We are opposed to neutrality,'' The negative White House reaction, which was echoed at the State Department, followed a Soviet proposal for dual German membership in both military alliances for a five-to-seven-year transition period, culminating in the formation of a wholly new but yet undefined European security system. During his visit to Washington last week, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze dropped the previous Soviet insistence that a united Germany had to be entirely neutral. Asked if there was room for compromise in the U.S. position, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said there was not. She also said she did not know whether the Soviet proposal represents ``an opening shot, an opening (negotiating) position.'' Ms. Tutwiler and Fitzwater declined to discuss a possible transitional period in Germany's status, saying only that a unified Germany must stay in NATO. Fitzwater raised the possibility of a NATO summit meeting later this year to discuss Germany and the alliance's own changing role. ``President Bush and many of the Western leaders have spoken about a larger political role for NATO and one that is more involved in providing political, economic and social stability in Europe in these times of change,'' the spokesman said. Concerning whether Soviet troops should be allowed to stay in East Germany and whether NATO troops should be allowed in the East, Fitzwater said, ``Those are all issues that will have to be worked out with the alliance.'' He said NATO will determine its troop deployment position, not the World War II victors _ France, Britain, the Soviet Union and United States _ that are working with East and West Germany on the reunification plan. Shevardnadze first raised the possibility of German membership in both pacts simultaneously at a news conference at the State Department last Friday, saying it was an idea he had heard mentioned. But he had already used the idea as the centerpiece of a magazine article to be published next month. ``Many of our experts ... believe that the idea of `dual membership' for Germany could provide a pragmatic way out of the difficulties emerging now,'' Shevardnadze wrote in his article for the May issue of ``NATO's Sixteen Nations,'' an independent publication focusing on international security issues. ``I would favor a serious and thorough analysis of this option,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush's Broccoli Ban Well Known to Public, Survey Finds
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's distaste for broccoli is getting nearly six times as much public attention as Earth Day, according to a survey of people's attentiveness to the news. The Times Mirror Center for The People and The Press said Wednesday that its interviewers asked 1,212 people age 18 and older what vegetable it is that Bush recently said he wouldn't eat. Seventy-six percent said broccoli, the right answer. Four percent named some other vegetable. The rest refused to answer or said they didn't know. By contrast, 13 percent knew that April 22 is being observed as Earth Day to honor the environment. Fifteen percent gave a wrong answer and 72 percent said they didn't know when asked what was special about the date. On another question, the center reported that 74 percent of those responding said they approved of Bush's overall performance. Sixteen percent disapproved. Sixty-four percent said they were optimistic that the president would make progress in solving the country's long-term problems. In response to more specific questions, 39 percent said Bush was doing a good or excellent job in dealing with long-term economic problems. The corresponding percentage was 20 percent on health care problems and 32 percent on education and the environment.
