DOC.HEAD: U.S. Senators Meet With Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: Seven Democratic U.S. senators met with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at the Kremlin today. Gorbachev greeted the delegation, led by Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell of Maine, in a large office dominated by a Soviet flag and photographs of Communist heroes Vladimir Lenin, Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels. It was not clear whether Gorbachev regularly uses the office, labeled No. 1 and located on the third floor of the Presidium building at the end of a corridor lined with cabinets full of gifts from foreign governments. The senators were scheduled to meet with Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze later in the day. They met earlier with the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Soviet parliament and in Leningrad with city officials and representatives of the independence-minded Baltic republics. The delegation also included Sens. John Glenn of Ohio, Bill Bradley of New Jersey, James Sasser of Tennessee, Wyche Fowler of Georgia, Paul Sarbanes of Maryland and Tom Dachle of South Dakota.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Apologizes for Racial Slur
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note language in 2nd graf.
DOC.TEXT: The 85-year-old mayor survived a vote to impeach him for racial slurs when two councilmen, his nephews, voted in his favor. Mayort Ivey C. Berry couldn't remember a woman's name at a Tuesday night council meeting and referred to her home as ``the nigger's house,'' City Clerk Emily Daughtry said. He later used the epithet again. The council chairman called for his resignation and held a 90-minute impeachment hearing. Berry has been mayor of the small central Florida town for three months. Under the city charter, impeachment requires approval of four of five council members. But Councilmen Doyle and Gordon Craig sided with their uncle. Berry apologized, saying he had been told when he was raised that's what blacks were called. ``There was no malice intended by Mr. Berry. He has a lot of black friends in this community,'' Berry's attorney, C. John Coniglio, said. T.H. Poole Sr. of the Florida branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People favored Berry's removal. ``Don't let him tell you this was a nickel-and-dime mistake,'' Poole said.

DOC.HEAD: China's President To Visit Five Latin American Countries
DOC.TEXT: President Yang Shangkun will visit five Latin American countries in mid-May, the latest in a series of trips by Chinese leaders to court better relations with the Third World. The Foreign Ministry said today that the 82-year-old Yang will make official visits to Mexico, Brazil, Uruguay, Argentina and Chile. High-level official contacts with the West have virtually stopped since China's military crackdown on the pro-democracy movement last spring, and the Beijing government has sought to fill the diplomatic gap by stressing its Third World ties. Yang visited Egypt and three other Middle East countries in December and Premier Li Peng traveled to Nepal, Pakistan and Bangladesh in November. Foreign Minister Qian Qichen has traveled extensively through Africa, the Middle East and India. The post of president is largely ceremonial, but Yang, a former general in the People's Liberation Army, is one of China's most powerful political figures because of his strong military links. Foreign China-watchers say Yang is a top candidate to succeed 85-year-old Deng Xiaoping as China's paramount leader.

DOC.HEAD: Merc Makes Members Take Ethics Course
DOC.TEXT: At least one trader at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange wasn't enthusiastic about the mandatory ethics course that professors at a downtown law school will teach the Merc's 2,500 members. ``To get some lawyers to try to tell us what's ethical and what isn't ethical is kind of funny,'' said the livestock trader, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``I don't think I'm going to come out of there doing anything different than when I went in.'' Members began signing up Wednesday for the mandatory two-hour class, part of a reform effort implemented after FBI moles infiltrated the Merc and the Chicago Board of Trade in a probe of suspected fraud. Forty-eight people, mostly traders, were indicted last summer. ``We believe you will find the session both interesting and stimulating, and trust you will leave the session with much to think about,'' Merc officials said in a letter to members last week. The Board of Trade already has started a mandatory ethics session for all new members, said spokesman Michael O'Connell. He said BOT officials also are working with the Center for Ethics and Corporate Policy in Chicago to create an course that could include other members as well. James Oliff, second vice president of the Merc's Board of Governors, said anyone who trades at the Merc must take the new course. He said they will first be given ``a definition of what ethics is all about.'' ``Basically, we want to impress upon our members that in addition to looking at rules, that there are other actions that should govern their conduct and that's ethical behavior,'' he said. ``They are guardians of the exchange as a financial institution as well as guardians of themselves.'' Merc members will be told the consequences of violating rules, and will be shown hypothetical situations involving questionable trading practices, Oliff said. The class is being offered free, after trading hours, and will be taught by faculty at Chicago-Kent College of Law.

DOC.HEAD: Social Club Fire Suspect Pleads Innocent
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: A man charged in an illegal nightspot fire that killed 87 people pleaded innocent today to 174 counts of murder and other charges. Julio Gonzalez, 36, was guarded by four armed court officers as he was arraigned before Judge Burton R. Roberts in trial-level state Supreme Court. Gonzalez, who spoke to the court through a Spanish translator, mumbled ``no culpable'' when asked how he pleaded on the charges. The judge told attorneys that under state law, Gonzalez could serve only a single 25 years-to-life sentence even if convicted on all charges. The law stipulates his sentences would have to run concurrently, Roberts said. Gonzalez is accused of setting a fire that trapped revelers inside the tiny Happy Land Social Club in the Bronx. Authorities charge that the Cuban immigrant, enraged by the rejection of a former girlfriend who worked at the club, bought $1 worth of gasoline, spilled it in the illegal club's doorway and set it aflame. Only five people escaped the cramped club following the 4 a.m. fire, including the girlfriend. Court-appointed defense attorney Richard W. Berne said today he had not decided whether to use an insanity defense for his client, although he had indicated earlier that was a possibility. Berne said he plans to ask for a dismissal of all charges against Gonzalez because the lawyer was not given access to a videotaped confession by his client when the case was submitted to the grand jury. Gonzalez was indicted March 30 on 174 counts of murder, two counts of arson and single counts of attempted murder and assault. He was charged with two separate murder counts for each of the victims killed in the social club blaze. The club lacked proper permits and did not have adequate exits and sprinkling systems.

DOC.HEAD: Writer Alma Sioux Scarberry Dead at 90
DOC.TEXT: Alma Sioux Scarberry, a reporter, writer, entertainer and publicist whose career spanned more than seven decades and included interviews with Charles Lindbergh, Babe Ruth and Jack Dempsey, has died. She was 90. Ms. Scarberry, who moved to Austin in 1965, was ``a flamboyant woman,'' said her longtime friend, Cactus Pryor. ``She had a lot of color in her clothing and in her personality. She just had a lot of verve.'' Ms. Scarberry died Tuesday of a stroke at a San Antonio nursing home. She got her start in reporting in 1919 at the Elmira (N.Y.) Advertiser. She also worked for the New York Mirror, Pittsburgh Sun-Telegraph, Washington Herald Times and King Features. Ms. Scarberry enjoyed telling tales from her days as a journalist. ``She was accidentally knocked down by Jack Dempsey once,'' Pryor recalled. ``She and a bunch of other reporters were interviewing him and he was demonstrating (a punch). I guess she got in the way.'' She wrote 21 novels, including ``Thou Shalt Not Love,'' ``The Flat Tire'' and ``Dimpled Racketeer.'' Ms. Scarberry also wrote songs for country singer Tex Ritter and performed in Irving Berlin's Broadway show ``Music Box Revue'' in 1922 and 1923. ``She had a very full life and enjoyed good health through her 90th birthday,'' said her son, Theodore Klein Jr. In addition to Klein, survivors include four grandchildren. A memorial service will be next week, Klein said.

DOC.HEAD: Irish Leader Urges Economic Unity With British Province
DOC.TEXT: Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey brought a message of economic unity to Northern Ireland on Wednesday, but Protestant demonstrators shouted support for the island's political division. ``Haughey, Haughey, out, out, out!,'' demonstrators cried. Haughey, chairman of the European Community's Council of Ministers, told a conference on cross-border trade that ``economic forces will inevitably interlink the economies of both parts of Ireland.'' ``As the technical and fiscal borders disappear, and both economies will converge, it will make simple common sense for us to combine in facing the problems and opportunities that the situation will present equally to us both,'' Haughey said. ``These are the economic realities of the future.'' The overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Republic of Ireland has been separated from Protestant-dominated Northern Ireland since 1922, when Ireland gained independence from Britain. Ireland's constitution lays claim to the whole island, and Northern Ireland has been torn by conflict between advocates of Irish unity and those loyal to Britain. Reg Empey, the lord mayor of Belfast and a Protestant, spoke to the conference before Haughey and denounced Ireland's claim on the province. About 300 Protestants gathered outside the Europa Hotel before Haughey's speech. They were kept under control by a large security operation mounted by the Royal Ulster Constabulary, Northern Ireland's police force. ``Haughey is here to dance on the graves of the province's bereaved,'' the Rev. Ian Paisley told reporters outside the hotel. Paisley, leader of the Democratic Unionist Party, referred to the slaying of four members of the Ulster Defense Regiment. They were killed Monday by an Irish Republican Army bomb. Ireland's foreign minister, Gerry Collins, earlier this year had called for the heavily Protestant unit to be disbanded. Haughey repeatedly stressed the two parts of Ireland should cooperate within the 12-nation European Community. Haughey currently speaks on behalf of the bloc; its presidency rotates every six months. ``Our economic and social characteristics, which are shared by both parts of Ireland, would benefit if a combined approach could be established,'' Haughey told the conference, which was organized by the Institute of Directors. ``We have a clear mutual interest in strengthening community policies for the less developed regions. It makes sense for both parts of the island to cooperate and share the costs in developing strategy.'' Earlier, as he was ushered quickly past the demonstrators into the hotel, Haughey was asked whether he worried about his personal security while in Belfast. ``Not particularly,'' he said. ``I know the RUC (Royal Ulster Constabulary) will make every effort to look after me.'' A front-page cartoon in The Irish Times of Dublin on Wednesday taunted Haughey for his past criticism of British rule in Northern Ireland. The cartoon showed Haughey surrounded by RUC men with the prime minister saying: ``Still a police state!! Thank goodness.'' Irish leaders have rarely visited Northern Ireland since sectarian and political fighting flared in 1969. Haughey's predecessor, Garret FitzGerald, was in the province in November 1985 to sign the Anglo-Irish Agreement with Mrs. Thatcher. The accord, deeply disliked by Protestants, gives Dublin a formal consultative role in Northern Ireland's affairs and pledges the two governments to cooperate against terrorism.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese High Schools Requiring More Class Hours
DOC.TEXT: The pressure of college entrance exams has led to more class hours and required courses in the nation's public high schools, the Education Ministry said today. Of Japan's 3,893 public high schools, 12.4 percent require more than 35 hours of classes per week, up from 7.9 percent in 1982, when the ministry urged high schools to reduce classes to 32 hours per week, according to a ministry survey. It said 63.1 percent of the schools required 34 hours of classes per week _ six hours a day Monday through Friday and four hours on Saturday _ during the academic year that ended March 31, 1989. The ministry also has urged schools to limit their school year to 35 weeks. However, 65.7 percent of the high schools had more than 35 weeks of classes, including 16.3 percent with more than 41 weeks, the ministry said. The number of courses required for graduation also has increased at many schools, the ministry said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Higher, Dollar Falls
DOC.TEXT: The chief index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange ended higher after a day of up-and-down trading today, while the dollar fell against the Japanese yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average closed at 29,623.20, up 182.92 points, or 0.62 percent. The index first quickly gained more than 230 points, then sank 197.73 points at the morning session's end before rebounding in the afternoon. Traders attributed the Nikkei's afternoon recovery to index-linked arbitrage buying in options, which allow holders to buy or sell a certain stock at a given price and time. Today was the last day for using options in April. ``The index rose after mixed trading involving options,'' said Nomura Securities analyst Yoshiro Inoue. He said speculative trading was likely to decrease before the Easter holidays that start Friday in many European nations. While this week's earlier losses contributed to the index's morning decline, the yen's stability against the dollar reassured market players, prompting buying in the afternoon, he said. ``The yen can support the stock market as long as it remains stable. It does not have to continue to rise,'' Inoue said. Trading was thin with 430 million shares changing hands on the first section, down from Wednesday's 500 million. On the foreign exchange market, the dollar closed at 158.00 yen, down 0.50 yen from Wednesday's close of 158.50 yen. The currency opened lower at 158.17 yen and ranged between 158.00 yen and 158.53 yen. The dollar began rising against the yen during the morning session as market players sold the yen against the West German mark, dealers said. The yen rose back against the dollar in the afternoon following a reversal in the yen-mark trading, said a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``Dollar selling against the mark also supported the yen in the afternoon,'' he said. ``Market players are having difficulty figuring out the direction of dollar-yen trading, so their interest has shifted from the dollar to the mark,'' Minori Takeuchi, a dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo, said. Other dealers said market participants were shying away from major moves ahead of the Easter holidays. In the bond market, the price of benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bonds closed at 86.30 points, unchanged from Wednesday's finish. Their yield also was unchanged at 7.295 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Lead Japanese in Leisure
DOC.TEXT: Japan is leading the United States in areas of productivity, education and trade but, not surprisingly, it lags behind in one category: leisure time. American men spend on average 20.5 hours a week at leisure, compared with 13.3 hours taken by Japanese men, according to a University of Michigan study. The disparity is even greater between American women, who take 21.8 hours of time out each week, and Japanese women, who take just 10.6 hours. Economics professors Frank P. Stafford and F. Thomas Juster said they studied time spent on ``active leisure,'' or sports and hobbies, and ``social interaction'' in the United States, Japan and six other countries. Using statistics from surveys of 1,000 or more adults conducted between 1964 and 1987 in the United States, Japan, the Soviet Union, Finland, Hungary, Norway, Denmark and Sweden, they found a gradual decline in the number of hours men spend at work in all eight countries. Among the other findings: _The workweek ranged from 54 hours in the Soviet Union to 33.4 hours in Denmark. Japanese men worked 52 hours a week, Hungarian men 50.8 hours and American men 44 hours. _The amount of time that men spend on housework ranged from 18.1 hours a week in Sweden to 3.5 in Japan. American men spent 13.8 hours, Soviet men 11.9 hours and Norwegian men 16.8 hours a week on housework. _Women in the Soviet Union spent more time working than women in the other countries, averaging 39.3 hours a week on the job and 27 hours a week doing housework. American women averaged 23.9 hours a week on the job and 30.5 hours a week working at home. Danish women worked 20.8 hours a week on the job and 23.1 hours a week at home. The researchers said Hungarians and Soviets work so many hours because they earn relatively low wages, not enough to buy added leisure time. Neither Japan nor the United Sates approaches the 54.3 hours a week spent on leisure activities by men in Denmark or the 53.7 hours spent by Danish women, according to Stafford's study.

DOC.HEAD: Hydrogen Fire, Explosion Shut Down Oil-Fired Unit
DOC.TEXT: Engineers will need a day or two before considering the start-up of an oil-fired unit at the Turkey Point power plant complex after a hydrogen gas explosion and fire shut the unit, utility officials said. No one was injured and two nuclear plants and another oil-fired plant at Turkey Point were not affected by Wednesday's gas leak, spokesmen said. The fire was confined to an elevated enclosure housing an exciter, a small auxiliary generator that provides the initial source of electricity to power the generator. Plant operators took the unit off line when they detected a loss of hydrogen pressure, and the fire was discovered in the exciter about 15 minutes later, the Florida Power & Light Co. said. ``The visible damage is very, very moderate,'' said spokesman Dale Thomas. ``We can see a little bit of twisted metal around the housing that contains the generating equipment, and there's a little bit of black soot around the bearings.'' The plant's fire brigade had to put out the fire twice because the flammable hydrogen continued leaking and exploded a second time, he said. The hydrogen leaked from the sealed room where the gas cools the spinning turbine generator, passed through a turbine shaft and into the exciter enclosure, a shed-sized building on a deck two stories high, the utility said. Utility workers will have to remove the generator housing on Unit 2 to assess damage and repair costs, which could take a day or two, Thomas said. Engineers would have to make sure the turbine generator, which spins at 3,600 revolutions per minute, remained in alignment and its mounts and shafts were not damaged by the force of the explosion, said Gary Mehalik, another utility spokesman. Unit 2 was the only one operating at Turkey Point at the time of the fire, which left the 2,090-megawatt plant idle indefinitely. The loss of Turkey Point's generating capacity was not considered crucial because Florida Power & Light could boost the power generated at other plants or turn on idle units elsewhere in its system. The Miami-based utility is the state's largest, serving 3 million customers from Key West almost to Jacksonville.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS Jose de Vega Jr.; No separates moved for PMs.
DOC.TEXT: Harold Ballard, the colorful and eccentric owner of the NHL's Toronto Maple Leafs, died Wednesday of diabetes-related heart problems at age 86. Ballard became vice president of the Maple Leafs in the 1960s and president and governor of the club in 1971. In 1972, Ballard was convicted of fraud and theft involving $205,000 in the arena's funds and served one year of a three-year sentence. He was inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame in 1977.

Ivar Lo-Johansson, a Swedish novelist whose powerful stories about landless peasants spurred farm reforms 60 years ago, died Wednesday of cancer at age 89. Lo-Johansson became a force among the ``proletarian writers,'' who based their stories on the lives of poor workers and peasants. His writings in the 1930s helped end a system under which farm workers were strongly dependent on land owners. He wrote 60 works from 1927 to 1986. In 1985, France named him an Officer of the Order of Arts and Letters.

Alma Sioux Scarberry, a reporter, writer, entertainer and publicist whose career spanned more than seven decades, died Tuesday of a stroke at age 90. Ms. Scarberry got her start in reporting in 1919 at the Elmira (N.Y.) Advertiser. She also worked for the New York Mirror, Pittsburgh Sun-Telegraph, Washington Herald Times and King Features. She wrote 21 novels, including ``Thou Shalt Not Love,'' ``The Flat Tire'' and ``Dimpled Racketeer.'' Ms. Scarberry also wrote songs for country singer Tex Ritter and performed in Irving Berlin's Broadway show ``Music Box Revue'' in 1922 and 1923.
She is survived by a son, Theodore Klein Jr.

Petar Simic, chief of the Communist Party within the Yugoslav armed forces, died Wednesday of a brain hemorrhage at age 57. Simic had advocated strong army and Communist Party influence in Yugoslav politics. His hard-line stands were often criticized by the media and officials in Slovenia and Croatia, the liberal Yugoslav republics that have rejected Communist Party monopoly.

Don Franklin, veteran Miami television weatherman, died Monday of lung cancer at age 63. Franklin started as a radio announcer in Jacksonville, Fla., worked in television at Memphis, Tenn., then came to Miami in 1957. After three years as a radio disc jockey, he joined WTVJ as midday news weatherman. Franklin left WTVJ in 1973 to work for KNXT-TV and KGIL radio in Los Angeles, returning to Miami in 1975 as WCIX weatherman. He moved over to WSVN in 1985. Franklin had resigned from WSVN-TV in 1988 after he was diagnosed with lung cancer.

Helio Smidt, president of Varig Airlines for the past 10 years, died Wednesday of cancer at age 64. Smidt joined the employee-owned Brazilian airline in 1945 at age 19 in Port Alegre, Brazil. After 12 years he was made regional director for Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo and in 1961 he became director of administration for the carrier. He was elected president in 1980 and also assumed the presidency of the Varig Group, which consists of about two dozen subsidiary companies.

Darrell Orvis Glenn, a country and western music songwriter and musician, died Monday. He was 54. The cause of death was not disclosed. Glenn's songs included ``Indescribably Blue,'' a tune recorded by Elvis Presley. He also wrote ``Bear With Me a Little Longer,'' which was recorded by Eddy Arnold, and ``Only the Redeemed,'' a song recorded by Kenneth Copeland that received a Grammy nomination.

Jose De Vega Jr., an actor and choreographer who worked to eliminate ethnic stereotypes in show business, died of AIDS-related complications. He was 56. De Vega died Sunday at Veterans Memorial Hospital in Westwood. Born in San Diego to a Filipino father and Colombian mother, De Vega began his career as the character Chino in the Broadway and film versions of ``West Side Story.'' He also appeared in the film ``Blue Hawaii'' and in the television series ``Bonanza,'' ``Dynasty,'' ``Mission Impossible'' and ``Hart to Hart.'' For the last nine years, De Vega choreographed, directed and performed in concerts and productions of Great Leap, a Los Angeles group of Asian-American artists working to end entertainment stereotypes. He sang in the group's ``Talk Story'' last year at the Los Angeles Theater Center.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Forces Duel with Artillery
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Michel Aoun's gunners battled rival forces under militia chieftain Samir Geagea with howitzers and mortars today in the fight for control of the Christian enclave. Police said four people were killed and seven wounded in the exchanges across east Beirut and Kesrouan province north of the capital. The thuds of exploding shells echoed across the city as the two sides hammered each other's residential districts with 130mm howitzers. The escalation, which began about 3 a.m., kept civilians in underground shelters and brought life to a standstill. By police count, the struggle for the 310-square-mile Christian enclave has killed 873 and wounded 2,365 since it broke out Jan. 30. The showdown, the worst intra-Christian confrontation of the nation's 15-year-old civil war, has caused material damage estimated at $1 billion. According to police figures, 400,000 of the enclave's 1 million people have fled to safer areas in Lebanon and neighboring countries. Palls of smoke billowed from the mountain resort of Kleiat, a no man's land separating Aoun's troops and Geagea's fighters in upper Kesrouan. Phosphorous shells rained on its already wrecked restaurants and villas, a police spokesman said. Poor villagers, who had remained in Kleiat despite the savage shelling duels, deserted their town early this week to caves they dug in nearby mountains, said the police spokesman, who cannot be named in line with regulations. Interior Minister Elias Khazen visited Jounieh, provincial capital of the Kesrouan province, on Wednesday and said the government of Syrian-backed President Elias Hrawi planned to spread its authority to the Christian enclave. Khazen, who has been based in Moslem west Beirut since the government was formed Nov. 24, said he will operate from Jounieh's city hall for two days weekly to underscore Hrawi's determination to govern the enclave. His visit to the province came after repeated calls by Geagea for Hrawi's government to assume control over the army barracks and government facilities in his areas of influence. Aoun has rejected the Arab League peace agreement under which Hrawi was elected and does not recognize the president. Khazen sailed to Jounieh by boat from Beirut to avoid checkpoints erected by Aoun's troops along part of the coastal highway that connects the capital with the port, which is under Geagea's control. He also visited Maronite Catholic patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir at Bkirki, his mountain seat above Jounieh, and declared that ``Lebanon will be united again.'' Khazen, his eyes brimming with tears, said: ``The extraordinary conditions that had prevented us from living in the eastern areas (Christian enclave) will be over soon. Now we are in Kesrouan.'' Kesrouan province is Geagea's main power base and the reserve for his militia, which fields 6,000 hard-core fighters and about 30,000 reservists. Aoun has 19,000 army troops.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Continue to Dodge Questions About Reported Ethnic Strife
DOC.TEXT: China's Foreign Ministry today refused to answer questions about reported violent ethnic uprisings in extreme western China and a ban on travel by foreign tourists and journalists to the area. Unconfirmed reports say dozens of people have been killed. At a weekly briefing, spokeswoman Li Jinhua evaded repeated questions on reported Moslem unrest in Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region, saying the Foreign Ministry was not responsible for internal affairs and ``I am not clear about the situation.'' Government officials in Xinjiang and Beijing have neither confirmed nor denied reports that troops were sent in Friday to quell rioting by Moslem ethnic groups in three cities near Xinjiang's borders with the Soviet Union and Pakistan. Few details were known of the unrest, reported by Western and Asian diplomats in Beijing. Foreign travelers in Xinjiang say the disturbances occurred in the Taklimakan Desert cities of Kashgar, Hotan and Kuqa. One Asian diplomat said the rioting in Kashgar was sparked by a dispute over the construction of a mosque and involved Kirghiz people, a Moslem group with ethnic ties in the Soviet Union. Kashgar is an ancient Silk Road oasis city of 100,000 people about 150 miles from the Soviet border and 700 miles west of Urumqi, the provincial capital of Xinjiang. Foreign travelers in Urumqi quoted residents as saying two Chinese officials sent in to resolve the dispute over the mosque were murdered. Troops then dispatched killed 50 people in putting down the rioting, according to the unconfirmed reports. Foreign travelers have been prevented from traveling from Urumqi to Kashgar since the weekend and the Urumqi Foreign Affairs Office has told foreign journalists they may not come to Xinjiang. The Pakistan government was informed Monday that the Khunjerab Pass, the 13,120-foot-high road linking Pakistan with Kashgar, will not open as planned at the end of this month because of an avalanche. The Urumqi office has referred journalists to the Foreign Ministry in Beijing, but spokeswoman Li said she could not say why travel to Urumqi and Kashgar, both open cities, had been halted. Asked about bans on travel by reporters to other areas with heavy minority populations, such as Tibet, Inner Mongolia and the southern border with Burma, Li said there were more than 600 open cities in China and ``it will take you a long time to go to more than 600 places.'' Such a city supposedly is open to any foreign tourist, but Beijing-based foreign journalists must obtain approval from local authorities before traveling to any city outside the capital. The Chinese government has become increasingly sensitive about minority unrest since the rise in ethnic nationalism in bordering Soviet republics and a surge of challenges to Communist Party rule in Mongolia. Xinjiang officials in recent months have repeatedly warned of a threat of separatist activities backed by foreign forces. The local government has called for increased surveillance of religious activities being used for separatist causes. More than half the 14 million people of Xinjiang, an arid province that comprises one-sixth of China's land, are Moslems of the Uygur, Tartar, Kazakh, Kirghiz and other groups.

DOC.HEAD: Arguments Abound Over Ownership of Shipwreck Treasure
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Edits throughout to CORRECT noun-verb agreement, style.
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 133 years after the SS Central America sank in a hurricane, assorted predators are churning up a storm over the shipwreck's $1 billion cargo of gold ingots, coins and passengers' fortunes. A lawsuit to establish whether the treasure had ever been abandoned originally pitted the Columbus-America Discovery Group, a group of 100 investors who used Space Age technology to find the wreck, and 45 insurance companies who claim rights to the treasure. But the intervention of Columbia University and two businessmen, who contend their data were used to pinpoint the wreck, has turned the trial into a multisided squabble over fine points of law. The sixth day of testimony ended Wednesday, and arguments in the case are expected to end this week. The treasure hunters have invested $10 million and 13 years in raising to the surface more than a ton of gold ingots and coins buried 1{ miles under the sea 160 miles off the South Carolina coast. They say 2 tons remain on the ocean floor. The ship ran into a hurricane and sank on Sept. 12, 1857, as it sailed to New York from California. Between 362 and 423 of the 578 people on board are said to have perished. Among the cargo were 3 tons of gold bars and freshly minted ``double eagle'' gold coins from the San Francisco mint worth $1.6 million at the time and about $450 million at today's prices. Many passengers were carrying fortunes, and Columbus-America officials believe the total treasure could be worth up to $1 billion. The insurance companies argue that they never gave up their claims, and are asking for the return of the insured gold. However, not all of the gold was insured, and business records describing the insured cargo and proof that the claims were paid no longer exist. Lawyers for Columbia said a sonar survey by Dr. William Ryan, an oceanographer at Columbia, was done for two businessmen in search of the wreck in 1984. Richardson said Harry John and Jack Grimm, a Texas oilman, paid for Ryan's research. The lawyers said Ryan later exchanged the data with Thomas G. Thompson, a president of Columbus-America, and that Thompson used the data to locate the wreck site. The university claims Columbus-America then misled the public by saying the wreck was discovered when it hadn't been. Attorneys for Columbus-America denied the information from Ryan was of any use. The treasure hunt has been further complicated by revelations about John, the heir to the Miller Brewing Co. fortune. John used DeRance Inc., a Catholic charity he had set up in 1946, to establish Santa Fe Communications, which he used to spend millions looking for lost treasures. Santa Fe paid Columbia University more than $300,000 for a sonar survey of a portion of the ocean floor looking for the Central America. John testified that in 1984 the board of directors of DeRance decided to stop all treasure hunts, and he signed over the rights to the Columbia research to the Province of St. Joseph of the Capuchin Order in Detroit. At the time, the Internal Revenue Service was questioning Santa Fe's tax-exempt status. John testified that he bought back the rights from the order for $10 two weeks before the trial. On Tuesday night, the order renegotiated the agreement, which now will give it one-third of any proceeds John recovers through the court.

DOC.HEAD: Boston Student Wakes Up in Ypsilanti
DOC.TEXT: A fifth of vodka goes a long way. Adil Altom Hamza drank most of one in Boston and woke up in a cargo plane on his way to Ypsilanti, Mich. ``I'm drunk,'' he told Michigan State Police officers when he walked off the four-engine Lockheed Electra at Willow Run Airport in Ypsilanti at 3:30 a.m. Wednesday. The troopers were there because the pilot, startled in mid-flight by the appearance of Hamza radioed that he had a stowaway. Hamza, a 27-year-old student from Sudan, told The Boston Globe he drank most of a bottle of vodka while wandering Boston streets alone Tuesday night, took public transportation to Logan International Airport and got on a plane. ``I had a few drinks too many. All I can remember is looking for a place to sleep,'' he was quoted as saying. The place he found was the cargo hold of the Zantop Airlines plane, and that's where he woke up, scared and surprised, he said. ``It was dark. There were boxes all around me. It was freezing. There was nothing there, just the feeling of flying. I thought it was a nightmare.'' He went through a door leading into the plane's cabin and tapped on the shoulder of the flight engineer, one of three crew members, to ask where he was. ``They were scared. Really scared,'' Hamza said. ``They thought I was going to hijack the plane. But I said, `It's OK, I'm drunk.' When the pilot said, `You are halfway across the U.S.,' I said, `Oh my God.''' A half-hour later, the plane landed in Ypsilanti. State troopers questioned Hamza and then let him sleep it off in the state police lockup. Later they got him a bed at the Shelter Association of Ann Arbor, and he slept 12 more hours. The Massachusetts Port Authority, the Federal Aviation Administration and the FBI are trying to find out how Hamza evaded security and got on the plane. Hamza, of Brookline, Mass., came to Boston more than three years ago to attend the University of Massachusetts. He took off a term this year and hopes to transfer to Northeastern University in the fall, he said. Meanwhile, he is trying to find a way back to Boston. ``They are going to let me sleep here, and they are feeding me,'' he said. ``Everyone is nice. I'm just trying to find a way back home now. I'll work or take donations.''

DOC.HEAD: Highest Roller Coaster Lawsuit Settled
DOC.TEXT: The saga of the dueling roller coasters _ with officials in Pennsylvania and Texas each claiming title to the world's highest wooden roller coaster _ has coasted to a not-so-thrilling conclusion. Representatives of Dorney Park and Six Flags Over Texas met for 2{ hours Wednesday to settle their argument, which wound up in federal court after Dorney Park sued. The dispute arose because there is no universally recognized way to measure a roller coaster. The agreement: Six Flags' Texas Giant has the highest lift and Dorney's Hercules has the highest drop. Six Flags in Arlington has been saying its new Texas Giant is 143 feet high, compared with 95 feet for Hercules. Dorney maintained that although the Texas ride climbed higher, Hercules plummeted farther because its tracks go over a cliff. ``Who goes on a roller coaster for the lift?'' said Harris Weinstein, chairman of the board of Dorney Park and Wildwater Kingdom outside Allentown. Under the agreement, both parks released a statement that said, in part: ``Six Flags Over Texas recognizes that Hercules at Dorney Park and Wildwater Kingdom has the highest drop of any wooden roller coaster in the world at 157 feet. ``On the other hand, Dorney Park and Wildwater Kingdom recognize that the Texas Giant at Six Flags Over Texas has the highest lift of any wooden roller coaster in the world at 143 feet.'' Michael Crowther, Dorney's director of marketing, said, ``The general public is perfectly free to develop their own opinion on which coaster is the tallest.'' A message left for Six Flags' attorney was not returned Wednesday night. The agreement was approved by U.S. District Judge Franklin S. VanAntwerpen.

DOC.HEAD: Police Fire Tear Gas in Protest over Jewish Settlement
DOC.TEXT: Police fired tear gas today to disperse Christian clerics, including the bishop of the Greek Orthodox Church, who protested the settlement of about 150 Jews in the Arab Christian Quarter of Jerusalem's Old City. Police moved in after one priest tore down a poster with an Israeli Star of David that was put over a cross on the main door of the building taken over by the Jews, witnesses said. The Jewish families, most of them headed by ultra-Orthodox seminary students, moved into a four-building complex in the heart of the Christian neighborhood Wednesday under police guard. The site, near the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, was viewed as particularly provocative by Palestinian Christians, as was the timing in the midst of Easter week observances. It was the largest and most significant settlement of Jews outside the Jewish Quarter in the old, walled city. Previously, two Jewish yeshiva seminaries were set up in the Moslem Quarter and about 40 Jewish families took up residence in the area, including former Israeli Defense Minister Ariel Sharon. Jerusalem's Old City, divided into ethnic quarters, is home to 50,000 Moslems, more than 7,000 Christians and about 4,000 Jews. It was controlled by Jordan from 1948 until 1967, when it was captured by Israel in the Six-Day War and immediately annexed. Jews in the new settlement _ named Neot David, which is Hebrew for Dwellings of David _ told reporters today that their 72-room complex had been purchased legally from a Christian. They said they were trying to re-establish the Jewish community that was driven from the area by Arab riots of 1936. But their move caused stone-throwing demonstrations by Palestinian youths, angry statements from city and religious leaders and a demonstration by Christian clerics. More than 200 clerics demonstrated outside the Greek Orthodox Church headquarters around the corner from the Jewish settlement and charged that the building had been illegally sold by a tenant. ``This is the property of the church. ... The Jews took over this building. They made a contract in Geneva and bought it. I denounce this act,'' said Greek Orthodox Patriarch Diodorus I. Police said an investigation proved the purchase was legal. Diodorus spoke after being overcome by tear gas and falling to the ground. He showed reporters the chain on one of the gold crosses he wears around his neck which was broken in the melee. Christian merchants closed their shops in protest, and scattered bands of Arab youths were dispersed by tear gas when they threw stones at the Jewish complex and at police, witnesses said. Police said three Palestinians were arrested. The move to set up the Jewish settlement drew strong criticism from Jerusalem's mayor, Teddy Kollek, who said he was upset that the Jewish group had made the move during the Easter holiday. ``You can do this in another two days, when the holiday is finished,'' Kollek said on Israel radio. ``To expect now that there will be good relations, this won't happen.''

DOC.HEAD: Rep. Frank Case Figure Arrested
DOC.NOTE: EDs: UPDATES thruout with police confirming arrest, additional details
DOC.TEXT: Steve Gobie, the former paid lover of Rep. Barney Frank, D-Mass., has been arrested on charges of marijuana possession and destruction of property, police said today. Gobie was to be arraigned later today on charges of property destruction and marijuana possession, police spokesman Ed Wilson said. Police said the charges stemmed from an incident Wednesday in which Gobie confronted Karen Zibrat, 27, an off-duty female police officer, who was driving her personal car. Zibrat said a car being driven erratically nearly struck her car and another vehicle Wednesday afternoon, Wilson said. ``When Gobie stopped at a traffic light in northwest Washington, Zibrat attempted to find out why he was driving erratically,'' Wilson said. Gobie then got out of his car, he said. When Zibrat attempted to back up, Gobie jumped on the roof of her car and broke through the sunroof, falling inside the vehicle, where a struggle ensued, police said. Witnesses summoned police and arrested Gobie, who was held on a $5,000 bond pending his arraignment. Gobie gained notoriety last year with his story of being Frank's lover and operating a prostitution service out of Frank's home. Frank admitted that he paid Gobie for sexual favors, but has denied any knowledge of the prostitution service.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Killed in New South African Unrest; Mandela Slams Conservatives
DOC.TEXT: At least nine people were killed in clashes between rival black factions, including five people who were shot to death when assailants riddled a bus with bullets, police said today. The new violence came as African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela criticized the pro-apartheid Conservative Party, claiming the white opposition group was stirring racist fears to try to wreck peace talks. The unidentified gunmen attacked the bus near Pietermaritzburg in Natal Province late Wednesday, killing five of the occupants and seriously wounding three, police said. The attack appeared to be part of black factional fighting in the region that has claimed hundreds of lives. In another part of Natal, a mob killed a woman by placing a blazing tire around her neck in a ritual ``necklace'' killing near Port Shepstone, police said. Few details were provided on the other killings. Police also reported dispersing black protesters in several areas who set fire to houses, stoned vehicles and clashed with police patrols. Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok, who heads the police, told Parliament in Cape Town today that he was confident the police could maintain control of the country despite a rising tide of violence. Vlok said the police could handle the challenges facing South Africa during the coming decade as the country goes through major changes. Mandela lashed out Wednesday night at the pro-apartheid Conservative Party, charging it was racist and incapable of accepting progress. Mandela, in an unusually harsh attack, said the party was attempting to break up efforts by the government and the ANC to negotiate an end to white-minority rule. He said the Conservative Party was waging a campaign to discredit the ANC by stirring up white fears. Party leader Andries Treurnicht ``is shaken by events he cannot control and he is therefore seeking to sabotage a settlement between the ANC and NP (the ruling National Party) and is trying to corrode all potential support,'' Mandela told journalists after returning from Zambia. Mandela charged that ``racist slurs'' being spread by the Conservative Party were a threat to hopes of negotiating a peaceful settlement in South Africa. The party contends that whites and blacks cannot live together and is calling for a white homeland. Mandela and other ANC leaders are to meet May 2 with President F.W. de Klerk to try to clear the way for full-scale negotiations on ending white minority rule and sharing political power with blacks. De Klerk legalized the ANC and other black opposition groups and released Mandela in February to clear the way for power-sharing talks.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Forces Put Popular Entertainment District Off-Limits
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials put a popular entertainment and disco district in Seoul off limits to American personnel today in an attempt to stem anti-American violence and protect U.S. soldiers. A statement issued by the U.S. 8th Army for the 43,000 U.S. troops, thousands of civilian employees and their dependents in South Korea said the Itaewon entertainment district would be off limits indefinitely from midnight until 5 a.m., effective Friday. Many American families live in the area. It was the first time in recent years that U.S. military officials have placed an entire South Korean district off limits to American soldiers and civilians. Officials said it was being done to protect ``the health and welfare'' of U.S. personnel. ``When lives are at stake, no measure is too extreme,'' said an unidentified official quoted in the statement. Itaewon is a shopping and entertainment area several city blocks long near the 8th Army headquarters. Foreign tourists, shoppers and U.S. military personnel shop there by day, and at night its neon-lit bars and discos draw hundreds of young Koreans as well. The announcement was an apparent move to avoid clashes between South Korean civilians and American soldiers who frequent late-night bars and entertainment establishments. On Sunday, a crowd of Koreans chased two U.S. military policeman and threw bottles, bricks and sticks. Two vehicles, including a U.S. military patrol car, were demolished, the windows of a police station were shattered and at least half a dozen people were injured. U.S. authorities said the melee began when several Koreans attacked a car being driven by a civilian Defense Department employee. The Koreans say the man had struck several pedestrians in the street with his car. One official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said there was a feeling the ``rash of incidents must be stopped.'' U.S. authorities have expressed concern over the use of group violence to solve disputes between American soldiers and South Koreans who frequently cannot communicate in a common language. This week the U.S. military asked the South Korean military to consider assigning uniformed national police to patrol the area. Anti-American feeling is strong in South Korea, especially among radicals and dissidents who have demanded the withdrawal of U.S. troops, claiming their presence hinders unification of South Korea with Communist North Korea. Meanwhile, a group of American soldiers on a routine training mission accidentally fired artillery rounds near a bridge leading to the heavily fortified Korean border and five U.S. and Korean soldiers were wounded. A guardpost at one end of the Freedom Bridge, frequently used by tourist buses, was destroyed by the explosion, witnesses said. The bridge itself was undamaged in the incident Wednesday. The site is 35 miles north of Seoul. In an unrelated incident, an American soldier was electrocuted today at Camp Stanley north of Seoul when the communications wire he was working on touched a high power line, U.S. military officials said. The soldier's name was not released, pending notification of relatives. He was assigned to the 2nd Infantry Division.

DOC.HEAD: Retail Sales Fall in March for Second Straight Month
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 1 graf after 3rd, bgng, March sales ..., with comment from economist
DOC.TEXT: Retail sales fell 0.6 percent in March following a drop in February, the first back-to-back declines in more than three years, the government said today. The Commerce Department said sales decreased $907 million to a seasonally adjusted $148.6 billion. That followed a revised drop of 0.3 percent in February, which had originally been reported as a sharper 0.9 percent decline. March sales, which showed the steepest drop in five months, softened in all sectors except food stores. Auto dealers reported the fifth decline in six months. Sales at department and clothing stores suffered from a later-than-average start to the Easter buying season. ``March was weak but to me it was a deceptive weakness because the previous month was revised up sharply,'' said economist Robert G. Dederick of Northern Trust Co. ``It's another one of those more-of-the-same reports. ... The consumer is sort of doing what the economy is doing. He's plodding ahead, but not in a straight line.'' Retail sales, which account for about a third of all economic activity, are closely watched as a barometer of economic health. Consumer demand has been weakened by the Federal Reserve Board's high interest rate policy aimed at dampening the economy and easing inflationary pressures. Auto sales totaled $30.7 billion in March, down 1.4 percent following a 6.5 percent decline in February. Excluding the volatile auto sector, sales fell 0.4 percent in March after a strong 1.5 percent gain a month earlier. Durable goods, ``big ticket'' items expected to last three or more years, have been particularly hard hit by interest rates because buyers usually borrow to purchase them. Durable goods fell 0.8 percent in March following a 2.7 percent drop a month earlier. Non-durable goods dropped 0.5 percent after rising 1.1 percent in February. The department offered these other details of retail sales last month: _Department and other general merchandise stores, down 1.0 percent following a 2.4 percent gain a month earlier. _Building materials, hardware and garden supplies, down 0.8 percent after a 2.5 percent gain. _Furniture, down 0.1 percent after a 2.2 percent rise. _Food stores, up 0.2 percent after a 0.9 percent advance. _Gasoline stations, down 1.7 percent after a drop of 0.8 percent. _Clothing stores, down 0.5 percent following a 1.7 percent gain. _Restaurants and bars, down 1.5 percent after a 3.6 percent rise. _Drug stores, down 0.9 percent following a 2.2 percent drop.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Breaks After First Day of Deliberations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 graf to UPDATE with deliberations resuming. Picks up 3rd graf pvs.
DOC.TEXT: A jury must decide whether John E. List carefully weighed his decision or was compelled by twisted religious beliefs to kill his wife, three children and mother 18{ years ago. The jury resumed deliberations this morning after meeting for six hours following final arguments Wednesday, the eighth day of the trial of the former Sunday school teacher. Defense attorney Elijah L. Miller Jr. has conceded that List, 64, committed the killings, but is seeking a verdict of second-degree murder, which carries a 30-year maximum sentence and possible parole after a third of the term. The prosecution, which argued that List acted with premeditation, is seeking a verdict of first-degree murder, which carries a life term with no parole until after 15 years. Miller argued that List, a pious and strictly raised Lutheran, was watching his ``whole world falling to pieces'' when an ``obsessive-compulsive'' personality disorder, combined with corrupted religious notions, turned him into a killer. List was beset by pressures, couldn't provide for his family after a series of job failures, and saw his family slipping from the church, Miller said. Union County Assistant Prosecutor Eleanor J. Clark urged jurors not to delay justice any longer. ``Because this defendant was so successful in maintaining his fugitive status, don't deny the state of New Jersey or Alma, Helen, Patricia, John or Frederick justice,'' she said. Authorities found the bodies of his wife Helen, 45; mother Alma, 84; daughter Patricia, 16; and sons John, 15 and Frederick, 13, in their 18-room Westfield mansion on Dec. 7, 1971. List, she said, ``acted as a hideous angel of death, weighing the options right up until the night before, killing his family.'' After slaying his family, List assumed another identity, remarried and settled down in the Richmond, Va., area. He was arrested in June after the killings were dramatized on a television crime show and a viewer tipped authorities.

DOC.HEAD: Precede Bucharest
King Prevented From Returning to Romania
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with king barred from flight home, comments by the king on visa withdrawal. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Exiled King Michael of Romania was forced today to cancel his first visit to his native country in 43 years after the Bucharest government canceled his visa. The official Romanian news agency Rompres said officials rescinded the visa today after the ex-monarch rejected the government's appeal that he postpone his trip until after elections set for May 20. While there was no official explanation for the visa cancellation, the provisional government said the visit could cause violence in Romania, which is still recovering from the overthrow of hard-line Communists in December. The governing National Unity Front led by interim President Ion Iliescu also was reportedly concerned that the former king's visit might give a boost to rival parties in the election campaign. A spokesman for the Bucharest government, reading a statement, said: ``The government has nothing against a private visit of the ex-king in Romania. It cannot agree, however, to a visit with a very political character.'' ``It was to be a strictly private visit,'' former King Michael, 68, told a news conference at the Zurich airport, where he was barred from boarding a Swissair flight to the Romanian capital of Bucharest. ``I don't understand the decision to rescind the visas. I don't know what concerns there could have been,'' he said. Rompres said authorities had conveyed a message to the former king asking him to postpone the trip and had also issued instructions to border guards to prevent him from entering the country. The news agency said the Romanian Embassy in Berne, Switzerland, also told Swissair officials the airline would be ``breaking international regulations'' if it allowed a passenger without a visa to board the flight to Bucharest. Despite the Romanian government's action, the former king flew from Geneva to Zurich, where he had planned to catch a scheduled direct Swissair flight at noon to Bucharest. But the airline's management decided after a hastily called meeting that the ex-monarch would not be allowed to board the plane. At his news conference, the ex-monarch held up his British passport to show that it had been stamped with a Romanian visa. Despite the Bucharest government's decision, Michael said he was still planning a visit ``as soon as possible.'' The airport news conference marked the first time that former King Michael himself has commented on the visit. Normally all contacts with the press are handled by his daughter, Princess Margarita, or by a Swiss spokeswoman. He was to have been accompanied on the visit by his wife, Queen Anne, and his daughters, Margarita and Anne, who also all had their visas canceled. They learned of the Romanian decision only after leaving their home in Versoix near Geneva, Switzerland, to catch the flight to Zurich. Another daughter, Helen, 39, arrived in Bucharest on Tuesday with a convoy from Britain containing 120 tons of relief supplies. The princess said she was ``struck by the dilapidation and poverty'' she had seen in several cities. The former king has not set foot on Romanian soil since he was forced to abdicate and leave the country by the Communists on Dec. 30, 1947. Michael said he had intended to stay no longer than 10 days in Romania. Princess Margarita said in Geneva that the deposed monarch viewed his trip as a spiritual pilgrimage and was not concerned with possible violence. On Wednesday, the Bucharest provisional government, which came to power in December after Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was ousted in a bloody revolution, issued a statement warning of the possibility of ``some violent manifestations'' if the ex-monarch's visit took place as scheduled. The visit ``and the publicity surrounding it are interpreted as a political gesture of a nature to bring about unwelcome elements in the electoral campaign and stir new passions,'' the government statement said. It said Michael's visit before the elections ``would be of a nature exacerbating existing conflicts, while also endangering his personal security.''

DOC.HEAD: College Art Group Rules Out Cincinnati Because of Photo Controversy
DOC.TEXT: A college art group has ruled out holding its 1995 conference in Cincinnati because of the controversy over a photography exhibit that led to obscenity charges against a museum. Ruth Weisberg, president of the College Art Association, told offficials in a letter that indictments charging the Contemporary Arts Center and its director with pandering obscenity make Cincinnati ``incompatible with the College Art Association's goals of academic freedom.'' A Hamilton County grand jury issued the indictments Saturday, citing seven photographs of homosexual acts or nude children in the 175-photo exhibit of works by the late Robert Mapplethorpe. ``We were seriously considering Cincinnati,'' Ms. Weisberg, an art professor at the University of Southern California, said Wednesday. The Mapplethorpe exhibit opened in Cincinnati on Saturday and more than 14,000 people visited the museum during the first five days. Last year, the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C., canceled the exhibit, but it has been shown in several other cities. The Washington exhibit prompted Congress to limit funds for the arts after Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., declared the photographs obscene. The 11,000-member association was founded in Cincinnati in 1912 and is based in New York. The National Council on Education for the Ceramic Arts was holding its national conference in Cincinnati in March when the Mapplethorpe controversy erupted. It ended its conference by resolving never to return to Cincinnati.

DOC.HEAD: Education Secretary Criticized for Questioning Hispanic Parents' Values
DOC.TEXT: Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos' claim that Hispanic parents deserve much of the blame for their children's high dropout rate is drawing fire from the nation's largest Hispanic organization. Cavazos, himself Hispanic, said in a news conference Tuesday night that problems Hispanics have in school cannot be attributed completely to economic difficulties or language barriers because other ethnic groups have overcome such barriers. ``We really have not cared that youngsters have dropped out of school. We don't care, either teachers, parents, business community, elected officials. We must have a commitment from Hispanics, from Hispanic parents especially, that their children will be educated,'' Cavazos said. The remarks upset Cruz Chavira, national chief of staff for the League of United Latin American Citizens, based in San Antonio. Chavira said Wednesday that scores of educators had called his office to complain. ``That is incredible,'' said Chavira. ``I just can't imagine how he can direct the guilt at parents. I don't know of a single Hispanic not concerned about education. ``For him to ignore the facts _ that Hispanics have the least-salaried people in our schools, the poorest of real wealth to be taxed _ for him to discard those factors and lay it on the parents, I'm getting very emotional here. He is absolutely incorrect.'' Cavazos' comments came after he opened a hearing on Hispanic education, the first of five regional meetings on the subject. About 40 percent of Hispanics nationwide left school before high school graduation during the 1980s, Cavazos said. The rate for all groups in the United States is 30 percent. He said only 11 percent of Hispanics complete four or more years of college by the time they are in their early 30s. But Cavazos didn't intend to imply that Hispanic parents don't value education, said Etta Fielek, director of public affairs for the Department of Education. Cavazos meant to say that the Hispanic population lacked leadership, not values, Ms. Fielek said. Jose Cardenas, executive director of the Intercultural Development Research Association, disagreed. ``There is a lot of leadership in the Hispanic community,'' said Cardenas. Hispanic leaders have not been able to become involved in the decision-making process because they have repeatedly been stymied, he said. The hearing, and others to follow in Miami, Chicago, Los Angeles and Boston, were organized by a federal task force to address what President Bush has called the crisis in Hispanic education.

DOC.HEAD: Looting, Violence in Riot Over Teen-Ager's Death
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with two grafs to UPDATE with teens on streets this morning but no violence. INSERTS one graf after 14th, `George Powell...', to UPDATE with no decision from governor on special prosecutor. Picks up 15th graf, `The boy's...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NR1, NR2, NR4, NR5
DOC.TEXT: Youths overturned patrol cars, smashed windows and looted stores after the slaying of a black teen-ager by a white police officer. At least five people were injured. About 1,000 people had rallied peacefully Wednesday night, demanding that a special prosecutor investigate the killing of 15-year-old Phillip Pannell. Groups of teen-agers were on the streets this morning, but there were no reports of violence. The boy was shot Tuesday evening after he was questioned at a park by two officers responding to a report of a teen-ager pulling a gun. Pannell died of a gunshot wound that entered his back, the Bergen County medical examiner said. Police said Pannell had a gun, but his friends denied it and said the killing was racially motivated. Violence began Wednesday night after a candlelight vigil, when about a dozen police officers in riot gear appeared at the edge of the crowd to try to force people to disperse. Police pushed the crowd into the parking lot of the police headquarters and some people were trampled, witnesses said. Some in the crowd retaliated by smashing windows and doors at the police station. They smashed the windows of three patrol cars and overturned a fourth. Gangs of youths ran up and down Teaneck Road, adjoining the station, smashing shop windows and looting some stores, including a video rental shop. Police wearing riot helmets milled around a liquor store with smashed windows to keep people from entering. Police said they arrested a 17-year-old man. Two police officers and two other people, a woman and a man, were treated for minor injuries and released from a hospital, a nurse said. A photographer from the Black Star photo agency was attacked by a gang and was helped into an ambulance with a bloody nose. Most of the protesters had dispersed by about 11 p.m. Teaneck police called in reinforcements from the State Police, Bergen County and at least five surrounding towns. Teaneck is an affluent community of 37,000 not far from the George Washington Bridge linking northern New Jersey and Manhattan. The town, which has prided itself on its racial and ethnic diversity, is 64 percent white and 24 percent black. Acting Bergen County Prosecutor John Holl said a grand jury will hear evidence on the teen-ager's shooting next week. ``There is a lot of confusion in this case,'' he said. ``There are more questions than answers.'' George Powell, executive director of the Bergen County NAACP, told demonstrators before the violence broke out that his organization sought the suspension of Gary Spath, the officer who shot Pannell, and would ask Gov. Jim Florio to assign a special prosecutor. The governor's spokeswoman today said Florio planned to meet with state officials and had made no decision on a special prosecutor. The boy's father, also named Phillip, pleaded with the crowd to avoid confrontation. ``There's no violence here, no violence,'' he told the crowd. Spath was treated and released from a hospital after going into shock following the shooting. Spath and the other officer at the scene, Wayne Blanco, were placed on sick leave pending an investigation, Holl said. Earlier in the day, Holl told reporters that investigators had found a gun on the youth's body. One of the officers was frisking Pannell when he said he felt what he thought was a gun, Holl said. At that point, Pannell bolted and the officers chased him, according to the account given by Blanco. Blanco said Spath fired one shot that missed. Spath fired again after Pannell reached into his jacket pocket, Blanco said. Friends of Pannell denied that he had a gun. One witness said Pannell was asking for mercy. ``Phil was begging. He was yelling, `Please, don't shoot!''' said Irin Rivers, 18. ``I was just with him playing basketball. He died just after the game was over.'' Police rallied behind Spath, 29, who last month received his fifth commendation from the Teaneck Policeman's Benevolent Association since joining the department in 1982. ``I can't begin to express to you what a gentle soul he is,'' said Fred Greene, a retired police officer who was the first black to join the township's police force. ``What happened here is a tragedy.''

DOC.HEAD: Author, Psychology Professor Dies
DOC.TEXT: James McConnell, a retired psychology professor at the University of Michigan who wrote a widely used textbook, has died of a heart attack. He was 64. McConnell died Monday at St. Joseph Mercy Hospital in Ann Arbor. McConnell, who studied autistic children, subliminal stimulation and the psychology of persuasion, wrote at least eight books and numerous articles for journals. His introductory psychology text, ``Understanding Human Behavior,'' was used by more than a generation of college students in the United States. In 1959, McConnell founded Worm Runners Digest, a satirical publication that poked fun at his colleagues. McConnell was born in Okmulgee, Okla., and earned a bachelor's degree from Louisiana State University and master's and doctoral degrees from the University of Texas. He joined Michigan's faculty in 1956 as an instructor and became a professor in 1963. He retired in 1988. Survivors include an aunt and a cousin. A memorial service was scheduled for Friday in Ann Arbor. The body was cremated.

DOC.HEAD: First Lady, Celebrities Attend Funeral for Young AIDS Victim
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf with one graf to CORRECT that Mrs. Bush had no role in the ceremony.
With LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: With the pomp and circumstance usually reserved for state funerals, the rich and famous joined in paying final respects to Ryan White, who fought prejudice against AIDS sufferers during his long battle with the disease. The funeral, attended by 1,500 people and broadcast live on CNN, showed how the articulate, poised 18-year-old had touched the nation's heart with his pleas for understanding. First lady Barbara Bush led the list of dignitaries at the ceremony, also attended by pop stars Michael Jackson and Elton John. The pallbearers included talk-show host Phil Donahue, John and Los Angeles Raiders star Howie Long. White was buried in his favorite clothes: blue jeans, a red shirt, blue jeans jacket and sunglasses. He had told his mother, ``I just want to be comfortable,'' before he died Sunday. White, who got AIDS in 1984 from a blood transfusion to treat his hemophilia, gained national attention when he and his mother fought attempts by frightened parents to keep him from attending public school in his hometown, Kokomo. He later won a court battle and began attending school in another town in 1987. As a 13-year-old suffering from what was then a disease known mainly to inflict homosexuals, Ryan was able to appeal to the nation's empathy for AIDS patients with a voice most were willing to hear. ``He was the boy next door who first showed a stunned nation that no one is safe from the risk of AIDS,'' Dr. Martin B. Kleiman, White's physician said recently.``With an honest simplicity, his was the voice that many, if not most, first heard.'' ``He showed us all that we need to devote ourselves to fighting the disease of AIDS, not those who suffer from it,'' White's mother, Jeanne, said Wednesday. White's father, Wayne, who is divorced from Mrs. White, also attended the service at the Second Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Raymond Probasco encouraged the mourners to continue to seek a cure for acquired immune deficiency syndrome. ``With God's help, and each of yours, we'll make AIDS a disease and not a dirty word,'' said Probasco, pastor at Center Chapel United Methodist Church in Muncie. About 300 of White's schoolmates at Hamilton Heights High School in Arcadia, 25 miles north of Indianapolis, attended the funeral. The school's choir sang ``That's What Friends Are For,'' standing near the open casket at the front of the church. White was welcomed by the school after his family moved from Kokomo. John, who had maintained a bedside vigil during White's final week of life and was there when he died, led the congregation in singing a hymn and then sang his own composition, ``Skyline Pigeon.'' After the ceremony, John and Jackson joined White's mother in a final viewing of the body before the casket was closed. ``Mrs. White gave her son one last kiss before it was closed. Michael remarked that the silence in the room was loud enough to express the love and appreciation of the world,'' said Lee Solters, a spokesman for Jackson. Solters said White was buried wearing a watch he had received from Jackson, who had given White a Ford Mustang last year and had hosted him at Jackson's California ranch during the New Year's holiday. ``Ryan and his family always believed there would be a miracle,'' Probasco said. ``But that didn't happen. I believe God gave us that miracle in Ryan. He healed a wounded spirit in the world and made it whole.'' Later the funeral procession of about 150 cars and 30 motorcycle police moved slowly through the rolling farmland to the Cicero Cemetery. Along the way, well-wishers stood along the side of the road, some holding signs and others holding video cameras. Calvin Brown watched the burial from across the road with his two sons. His daughter, a schoolmate of White's, attended the service. ``I think he made people appreciate their own chidren more. I know he has mine,'' Brown said. ``I was hoping he'd lick this disease.''

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Names De Maiziere Premier, Apologizes for Nazi Atrocities
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 3 grafs after 9th graf, ``Jews in...'' to UPDATE with reaction by Israeli official. Pickup 10th graf, `Parliament chose...'
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's new Parliament today named Lothar de Maiziere as prime minister, backed a plan for swift unification with West Germany and apologized to Jews for the atrocities of the Nazis. The nation's first freely elected government also said a unified Germany should at least temporarily be a part of the NATO alliance, a key issue when the superpowers begin unification talks in the coming weeks. And it endorsed a merger of the two German currencies by July 1, a demand of West Germany. The agreement among East Germany's major political parties on the speed of reunification, a united Germany's military alignment and a timetable for a currency union was a huge leap forward to creating a single Germany. The sweeping moves will be followed by unification talks with West Germany and the four World War II allies that divided the countries: the Soviet Union, United States, Britain and France. In a remarkable string of conciliatory gestures, Parliament recognized the legitimacy of Poland's postwar borders and apologized for East Germany's role in the Soviet-led invasion that crushed reforms in Czechoslovakia in 1968. It also said East Germany is prepared to make reparations to Nazi victims and urged establishment of diplomatic relations with Israel. The hard-line Communist government that was toppled in October had never formally apologized for the Holocaust. West Germany has apologized for Nazi atrocities and has paid reparations to Jews. Parliament approved a declaration saying that East Germany ``admits in the name of the citizens of this country its co-responsibility for the humiliation and expulsion and murder of Jewish women, men and children. ``Jews in all the world and the people of Israel are asked to forgive us for the wrongs they experienced. Persecuted Jews should be granted asylum in the future in East Germany.'' An Israeli Foreign Ministry official, Michael Shilo, said the declaration ``paves the way for further dialogue'' on establishing diplomatic relations between the two countries. ``It's a very positive text. It may be overdue, but it is nonetheless welcome,'' said Shilo, who headed an Israeli delegation that earlier this year held two rounds of preliminary talks with East Germany's Communist-led transition government on setting up diplomatic ties. Shilo said the declaration appeared to meet Israel's two conditions for establishing ties _ East Germany's acceptance of moral responsibility for the Holocaust and its willingness to negotiate reparations. Parliament chose de Maiziere, leader of the conservative Christian Democrats, and installed his 24-member Cabinet on a vote of 265-108, with nine abstentions. Eighteen members of the 400-member Parliament were absent. The prime minister was strongly backed by Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany. His conservative alliance won 48 percent of the vote in March 18 elections. That gave de Maiziere a mandate to negotiate with West Germany. The coalition agreement on the makeup of his government was reached Wednesday after nearly a week of intense negotiations cleared the way for parliamentary approval. The Cabinet pledged to secure prosperity, social justice and freedom for all East German citizens, according to excerpts carried by the East German news agency ADN. The agreement also paved the way for rapid reunification by stating the merging of the two countries should be based on the article of the West German Constitution that permits direct incorporation of East German territory into West Germany. It calls for a direct 1-1 conversion of East German marks for West German marks when the nations merge their currencies. West Germany's central bank has proposed a 2-1 rate for all but only small savings accounts. The coalition agreement also lays the foundation for East Germany's foreign policy and says: ``It can be assumed that a unified Germany, during a transition period and until the creation of a collective European security system, should be a member of a NATO that itself is transforming its military functions.'' The statement endorses Western demands that a united Germany be part of NATO. The Soviet Union wants a new Germany to be neutral, but this week proposed that it have joint membership in NATO and the Warsaw Pact. West Germany now is in NATO and East Germany is part of the Warsaw Pact. An increasingly restive workforce worried about rampant unemployment associated with reunification planned demonstrations today. About 20 tractors and farms trucks, some bearing signs saying ``Market Economy for Farmers?'' rolled into the parking lot of Parliament to demonstrate their concern over loss of state subsidies and fear the government-owned land they till will fall into private hands. But telephone and other electronics workers fearing unemployment did not follow through with their appeal for a three-hour strike in the capital. Approval of the de Maiziere government clears the way for the start of talks with West Germany on merging their divergent economic and political systems after four decades of separation. A West German government spokesman said Wednesday that Kohl wants to sign a treaty on monetary union between the two states by May 6, with the currency merger to go into effect by July 7.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Arrested for Violating Court Order Restricting School Protests
DOC.TEXT: Seven demonstrators were arrested for violating a court order that restricts protests over the firing of Selma's first black school superintendent. The arrests Wednesday occurred one day after Lauderdale County Circuit Judge Leslie Johnson issued an order restricting demonstrators to the sidewalk in front of City Hall. It also prohibits them from encouraging car horn honking, marching around the building or holding picnics in the lobby. Four protesters were arrested outside City Hall and three others were arrested Wednesday afternoon after a scuffle outside a restaurant involving three policemen. The protests have been continuing since mid-December, when the white-controlled school board refused to extend the contract of Superintendent Norward Roussell. Roussell has filed a racial discrimination lawsuit against the white school board members who voted not to extend his contract, which expires in June. Police Chief Melvin Summerlin said the first arrests occurred after a group of protesters set up chairs on the sidewalk in front of City Hall, blocking a loading zone in violation of the order, and refused to move. Summerlin said he ordered the group to disperse but he was ignored. The incident at the restaurant apparently was sparked when a driver was cited for blowing his horn about a block away from City Hall. Attorney Rose Sanders said the people arrested had been abiding by the court order. ``Those people were exercising their constitutional rights and the actions by the city against them were immoral and unjust,'' she said. Several motorists were given tickets for blowing their car horns as they drove by City Hall. Mayor Joe Smitherman said officials believe the motorists were deliberately testing the court order.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Arrests Man in Assassination of Chilean Ambassador
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 4th graf, `U.S. officials...', to ADD comment from Sen. Kennedy. Picks up 5th graf, `A former...'.
DOC.TEXT: A fugitive arrested in the 1976 car bombing that killed the former Chilean ambassador was being held without bond awaiting trial in Washington, D.C. Jose Dionisio Suarez y Esquivel, 51, arrested at his St. Petersburg home early Wednesday, waived his rights to a bond hearing before a federal magistrate here on charges of conspiracy to murder a foreign official. Suarez is accused of providing the explosives and detonating devices in the explosion that killed former Chilean Ambassador Orlando Letelier and business colleague Ronni Moffitt as they drove to work in Washington on Sept. 21, 1976. U.S. officials said they expect the new Chilean government to prosecute top intelligence officials of the former military government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet on charges of planning Letelier's assassination, The New York Times reported today. The killings long have been a sore point in relations between the United States and Chile. In Washington, Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., welcomed the arrest and commended the FBI, but said, ``Unfortunately, the masterminds of this atrocity remain at large in Chile.
