I hope and expect that the new democratic government in that nation will do all in its power to bring them to justice.'' A former Chilean diplomat, Jose Miguel Barros, testified in a Chilean court last year that Letelier's assassination was ordered by Chilean army Gen. Juan Manuel Contreras Sepulveda, who headed the Chilean National Intelligence Agency. Pinochet stepped down as president last month after the election of a civilian, Patricio Aylwin. U.S. marhals said Suarez would be flown to Washington as early as Saturday. If convicted, he could face life in prison. FBI agents said Suarez had been leading a secretive, cautious life in St. Petersburg, rarely even leaving the house. ``To our knowledge, he hasn't been employed in the last 12 to 14 years,'' said Assistant U.S. Attorney Terry Furr. But his 30-year-old wife Elizabeth said Suarez worked at home as an artist and never realized his face had been plastered in post offices and courthouses around the country for more than a decade. ``No one ever notified him he was a fugitive,'' said Mrs. Suarez, a hospital administration employee and mother of a 15-month-old boy. She said they have lived either in Tampa or St. Petersburg throughout their nine-year marriage. Letelier served as Chilean ambassador to the United States in 1971-1973, during the presidency of Salvador Allende, who was ousted by Pinochet in a coup. Letelier had begun to emerge as a leading international critic of Pinochet when he and Moffitt were assassinated. Michael V. Townley, a U.S. citizen who also was an employee of the Chilean intelligence agency, was arrested in April 1978. Townley was extradited to the United States, confessed to planting the bomb on the order of superiors and spent 40 months in prison. According to the FBI, Townley, Suarez and fugitive Virgilio Pablo Paz built the bomb used in the assassination. Suarez allegedly provided the explosives and detonators and purchased the bomb parts. A federal grand jury also indicted three Chilean army personnel in connection with the case. Maj. Armando Fernandez Larios pleaded guilty to being an accessory after the fact to Letelier's death and was sentenced to 22 months in custody. The Justice Department has failed to obtain the extradition of two others.

DOC.HEAD: Man Given Death Sentence for Slayings of Family, Fetus
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-5, `Slawson had...eight-month fetus,' to properly place first reference to Wood.
DOC.TEXT: A man convicted of murdering a family of four and carving a woman's nearly full-term fetus out of her womb has been sentenced to die in Florida's electric chair. Newton Slawson, 35, showed no emotion Wednesday as Hillsborough Circuit Judge Robert Bonanno followed the jury's recommendation and sentenced him to four death sentences plus 30 years in prison. ``He wasn't surprised. We weren't surprised,'' said defense attorney Brian Donerly. Slawson had pleaded involuntary cocaine intoxication, claiming that Gerald Wood, a co-worker at a compost company, had secretly slipped some crack cocaine in his beer during a visit. But the jury recommended the death sentence after convicting him last month of four counts of first-degree murder and one manslaughter count in the April 11, 1989 slayings of Wood, 23, his pregnant wife, Peggy, 21, and their children, Jennifer, 3, and Glendon, 2. The manslaughter conviction was for the death of Mrs. Wood's eight-month fetus. Bleeding heavily, Mrs. Wood managed to drag herself next door to her parents' house and tell her mother that Slawson did it. Wilma Williams, Mrs. Wood's mother, said afterward she couldn't say she was happy at the sentence. ``He has a mother, too, and I can feel for her.'' Slawson didn't deny the killings, but testified that he didn't remember them. He said he came to at the Wood apartment with a gun in his hand, found bodies around him and decided to try to save the fetus. ``I used my knife and I slit her open,'' Slawson testified. ``And when I got into her and I had opened the uterus and saw the child and saw the damage to the child, I knew there was no way that baby was going to live.'' Slawson said he left and reloaded his .357-caliber Magnum to kill himself. But he wasn't sure if it all was a dream, so he drove back past the Woods' apartment, saw police and was arrested. During the trial, Slawson's mother testified she routinely abused her son when he was a child. She often tied him up and beat him, and locked him in a closet until he curled up in a fetal position. ``I whipped him for no reason at all,'' Tully Slawson said. ``I was sick and he was my whipping boy.''

DOC.HEAD: Review With No Book Embarrasses Paper
DOC.TEXT: A journalism student's review of a non-existent American book caused a flush of embarrassment to a leading newspaper, which missed the pun and printed it. The review of a novel called ``Surface'' said it was about a future when writers no longer write books, only reviews, because people have become too superficial to read literary works. The fictional review was published by Goteborgsposten, Sweden's second-largest morning daily. It was written by Ulf Eliasson, a journalism student who had contributed to the paper before. The episode prompted amusement and outrage in the journalism world. In an acrid comment to Journalisten, the Swedish Journalists' Union paper, a cultural editor from Goteborgsposten called Eliasson's prank stupid and said it ``discredited all those serious cultural journalists who wants to discuss media and art honestly.'' Others defended Eliasson. One wrote a letter to Journalisten calling it one of ``the funniest things I ever read. ... If this wonderful effort by Ulf would undermine cultural journalism, there is not much to it.'' The review said the book was ``the literary debut by 90-year-old Friedrich Cass, published by Aquarius, of Denver, Colo.'' Cass, Eliasson said later, should have been a tip, since it means ``lousy'' in Swedish when spelled with a K.

DOC.HEAD: Reactor Aboard Nuclear-Powered Ship Shut Down
DOC.TEXT: The reactor aboard Japan's only nuclear-powered ship was shut down for more than two hours Thursday after operators discovered problems with a switch used to move its control rods, the Atomic Energy Research Institute said. Kazuyoshi Haga, spokesman for the government-affiliated institute, said the shutdown came during a test of the reactor aboard the 8,214-ton Mutsu. It was the fifth time the reactor has been shut down since the institute began testing it March 29, Haga said. The reactor had not been used since it developed a radiation leak in its protective shield on the ship's maiden voyage in 1974. After developing the leak, the ship drifted 50 days before residents of Mutsu, its home port, allowed it to return temporarily. The ship has been docked at Sekinehama, 360 miles north of Tokyo, since 1988. The ship's reactor, including the defective shield, was extensively remodeled after the leak. In Thursday's shutdown, operators manually halted the reactor and found that a portion of the switch was faulty, Haga said. The switch was replaced and the reactor resumed operations, he said. Institute officials say the reactor will be tested further and the ship will make several test voyages aimed at obtaining data for possible future development of nuclear-powered commercial vessels. Following the tests, the Mutsu, with an output capacity of 36,000 kilowatts, is to be retired.

DOC.HEAD: Inflation Jumps to 8.1 Percent, Jobless Rate Steady at 5.6 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Britain's annual inflation rate jumped to 8.1 percent in March from 7.5 percent in February, largely because of increases in mortgage rates, the government said Thursday. The increase brought inflation to its highest level since July, when it was 8.2 percent. Unemployment held steady at 5.6 percent in March, the government said. Britain's inflation rate, the worst among the major industrialized nations, is expected to move up to 9 percent before decreasing. Curbing resurgent inflation is Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's No.1 economic priority, and 15 percent interest rates are her weapon. Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major has said that a new per-capita tax called the community charge, introduced this month, will boost the inflation rate. There have been widespread protests against the community charge, which replaces a property tax system used to pay for local services. New excise taxes also will push up the index in the next few months, the department said.

DOC.HEAD: Cafeteria Explosion Injures 69
DOC.TEXT: An explosion Thursday at the cafeteria of a bicycle parts factory in central Taiwan injured 69 workers during lunch, police reported. Police in Taichung, 112 miles southwest of Taipei, said the blast was caused by a gas leak in the cafeteria kitchen. Nineteen workers were hospitalized with serious burns, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Kill Man in Hospital Bed
DOC.NOTE: EDS: 'ndrangheta in 2nd graf cq.
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen slipped into a hospital early Thursday and shot to death a local politician who had been seriously wounded two days earlier in an assassination attempt, police said. Investigators blamed the slaying on the 'ndrangheta, the Calabrian Mafia. Shortly after midnight, at least two men entered the recovery room of Riuniti Hospital and fired three shots into Vincenzo Reitano, 29. The assailants escaped. Police said the gunmen took advantage of the lack of night security at the hospital. They used a key to get into the locked room where Reitano was sleeping, leading investigators to assume they had accomplices working inside the hospital. Reitano was shot and wounded Tuesday in the nearby town of Fiumara di Muro, where he serves on the town council. He had been expected to be released from the hospital shortly. The deputy major of Fiumara di Muro was assassinated last March by Mafia gunmen.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Convicts List on Five Counts of Murder
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs. Leads with 5 grafs to move up reaction to verdict, add defense lawyer's name. Picks up 7th graf, ``List was...' SUBS 9th graf pvs to delete now-redundant date of killings.
DOC.TEXT: A jury Thursday convicted a mild-mannered former accountant and Sunday school teacher of the premeditated murder of his wife, mother and three children in their suburban mansion 18 years ago. A gaunt, white-haired John E. List, 64, showed no emotion as the verdict was announced after the jury deliberated almost nine hours over two days. His sentencing is scheduled for May 1. Defense attorney Elijah L. Miller Jr. acknowledged in opening arguments that List committed the killings on Nov. 9, 1971. Miller sought a verdict of second-degree murder based on a contention that List had a mental disease or defect. The jury found List guilty of five counts of first-degree murder, an offense that carries a life term with no parole until after 15 years. Second-degree murder would have allowed parole after a third of the 30-year maximum sentence. List was arrested in Richmond, Va., in June after a telephoned tip to the ``America's Most Wanted'' television show, which had broadcast his case. His arrest ended a secret life as a fugitive spent mostly in Denver in which List again took up his profession, returned to the Lutheran church and remarried. Authorities found the bodies of his wife Helen, 45; mother Alma, 84; daughter Patricia, 16; and sons John, 15, and Frederick, 13, in their 18-room Westfield mansion on Dec. 7, 1971. Dirgelike religious music was playing over an intercom system, the heat had been lowered to 50 degrees and List left a series of chillingly matter-of-fact notes explaining his actions and apologizing. Two pictures of List emerged during the trial. Witnesses testified he was a mild-mannered, deeply pious and strictly raised Lutheran born in a hard-working German immigrant community in Bay City, Mich. He was a history buff deeply involved in his church who loved to play war games. But other evidence clouded the image of the strait-laced father and ordinary suburban family. List told his psychiatrist he watched erotic films to become sexually aroused. Witnesses told investigators shortly after the bodies were discovered that Patricia was interested in witchcraft. List said he feared she would start smoking marijuana. His sister-in-law's husband, Gene Syfert, testified that List was fascinated with unsolved mysteries. And List's wife was dying, turned psychotic and bed-ridden by late-stage syphilis caught from her first husband in 1943. Defense psychiatric experts testified that an ``obsessive-compulsive'' personality disorder combined with List's twisted sense of religion and a series of a pressures on his life made him unable to deliberate over his decision. List felt unable to support his family and dreaded the prospect of welfare. He was oppressed by his wife's illness and the shame it caused. His daughter's acting ambitions concerned him. And he feared his family was falling away from their religion and facing damnation, the defense contended. Eleanor J. Clark, a Union County assistant prosecutor, called List a ``hideous angel of death'' who carefully planned the killings and deliberated his options right until the end. The state presented 41 witnesses in 2{ days, most of them investigators, forensic experts and neighbors and acquaintances. Their testimony was intended to show that List meticulously planned the killings. A prosecution psychiatrist testified that List had an obsessive personality, but suffered from little more than a mid-life crisis. On the day of the slayings, witnesses said List ate meals before and after shooting his victims, even cleaning the house and washing the dishes. He calmly withdrew money from the bank and left instructions for funerals and for wrapping up his financial affairs, even leaving a note for the milkman and labeling a desk drawer, which contained the pistols he used, ``guns and ammo.'' List then zig-zagged across country by train before settling in Denver because, he told a psychiatrist, he always liked the mountains. After working as a cook, he returned to his accounting profession and moved to Midlothian, Va., a Richmond suburb, in 1988. He was known to spend time watching television. One of his favorite show was said to be ``America's Most Wanted.''

DOC.HEAD: Explosion at Acetylene Plant Rocks Oklahoma Town
DOC.TEXT: An explosion at an acetylene plant today caused three injuries and briefly knocked out electricity to 3,000 customers when debris hit a power line, authorities said. None of the injuries was serious. The blast at the Big Three Industries plant, which had only two employees, shook surrounding buildings, witnesses said. Plant foreman Robert Bye, 27, was in good condition at St. John Medical Center in Tulsa, said hospital spokesman Barrett Waller. He didn't have any details about Bye's injuries. Two people who worked at a nearby glass factory were treated for minor injuries and released, said Frank Mitchell, manager of Kerr Glass. The cause of the explosion could not be determined immediately. Al Martin, a salesman who answered the phone at Big Three Industries offices in Tulsa, said company officials were at the scene and not available for comment. A woman who answered the phone earlier who asked not to be identified said of the two employees at the plant: ``We've talked to one of them and he said he was OK and that the other one was fine, too.'' The plant fills tanks with acetylene, a highly flammable gas, for use in welding. Fire Chief Fred Shawger said the fire department evacuated a half-mile area around the plant for an hour because of the potential of other explosions. ``There was a lot of metal flying,'' Shawger said. ``It was a metal building which just blew up and sprayed shrapnel.'' The 7:43 a.m. explosion knocked out power to about 3,000 customers from Sand Springs to just south of Bartlesville, said Brian Miller, spokesman for Public Service Co. of Oklahoma. He said power was restored to all but about 200 customers within the hour. ``Apparently some sheet metal that was part of this building flew up and got in our lines,'' Miller said. Tom Watson, manager of Morrow-Gill Lumber Co., said the explosion damaged part of his ceiling. ``We've got eight-foot florescent lights on the floor. It completely tore down part of the ceiling and warped all of our ceiling structure.'' Sue Clark of the city public works office, which is about 300 yards from the plant, said employees thought their building had exploded. ``Stuff fell out of the ceiling and the floor shook, so we ran out of the building,'' she said. ``There was just black smoke and debris coming up in the air.''

DOC.HEAD: Vendors Try to Cash in on Earthquake Jitters
DOC.TEXT: Merchants eager to cash in on Californians' seismic jitters hawked survival kits, wind-up radios and furniture fasteners at an earthquake bazaar. The several dozen vendors at the downtown sale credited brisk business Wednesday to increased anxiety following October's San Francisco Bay area quake. ``When there has been a recent earthquake ... it really is good for us,'' said Jeannie Rothfuss of Marathon Medical Corp., where earthquake kits have been a big seller since the devastating quake. Hundreds of people browsed at the Second Annual Downtown Earthquake Preparedness Action Council Earthquake Education and Vendor Fair in the Arco Plaza subterranean shopping center. For $150, Steve Ballenberg offered a 14{-pound duffel bag of survival goodies described as ``the state-of-the-art'' emergency kit. Dave Wallace of Survivor Industries Inc., passed out hundreds of water samples, inviting passersby to, ``Have a drink on me!'' Those afraid of running out of batteries could spend $40 on a flashlight-radio that plays for 30 minutes on 200 wind-up cranks.

DOC.HEAD: Security Measures Increased After Car Bomb Kills 20 People
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 15 grafs to UPDATE death toll from 16 to 20, anonymous callers claiming responsibility for blast, add comments by police official. Pickup 13th graf, ``Colombia's security ...'
DOC.TEXT: A car bomb attack that killed 20 people, including eight members of an elite police anti-drug squad, was part of a terrorist campaign being waged by drug traffickers, anonymous callers said. Police, fearing more attacks, set up dozens of checkpoints and increased patrols in Medellin today. Cocaine traffickers have targeted police in the northern city of 2 million in retaliation for the government's anti-drug campaign. The bomb, packing 220 pounds of dynamite, exploded Wednesday beside a crowded highway as a truck carrying 21 officers of the elite police unit passed by. The explosion badly damaged buildings and cars nearby. Police said the death toll from the blast rose to 20 early today after four civilians who had been critically wounded in the attack died at hospitals. More than 100 people were wounded, including the other 13 police officers in the truck. ``We are expecting more attacks by the Medellin cartel, and for that reason we are increasing security measures in a drastic manner,'' a Medellin police spokesman said in a telephone interview. He refused to give his name. Police also increased increased vehicle checkpoints in Bogota, the capital, where one week ago police deactivated a truck bomb packing 1,650 pounds of dynamite. In December, traffickers exploded a 1,100-pound truck bomb at security police headquarters in Bogota, and 63 people were killed. Anonymous callers to newspapers said Wednesday's attack was carried out by the Extraditables, a name used by drug traffickers who are fighting government efforts to extradite them to the United States. The callers warned that more bombings would be staged in retaliation for what they claimed was the torture and murder of drug traffickers by the police. The government has denied the allegations of brutality. ``We accept responsibility for what happened (in Medellin),'' a caller to the El Tiempo newspaper said late Wednesday. ``If the torture continues, we are not going to leave a single policeman alive.'' The chief of police operations, Gen. Octavio Vargas, denied the traffickers' accusations in a radio interview today with the RCN network. He said Medellin cocaine cartel leader Pablo Escobar had begun killing his own people because he feared betrayal. In Bogota, the news program ``TV Hoy'' reported that senior police sources said the bombing was ordered by Medellin cocaine cartel leader Pablo Escobar. The program quoted police as saying that they had irrefutable evidence of Escobar's involvement. The unit the slain police officers belonged is charged with battling terrorism by drug traffickers and leftist guerrillas. The force has received training in Colombia from U.S. and British security personnel in recent months. The explosion occurred as thousands of Colombians drove out of Medellin to begin Holy Week vacations. Radio reports said it left a 7-foot-deep hole in the highway. In the port of Cartagena, President Virgilio Barco said he was ``sorry to receive such bad news,'' the radio network RCN reported. ``Colombia's security forces will not rest,'' Interior Minister Horacio Serpa said in an interview with the ``Noticiero National'' news program. ``The government will pursue criminals no matter what sacrifice is involved.'' Authorities say Escobar has placed a price of $4,290 on the head of each police officer in Medellin, and they blame gunmen working for the Medellin cartel for the murders of 19 police officers last week. The traffickers said in a communique Friday that they would step up their war against police and the country's political and business elite. Late last month, the cartel promised to bomb Bogota because the government has refused to stop extraditing suspected drug traffickers to the United States. Barco's administration has extradited 15 drug suspects in the last eight months. Security forces blame Escobar for masterminding the bombing campaign and other attacks that began shortly after the government intensified its U.S.-backed crackdown on traffickers in August. More than 200 people were killed in bombings and assassinations blamed on drug bosses before they declared a unilateral truce on Jan. 17. But the government then resumed extraditions of drug suspects to the United States, ending a two-month hiatus, and the traffickers said they were renewing their terror campaign because their offer to negotiate peace had been rejected.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmits a0569 to fix cycle designation
DOC.HEAD: IRS Car Immobilized for Unpaid Parking Tickets
DOC.TEXT: An Interal Revenue Service car parked outside the federal courthouse was ``booted'' for unpaid parking tickets, forcing tax collectors to fork over $122.50 to set it free. Officers can immobilize any vehicle by locking a device on a tire if four parking tickets go unpaid for 30 days, said Gertrude Bradley, clerical supervisor for the the city parking division. The IRS had to pay $95 for five tickets, a $25 removal fee plus $2.50 for processing to get the boot taken off. With April 15th's tax-filing deadline closing in, courthouse employees were chuckling about the IRS' misfortune Wednesday. But the agency was not amused. ``We're not pleased with it,'' said spokesman Holger Euringer. ``No one is ever happy to see a boot on their car, and that includes the federal government. But we can certainly understand why some taxpayers would find that rather humorous.'' Euringer said the agency would track down the employees who got the tickets and seek reimbursement.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Dies in Suspected Airport-Linked Arson Attack
DOC.TEXT: A fire that may have been set by radicals opposed to the expansion of Tokyo's international airport swept through the home of an aircraft parts maker Thursday and killed his wife, police said. The executive, Atsumasa Kamakura, was seriously injured in the predawn blaze at the couple's home in Kamakura, west of Tokyo, police said. Kubota, 66, is an executive of Japan Aircraft Manufacturing Co. His wife, Fumie, was 53. The fire broke out shortly before 3 a.m., spread quickly and destroyed the home. A police official said investigators found timer devices, batteries and cables in the debris. ``We suspect that the blaze was set by the extremists,'' said the official, speaking on condition of anonymity. He was referring to radicals opposed to the expansion of the airport. They have been linked to attacks on facilities and equipment related to the project. However, officials at Kubota's company said it was not directly involved in the airport expansion. The government plans to build a new terminal and two additional runways by the end of March 1991 at an estimated cost of $3.8 billion. Eight farmers still live on the planned expansion site and refuse to leave. Local farmers and their supporters, including radicals who have used the issue for anti-government activities, have been resisting the government's plan to expropriate farmland for the expansion project.

DOC.HEAD: Sleeping 6-Year-Old Girl Killed in Drive-By Shooting
DOC.TEXT: A 6-year-old girl was shot and killed as she slept in her bed after a barrage of bullets from a passing car pierced her bedroom wall, police said. The girl, whose identity was withheld, was struck in the chest last Wednesday by a large-caliber bullet that went through an exterior wall and then through her bedroom wall, said Sgt. J.D. Evans of the homicide squad. She was dead on arrival at Ben Taub Hospital. Neighbors told police they heard up to nine gunshots, then saw a car speeding away on the dimly lit street. There are at least six bullet holes in the house's front wall. The eight children and four adults in the house fell to the floor when the shooting began and none was hit, police said. Police believe a 9 mm semiautomatic pistol was used. A neighbor reported several shots were fired at the same house Friday when an intoxicated man could not find his car. Police said they did not know if the shootings were related, but they were looking for a boyfriend of a woman who lived at the house for questioning. Police said the two had quarreled earlier in the evening.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Equipment Ordered By Iraq Could Be For Huge Artillery Gun, Customs Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with more from Customs statement, no comment from manufacturer. Pickup 10th, `Everything that...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LON1
DOC.TEXT: Equipment ordered by Iraq and impounded at an English port could be used as a barrel of a large artillery gun, the Customs and Excise Office said today. Arms experts said a gun of the size seized by Customs _ 130-feet-long with a 40-inch bore _ could fire nuclear or chemical warheads as far as Tehran or Tel Aviv, each within 350 miles of Iraq's borders. The manufacturer and the Iraqi government insisted that the equipment was a pipe intended for use in a petrochemical plant. Customs officers seized the equipment Tuesday night, and the agency said it was investigating whether there had been a violation of the British embargo on arms shipments to Iraq. ``We are now satisfied that this equipment is covered by the Munitions List of the Export of Goods Control Order 1989,'' Customs chief Douglas Tweddle said this afternoon. ``There is no question it could be used as a barrel of a large artillery gun to fire a projectile of some considerable size. It is definitely subject to export licensing controls. ``The goods are now seized. Investigations will continue to prove intent and to establish whether offenses have been committed,'' Tweddle said. He said the gun's capability was confirmed by Ministry of Defense experts who inspected the cargo today on the docks at Middlesbrough in northeastern England. Executives at Sheffield Forgemasters, which has been identified as the manufacturer, were in a meeting and not immediately available for comment, according to a woman who answered the telephone at the plant. On March 28, customs officials seized U.S.-made atomic bomb triggers that were bound for Iraq. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein last week threatened to use missiles armed with chemical warheads against Israel if it attacked any Iraqi facilities. Iraq has confirmed it has chemical weapons but denied that it is seeking a nuclear capability. The seizure of the triggers and Iraq's execution on March 15 of a British reporter convicted of spying have soured British-Iraqi relations. Iraq has accused Britain and Israel of orchestrating an anti-Iraqi campaign. ``Everything that is said about these pipes is baseless,'' said Naiel Hassan, press attache at the Iraqi Embassy in London. ``The British and the Israelis are trying to make a fuss about this matter. Even the company itself said that these pipes are used for only petrochemical industries,'' Hassan said. A spokesman for Sheffield Forgemasters, which has been identified in news reports as the manufacturer, said earlier today that the government Department of Trade and Industry approved the order. ``The Department of Trade saw specifications, drawings, everything. We were supplying a pipe for a petrochemical production unit,'' said company spokesmn Tony Peck. Sheffield Forgemasters' chief executive, Phillip Wright, said earlier today that his company had been approached by Iraq to make a gun barrel, but the company took the government's advice and refused. ``What we made were a series of tubes and they are not like any sort of a gun,'' Wright said. ``We do make gun barrels and in fact they are immediately recognizable.'' A spokesman for the Department of Trade said it was department policy not to comment on dealings with individual companies. A Customs spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said officers raided offices in the northern English steel-making city of Sheffield and in the industrial city of Birmingham in central England on Wednesday. He said they ``took away papers relevant to the specifications, ordering and delivery arrangements for this piece of equipment.'' A spokesman for Walter Somers Ltd. in Halesowen, near Birmingham, said Customs officers seized documents there on Wednesday. The spokesman said the company produced some steel piping ``of very much smaller dimensions'' for Iraq in 1988 and had no pending orders from the country. The unidentified Customs spokesman said the goods were consigned to Iraq and were being loaded aboard a ship chartered by the Iraqi Maritime Agency. Britain banned all arms sales to Iraq and its enemy Iran following the outbreak of the eight-year Persian Gulf War. There has been a cease-fire since 1988, but Iran and Iraq are still not officially at peace and the British embargo remains. Two weeks ago, Customs officers seized 40 American-made components for nuclear bomb triggers as they were being put aboard an Iraqi Airways flight to Baghdad. Five people were arrested; three are facing charges, one was deported and one was released. The Iraqis are widely believed to be building a nuclear bomb, and there has been increasing concern about the country's weapons program.

DOC.HEAD: Ratings Down for Morning Shows, But ABC Wins Again
DOC.TEXT: Ratings dropped for all three network morning shows last week, but ABC's ``Good Morning America'' continued in first, winning its 14th consecutive week, A.C. Nielsen Co. audience estimates showed Thursday. ABC's show averaged a 4.5 rating, down 0.3 from the previous week. NBC's once-dominant ``Today'' show, which fell into second place after co-host Jane Pauley left at the end of last year, took the biggest drop. It averaged a 3.3 compared with 3.8 the previous week. ``CBS This Morning'' remained in a distant third, averaging a 2.4 rating, down one-tenth of a point from the week ending April 1. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. A ``Today'' spokeswoman, Mary Neagoy, attributed part of the ``Today'' drop to last week's national switch to daylight-saving time. She said morning show ratings tend to go down initially when the change occurs. Meanwhile, negotiations are still under way for a replacement for ``Sunday Today'' co-anchor Maria Shriver, who left the show last week. Mary Alice Williams is expected to succeed her. No announcement on Shriver's successor is expected until next week, said Jerry Solomon, executive producer. He said Michelle Gillen, a New York-based correspondent, would would co-anchor this Sunday's ``Today.''

DOC.HEAD: New East German Leader Has Long Links With Sister State
With AM-East Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: With his strong ties to West Germany, the first freely elected leader of East Germany, Lothar de Maiziere, is well-equipped to lead the former Communist bastion to unification and democracy. De Maiziere was confirmed as prime minister by the country's first democratically elected Parliament on Thursday after leading the Alliance for Germany to victory in elections March 18. The 50-year-old lawyer's political skills were tested in two weeks of tough negotiations with other mainstream parties that resulted in a broad governing coalition. The agreement gives de Maiziere a two-thirds majority needed in Parliament to pass constitutional changes required for quick unification with West Germany. The new prime minister was little known in the West before he assumed leadership of the Christian Democratic Union, or CDU, on Nov. 10, after the opening of East Germany's borders. De Maiziere, who is married with four children, belongs to a prominent Huguenot family with strong links to West Germany. His uncle, Ulrich, held a top post in the West German army, and his cousin Thomas, is spokeman for the CDU's sister party in West Berlin. De Maiziere was born March 2, 1940, in Nordhausen, now an East German town close to the West German border. Like many Germans, he stayed away from politics immediately after the trauma of the Nazi era and World War II. His first love was music, and his proficiency in playing the viola won him a place in various orchestras in East Berlin in the 1960s. But the musician was drawn to law. He earned a degree from East Berlin's prestigious Humboldt University in 1975. De Maiziere made a name for himself by defending conscientious objectors and independent political activists. For many years, he headed the Lutheran Church Council. But the lawyer and musician was also drawn to politics. De Maiziere joined the Christian Democrats in 1956 when they were allied with the Communist Party, but he never numbered among the top ranks of party officials. When Communist rule crumbled under popular pressure last fall, East Germany needed credible politicians to manage the crisis and help with the merger of the two Germanys. De Maiziere became deputy prime minister in the caretaker government of reform-minded Communist Hans Modrow. The governing Christian Democrats of West Germany at first snubbed the weaker East German CDU and de Maiziere, fearing they were too tainted by long links with the Communists. De Maiziere boldly risked alienating voters by acknowledging early on that the CDU had received funds from the Communist Party. He earned credibility. Once accepted by West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's party, de Maiziere fell in line with the West German CDU's wishes and came out in favor of quick unification. With a clear mandate to seek unification, de Maiziere set about opening coalition talks under the shadow of links with the hated Stasi, as the disbanded Communist secret police was known. There have been allegations many members of the new Parliament, including de Maiziere, collaborated with the Stasi. De Maiziere denied the allegations. He also has faced charges he is too close to the Kohl government and will not protect East German interests during unification talks later this year. However, he dispelled some doubts when he opposed a West German central bank proposal to convert East German marks to West German marks at a 2-1 conversion rate. De Maiziere said he wants a 1-1 conversion.

DOC.HEAD: To Some, Friday the 13th is Good Time
DOC.TEXT: Superstitions generally cast Friday the 13th into a bad luck day for the so-called ``triskaidekaphobics'' who fear it, but the number 13 also has some good signs. In this Liberty Bell city the 13 colonies declared independence, and the 13-letter slogan ``E Pluribus Unum'' is placed on U.S. coins. Also Philadelphia is the headquarters for the Friday the 13th club, founded 54 years ago by 13 men, limits membership to 13 and only meets on Friday the 13th. ``We replace members only when someone dies or leaves town,'' member Arthur Klein said of the club, whose theme is to defy all the superstitutions. This Friday the 13th, the club will gather at 8:13 a.m. in a paint warehouse where chairman Max Buten has assembled some ladders. Not only will members walk under the ladders. They also will open black umbrellas, break mirrors and spill salt. They may even have a few black cats. Scared? ``Not us,'' said Klein, who wouldn't say if he would be carrying a rabbit's foot or would be knocking on wood when walking under the ladders. ``As soon as this meeting's over I'm asking for a substantial premium reduction on my warehouse's catastrophe insurance,'' Buten said. Nordic myth has it that number 13 first became unlucky a few thousand years ago when, at a banquet of a dozen benevolent gods, an uninvited bad god intruded and started a fight that killed the most popular god. Another explanation for calling it a bad day was that Jesus was crucified on a Friday and there were 13 at his Last Supper. Many buildings omit 13 when numbering floors. Some hospitals don't have a room 13. Some people won't start a trip on the 13th. Klein isn't worried about defying the superstitions. ``Hey, we've been meeting every Friday the 13th, and nothing's stopped us yet,'' he said. There's a target date for stopping, though. The last scheduled meeting, according to the club's charter, is Friday, Oct. 13, 2000.

DOC.HEAD: Retail Sales Down Two Months in Row
DOC.TEXT: A late-starting Easter selling season and a continuing auto slump combined to push March retail sales down for the second straight month, the government said Thursday. Sales fell 0.6 percent to a seasonally adjusted $148.6 billion after a 0.3 percent drop in February, the Commerce Department reported. The drop was the steepest in five months and marked the first back-to-back sales slump since October and November 1986. Only food stores posted higher sales. ``Consumers ... seem to be much more wary of spending money than they had been,'' said economist S. Jay Levy of Levy Economic Forecasts in Chappaqua, N.Y. ``With home prices in many areas of the country falling, I think this gives pause to many people.'' Stock prices rose immediately after the report's release. The new indication of continued sluggish economic growth suggested less upward pressure on interest rates than had been feared lately. However, analysts pointed to a number of mitigating factors that softened the news: _February sales, originally reported as falling 0.9 percent and later revised to a minus 0.8 percent, were revised upward again, this time sharply. _Both months followed a very strong January increase of 2.8 percent. _Easter this year falls three weeks later than it did last year. Some clothing and department store sales that would have occurred in March with an earlier Easter were thus shifted to April. ``March was weak but, to me, it was a deceptive weakness,'' said economist Robert G. Dederick of Northern Trust Co. ``It's another one of those more-of-the-same reports. ... The consumer is sort of doing what the economy is doing. He's plodding ahead, but not in a straight line.'' Sales in the first three months of the year were up 5.5 percent from the same period of 1989. However, some of the gain was attributed to unseasonably mild weather and auto discounting in January. ``I think (first quarter) sales borrowed from the spring and that could show up in (depressing) the April number,'' said economist Maury N. Harris of Paine Webber Inc. Retail sales, which account for about a third of all economic activity, are closely watched as a barometer of economic health. In recent months, consumer demand, particularly for high-priced items such as autos, has been weakened by the Federal Reserve Board's policy of using high interest rates to dampen demand and consequently inflationary pressures. Car dealers and auto parts stores reported their fifth sales decline in six months. Sales totaled $30.7 billion in March, down 1.4 percent after a 6.5 percent drop in February. Excluding the volatile auto sector, sales fell 0.4 percent in March after strong gains of 1.5 percent in February and 1.1 percent in January. Sales of durable goods, ``big ticket'' items expected to last three or more years, slumped 0.8 percent in March after a 2.7 percent drop a month earlier. Sales of non-durable goods fell 0.5 percent after rising 1.1 percent in February. In other sectors, March sales fell 1 percent at department and other general merchandise stores; 0.5 percent at clothing stores; 0.1 percent at furniture outlets; 0.8 percent at building supply, hardware and garden stores; 1.7 percent at gasoline stations; 1.5 percent at restaurants and bars, and 0.9 percent at drug stores. They rose 0.2 percent at food stores.

DOC.HEAD: Wool, Mohair Producers Getting Subsidies
DOC.TEXT: Wool and mohair producers are getting about $100 million in subsidies because 1989 market prices fell below the federal support level, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. The $100 million in payments, which are to begin immediately, will be split equally between wool and mohair producers, officials said. Last year's federal support level for shorn wool was $1.77 per pound, but the national average market price was only $1.24 per pound. Mohair supports were set at nearly $4.59 per pound, while the 1989 average market price was $1.58 per pound. The USDA announcement on wool and mohair subsidies followed a report this week by the General Accounting Office urging Congress to consider the need for the wool and mohair program as lawmakers deliberate the 1990 farm bill. Since price supports for wool and mohair were established by the National Wool Act was passed in 1954, federal subsidies to producers have totaled about $2 billion, the GAO said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Reiterates Support for Barco After Bomb Kills 16
DOC.TEXT: President Bush expressed solidarity with Colombian President Virgilio Barco on Thursday and condemned drug lords for a bombing that killed 16 people, including eight members of an elite anti-drug police unit. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush wanted to express sympathy and condolences to Colombians for Wednesday's attack and ``reiterate our determination to assist President Barco and the people of Colombia to win the battle against the drug terrorists.'' The bomb, packing 220 pounds of dynamite, exploded beside a crowded highway in the northern city of Medellin, a headquarters of drug lords, as a truck carrying 21 officers of the elite police unit passed by. ``We condemn this cowardly action in the strongest possible terms,'' Fitzwater said. ``The brutality of the drug lords who have taken credit for the recent wave of killings seems to know no bounds,'' he said. ``Yesterday's killing has to be seen as especially crude and shocking, coming as it does during Holy Week, which is observed as a solemn and joyous occasion throughout Colombia and the rest of Latin America.''

DOC.HEAD: Wisconsin's `Learnfare' Program Meets Resistance; Governor Seeks Expansion
DOC.TEXT: Opponents of a state welfare experiment that cuts benefits for families whose teen-agers play hooky are pressuring the government to withdraw its permission for the program. But Gov. Tommy G. Thompson, who introduced the Learnfare program two years ago, wants to expand the program to include elementary school children. He's also considering plans that would refuse to increase benefits to single mothers who have more children while on welfare rolls and would allow welfare recipients to work more than 100 hours a month and still receive benefits. ``We think Wisconsin deserves it,'' said Thompson, a Republican who is up for re-election this fall. ``Wisconsin is recognized as a leader in welfare reform and we'll continue to move forward.'' While Thompson forges ahead with the experiments, church and social groups are organizing their opposition to Learnfare, saying the state is moving too fast with programs that penalize the poor. Learnfare cuts Aid to Families with Dependent Children benefits to families whose teen-agers skip school without an excuse. AFDC benefits in Wisconsin range from $249 to $983 a month, depending on family size. Learnfare cuts those benefits by $20, to $192 a month, for each month a family's child or children fail to regularly attend school. Food stamps and other public assistance are not affected. About 2,200 of the estimated 30,000 teen-agers whose families receive AFDC have been penalized each month. Most are in the Milwaukee area. Supporters such as Thompson argue that education is the first step to breaking the cycle of welfare dependency and that Learnfare encourages students to stay in school. Opponents point to a recent study conducted by University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee that showed only 28 percent of children whose families were punished under Learnfare returned to school and remained there for at least two months. An earlier analysis by the state had estimated that about 70 percent of the violators returned to school. Carol Croce, executive director of the Wisconsin Nutrition Program, a Madison-based advocacy group, said Learnfare unfairly sanctions parents and ``doesn't get at why the kid is missing school. By taking away that money, you're plunging them further into poverty.'' Ms. Croces' group is among nearly 20 church and community organizations statewide that have jointly asked U.S. Secretary of Health and Human Services Louis Sullivan to abolish Learnfare on the grounds that it causes families undue hardship. Others joining in include the Milwaukee Catholic Archdiocese, the Milwaukee Urban League, the NAACP, the League of Women Voters and the National Association of Social Workers. ``We all came to the realization after the release of the UW-Milwaukee study that all of our worst fears had been justified _ that Learnfare harms families who are in distress,'' said Mike Soika, a spokesman for the Milwaukee Catholic Archdiocese. In Washington, two Wisconsin Democrats, Sen. Herbert H. Kohl and Rep. Jim Moody, cautioned Sullivan not to grant Thompson permission to expand the program until more statistics are compiled. ``It may be premature to grant a waiver'' for a program that hasn't proved its effectiveness, said Marcus Kunian, a spokesman for Moody. Thompson's request to expand Learnfare remains ``under consideration and a final decision has not been made,'' said David Siegel, spokesman for the Family Support Administration of the U.S. Department of Health and Social Services. On a national level, the American Public Welfare Association, a Washington-based professional organization for social workers, considered including a Learnfare model program in proposed 1986 welfare changes but decided against taking a position. ``Some felt it was too punitive,'' said Kathy Patterson, spokeswoman for the association. ``The people we represent are very much divided on the Learnfare model.'' Ms. Patterson said many states ``certainly are looking with interest'' at Learnfare and await more comprehensive studies of it. Whether or not Thompson succeeds in expanding Learnfare, opposition to the program won't stop, Ms. Croce said. ``We'll work to make the administration accountable,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Top Government Employees Arrested for Alleged Espionage
DOC.TEXT: Two senior West German government employees have been arrested on suspicion of spying for East Germany, officials said Thursday. Rolf Hannich, a spokesman for the chief federal prosecutor's office in Karlsruhe, said a Foreign Ministry employee was arrested Tuesday. A high-ranking official of the federal border police was arrested Wednesday, Hannich said. Hannich said both suspects were in investigative custody ``on suspicion of working as agents for an East European country.'' He refused to provide any other information, saying it could jeopardize the investigation. Security and diplomatic sources in Bonn, who requested anonymity, said the Foreign Ministry employee had worked in Paris for the West German UNESCO mission. According to the Hamburg-based Bild newspaper, the Foreign Ministry employee had been working as an agent since the mid-1970s. A tip leading to the arrest came from a former officer of the East German intelligence agency, Bild said. The arrests follows reports in Bonn that East German intelligence agents are still gathering information on high-ranking West German officials. The Bonn-based Die Welt newspaper on Thursday quoted Ottfried Henning, a state secretary in the Ministry for Inner-German relations, as saying officials' telephone calls are still being tapped by East German security agents. On April 5, the federal prosecutor's office announced the arrest of a 45-year-old man working for the West German NATO mission in Brussels. The Hamburg-based Spiegel magazine on Thursday identified the man as Heinz-Helmuth Werner, a former West German soldier. It said he had been paid by East German intelligence since 1969 to work as an agent. In a telex report to other news media in advance of its publication Saturday, Spiegel said Werner had access to highly classified material in the West German Foreign Ministry. It said he had worked there since 1974. The report said Werner was moved to the ministry's NATO mission in 1987, where he continued to work as a cipher clerk. According to the report, Werner delivered more classified information to the East Germans and the Soviet KGB than East German spy Guenther Guillaume. Guillaume was a top aide to then-Chancellor Willy Brandt. Brandt resigned in 1974 after Guillaume was unmasked as an East German spy. Guillaume was sentenced to 13 years in prison in 1975, and six years later traded in a spy swap to East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Discovery Launch Set for April 25
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `NASA planned...' to restore first reference to Buckingham.
DOC.TEXT: NASA said today it will try again to launch the shuttle Discovery with the Hubble Space Telescope on April 25, 15 days after the first attempt. The space agency said the date is based on the decision to remove and replace a malfunctioning power unit on the shuttle and to recharge the telescope's batteries. Discovery's launch was postponed four minutes before liftoff Tuesday when one of the shuttle's three auxiliary power units failed. Technicians on Wednesday removed the unit's 15-pound controller, which controls its speed, for shipment back to the manufacturer for testing. The manufacturer informed NASA the controller was fine, indicating an unknown problem elsewhere in the unit. The unit will be replaced with a new one that will be delivered to Kennedy Space Center this week, National Aeronautics and Space Administration officials said. Shuttle managers expect removal and replacement to take two to three days. The shuttle's three APUs pressurize the hydraulic system, which is used to move wing and rudder surfaces and in the ship's braking and steering systems. NASA planned to open Discovery's sterile payload bay later today, space agency spokesman Bruce Buckingham said. The telescope's nickel-hydrogen batterires will be removed and recharged in a laboratory at Kennedy Space Center. ``This allows the batteries to be serviced under the most favorable conditions while HST remains in the clean environment of the cargo bay,'' NASA said in a statement early this afternoon. Technicians set up traps in a payload preparation room of the launch pad tower to catch any midges, mosquito-like insects, that might have been trapped there when the tower was rolled back into place. Several-dozen midges were spotted in the preparation room two weeks ago, delaying the telescope's installation in the orbiter for two days. No midges were caught, however, and the traps were removed today, said NASA spokesman George Diller. Insects or any other kind of debris easily could damage the Hubble's 94-inch mirror, the finest ever made. The $1.5 billion telescope is NASA's most valuable and complex payload.

DOC.HEAD: School Superintendent Agrees to Remove Tanning Chair From Her Office
DOC.TEXT: The school superintendent has removed her personal tanning chair from her office after protests that it was in poor taste, giving an appearance of luxury while the school and town face severe budget problems. The chair, with an ultraviolet lamp attached, also took up space that had been used by a town agency. Superintendent Concetta Verge said she had the equipment at school because her husband would not allow her to use it at home. She said he considered it harmful to her health. Ultraviolet light has been linked to skin cancer. ``It's gone. It's been removed,'' she said Wednesday. ``This is silly'' she said of the furor raised over the tanning equipment. ``People who have talked to me aren't too happy,'' said Joseph Bilotta, chairman of the selectmen. ``Things are tight and people take offense.'' Marcella Collier, a member of the School Committee, said the tanning equipment did not enhance the superintendent's image in the conservative north-central Massachusetts town. ``I requested to go see it and make sure it was going to be removed,'' she said. ``I'm totally outraged,'' said resident Mary Alatalo. ``It's more than bizarre because the town is squeezing every department for everything they've got.'' Massachusetts has a $2.3 billion budget deficit and has had to sharply cut aid to local governments, forcing schools to make deep cuts. At one point, Lunenberg had to close its town library. Mrs. Verge said she had been keeping the equipment temporarily in the school until it could be moved to a relative's home. The chair was in a hallway alcove adjoining her office and was walled off on three sides by doors that were propped up against it. The space had housed a desk, file cabinet and telephone belonging to the town Conservation Commission. But last fall, Mrs. Verge said the School Department needed the space and the commission had to truck its gear across town to a Parks Department garage.

DOC.HEAD: `Godfather of Soul' Moves to Work-Release Center
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Brown's arrival, CORRECT date he began serving prison term. Picks up 8th graf, `Brown becomes...'.
DOC.TEXT: Soul singer James Brown was moved today to a work-release center after serving 15 months of a six-year prison sentence for aggravated assault, a corrections official said. Brown will work for the Aiken-Barnwell County Community Action Commission, making speeches to young people about not using illegal drugs and alcohol, said Francis X. Archibald, a spokesman for the state Department of Corrections. The 56-year-old Brown left the State Park Correctional Center in Columbia about 12:30 p.m. and arrived at the Lower Savannah Work Center near Aiken a little over an hour later, Archibald said. Brown, nicknamed the Godfather of Soul, will undergo orientation and probably will not start work until Monday, the spokesman said. The singer is only allowed out of the minimum-security facility to go to work. He must return to the facility, which has a small fence and unarmed guards, at night and on weekends. After two to three months in the work-release program, Brown can apply for extended work-release, which would allow him to live at an approved place away from the center, possibly his home in nearby Beech Island, Archibald said. Brown is serving a concurrent six-year sentence in Georgia and South Carolina for failing to stop for police, aggravated assault and weapons violations stemming from a chase in September 1988. He began serving his prison term on Dec. 29, 1988. Brown becomes eligible for parole in South Carolina in May 1991 but will not be eligible for parole under the Georgia sentence until March 1992. Archibald said the Aiken-Barnwell County Community Action Commission must pay Brown at least the minimum wage, but his paychecks will be turned over to the corrections department. Inmates are not allowed to have more than $50 at one time.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Reportedly Pushing for Arms Accord at Summit
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said he is determined to sign the framework for an accord to limit long-range nuclear arms at a May summit in Washington, Senate Majority leader George Mitchell reported Friday. Mitchell spoke to reporters after he and six other U.S. senators met with the Soviet president at his office earlier in the day at the Kremlin. The Senate leader said Gorbachev ``stressed his determination'' to make enough progress on a treaty cutting long-range nuclear weapons to allow it to be initialed at the May 30 superpower summit. After a visit in Washington last week by Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, both sides virtually ruled out signing a formal treaty at the summit. The goal then became to initial the framework for an agreement. Asked by the U.S. senators about the Kremlin's month-old confrontation with Lithuania, Gorbachev ``stated his intention to resolve the matter by peaceful, non-violent means,'' said Mitchell. Gorbachev has previously said he does not want to use force against the Lithuanians, who declared independence March 11. Mitchell, of Maine, said he restated to Gorbachev the U.S. government's position that if the Kremlin resorts to force to bring the Baltic republic back into line, it would bring ``grave consequences'' for Soviet-U.S. relations. Sen. Bill Bradley of New Jersey said Gorbachev also mentioned the ban on foreign press in Lithuania and argued that ``from time to time, such actions have to be taken.'' Asked if he was satisfied with the justification for expelling hundreds of reporters last month, Bradley said, ``I, personally, was not.'' Mitchell said the delegation met with Lithuanian lawmakers while in Leningrad but did not plan to visit the republic itself. Mitchell also said Gorbachev, in the talk with the seven Democrats that lasted more than two hours, discussed Soviet economic reform. Mitchell said the Soviet leader called the current transition period between a planned and a market economy ``the most crucial stage of perestroika.'' Gorbachev is scheduled to meet with his top advisers Saturday to decide on the radical reform he has promised since taking office as president last month. The basic outline of the reform _ with changes in pricing, the banking system, taxation and ownership laws _ has been made public, but few details have been announced. The senators also met with Shevardnadze on Thursday afternoon. The delegation consisted of Mitchell, Bradley, Sens. John Glenn of Ohio, James Sasser of Tennessee, Wyche Fowler of Georgia, Paul Sarbanes of Maryland and Tom Daschle of South Dakota.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Black Caucus Asked to Help in Police Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Black U.S. Capitol police officers, who have complained of racial discrimination in hiring and on the job, asked Thursday for help from the Congressional Black Caucus. ``We are black police officers and expected the Congressional Black Caucus to be the first in line to support our cause,'' said Sgt. Ronald L. Richardson, executive director of the Capitol Police chapter of the National Black Police Association. ``It has become crystal clear that even after following all the rules and going through all the proper channels, no one on Capitol Hill is serious about our plight,'' Richardson told a news conference. Black officers say top commanders, all of whom are white, have discriminated in promotion and training practices and engaged in racial harrassment. There are 1,238 officers, including 336 blacks. Among the top ranks of lieutenant, captain, inspector, deputy chief, assistant chief and chief, however, there are 61 whites and four blacks. The top-ranking black officer is a captain. Responding to the allegations, Capitol police spokesman Dan Nichols said that it ``has been our position that we do not want to mediate these issues through the press.'' ``We have asked and are awaiting them to come forth with substantive issues,'' Nichols said. Most lawmakers were away from Capitol Hill for a holiday recess and plan to return next week. But Congressional Black Caucus spokeswoman Amelia Parker described the group as ``very concerned'' about the allegations. ``The issue was brought before the caucus immediately before the recess period,'' she said. ``Upon their return the members will continue to pursue resolution of this matter and investigation into charges iof harassment.'' On March 22, black officers told a House subcommittee that cronyism and nepotism exists in employment practices of the Capitol force. Witnesses said department rules say police must be given study materials six months before exams but some minority officers do not receive their copies until two months before taking the tests. Black officers complained of being victims of harassment, racial jokes and threats. One said he found a note on his locker saying that the Ku Klux Klan was watching him. A 14-year veteran of the force said she was placed under investigation for misuse of her lunch hour shortly after appearing as a witness at a congressional hearing. She said her superiors did not explain the charge. Police Chief Frank A. Kerrigan told the subcommittee hearing that he was unaware of those examples or of any discrimination. He asked the officers to provide him with specifics.

DOC.HEAD: Highway Patrol Officer Finds Son Killed in Truck Crash
DOC.TEXT: A California Highway Patrol officer responding to a traffic accident discovered that his 16-year-old son had been killed in the crash, authorities said. Timothy Brown was pronounced dead at the scene, said Santa Barbara County Coroner's Detective John Hupp. Brown was killed Tuesday when the truck he was riding in veered off a curve, plowed into some trees and overturned in a creekbed outside Solvang, said Highway Patrol spokesman Kevin Dougherty. His father, Officer T.Y. Brown, responded to the accident call. When he arrived, ``he found out it was his son and was immediately relieved of duty,'' Dougherty said. The 17-year-old driver was listed in fair condition at Cottage Hospital in Santa Barbara. He was arrested for investigation of vehicular manslaughter and driving under the influence, a Highway Patrol spokeswoman said. Solvang is northwest of Santa Barbara.

DOC.HEAD: NOW Targets Oregon, Nevada For Next Abortion Fights
DOC.TEXT: The National Organization for Women is stepping up its fund-raising efforts for campaigns over ballot initiatives in Oregon and Nevada, states NOW officials on Thursday called the newest battlegrounds over abortion. ``We do not intend to lose Oregon,'' said NOW President Molly Yard, promising a strong fight against two proposed ballot questions that would limit abortion in the traditionally liberal state. ``What they are deciding is going to affect every woman in this country,'' she said. ``It is not a state issue. It is a national issue.'' She said the group is holding rallies in Oregon to fight the proposed initiatives and in Nevada to support a pro-choice referendum there. The emotional abortion debate has focused on the states since a Supreme Court ruling in a Missouri case last year gave state legislators greater power to regulate abortion. Since then, both sides have fought over moves by state lawmakers and ballot questions to change local laws. This week, New Hampshire Gov. Judd Gregg, a Republican, vetoed a bill he said would have been the most liberal abortion law in the country. Anti-abortion activists in Oregon are gathering signatures to place two questions on the ballot this fall that would put new limits on abortion in that state. ``They believe if they can win in one of the most progressive states in the nation, they will have an impact across the country,'' said Sheri O'Dell, a NOW vice president. Yard said that abortion rights activists hope to head off possible action by Nevada's legislature, which does not meet this year but is considered strongly anti-abortion. ``The plan is to pass a law through initiative this year so the legislature can't touch the question,'' she said. Yard told a press conference that NOW will use rallies in both states to step up its efforts to raise money and recruit new pro-choice activists. ``We know we are up against a very well-financed right wing in this country,'' she said. ``They pass the collection plate at evangelical churches. They pass the collection plate at Roman Catholic churches. It is a very quick source of money.'' A spokeswoman for the National Right to Life Committee said Thursday officials were not immediately available for comment about NOW's new plans. O'Dell said NOW officials hope to spend $500,000 to stop the anti-abortion ballot measures in Oregon and $300,000 to pass the pro-choice initiative in Nevada. Yard said the abortion debate is also causing more women to run for office. She said 91 women in Pennsylvania have announed plans to run for the state legislature there, partly in response to anti-abortion legislation in the state. Seventee of Pennsylvania's 253 lawmakers are women.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Anti-Drug Personnel Engage in Firefight With Guerrillas
DOC.TEXT: Maoist guerrillas attacked a base built by the U.S. government as a staging ground for anti-drug operations, sparking a battle involving American civilians and Peruvian police, U.S. officials said Thursday. No Americans or Peruvian police were killed or wounded in the hour-long battle Saturday. A U.S. Embassy spokesman said base personnel found no rebel bodies but that police believed several dead rebels may have been carried off after the pre-dawn battle. He said between 40 and 60 guerrillas attacked the base with small arms and grenade launchers. It was the first attack on the new $3 million base in Santa Lucia, 265 northeast of Lima. The base is a staging ground for anti-drug operations in Peru's coca-rich Upper Huallaga valley. The valley is a stronghold of the Maoist Shining Path rebels. Drug smugglers pay the rebels to operate in the area. The guerrillas say they are defending the interests of peasant coca farmers from abuses by drug traffickers and the police. The spokesman, who asked that his name not be used for security reasons, said U.S. anti-drug personnel working in the area have been fired on in the past, although this was the biggest attack to date. Peruvian police sources said U.S. helicopters were called in to repel a December guerrilla attack against a police post in Nuevo Progresso, a town about six miles from the base. Embassy officials denied the report at the time. An American pilot was wounded in the leg when his helicopter was fired on during an operation in February 1989. That prompted the withdrawal of U.S. personnel from the valley until the fortified Santa Lucia base was finished in September. U.S. law prohibits American personnel or equipment from being used against guerrillas except when they are attacked during anti-drug operations. About 30 Americans have worked out of the base since September. They include federal Drug Enforcement Administration agents and civilian helicopter pilots and mechanics working for a private company under contract to the U.S. State Department. Normally about 500 people are stationed there, including Peruvian police rangers and civilian eradication workers. But the embassy spokesman said only about 120 people were there Saturday because many of the civilians had left to vote in Sunday's presidential elections. He said police were tipped off to a possible attack Friday night by people abandoning their homes in the small village of Santa Lucia, just outside the base. Police were dispatched to patrol the area and spotted the rebel column late Friday night. He said the guerrillas opened fired from across the Huallaga River, which borders the base, but were too far away to be effective. The river is about 100 yards across at that point. The base personnel responded with small arms fire, and two helicopters piloted by Americans using night-vision goggles took off and attacked the rebel positions, he said. Peruvian police manned the M-60 machine guns aboard the helicopters. Ten UH-1H Huey helicopters belonging to the U.S. State Department are on loan to the Peruvian police for use in anti-drug operations. The Shining Path launched its armed insurgency against Peru's elected government in 1980 in the southern Andean highlands.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Giant African frogs with teeth, foot-long legs and prodigious jumping ability have arrived to get a toehold in the 62nd annual Jumping Frog Jubilee at the Calaveras County fairgrounds. Animal importer Andy Koffman of Seattle applied Wednesday to enter the behemoths in the May 17-20 competition inspired by Mark Twain's short story, ``The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County.'' ``You want me to predict? OK, they'll break the world record,'' said Koffman. He plans to bring 20 frogs to Angels Camp, ranging from 2 to about 9 pounds. Twelve are too big for the competition and would make exhibition jumps only, he said. Eight others are small enough to place all four feet on the jubilee's official 9-inch-diameter launch pad and to compete with domestic 1-pound frogs. The current record is held by a 1-pound frog, Rosie the Ribiter, which jumped more than 21 feet in 1985. Under contest rules, frogs must have all four feet on the 9-inch pad, and jump without being touched by their owners, who can shout and pound the stage. The distance is measured as the total of three successive hops. On Wednesday, one of Koffman's 4-pound African frog's covered 19 feet in two hops. But he said he once saw one in Africa jump a 20-foot river.

It took nine years for 75-year-old Benjamin Blakeman IV and his wife, Mary Lou, to have one baby _ then another and another. Mrs. Blakeman, 37, delivered triplets, two girls and a boy, Sunday at Swedish Hospital Medical Center. ``These babies are both a blessing and a reward after nine years of trying,'' she said. ``We'd like to encourage people who are trying and to tell them to stick with it.'' The pregnancy was assisted by the Reproductive Genetics Group of Swedish Hospital Medical Center. More than 150 babies have been born with the group since it began offering assisted reproductive techniques, such as in vitro fertilization, in 1984.

Forget about egg rolling contests and colorfully dyed Easter eggs. The real egg-citement this weekend is the expected hatching of a California condor chick. Four chicks have hatched this year, the latest on Tuesday, bringing the total population of the endangered species up to only 36. San Diego Wild Animal Park officials are anticipating another hatching, on Easter Sunday, said park spokesman Tom Hanscom. ``The chick has broken through the air cell to the top end of the egg, and that's the first step in the hatching process. Sometime in the next couple of days, the chick will make a hole in the shell and we will begin a three-day countdown to hatching,'' he said. More hatchings are expected this year at the San Diego park and the Los Angeles Zoo, where all the condors are in captivity in an effort to breed them to greater numbers. ``We are still incubating six eggs between (the Wild Animal Park) and L.A. Zoo, including one that was just laid on April 7,'' said Hanscom. ``Five certainly are fertile and one is unknown at this time.''

DOC.HEAD: Smog Snitches Are Reporting Polluters in Record Numbers, Thanks to Car Phones
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Dona is cq in 8th graf
DOC.TEXT: Motorists fuming over noxious tailpipe emissions on Southern California roads are becoming smog snitches in record numbers, officials said. Calls last month to the smog snitch hotline at the South Coast Air Quality Management District in El Monte jumped 152 percent over March 1989 totals, spokesman Tom Eichhorn said Wednesday. Air quality officials attribute the success partly to a $100,000 billboard advertising campaign, which shows a car belching dense black smoke beneath the words ``Report This Crime: 1-800 CUT SMOG.'' ``It has been a dynamite ad campaign for us,'' Eichhorn said. The regional smog control agency placed 125 billboard ads throughout its jurisdiction in Los Angeles, Orange, San Bernardino and Riverside counties. ``You drive all the time in your car and you're always following all these obnoxious cars and trucks,'' said one tipster, Kathleen Felde of Los Angeles. `` ... It's a great way to get even, I'll just put it that way.'' The program's success reflects how tips from cellular car phones have become a way of life on Southern California freeways. Dona Dower, traffic reporter for KNX-AM radio in Los Angeles, says she typically gets 75 to 100 calls a day about traffic conditions from commuters with cellular car phones. Regular callers often adopt pseudonyms such as ``Mr. Smog Man'' or ``Mr. Ed,'' and report as many as 30 tailpipe polluters a month, said Bruce Collins, manager of the district's smoking vehicle program. Last month, smog hotline operators received a record 17,671 calls, compared with 7,000 received in the previous March. About 150,000 complaints have been received since the hotline was established in June 1988, Collins added. After receiving a license plate number phoned in by a tipster, the district tracks down the vehicle's registered owner and mails a warning that driving an excessively smoking motor vehicle is a violation. ``Local law enforcement agencies and the California Highway Patrol will cite drivers of such vehicles and you may be subject to a fine of $100,'' the letter says. Compliance is voluntary, and Eichhorn estimated that about 20 percent of the people contacted reply that they've fixed the problem. Eichhorn said he's familiar with complaints that the smog snitch program is just another example of the ``Big Brother'' mentality in the agency. ``Our response is that this a voluntary program,'' Eichhorn said. ``There is no ticket. There is no cop knocking on the door. This is just a letter, a friendly letter _ well, a sort of friendly letter _ telling them that their car is a problem and they could get a ticket.'' The California Highway Patrol reports that the number of citations it has handed out also has increased, mostly because of the addition of eight officers who work exclusively on issuing tailpipe citations. Citations issued from January to March 1990 reached 3,170 _ a 25 percent increase over the same three-month period a year ago, said Sgt. Mike Brey, a highway patrol spokesman.

DOC.HEAD: Mongolia's Communist Party Drops Word `Communism' From Charter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Mongolians use only one name.
DOC.TEXT: The world's second-oldest ruling Communist Party dropped the word ``communism'' from its constitution Thursday and set a new goal of building ``democratic humane socialism.'' An extraordinary congress of the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party adopted a new party constitution and platform to reflect its recent acceptance of democratic reforms and opposition parties. A proposal to change the party's name, dropping the word ``revolutionary,'' was defeated. The party, which is trying to change its image to keep power in free elections, appeared to be suffering from an identity crisis. ``Our party remains Marxist-Leninist,'' party ideology chief Tsahilgaan said. But he said that ``Marxism-Leninism or any other theories are not dogmas,'' and that the party no longer used the word ``communism.'' ``We now have realized that communism is a thing far away from us,'' he said. ``We are for building a humane, democratic socialism.'' Asked if the party should be called communist or socialist, he said: ``Let's leave it to you.'' Tsahilgaan said the new party constitution cuts the number of party employees, gives more financial and decision-making power to local party bodies, and guarantees their right to criticize the center. But one party intellectual, speaking on condition of anonymity, noted that the party is keeping its cells in ministries, factories and other work units. ``Nothing can change,'' he said. ``Someone still can say, `You are a party member. Do this.''' The congress' 926 delegates continued meeting late into the night to elect a new Central Committee. It will in turn select a new top leadership body, to be renamed the Presidium instead of the current Politburo. It was unclear if the new Presidium would consist of the same five men who make up the Politburo. They were appointed less than a month ago after an opposition hunger strike forced out the old party leadership. The Communists have ruled this Soviet-allied pastoral nation with an iron grip since 1921, when the Soviets helped Mongolia gain independence from China. Following the Soviet example, party leaders began talking about reform several years ago. Real changes have come only in the past few months, since young intellectuals began demonstrating. They said they were inspired by Soviet glasnost and the fall of Communist parties in Eastern Europe. ``We do not have great hope that (the ruling party) will be able to renew itself,'' said Batsukh, chairman of the New Progressive Party, which wants rapid privatization of the economy. The New Progressives said Thursday they had agreed to cooperate with two other opposition parties, the Mongolian Democratic Party and the Social Democrats, in fielding canddates for legislative elections tentatively planned for July. Some observers were skeptical that the parties, which want reform at different paces, would be able to cooperate. Already, divisions have appeared within individual parties. For example, half the leadership of the Mongolian Democratic Party dismissed the other half earlier this week in a power struggle.

DOC.HEAD: Employees of Union Allege Discrimination Against Blacks
DOC.TEXT: Three clerical workers at the nation's second-largest public employee union charged in a federal suit Thursday that the union had discriminated against blacks in its hiring and promotion decisions. The suit, filed in U.S. District Court, alleged that the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees had violated federal civil rights laws by engaging in ``deliberate and systematic'' employment practices that discriminate against blacks. ``AFSCME's employment practices are sound and within the law,'' said Bob Harman, a spokesman for the 1.25-million member union. He declined further comment until lawyers had reviewed the case. About 17 percent of the union's rank-and-file members are black, the union said. The suit comes at a time when the American labor movement, facing declining membership in recent years, is trying to court blacks and women to rebuild strength. The suit charged that AFSCME, ``through the acts and omissions of its overwhelmingly white supervisory work force,'' discriminated against blacks in decisions involving hiring, assignments, promotion, compensation and discipline. Furthermore, the suit alleged, white supervisors harassed and disciplined blacks who complained about discriminatory practices. The suit said that in 1988 blacks made up about 32 percent of the work force at the union's Washington headquarters, but that there were no black department heads. Last year, only one of 14 department heads was black, it said. Blacks are confined to lower-level jobs in the organization, the suit also contends.
