While blacks had only 15 percent of the jobs paying more than $50,000 a year in 1989, they held 47 percent of the positions in the union's four lowest pay grades, the suit said. The three black workers who filed the suit are Mary Craft and Mary Maynard, office assistants at the union's Washington headquarters, and Jean Brown, a secretary in the union's Baltimore field office. The three women, all Maryland residents, represent former, current and future black job applicants and employees dating back to February 1984. The suit seeks back pay, promotions and reclassifications for those blacks and compensatory and punitive damages in amounts to be determined at trial. The National Education Association is the only public employee union with more members than AFSCME.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Former W.Va. Governor Indicted, Pleads Guilty
LaserPhoto CN2
DOC.TEXT: Arch A. Moore Jr., three time governor of West Virginia, pleaded guilty to extortion, mail fraud, tax fraud and obstruction of justice charges, a federal prosecutor said today. Moore faces up to 36 years in prison and fines of up to $1.2 million, U.S. Attorney Michael Carey told reporters. It was the second time Moore was indicted for alleged improprieties in office. The indictment accused Moore of committing illegal acts relating to his 1984 campaign, his third term as governor from 1985 to 1989, and his unsuccessful 1988 campaign. Moore, a Republican in an overwhelmingly Democratic state, also is accused of blocking a federal grand jury's investigation of him last year and this year, Carey said. The indictment further alleged Moore used his public position to extort approximately $573,000 in 1985, Carey said. It also accused him of filing false income tax returns in 1984 and 1985, the official said. And it charged that he schemed to defraud the state of his salary and benefits by funneling approximately $100,000 in cash into his 1984 campaign fund, Carey said. Moore and his 1972 campaign manager were indicted in December 1975 on a charge of extorting $25,000 from the president of a shaky financial holding company trying to get a state charter for a new bank. He was acquitted in 1976. Moore, who will be 67 on Monday, was the first West Virginia governor elected to two four-year terms and the first elected to three, serving from 1969 to 1977 and from 1985 to 1989. He lost his bid for a fourth four-year term as governor in 1988 to Gaston Caperton. The silver-haired Republican patriarch extended his reign over three decades despite a 2-to-1 registration edge for the Democrats and almost constant controversy. He served one term in the state House of Delegates from 1953 to 1954 and was elected to Congress in 1956. At 33, Moore was the youngest freshman in the 85th Congress and represented the state's Northern Panhandle for six terms. In 1968, Moore gave up his House seat to run for governor. He was injured two days before the election when his helicopter crashed at a political rally in Hamlin. He made a brief statement to the crowd before being rushed to the hospital and many political observers credit that event for helping him win. In August 1979, his former state liquor commissioner, J. Richard Barber, was convicted of racketeering, extortion and mail fraud. The conviction involved charges that Barber received cash and free liquor from distillers while serving as Moore's commissioner of alcohol beverage control. The trial included testimony that some of the cash was used for campaign contributions, and some of the liquor was passed on to the governor's office. Barber was sentenced to three years in prison. Moore was the second West Virginia governor to encounter legal trouble. Former Democratic Gov. W.W. ``Wally'' Barron, who served from 1961 to 1965, and several of his associates were tried on bribery conspiracy charges in 1968. Barron was acquitted but later went to prison for bribing the foreman of the U.S. District Court jury that acquitted him.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
NEW YORK: Eastern Europe.
DOC.TEXT: Pulitzer winners receive $3,000 in each category except public service, for which the prize is a gold medal. The awards were first given in 1917. Prizes are awarded by the trustees of Columbia on the recommendation of an advisory board. Juries draw up a list of entries for the board's consideration, but the board is not confined to their recommendations.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Suffering From `Early Glaucoma' ^EDs: Combines pvs, inserting grafs 5-6 on glaucoma.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is suffering from ``an early glaucoma'' in his left eye, medical tests disclosed today. The glaucoma, which the White House said has not affected his vision, was discovered during a routine physical at Bethesday Naval Hospital, the White House said. It will be treated with eye drops. In general, Bush ``is in excellent health,'' said White House physician Dr. Burton Lee in a statement released by the press office. ``He continues to keep extremely fit through vigorous physical activities.'' The glaucoma will be treated with Betagen eye drops, which Bush will take for the rest of life. The dosage is one drop every 12 hours, press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said in the statement. Although Bush is not suffering impairment of his vision, glaucoma can lead to blindness if not treated. The disease is characterized by increased pressure and hardening of the eyeball. Bush has had a stye in his right eye for the past week, which is nearly gone after treatments with soaks and antibiotics, Fitzwater said. He said X-rays of Bush's hips and neck showed mild degenerative osteoarthritis, a condition disclosed in past physical examinations. During four hours of tests and examination, he also underwent chest X-rays, which were normal; an electrocardiogram and stress tests, which were normal; urinalysis showing no abnormality; blood tests which were normal; and a dermatology exam, showing ``no significant problem or change,'' Fitzwater said. The only problem cited during last year's physical was a cyst on the third finger of Bush's right hand. The cyst was surgically removed last October and later was pronounced benign. ``His allergy problems remain minimal and unchanged,'' the spokesman said. The 65-year-old president's last physical was May 10, 1989, and he was pronounced in good health. Bush emerged from the examination telling reporters he felt ``like a spring colt.'' He told reporters ``all is well'' on his return to the White House. Bush left the medical center in suburban Maryland for his helicopter flight back wearing sunglasses and flashing a double thumbs-up sign. Bush left the White House after 7 a.m. for the short helicopter ride to the suburban hospital. He was accompanied by Lee, who oversaw the examination.

DOC.HEAD: British Seize Tube They Say Was Intended As Iraqi Weapon
LaserPhotos LON1,3
DOC.TEXT: Customs officers seized a huge forged steel tube ordered by Iraq after military experts determined Thursday that it could be used to build a gun capable of hurling nuclear or chemical warheads hundreds of miles. Iraq denied the accusation, and the British manufacturer said the tube would blow up if anyone tried to use it as a gun barrel. Arms experts say a gun with a barrel the size of the tube seized by Customs _ 131 feet long with a 39-inch bore _ could fire artillery shells as far as Tehran or Tel Aviv, each within 350 miles of Iraq's borders. Such a weapon would be the longest gun ever made. ``There is no question it could be used as a barrel of a large artillery gun to fire a projectile of some considerable size. It is definitely subject to export licensing controls,'' said Douglas Tweddle, head of the Customs and Excise Office. On March 28, customs officials seized U.S.-made parts for atomic bomb triggers that were bound for Iraq. Iraq has confirmed it has chemical weapons but denied seeking a nuclear capability. Last week, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein threatened to use missiles armed with chemical warheads against Israel if Israel attacked his country. The seizure of the triggers and Iraq's execution March 15 of a British-based reporter convicted of spying have soured British-Iraqi relations. ``Even if we bought a box of chocolates from Britain, they would say Iraq will use it to produce an atom bomb,'' Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz told reporters in Mosul, Iraq. ``Everything that is said about these pipes is baseless,'' said Naiel Hassan, press attache at the Iraqi Embassy in London. ``The British and the Israelis are trying to make a fuss about this matter. Even the company itself said that these pipes are used for only petrochemical industries.'' The Iraqi government and the reported manufacturer, Sheffield Forgemasters, had insisted the equipment impounded was a pipe designed for a petrochemical plant. The company said the government's Department of Trade and Industry had reviewed and approved the project. Phillip Wright, chief executive of Sheffield Forgemasters, said the company had been approached by Iraqis about building gun barrels, but the company refused after consulting the British government. Customs officials are convinced that the impounded tube is covered by government rules banning the export of certain munitions, Tweddle said. Britain banned all arms sales to Iraq and its enemy Iran following the outbreak of the eight-year Persian Gulf War. There has been a cease-fire since 1988, but Iran and Iraq are still not officially at peace and the British embargo remains. ``The goods are now seized. Investigations will continue to prove intent and to establish whether offenses have been committed,'' Tweddle said. The equipment, impounded at the northeastern English port of Middlesbrough Tuesday night, was packed in eight crates and was being loaded aboard a ship chartered by the Iraqi Maritime Organization, Customs officials said. Wright said the tube seized by Customs could not be used as a gun. ``If they did manage to get all the other necessary components I wouldn't stand within a mile of the thing if they tried to fire it. It would blow itself to pieces,'' the Sheffield Star newspaper quoted Wright as saying. Wright said Iraqi officials had approached his company about making gun barrels, but it declined. ``What we made were a series of tubes and they are not like any sort of a gun,'' he said. ``We do make gun barrels and in fact they are immediately recognizable.'' Sheffield Forgemasters confirmed that Customs officers seized company documents Wednesday. A spokesman for Walter Somers Ltd. in Halesowen, near Birmingham, said Customs officers also seized documents there. The spokesman, who spoke anonymously, said the company produced some steel piping ``of very much smaller dimensions'' for Iraq in 1988 and had no pending orders from the country. Two weeks ago, Customs officers seized 40 American-made components for nuclear bomb triggers as they were being put aboard an Iraqi Airways flight to Baghdad from London. Five people were arrested; three are facing charges, one was deported and one was released. Iraq is widely believed to be building a nuclear bomb, and there has been increasing concern about its weapons program. In Washington, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said the United States was asking the British government for information about the impounding action and would have no comment for the time being. British news reports speculated that an Iraqi gun project could be linked to Gerald Bull, an American ballistics expert who was killed in Brussels on March 22. Bull, 62, a Canadian-born American citizen, was found shot to death with $20,000 in his pockets, Belgian police said. Jane's Defense Weekly said Bull had been a principal designer of South Africa's G5 howitzers, which have been sold to Iraq. In 1980, he was convicted in Vermont, where he had taught at Norwich University, on charges of smuggling arms to South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Nearly 30 Years Later, Glenn Can't Escape the Space Race
DOC.TEXT: Lose one space race and some Soviets just won't let you forget it. At least it may have seemed that way to Sen. John Glenn on Thursday as a visit to the Kremlin happened to coincide with the Soviet Union's ``Cosmonaut Day.'' On April 12, 1961, Yuri Gagarin became the first person to orbit the Earth. Ten months later _ after another successful orbiting by the Soviets _ Glenn became the first American to orbit the Earth. The Ohio Democrat was in a seven-senator delegation that met with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in the Kremlin on Thursday. They also met with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and other officials. In a telephone conversation with reporters in Washington, Glenn said references to the space race and Cosmonaut Day dogged him throughout the day. ``It was brought up every place today,'' Glenn said in Moscow. ``I assured everyone today that I remember the day very, very well because I was in training as an astronaut at that time and we had hoped to be the very first into space with out program. ``It came as a shock to us when the Soviet Union went ahead of us,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Largest Gypsy Congress Calls for Unity, Fighting Discrimination
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to CORRECT name to Ian Hancock sted of Ian Hamilton. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: At what they billed as their largest congress ever, Gypsies from 27 countries demanded respect for their culture and an end to the stereotypes that have long seen them scorned as thieving fortunetellers. The weeklong meeting of some 300 delegates ended Wednesday with the appeals from the worldwide wanderers that they be treated as any other disadvantaged minority. Delegates to the fourth Congress of the World of Romany Union discussed issues including standardizing their Roma language, discrimination, memorializing Gypsy victims of the NaziHolocaust and the potential dangers for Gypsies posed by rising nationalism in Eastern Europe. Sessions were held at a steel mill's country recreation center 24 miles north of Warsaw. After somber speeches during the day, the delegates gathered for singing and dancing in unbridled celebration of their heritage. The conference was conducted in the Gypsy Roma language, but with 20 major dialects worldwide delegates sometimes had difficulty making themselves understood to all participants. Gypsies, or the Romany as they prefer to be known, are descended from nomadic tribes that left northwestern India sometime during the first millenium and made their first recorded appearance in Western Europe early in the 1400s. Their worldwide population is variously estimated at 5 million to more than 10 million. The Romany have been associated in popular lore with fortunetelling, stealing and music-making, and conference participants said the stereotypes had been forced upon them by ``gaje,'' or non-Gypsies. ``Nobody takes us seriously,'' said Ian Hancock, a British-born Gypsy who teaches linguistics at the University of Texas at Austin. ``We are one people who arrived in Europe 800 years ago who have become fragmented by the hostility we encountered from Europeans. But now we must work toward becoming one people again,'' he said. The meeting elected poet Rajko Djuric of Yugoslavia as president of the World Romany Union. The union ``calls on all governments to treat Gypsies as human beings,'' Djuric said. ``We call for giving them the right to life and their own culture and language.'' The first world meeting was held in 1971 in London, but this was the first that delegates from the Soviet Union and Albania were able to attend. ``Thanks to perestroika and democratization, we are here,'' said Lev Cerenkov of Moscow, who came with 15 other Soviet citizens. In the Soviet Union and most Warsaw Pact countries, Gypsies were forced by Communist governments to give up their nomadic lifestyles after World War II. Their horses were shot or taken away and the wheels removed from their painted wagons. Some still live in dilapidated barracks given to them at that time, said Stanislaw Stankiewicz of Poland. Europe's Gypsy population was devastated during the Holocaust, when 500,000 to 1 million were put to death in gas chambers. The genocide was only the culmination of the persecution for the Gypsies, Hancock said. Many countries banned Gypsies and some permitted them to be used as slaves or hunted. ``The romantic interpretation of the wandering gypsy is not romantic at all,'' Hancock said. ``It is really life on the run.'' Today, Gypsies suffer from lower education levels, income and life expectancy than their non-gypsy neighbors, and often have trouble obtaining basic services or recognition, Hancock said. If Gypsies steal, it is often ``subsistence theft'' to feed their families when discrimination prevents them from obtaining honest work, he said. ``We are third-class citizens,'' said Rudko Kawczinski, a former member of the European Parliament from Hamburg, West Germany. ``The political changes in Eastern Europe, which the West sees as very positively, is starting to look bad for Gypsies. There is a backlash of prejudice against minorities,'' Hancock said. There were many signs at the meeting of Gypsy pride, however. Many delegates sported Gypsy flag lapel pins, which are blue and green with a spoked wheel in the center. The ``wheel of fire'' is from Indian mythology and represents the Gypsies' origins in India, Hancock said. Some delegates said the Romany must become more involved in politics at home. ``What is important is getting people to notice us on this globe and understanding out culture and traditions,'' said Stankiewicz, of Bialystok, who recently founded Poland's first Roma-language newspaper.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Approves President's Economic Plan
DOC.TEXT: Brazil's Congress gave a major victory to President Fernando Collor de Mello by passing intact the heart of his draconian anti-inflation plan. Economists said a severe recession is a certainty. In a surprising vote late Wednesday, legislators passed by 249-204 a measure that froze for 18 months all bank deposits of more than $1,200 and money market deposits of more than $600. ``I am extremely satisfied with the result of the congressional session,'' Collor told reporters as he headed for a pizzeria in Brasilia to celebrate. Collor decreed the measure as part of a series of reforms launched Mar. 16, the day after he took office. He said it was central to his strategy of beating 4,854 percent annual inflation. Economic Minister Zelia Cardoso de Mello was exultant after the vote and said the legislators' action would ensure the success of the ``New Brazil Plan.'' But economists agreed that Collor's plan will produce a brutal recession, at least in the short term. ``A recession is inevitable _ its duration will depend on the government's future conduct of economic policy. But I would not be surprised to see a 20 percent drop in industrial production over the next three months,'' said Edmar Bacha, an economist. Bacha, who supports the plan, said an economic downturn was necessary to end chronic inflation. Signs of an impending recession are everywhere. The automobile, capital goods, construction and machine tools industries are virtually paralyzed. Unions say almost 1 million workers have either been fired, taken pay cuts, or been put on collective holiday. ``The government will have to create special credit lines for badly hit sectors to prevent the recession from getting out of of control,'' said Mario Henrique Simonsen, a conservative economist who served as finance minister between 1974 and 1979, when Brazil was run by a right-wing military regime. Simonsen said the depth of the recession would depend on the public's confidence in the plan. ``The bank confiscation has shaken the short-term confidence of investors and savers in the financial system. How they react in the longer term will be crucial,'' he said. Leftist economists were especially critical. ``We are going to have a deep and long depression. You can't solve economic problems with this sort of drastic solution,'' said Paul Singer, a leading economist with the socialist Workers Party. He said the Workers Party favored collective bargaining of wages and prices between labor unions and business to bring down inflation, without producing a recession. ``I am afraid of very serious social convulsions. This downturn will be far worse than the 1983 recession,'' he said. During that recession, the economy fell by 3 percent, resulting in widescale looting of supermarkets and an increase in urban violence. ``The logic of the plan is to paralyze the economy for several months and then make the recession tolerable. But the shock was so strong I'm not sure how long it will be before we reach the tolerable stage,'' said Rep. Cesar Maia, an economist and spokesman for the center-left Democratic Labor Party. Maia criticized the government for not increasing unemployment benefits and taking other measures to cushion the blow for those who are directly hit by the recession. But he said if the government managed the plan well, the economy could begin to grow again in about a year. Simonsen said the long-term success of the plan depends on what happens when the government begins returning the money in frozen bank accounts.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Austin Wilson Wins Second Pulitzer in Four Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 2nd with Hijuelos reax.
DOC.TEXT: Playwright August Wilson on Thursday captured his second Pulitzer Prize for drama in four years when he was honored with the 1990 award for ``The Piano Lesson.'' Oscar Hijuelos' book, ``The Mambo Kings Play Songs of Love,'' won the 1990 Pulitzer for fiction. Hijuelos' novel detailed the lives of three brothers from Havana who become minor celebrities as musicians in New York nightclubs. ``I had no idea it was even being announced this week,'' Hijuelos, a Manhattan resident, said in a telephone interview from a friend's house in Ulster County. ``I wasn't sitting around chewing on my nails. I came up here to really cool out. Now, I may have to turn around and drive back into the city. But worse things can happen.'' It was only the second novel written by Hijuelos. Pultizer Administrator Robert Christopher said he believed Hijuelos was the first Hispanic winner of the Pulitzer for fiction. Stanley Karnow's book, ``In Our Image: America's Empire in the Philippines,'' won for history. Karnow is a long-time foreign correspondent for several news organizations. He also wrote ``Vietnam: A History,'' which later won six Emmy Awards in its television incarnation. The Pulitzer for general non-fiction went to ``And Their Children After Them'' by Dale Maharidge and Michael Williamson. Maharidge is a reporter and Williamson a photographer for The Sacramento (Calif.) Bee. Their book was a 50-year follow-up on the descendants of three tenant families in Alabama who were made famous by James Agee and Walker Evans in the book, ``Let Us Now Praise Famous Men.'' ``Machiavelli In Hell'' by Sebastian de Grazia won the biography Pulitzer. The Chicago native has been a Rutgers University professor of political philosophy since 1962. Charles Simic's ``The World Doesn't End'' won for poetry. The Stratford, N.H., resident had been nominated for a Pulitzer once before for his ``Selected Poems: 1953-83.'' The Pulitzer for music went to ``Duplicates: A Concerto for Two Pianos and Orchestra'' by jazz and classical pianist Mel Powell. Powell, 67, started playing with the Benny Goodman Orchestra as a teen-ager, later joining the Glenn Miller Air Force band. He currently heads the composition faculty at the California Institute of the Arts. Wilson's ``The Piano Lesson,'' which takes place in Pittsburgh in 1936, concerns a sharecropper who wants to buy the land his grandfather worked on as a slave and is willing to sell the family heirloom, a piano, to pay for it. The play, which was one of the finalists last year, opens Monday on Broadway. Wilson won in 1987 for ``Fences.'' The prizes, recognizing outstanding work in journalism and the arts, are awarded by Columbia University. Pulitzer winners receive $3,000 in each category.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Washes Priests' Feet
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II washed the feet of 12 elderly priests on Thursday as he commemorated Christ's Last Supper at a Mass celebrated for thousands of people. Earlier, he said Holy Thursday Mass in St. Peter's Basilica, leading some 2,000 clergymen in renewing their priestly vows. The ceremonies marked the beginning of the most solemn and holy period of the year for Roman Catholics, climaxing with Easter on Sunday. At the evening Mass at the basilica of St. John Lateran, the white-robed pope knelt before each priest, washed their feet, then kissed them in a reenactment of part of Christ's Holy Thursday supper with his 12 apostles. The ritual symbolizes Jesus' humility before he was crucified on Good Friday. The 12 priests were from the diocese of Rome, three of them former missionaries. In his homily, John Paul described how the sacrament of the Eucharist, or turning of bread into Christ's body, represented Jesus' death and resurrection. Catholics believe the sacrament as well as the Mass and the priesthood were established at the Last Supper. The pontiff urged all Catholics to follow Christ's example of offering himself for others. ``What could we want more on this ... Holy Thursday, than solely and above all that which the Teacher himself showed in the washing of the feet?'' he asked. He prayed for ``a true sharing of goods and for mutual understanding among different social classes.'' About 5,000 people attended the Mass at St. John Lateran, which is considered the pope's special church as bishop of Rome. On Friday, the pope planned to carry a wooden cross in a Good Friday procession near the Colosseum. He will celebrate the Easter vigil on Saturday night followed on Easter Sunday by a Mass in St. Peter's Square.

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Police Uncover Mass Grave With 25 Bodies
DOC.TEXT: The bodies of 25 people, some of whom had been missing for months, were found buried in a common grave in northern Colombia, a police general said Thursday. Gen. Octavio Vargas, the chief of police operations, said the bodies were found Wednesday near the town of Valencia on the property of Fidel Castano. Authorities have accused Castano of leading a right-wing death squad that has killed several leftists and union leaders. Some of the bodies were victims of a mass kidnapping Jan. 13 in the town of Pueblo Bello, Vargas said in a radio interview. An unidentified group abducted 39 people in the town in the northern Uraba region, where death squads and leftist guerrillas are active.

DOC.HEAD: Atwater Released from Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Republican Party chairman Lee Atwater, described as ``in fighting trim,'' was released Thursday from a New York hospital where he was treated for a brain tumor. ``He's in excellent spirits,'' said Dr. Paul Kornblith, the neurologist who treated Atwater at Montefiore Medical Center. ``He's quite enthusiastic; he's gaining strength physically.'' Kornblith led a team that implanted radioactive isotopes in the tumor on the right side of Atwater's brain. Physicians hope the isotopes will halt the growth of the tumor and kill the cancerous cells. The 39-year-old Atwater also is undergoing chemotherapy treatments designed to destroy any tumor cells on the periphery of the lesion. Kornblith said it would be two or three months before it could be determined how effective the treatments were. If successful, he said a neurological scan would show ``the area has diminished in size or is not growing.'' While no further radiation was planned, Atwater will continue taking oral doses of chemotherapy every six weeks. Aides have said Atwater would spend the next couple of weeks at his Washington home regaining his strength. ``Knowing him, I think he's going to be working to some degree probably by next week,'' Kornblith said. ``He's in fighting trim and ready to fight the wars of his profession. ``He's already working, he's meeting with people, talking to people. How active he'll be, he'll have to judge for himself.'' Mary Matalin, chief of staff at the Republican National Committee, said she talked to Atwater on the telephone as many as six times a day while he was hospitalized. Atwater also talked by telephone nearly every day with President Bush and White House staff chief John Sununu. Former President Richard M. Nixon sent Atwater a copy of his new book, ``In the Arena.`` It was inscribed: ``To Lee Atwater. I can't think of anyone I'd rather be in the arena with.'' Atwater's wife, Sally, was expecting to give birth to their third child within days. Atwater also was celebrating the release of a rhythm and blues album, ``Red, Hot and Blue,'' on which he plays guitar and sings with blues artists B.B. King, Isaac Hayes and Billy Preston. The album was selling out in stores in the nation's capital, Matalin said. Kornblith said tumor-related problems Atwater was having on his left side, had ``gotten a hell of a lot better. He thinks he'll be able to play the guitar soon.'' As for the coming weeks, Matalin said it would be ``a different kind of waiting. The radiation waiting was, for his instincts, that was not a good procedure. It just didn't match his personality. It was too slow a process for him.'' The tumor was diagnosed March 6 after Atwater collapsed while speaking at a political breakfast. It first was described as a non-malignant growth that could be treated easily with daily radiation doses. Atwater was given medication to prevent additional seizures and to ward off nausea from the radiation treatments. He briefly re-entered a Washington hospital two weeks later after suffering dizziness attributed to problems adjusting the dosage of his medication. He flew to New York on April 2 to enter a new and more aggressive treatment program under Kornblith. After examining Atwater, Kornblith said that while the tumor was ``quite small'' it was ``aggressive and dangerous.'' The growth, called an astrocytoma, is the most common type of brain tumor. Tumors undergoing unrestrained growth cause pressure within the closed skull that could kill normal brain cells, bringing eventual death by destroying vital functions.

DOC.HEAD: Brazilian Cardinal Says Poor Needn't Observe Meat Ban
DOC.TEXT: Poor Brazilians do not have to observe a traditional ban on eating meat on Good Friday, said Roman Catholic Cardinal Paulo Evaristo Arns. What's important, Arns said, ``is for the poor to eat.'' About 85 percent of Brazil's 150 million people are Catholics. At Easter time, the increased demand for fish sends prices up. The most Rev. Angelo Sandalo, an assistant to Arns, said, ``It's meaningless for the poor to be told they cannot eat meat on Good Friday when they hardly eat any meat at all. In fact, they hardly ever know where their next meal will come from.''

DOC.HEAD: Rival Christian Gunners Fight in East Beirut, Nearby Province
DOC.TEXT: Shells crashed into east Beirut and the Kesrouan province north of the capital Thursday as rival Christian gunners fought daylong shelling duels. Samir Geagea's militia released five Moslem suspects it had held for more than two years on charges of ``disrupting order'' in the Christian enclave. The militia command, in a statement, said the move was a ``goodwill gesture'' on the eve of the 15th anniversary of the civil war, which broke out April 13, 1975. The five were released from Geagea's war council headquarters in east Beirut and turned over to the International Committee of the Rctors of Kesrouan with machine-gun fire from their mountaintop positions. Aoun's men control the Metn mountains that border the eastern flank of Kesrouan Province. The southeastern sector of east Beirut and the city's eastern suburbs also are dominated by Aoun's army. Geagea's militia controls the provinces of Kesrouan and Byblos north of Beirut as well as the capital's waterfront. The thud of exploding shells echoed across Beirut as local radio stations interrupted regular programming to flash reports of the confrontation. Geagea's command, in a statement broadcast by Voice of Lebanon radio, blamed the escalation on Aoun. It accused him of ``blocking Geagea's peace offensive that aims at turning over our areas to the legitimate authorities.'' Aoun's Radio Lebanon accused Geagea of ``selling out the liberated areas to Syria's surrogates.'' Geagea repeatedly has urged the Syrian-backed government of President Elias Hrawi to take over army garrisons and government installations in the Christian enclave. Aoun has rejected Hrawi's election Nov. 24. Hrawi was elected in line with an Arab League-brokered peace plan to end Lebanon's civil war. Aoun refused to accept the plan because it did not include a timetable for the withdrawal of Syrian troops from Lebanon. Geagea has said the plan was a way to peace and recognized Hrawi as the head of state.

DOC.HEAD: Higher Pay for Government Nurses Proposed
DOC.TEXT: The Veterans Affairs Department wants to reverse its shortage of registered nurses by pegging pay to local rates in private hospitals. While the plan would apply only to registered nurses, it would move the government in the direction of paying its employees at levels comparable to those of private industry, a goal of unions that represent federal workers. ``It could be the precedent that gets us going through the work force,'' said Janice Lachance, spokeswoman for the 700,000-member American Federation of Government Employees. Draft legislation, given to the Senate this week, also would add pay incentives for nurse managers and supervisors. The Veterans Affairs Department is the nation's largest employer of registered nurses, with 35,000 of them at work in its hospitals, clinics and nursing homes. Starting base pay for a registered nurse employed by the department is $18,174. The American Nurses Association, the average starting salary nationwide for a registered nurse is $25,261. The American Federation of Government Employees had opposed co-called locality pay in the past. But it now favors the concept as long as such a system includes safeguards advocated by the union. Ms. Lachance said she did not know whether the department's bill included those safeguards. The administration last month proposed a pay scale for federal employees that accounts for local pay. But the federal employee unions object to a feature of the proposal that eliminates ``step'' increases in certain job categories and instead links pay to performance. Under the proposal made by Veterans Affairs Secretary Edward J. Derwinski, the department would use pay data from private hospitals to establish ``community rates.'' But the national scale for nurses employed by the department would serve as a floor under their pay and the community rates would go into effect only if they exceeded that level. Also, limits on certain categories overtime for some nurses would be lifted and pay rates would be flexible for certain nurse-specialists. Premium pay increases would be given to head nurses and incentive pay would be allowed for nurse managers and executives. The department already has made some adjustments to move closer to local rates, but the process has proven so slow that the government has not caught up with levels in the private health care industry. The department was paying special rates at 130 of its 172 medical centers at year ago, Derwinski said. ``Even with the special rates, VA has not been able to offer competitive salaries at certain geographic locations'' such as Boston, Southern California and New York City, Derwinski said in a letter to lawmakers. Committees in both the House and Senate have been working on pay legislation for nurses and a similar measure for physicians and dentists also is on the drawing board.

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh's Ex-Legal Adviser Targeted in Drug Probe
DOC.TEXT: A former top legal adviser to U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh is the target of a federal investigation of alleged cocaine use by public officials and professionals, sources said Thursday. Henry G. Barr of Mechanicsburg, who was general counsel when Thornburgh was governor and later was an assistant to Thornburgh when he became attorney general, is being investigated by the same grand jury that has been hearing evidence about alleged cocaine use and distribution by Richard Guida, a former top deputy in the state attorney general's office, the sources said. The sources, including several lawyers close to the case who were interviewed independently, said Barr's attorneys were in Washington earlier this week asking the Justice Department to block an indictment that would name Barr. In Washington, Justice Department spokesman Dan Eramian said Thornburgh and members of his personal staff withdrew from the federal investigation when they learned of its existence earlier this year. Eramian added that Thornburgh had no knowledge of the drug issue when he was governor. The sources also said Guida has agreed to plead guilty to one count of using cocaine and to cooperate with the federal investigation. Under the agreement, they said, Guida could face a short jail term and suspension of his law license. The sources spoke on condition of anonymity because grand jury proceedings are supposed to be secret. According to court documents, Guida has been a target of the federal investigation since May. The grand jury's attention turned to Barr more recently, the sources said. Barr did not return telephone messages left on the answering machine at his Mechanicsburg home Thursday. Guida did not return messages left at his Harrisburg law office. In previous interviews, he denied using cocaine and being a target of the probe. Assistant U.S. Attorney Gordon Zubrod declined to comment because of a policy that prohibits federal prosecutors from confirming or denying details of investigations. By being allowed to plead guilty only to a possession charge, Guida would sidestep allegations that he also sold cocaine and provided it to friends. At least one witness, Brenda Snell of suburban Harrisburg, said in an interview with The Associated Press that she told the FBI she had purchased cocaine from Guida and sold it to him on several occassions. Guida called those allegations ``bold-faced lies.'' This is the second time cocaine allegations against Guida have been investigated. In 1986, when he was a chief deputy under state Attorney General LeRoy S. Zimmerman, an internal probe found no evidence to support a radio reporter's allegations that Guida was a user. State Attorney General Ernie Preate Jr. said Thursday he would not investigate allegations that the initial probe was a whitewash because the federal grand jury also was looking at that aspect of the case. Barr, 46, worked in the state attorney general's office before joining Thornburgh's gubernatorial administration. He became Thornburgh's general counsel about 18 months before the governor left office in 1987. In Washington, he served as a special assistant to the attorney general from September 1988 to May 12, 1989. Last year, he resumed a private law practice in Harrisburg, but quit earlier this year after allegations surfaced that connected him to the case, the sources said. Barr and Guida each served as deputy attorney general in charge of the state attorney general's criminal division. Barr also served as an assistant U.S. attorney in Pittsburgh from 1969 to 1979. Through much of that period, Thornburgh was the U.S. attorney in western Pennsylvania. The grand jury investigation has lasted nearly a year.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Adopts Sweeping Apology For Acts of Past
With AM-East Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Parliament's apology Thursday to Jews and other peoples who suffered under the Nazi occupation marks a dramatic break from four decades of denying a dark past. In a concisely worded declaration, the Parliament unanimously declared null and void the Communist version of East German history, which trumpeted the virtues of socialism and refused responsibility for any tragedies inflicted in the past by Germans on other nations. ``We, the first freely elected parliamentarians of the German Democratic Republic (East Germany), acknowledge the responsibility of Germans in the German Democratic Republic for its history and its future,'' the declaration said. The declaration was adopted by the Parliament was chosen last month in East Germany's first free elections after more than 40 years of Communist rule. East Germany, like other former Communist countries in Eastern Europe, has tried to break away from the official Communist histories that often emphasized ideology over historical accuracy. The Parliament's declaration turned first to the horrors of the Nazi period and acknowledged that ``immeasurable suffering was inflicted on the peoples of the world by Germans.'' ``National and racial illusions led to genocide, especially of Jews from all European countries,'' it said. The declaration could help the process of reconciling East Germany's historical view of the Holocaust with that prevailing in West Germany. West Germany was compelled after World War II to confront its Nazi past. Years ago it apologized for Nazi atrocities and began paying reparations to Jewish victims. East Germany long maintained its Communist leaders were also victims of Nazi repression, and therefore the country bore no responsibility for the deaths of 6 million Jews during World War II. In its declaration, the Parliament dramatically distanced itself from the policies of the Communist government toppled from power in October. ``The first freely elected Parliament in the name of the citizens of this country admits joint responsibility for the humiliation, expulsion and murder of Jewish women, men and children,'' the declaration said. ``We feel grief and shame and acknowledge this burden of German history.'' It asked forgiveness for the bad treatment of Jews who remained in the country after the war and for East Germany's policy toward the state of Israel. The declaration pledged to do everything possible to cultivate Jewish culture, and said asylum should be granted in East Germany for Jews persecuted elsewhere in the world. It also said East Germany is prepared to make reparations to Jewish victims and urged establishment of diplomatic relations with Israel. The declaration then turned to the Soviet Union and Poland, where millions of people died at the hands of the Nazis. ``We have not forgotten the terrible pain that the Germans in the Second World War inflicted on people in the Soviet Union. ... We want to intensively continue the process of reonciliation between our two peoples,'' the declaration said. Parliament said that the political changes in East Germany would not have been possible without Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms. It also sought to reassure Poland, which has expressed concern about German unification. The Parliament reiterated the Communist government's earlier commitments abandoning any territorial claims on former German lands ceded to Poland after World War II. The declaration said Poland's western border along the Oder and Neisse rivers was inviolable and should be guaranteed by a treaty passed by the future Parliament of a united Germany. The declaration then apologized to another neighbor, Czechoslovakia, for East Germany's participation in the 1968 Soviet-led Warsaw Pact invasion that crushed the Prague Spring reform movement. ``Out of fear and a lack of courage we did not hinder this breach of international law,'' the declaration said. ``The first freely elected Parliament in the German Democratic Republic asks the people of Czechoslovakia to pardon this occurrence of injustice.''

DOC.HEAD: AM-People,0817
People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Call it sex, lies and Suzukis. A Japanese advertising firm said in a lawsuit filed Wednesday that it had to yank a Suzuki ad campaign featuring Rob Lowe because of all the bad publicity associated with Lowe's infamous sex tape. Now Hakuhodo Inc. wants to collect damages. ``We found ourselves with an image different from that which we felt we had purchased,'' said Hakuhodo's lawyer, John O'Connor. The company did not specify damages, but claims it lost more than $1.6 million in revenues because of its lack of advertising for Suzuki's Cultus, a car model not sold in the United States. Hakuhodo also said it had paid $450,000 to Lowe starting in August 1988 and another $130,000 to talent agents. ``Rob's attorneys ... haven't been given a copy of the complaint, so there's nothing to comment on at this time,'' Lowe's publicist, Lisa Kasteler, said Thursday. The ad campaign was stopped in May 1989 with release of the tape, apparently featuring the 26-year-old actor engaging in sex with two young women. The tape was made while Rowe was in Atlanta for the 1988 Democratic convention. Lowe was ordered to perform 20 hours of community service after he was charged with sexual exploitation of a minor.

A man hired to protect Motley Crue band members during a concert is seeking $25,000 from the heavy-metal band, claiming its leader hit him in the head with a cowbell during the show. Mark Elrod of Fort Wayne filed the complaint Tuesday in Allen Superior Court against Motley Crue and Vince Neil, the band leader. Elrod's job as a security guard for the March 21 concert required him to stand between the audience and the band, with his back to the stage. During the concert, the lawsuit says, Neil ``hurled'' a cowbell toward the audience and it struck Elrod in the back of the head. Elrod claims Motley Crue was negligent and is seeking $25,000 in damages for medical expenses, missed workdays and personal injuries, including continual headaches and dizziness. He is also is seeking unspecified punitive damages for the band's alleged ``willful and wanton misconduct.'' Efforts to reach a spokesman for the band through the Elektra-Asylum record company in New York were unsuccessful Thursday. A woman at Elektra records said no one there knew about the lawsuit. She said she would try to locate a band spokesman.

Mayor Tom Bradley welcomed this year's Miss Universe Pageant with a proclamation, raising the ire of some feminists who say the event is sexist. The mayor's decision to support the event was based on economic benefit for the city, said his spokesman, Bill Chandler. The international pageant will be held Sunday night in Century City. ``In our minds there's no contradiction at all as the mayor being a supporter of women's issues and proclaiming this year's Miss Universe pageant,'' Chandler said. Bradley and City Council signed a proclamation Wednesday declaring it Miss Universe Day. Tammy Bruce, president of the Los Angeles chapter of the National Organization for Women, lambasted Bradley for welcoming the pageant. ``It is extremely distressing that society condones this and that the mayor of the country's second largest city can't see anything wrong with it,'' she said. Sara Meza, publicist fo the Madison Square Garden Television Productions, said the intent of such pageants are not to demoralize women, but to entertain the public. ``We don't want to tell you it's not a beauty pageant, it is, '' she said. ``The evening gown, swimsuit and interview, they're all weighed equally. It is what it is.''

Pennsylvania's honorary Highway Safety Month chairman is a man who routinely drives faster than 200 mph and has been in more than 100 car crashes. But when champion race car driver Richard Petty leaves the racetrack, he says he obeys speed limits and drives smart. The seven-time Daytona 500 winner came to the Capitol on Thursday to endorse Pennsylvania's new highway safety campaign. ``There's nobody in the world who has wrecked more cars then me,'' Petty said. He added that he has ``always been interested in the safety deal'' and noted that he has six grandchildren to think about when speeding around the racetrack. ``We want everybody to be aware that safety is everybody's job,'' said Petty, whose 200 NASCAR victories is a record. ``I drive safely at 200 miles per hour and I'm asking people to drive safely at 55 or below.'' But Petty did endorse a 65 mph speed limit for rural interstate highways in Pennsylvania, a position opposed by Gov. Robert P. Casey.

DOC.HEAD: Pulitzers Honor Work on Blood Industry, Water Contamination
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CORRECT year to 1950 sted 1935; pick up 5th graf, `Four reporters ...
DOC.TEXT: The San Jose Mercury News and The Tribune of Oakland won Pulitzer Prizes on Thursday for their coverage of last October's northern California earthquake. The Mercury News, which used emergency generators to put out its post-quake edition, won the prize for general news reporting. The Tribune's photo staff won for spot news photography. When the quake struck Oct. 17, California newspapers from Monterey to San Francisco were forced to improvise. The Mercury News not only published its own comprehensive coverage but printed papers for a competitor. The Tribune's photographs provided a gripping portrait of the devastation and appeared in newspapers around the world. Tribune Publisher Robert Maynard described the scene in the newsroom after the announcement as ``an earthquake of happiness,'' and told a caller: ``You're competing with the biggest party the Tribune has had since 1950.'' That was the year the newspaper won its last Pulitzer Prize, for a photograph of a near-miss air disaster. Four reporters from The Seattle Times won a prize for coverage of another disaster. Ross Anderson, Bill Dietrich, Mary Ann Gwinn and Eric Nalder were given the national reporting award for their coverage of the Exxon Valdez oil spill. The prizes, recognizing outstanding work in journalism and the arts, are presented annually by Columbia University. The Philadelphia Inquirer and the Washington (N.C.) Daily News won the Pulitzer's gold medals for public service journalism, the Inquirer for reporting on how the blood industry operates with little regulation, and the Daily News for revealing that the city water supply was contaminated with carcinogens. This is the first time in 23 years the Pulitzer board awarded two gold medals. It was the Inquirer's 17th Pulitzer Prize, all won in the past 15 years, and the sixth straight year the newspaper has won an award. It also was the second award for the author of the Inquirer series, Gilbert Gaul. Gaul, 38, won an investigative reporting award in 1979 for his work with The Pottsville (Pa.) Republican. ``I feel great. It is a terrific honor,'' Gaul said Thursday. ``The paper showed an incredible amount of courage to allow me to spend a year and a half on the story and to report on a subject that is of great importance to everyone that we don't often think about _ blood.'' It was the first award for the Washington Daily News, circulation 10,000, whose office erupted in pandemonium when the Pulitzers were announced. ``I will say we haven't had this much excitement in this town since the Union cavalry and the Confederate cavalry chased each other up Main Street in 1862, and there's been nothing like that since,'' said Bill Coughlin, the newspaper's executive editor. Lou Kilzer and Chris Ison of the Minneapolis-St. Paul Star Tribune won the Pulitzer for investigative reporting for stories that exposed local citizens' links to members of the St. Paul Fire Department, and the citizens' alleged profiteering from fires. The explanatory journalism prize went to David A. Vise and Steve Coll of The Washington Post for stories scrutinizing the Securities and Exchange Commission and its former chairman, John Shad. Tamar Stieber of the Albuquerque (N.M.) Journal won the Pulitzer for specialized reporting for stories that linked a rare blood disorder to an over-the-counter dietary supplement, L-tryptophan. The reporting led to a national recall of the product. Nicholas D. Kristof and Sheryl WuDunn of The New York Times won the international reporting prize for their coverage of political turmoil in China. The Times now has won 61 Pulitzer Prizes, more than any other newspaper. Dave Curtin of the Colorado Springs (Colo.) Gazette Telegraph won the feature writing prize for his account of a family's struggle after its members were burned in an explosion that devastated its home. Jim Murray of the Los Angeles Times won the commentary prize for his sports columns, and Allan Temko of the San Francisco Chronicle received the criticism prize for his writing on architecture. The prize for editorial writing went to Thomas J. Hylton of The Mercury of Pottstown, Pa., for editorials about a bond issue to preserve farmland and open space in rural Pennsylvania. Tom Toles of The Buffalo (N.Y.) News won the editorial cartooning prize. In feature photography, the winner was David C. Turnley of the Detroit Free Press for photographs of the uprisings in China and Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Estonia Bans Soviet Draft, Calls for Independence Talks
DOC.TEXT: The Estonian parliament has declared service in the Soviet army illegal and called on President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to begin immediate talks on the Baltic republic's independence, Soviet media reported Thursday. Estonia's new law on conscription says ``service by residents of Estonia in the U.S.S.R. armed forces is legally illegitimate,'' and does away with criminal penalties for draft-dodgers. The parliamentary move, accompanied by a strident letter to Gorbachev also approved Wednesday, stepped up the push for independence in the small republic of 1.6 million residents. Estonia has made clear it intends to follow neighboring Lithuania in seceding from the Soviet Union, but more cautiously. There was no immediate response Thursday from the Kremlin to the Estonian legislature. The law on the draft raised the prospect of new tensions. When Lithuania's legislature passed a similar measure last month, the Kremlin rejected its legality and ordered the army to detain deserters anyway. Military authorities raided two Lithuanian hospitals where deserters had taken refuge, and witnesses said they beat some of the men in the first reported violence after Lithuania's March 11 declaration of independence. The Lithuanian lawmakers have since issued statements saying each young conscript should decide for himself whether to respond to his call-up order, and it is not clear how the army plans to enforce the draft. In other Soviet republics with strong independence movements, including Latvia and Georgia, widespread draft-dodging is also predicted. The state news agency Tass, in its report on the Estonian law, complained it ``prods hundreds of youths to violate the Soviet law on universal military service and the Soviet Constitution.'' Mart Tarmot, an Estonian Popular Front activist, said Thursday the law's passage had evoked no particularly loud public reaction. ``Everybody was expecting it. It was necessary to start sometime and we've done the first step,'' he said in a telephone interview from Estonia's capital Tallinn. The Estonian legislature's letter to Gorbachev laid out Estonia's legal claims to independence and concluded with an appeal ``to immediately begin negotiations between the U.S.S.R. and an authorized Estonian delegation on the restoration of independence.'' Estonia, like its Baltic neighbors Latvia and Lithuania, was forcibly annexed to the Soviet Union in 1940. The letter tacitly rejected Gorbachev's demands in an angry telephone call last week to Estonian President Arnold Ruutel that the republic back down from its drive for independence. Ruutel said Gorbachev called him up soon after the Estonian parliament passed its March 30 resolution saying the republic was an independent country illegally occupied by the Soviet Union. ``When I heard about your resolution I was completely beside myself. You must declare the resolution null and void,'' Ruutel quoted Gorbachev as telling him. The letter told Gorbachev that if he restored Estonia's independence, he would eliminate a key source of political tension in Eastern Europe and raise the Soviet Union's prestige. It also assured him that the full rights of all citizens would be respected in an independent Estonia. About 40 percent of the republic's population consists of non-ethnic Estonians. Since elections last month, the Estonian parliament has been dominated by pro-secession groups and is expected to pursue independence as stubbornly as the Lithuanians, though more slowly.

DOC.HEAD: Godfather of Soul Has a Brand New Bag: Drug Education
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: With two inmates carrying his suitcases, ``Godfather of Soul'' James Brown started a brand-new bag Thursday. He was transferred from prison to a work-release center to counsel youths about drug abuse. The two-time Grammy award winner was released after serving 15 months of a six-year prison sentence for aggravated assault. He will be locked up nights and weekends at the minimum security Lower Savannah Work Center 60 miles from Aiken, where he will help educate young people about the dangers of illegal drugs and alcohol. When asked how it felt to be back home in Aiken County, the 56-year-old singer raised his hands and said, ``This is home?'' Brown was wearing a bright blue shirt, vest and black leather pants as two inmates helped him carry his three suitcases after his arrival from the State Park Correctional Center in Columbia. His job starts Monday. He will earn at least the minimum wage of $3.80 an hour, officials said. Brown billed himself as the Hardest Working Man in Show Business during his four decades as a rhythm and blues singer. He grunted, groaned and gyrated to pop stardom with 114 charted singles such as ``Papa's Got a Brand New Bag,'' ``Please, Please, Please'' ``I Got You (I Feel Good),'' ``Cold Sweat,'' ``I'm Black And I'm Proud,'' ``Hot Pants'' and more recently, ``Living in America.'' The wavy-haired Brown was imprisoned in December 1988 to serve a concurrent six-year sentence in Georgia and South Carolina for failing to stop for police, aggravated assault and weapons violations stemming from a two-state, high-speed chase that ended when police shot out the tires on his pickup truck. The incident began when a gun-toting Brown stormed an insurance agency next to his office and claimed strangers had used his bathroom. Tests showed Brown had used the illegal drug, PCP. He had earlier been arrested several times for illegal drug use. He becomes eligible for parole in South Carolina on May 5, 1991, and in Georgia in March 1992. At the Aiken-Barnwell County Community Action Commission, Brown will try to talk young people out of using drugs and alcohol, said George Anderson, executive director. ``That name is going to bring the people out,'' Anderson said. ``His name alone can command a crowd. You or I couldn't draw the attention he will.'' Reaction to his work-release was less than enthusiastic at Top Notch Entertainment, Brown's production and booking agency. ``He won't be able to leave and go to work here and put his people back to work such as the band and hairstylists who are out of work,'' said W.M. Glenn, the company's executive vice president. The singer had been offered an array of radio station jobs across the country. He had been the object of a ``Free James Brown'' movement that included the Rev. Jesse Jackson. A year ago, NASA awakened the shuttle crew Discovery with Brown's ``I Feel Good.'' Brown also had a volatile relationship with his wife, Adrienne, 39. He was arrested in 1988 for allegedly shooting his wife's car and attacking her with a lead pipe, but the charges were dropped. In July 1988, he was convicted for possession of PCP, resisting arrest and carrying a pistol. But he violated that probation when he tested positive for marijuana and PCP. At that time, Brown was out on bond for his September arrest for leading police on a chase in South Carolina and Georgia. Brown will live in a dormitory with 74 other inmates at the minimum-security work-release center in a rural, wooded area about 20 miles from Augusta, Ga. Eighty female inmates live in another building on the campus, which is surrounded by a small fence and patrolled by unarmed guards. While at the State Park Correctional Center, where he was No. 155413, Brown had conducted the prison gospel choir and worked in the prison cafeteria. He also had to forfeit $600 and lost 20 days of time-off for good behavior for keeping $40,600 in his cell. The Internal Revenue Service in August confiscated $40,000 in checks, claiming he owes about $11 million in back taxes.

DOC.HEAD: AM-US-Czech Trade,530
TRade Agreement Signed
DOC.TEXT: Officials of the United States and Czechoslovakia signed a trade agreement Thursday, the second economic pact negotiated with an Eastern European nation since last year's political upheaval. The new accord is one of the steps needed to cut tariffs on Czech products sold in the United States. The document also seeks to foster increased business ties and tourism between the two nations. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills participated in the signing ceremony along with Andrej Barcak, the foreign trade minister of Czechoslovakia. Hills said that the congressional legislation needed to put the lower tariffs into place could be completed by early summer. The United States is also negotiating a trade agreement with the Soviet Union and Hills said she was optimistic that the pact could be finished in time for the May 30 summit between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. Both the Czech and Soviet trade agreements are necessary steps that must be taken for the United States to grant the countries ``most favored nation'' trade status. That designation would lower American tariffs to the level charged against most other trading partners. Tariffs on products from the Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia now run as much as 10 times higher than those on goods from other countries. The higher tariffs were imposed as part of the Jackson-Vanik trade amendment of 1974, which Congress passed in retaliation for communist restrictions imposed on the free emigration of dissidents. Before tariffs can be lowered, the trade agreements must be in place and President Bush must certify that both countries permit free emigration. Both houses of Congress must approve the trade agreements. The president's certification is not expected to be a problem for either country. Bush has said he will make such a certification for the Soviet Union once the Soviet Parliament putting into law the current free emigration policies. Last month, the United States and Poland signed a business and investment treaty. That pact did not address the tariff question because Poland had already been awarded the lower tariffs under the most favored nation designation. In addition to the treaties with Poland and Czechoslovakia, Hills said exploratory discussions have been held with Hungary on adopting a new business and economic agreement. Czech-U.S. trade is now fairly small, adding up to about $150 million a year in both directions. Major U.S. exports are hides, yarns, cotton and tobacco; major U.S. imports are tractors, glass beads, shoes and tires. In his remarks to the U.S. business executives, Barcak made a plea for American investment, saying Czechoslovakia was moving rapidly toward a market economy. He said his nation expected to take a major step next Jan. 1 toward making its currency fully convertible. That would mean that investors could freely take their earnings home in dollars _ an important consideration to firms unwilling to tie up their cash abroad. Barcak also promised tax breaks for foreign investors and permission for them to own all the stock in new firms they establish, without the need to take in lcoal partners. But he said there was an on-going debate over whether foreigners should be allowed to own land. He said some people in the audience would be able to buy up all the land in Czechoslovakia with a single check. ``Some of us don't want to live in a country where foreigners have bought up the land at its present value, and then we have to buy it back ourselves in five years time,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Cost of Major Programs Up 3.8 Percent from September Estimate
DOC.TEXT: The estimated cost of the Pentagon's major weapons programs increased by $31 billion or 3.8 percent in the last quarter of 1989 because of inflation and a slight increase in planned missiles and ships. The Pentagon, in its congressionally required report released Thursday, offered a snapshot as of Dec. 31 of expected overall costs for 95 major weapons systems if President Bush's military budget is enacted. However, the overall estimate, now $843.8 billion, may change, given that Congress or Defense Secretary Dick Cheney may limit production on or terminate some weapons systems, including the C-17 cargo plane and the DDG-51 guided-missile destroyer. The previous report, released in September, predicted the overall cost of the major systems would be $806.6 billion. Upward revisions in expected inflation rates are largely responsible for the higher costs, the Pentagon said. The difference in the two figures is $37.2 billion, but comparisons on an apples-with-apples basis give a difference of $31 billion because the new estimate includes $6.2 billion for a Navy program that was not in the September figure. That program is the so-called ``Fixed Distributed System,'' a classified ocean surveillance project. One of the major increases was for the Midgetman strategic nuclear missile, now put at $7.3 billion, an increase of $1.9 billion or 35 percent over the previous estimate. The Pentagon said the jump was primarily the result of restoring costs expected all along but excluded last year because of the way Bush and Congress handled Midgetman in the current defense budget. The fiscal 1990 budget contains less than $250 million for the mobile, single-warhead, land-based missile. With those funds, the Midgetman program amounted to a research and development project. ``This is a reinstatement of the costs,'' said Roy Lietza, a spokesman for the Air Force. Among the increased costs for the Midgetman are $1.3 billion for the missile and its basing with a goal of initial operation in 1997; $458 million for six additional research and development missiles and $87 million for inflation. The estimated cost of the multiple-warhead MX nuclear missile dropped $3.9 billion from $23 billion, primarily because of a reduction in the number of planned missiles from 255 to 193. The drop was partially offset by inflation increase estimated at $236 million. The estimates consist of the annual costs of research and development, purchase of the weapon itself and associated construction, added together for the several years each weapon will be bought, sometimes extending into the next century. Cost of operations, such as fuel and crew wages, are not included. One program which Cheney is currently reviewing _ the Arleigh Burke-class destroyer or DDG-51 _ increased $4 billion from a previous estimate of $2.8 billion. The Navy cited an increase in the number of ships from 33 to 38 and revised inflation rates as the reasons for the 15 percent jump. The other Navy program the defense secretary may curtail _ the SSN-21 Seawolf attack submarine _ dropped in estimated cost from $20 billion to $16 billion because of a decrease in the number of submarines from 12 to nine. The estimated cost of the C-17 cargo plane, also under review, increased $4.4 billion from a previous price of $37.4 billion. The Air Force blamed the rise on inflation and schedule changes due to plans to stretch out the program. Slower production rates frequently raise total costs by reducing production efficiency. One of the largest increases in Army programs was in the medium tactical vehicles in which the estimated cost jumped from $8.6 billion to $16.1 billion, or 88 percent. The Army attributed the rise to an increase in the number of trucks from 79,157 to 102,322, an extension of the modernization program from 15 to 30 years, schedule changes and inflation. The estimated cost of the M-1 tank, which Cheney has proposed canceling in the budget for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, dropped $6 billion due to a decrease in the number of tanks.

DOC.HEAD: Gallery Settles Fraud Charges in Case of Art That's Not Famous
DOC.TEXT: An Illinois-based chain of art galleries and two company officials have agreed to pay $635,000 to customers who bought prints believing they were the work of Dali, Chagall, Picasso and Miro, the government said Thursday. The prints were worth $50 each, but Austin Gallaries, headquartered in Palatine, Ill., collected a total of about $2 million at galleries in Chicago and California, said Heather Hippsley, a Federal Trade Commission attorney. Customers were told the prints would be good investments, the FTC said. Austin and its president and sole shareholder, Donald Austin, will pay $625,000. Another Austin official, JoAnne Granquist, will pay $10,000, the government said. The FTC will notify Austin customers of the settlement; Ms. Hippsley said she did not know how many people that included. As part of the deal, which will become final when approved by a federal judge in Chicago, Austin also will surrender 400 prints the government claims are fakes. Donald Austin was not available for comment Thursday. Ms. Hippsley said he had promoted the prints as originals by Salvador Dali, Marc Chagall, Pablo Picasso and Joan Miro and sold them at prices ranging from $600 to several thousand dollars, . ``Austin will be allowed to sell other Dali or Chagall graphic art as long as they do not represent that the prints are ... by the artists,'' the FTC said. Austin has galleries in Chicago and three California cities _ San Francisco, Carmel and Laguna Beach.

DOC.HEAD: Undercover Agents in Personnel Fight
DOC.TEXT: Federal investigators have filed a complaint charging that Immigration and Naturalization Service officials unlawfully retaliated against undercover agents in Houston for writing to their congressmen. The complaint filed Wednesday with the federal Merit systems Protection Board said the retaliation came after the anti-smuggling agents told lawmakers their undercover identifies were compromised by a change of assignment. The 18-count complaint was filed by the U.S. Office of Special Counsel. It sought disciplinary action against three officials of the Houston district office of the Immigration and Naturalization Service. Named in the complaint were District Director Ronald Parra, Deputy District Director Michael McMahon and Carey Murphy, assistant district director for investigations. It alleged that they engaged in ``prohibited personnel practices.'' The agents complained about a switch from anti-smuggling duty to employer-relations work created by a 1986 immigration law. Not only were their undercover identities jeopardized, they said, but they were told to falsify time cards and record time spent on employer relations as anti-smuggling hours. After writing to lawmakers, the six agents and two supervisors received low performance appraisals or were pressured to take unwanted transfers, according to a separate investigation by the General Accounting Office. INS spokesman Duke Austin said the Merit Systems Protection Board is the ``appropriate forum'' for the complaints and would not comment further.

DOC.HEAD: President Will be Treated for ``Early Glaucoma''
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS in first 3 grafs to note eye drops are prescription and raise 9th graf pvs, Otherwise, the; INSERTS 4 grafs after 14th graf pvs, Unless the, with more medical comment and figures on extent of glaucoma; picks up 15th grav pvs, ``The vision
DOC.TEXT: President Bush was diagnosed Thursday with ``an early glaucoma'' in his left eye, but he said it had not affected his vision. The glaucoma was found during the president's routine physical at Bethesda Naval Hospital, and will be treated with prescription eye drops, press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said in a statement. Otherwise, the 65-year-old Bush ``is in excellent health,'' said White House physician Dr. Burton Lee in a statement released by the press office. ``He continues to keep extremely fit through vigorous physical activities.'' ``I haven't felt a thing, felt it at all,'' Bush told reporters. ``I'm taking drops now ... one in the morning and one at night, but the vision is very good.'' Fitzwater's statement said that during the examination, ``An early glaucoma of his left eye was detected,'' but that extensive tests showed no visual impairment. With early detection and continual treatment, the president should not develop vision problems, said Dr. Mansour Armaly, chairman of ophthalmology at George Washington University Medical Center, who did not examine Bush but is a specialist in glaucoma. Although Bush is not suffering impairment of his vision, glaucoma can lead to blindness if not treated. The disease is characterized by increased pressure and hardening of the eyeball. It has no cure, but can be controlled with drugs. Laser surgery may be performed on patients who don't respond to drugs, Armaly and other doctors said. ``It is quite a high probability he will have none,'' Armaly said when asked about the prospects for vision problems. ``It is a disease that requires regular follow up to make sure the medication is effective.'' For the glaucoma, ``he will receive Betagan eyedrops, one drop every 12 hours, and will continue this medication permanently,'' Fitzwater said. Bush has had a stye in his right eye for the past week, which is nearly gone after treatments with soaks and antibiotics, Fitzwater said. Betagan, the brandname for the drug levobunolol, is a betablocker _ similar to those that treat arterial high blood pressure _ that lowers the ocular pressure, said Armaly. There are different types of glaucoma, but all cause pressure within the eye as result of obstruction to the micro passages that allow ordinary fluid to leave the eye at the normal rate into the blood vessels, he said. Unless the glaucoma is transitory, resulting from something such as a previous blow to the eye, it is considered a lifetime condition, he said. Dr. M. Bruce Shields of the Duke University Eye Center in Durham, N.C., said once glaucoma is found in one eye it often appears in the other, but treatment can also save the sight in the second eye. The White House reference to ``early glaucoma'' apparently means the nerve was not damaged enough to affect Bush's vision, said Shields, who is chairman of the glaucoma committee of the National Committee to Prevent Blindness. Glaucoma is not unusual in a person in his 60s, Shields said. The NSPB estimates more than 2 million Americans ages 35 and over have glaucoma, but that nearly half are not aware of it. The society says the disease accounts for one out of every eight cases of blindness in the United States. ``The vision is very good, the vision thing's working well,'' Bush told reporters Thursday, joking about his habit of attaching the word ``thing'' to topics. Critics during his 1988 presidential said he lacked ``the vision thing.'' During the four hours of tests and examinations, doctors also found that Bush's hips and neck showed ``mild degenerative osteoarthritis,'' a condition revealed in past physicals. The White House said he also underwent chest X-rays, which were normal; an electrocardiogram and stress tests, which were normal; urinalysis showing no abnormality; blood tests which were normal; a dermatology exam, showing ``no significant problem or change.'' ``His allergy problems remain minimal and unchanged,'' Fitzwater said. Bush emerged from the examination, wearing sunglasses because his eyes had been dilated, and called to reporters that he felt ``like a spring colt.'' He told reporters ``all is well'' on his return to the White House. The president's last physical was May 10, 1989, and he was pronounced in good health. The only problem cited during last year's physical was a cyst on the third finger of Bush's right hand. The cyst was surgically removed last October and later was found to be benign.

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Leaders Stress Holocaust Education for Future
With AM-East Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: American Jewish leaders welcomed the East German Parliament's ``long overdue'' apology Thursday for the Holocaust, and said the new government must include education in its effort to make amends. ``Apology must be accompanied with deeds,'' said Benjamin Meed, president of the 65,000-member American Gathering-Federation of Jewish Holocaust Survivors. ``They must educate future generations to know what their fathers did and how they will prevent it from happening again.'' ``It is 45 years overdue, but apology is always good,'' added Meed, a 70-year-old survivor of the Warsaw Ghetto. By making the apology, East Germany's first freely elected legislature ended four decades of denials by its former Communist leaders that the country played any role in the deaths of 6 million Jews during World War II. ``Nobody can bring back the dead, but it's a long overdue statement,'' said Rabbi A. James Rudin, director of interreligious affairs of the 50,000-member American Jewish Committee. East Germany's legislature also promised to make reparations to Israel and to seek diplomatic ties with that country. Israel has long demanded reparations and an East German apology for Nazi crimes as a condition for diplomatic relations. ``Before you can have normalization, there had to be admission of guilt, remorse, said Rabbi Arthur Schneier, a Holocaust survivor and president of the interreligious Appeal of Conscience Foundation. ``This is a first step in a normalization process and it has to be advanced by education and re-education,'' said Schneier. ``All these years East Germans were conditioned to the fact that `We had nothing to do with it.' It is a great challenge to educate the public and particularly the younger generation as to the tragedy of the Holocaust so that another tragedy of this kind would be averted.'' Rudin urged East Germany not only to pay reparations for the Holocaust but to join with the United States and other countries to seek repeal of the 1975 United Nations resolution equating Zionism with racism, ``which was an act of anti-Semitism.'' ``Since they've apologized for terrible errors of the past, this is something else they can do to show good will and that they've really changed,'' Rudin said. ``Unhappily, East Germans have followed the practice until now of seeking to deny what had been their history,'' said Philip Baum, associate executive director of the American Jewish Congress. ``While the people alive now are not those who perpetrated the crimes, they have the burden of the history of their country to confront and this is a gratifying sign that they're doing it.'' ``Without self-recognition, one can't begin other steps of education, and that's why this is terribly important,'' said Kenneth Jacobson, director of the Anti-Defamation League division of international affairs. ``For the last 40 years East Germany has denied any role and now they're beginning to look history in the eye,'' Jacobson said. ``I don't think too many youngsters in that part of the world really understand what went on.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Hails `Great Progress' in Easing Japan Trade Tensions
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Thursday the United States and Japan must resolve more disputes to ease trade tensions but that ``great progress has been made'' with an agreement reached last week.
