In a meeting in the Cabinet Room, Bush congratulated Trade Representative Carla Hills, Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady for the success of U.S.-Japanese negotiations that resulted in the trade accord. ``It was well done,'' Bush said. ``I can't remember a one-month period in our relations with Japan like the one between Palm Springs and now.'' Bush and Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu met in Palm Springs, Calif., in March to discuss trade tensions arising from the $49 billion U.S. trade deficit with Japan. Bush said Kaifu ``has exemplified the best in cooperation and leadership. He's taken some very strong positions there.'' Bush told the officials, however, ``Lest any of you feel like you can totally relax, there are some outstanding issues.'' He specifically mentioned Japanese restrictions on U.S. forest products. He did say that ``great progress has been made'' on satellites and supercomputers and telecommunications. ``We've got to finish this agenda,'' he said, adding that ``we want to keep on going. I have a feeling we can get this concluded.'' ``What's your best bet on the time, Carla?'' Bush said, turning to the trade official. ``It's difficult to give a specific time,'' she replied. ``We are making progress. But as you put it, Mr. President, we have more to do.'' Bush told the officials, ``What she means is, we have more to do.'' In last week's agreement, Japan promised to take steps to make it easier for Americans and other foreigners to do business in Japan. U.S. negotiators pledged to boost America's ability to compete internationally by improving the education system, increasing savings and reducing the federal budget deficit. But U.S. trade specialists have expressed doubts over how far the Japanese will go in implementing the accord, especially in light of strong political resistance to some of the measures in Tokyo.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Killed Family and Disappared Is Convicted 18 Years Later
LaserPhoto NR11
DOC.TEXT: A jury Thursday convicted a former Sunday school teacher of first-degree murder for the 1971 deaths of his wife, three children and mother. He claimed he killed them in part because he feared for their souls. John E. List sat stone-faced as the five verdicts were read after the jury deliberated nine hours over two days. Jurors rejected lesser counts of second-degree murder and his lawyer's contention that List was innocent because of his mental state at the time. The 64-year-old List faces a mandatory life prison term at his sentencing May 1. There was no death penalty in effect in the state in 1971. ``The state's very gratified,'' said Union County Assistant Prosecutor Eleanor J. Clark. ``It deserved the verdict. Justice was not denied because of the delay.'' List disappeared before authorities found the bodies of his relatives on Dec. 7, 1971, in the family's 18-room mansion in suburban Westfield, 25 miles from New York. List was arrested in Richmond, Va., last June after a tip to the ``America's Most Wanted'' television show, which featured the case. His arrest ended a secret life as a fugitive, spent mostly in Denver and during which List again took up his profession as an accountant, returned to the Lutheran church and remarried. He moved to suburban Richmond in 1988. List's attorney, Elijah L. Miller Jr., left the courthouse without commenting. If a conviction was necessary, Miller urged the jury to return a second-degree verdict because List's mental condition made him incapable of ``deliberation,'' one of the necessary elements a jury must find for first-degree murder. Psychiatric experts testified for the defense that List suffered from a ``obsessive-compulsive'' disorder that made him inflexible and unable to find solutions to his problems. Combined with List's twisted sense of religion, the inability to support his family and a feeling they were slipping from their religion left List one option, Miller contended: Kill them so their souls could find salvation. Further pressure came from the shame and burden of his wife's terminal syphilis, which she caught in 1943 from her first husband. The disease made her abusive, psychotic, subject to frequent falls and unable to care for her family, witnesses testified. A prosecution psychiatrist testified that although List had an obsessive personality, he suffered from little more than a mid-life crisis. The bodies of List's wife, Helen, 46, and the couple's three children _ Patricia, 16; John, 15; and Frederick, 13 _ were lined up on the floor of their sparsely furnished ballroom. His mother, Alma List, 84, was found in her third-floor apartment. In a filing cabinet, List left a chilling five-page letter explaining his actions and motives to his pastor. ``P.S.: Mother is in the hallway in the attic _ 3rd floor. She was too heavy to move,'' he wrote. Police, called by worried neighbors and friends, testified they entered the home and heard dirgelike religious music playing over an intercom system. Matter-of-fact notes apologized to his in-laws and gave instructions for settling the family's affairs. List told a psychiatrist he shot his wife as she ate breakfast, then his mother upstairs. After eating lunch, he killed each child as they came home from school. Then he had dinner, slept in the house and dropped his car off at New York's Kennedy International Airport. The next day, List got on a train and ended up in Denver.

DOC.HEAD: Discovery, Space Telescope Launch Set for April 25
DOC.TEXT: NASA on Thursday set April 25 as the new launch date for space shuttle Discovery and the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope, the agency's most expensive and complex payload. The first launch attempt was scrubbed four minutes before liftoff Tuesday when one of Discovery's three auxiliary power units failed. ``The date is based on the decision to remove and replace APU No. 1 on space shuttle Discovery and to allow time for recharging the Hubble Space Telescope batteries,'' NASA said in a statement. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said a new power unit was expected to arrive at Kennedy Space Center this week. Shuttle managers estimate it will take two to three days to replace the unit, said NASA spokesman Bruce Buckingham. It will be the first time NASA has ever replaced an auxiliary power unit on the launch pad. NASA shipped the unit's 15-pound controller, which controls speed, back to the manufacturer for testing. The manufacturer informed NASA the controller was fine, indicating an unknown problem elsewhere in the unit. Auxiliary power units steer the ship's three main engines, control the movements of flaps on the wings and the rudder, lower the main and nose landing gears, and provide the hydraulics for the main landing gear brakes. NASA will remove the telescope's nickel-hydrogen batteries and recharge them in a laboratory starting Saturday. The batteries will power Hubble from the time it is disconnected from the shuttle's power system during deployment until its energy-collecting solar panels are unfurled. ``This allows the batteries to be serviced under the most favorable conditions while HST remains in the clean environment of the cargo bay,'' NASA said., referring to the telescope. Empty insect traps were removed Thursday from a payload preparation room of the launch pad tower. The traps were set up Wednesday to catch mosquito-like midges, which invaded the preparation room two weeks ago and delayed the telescope's installation in the orbiter. The telescope's 94-inch mirror, the finest ever made, is extremely sensitive to any kind of debris. NASA had feared the midges may have invaded a payload preparation room at the launch pad tower again. Traps were set up, but no bugs were caught and the traps were removed Thursday. Hubble's installation in the orbiter was delayed two weeks ago after several-dozen midges got into the preparation room. Discovery's five astronauts will place Hubble in space on the second day of the five-day mission, delayed since 1983 by technical problems and the 1986 Challenger explosion. The telescope is to orbit 380 miles high for 15 years, enabling astronomers to look back to almost the beginning of time.

DOC.HEAD: World Media Conference Ends With Praise for Perestroika
DOC.TEXT: A three-day international media conference closed Thursday with praise for the Kremlin reforms that allowed the group to meet for the first time in Moscow. The final document of the World Media Conference ``stressed that revolutionary restructuring in the Soviet Union is of worldwide and historic significance and positively influences processes all over the world,'' the Soviet news agency Tass reported. It said conference participants expressed hope that Soviet reforms would help establish a new world order based on principles of equality, cooperation and non-interference. The conference concluded with a joint sitting of the Summit Council for World Peace and the Association for Latin America Unity, Tass said. It quoted former Venezuelan President Luis Herrera Campins as telling the group that perestroika, the Kremlin's reform program, ``is a gift to all people of goodwill striving for good-neighborly relations and peace.'' After the conference, the Latin American group's board awarded medals ``of freedom and unity'' to Politburo member Alexander Yakovlev, Pravda editor Ivan Frolov and Presidential Council member Yuri Osipyan, Tass said. About 500 delegates from 60 countries, including more than 40 former heads of state, attended the opening of the association founded by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon to encourage East-West communication in politics, economics and the environment. Moon said in his opening remarks Tuesday that it was perestroika that made it possible for the association to hold its first meeting in the Soviet capital. ``I feel there is no place more appropriate to gather for these discussions than right here in the Soviet Union,'' Moon said. Participants in the conference met Wednesday with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and heard his latest assessment of the progress of perestroika. Gorbachev told the delegation Soviet society ``is leaving the rallying stage and is becoming involved in real deeds,'' Tass reported. Conference discussion also focused on ecology and media technology.

DOC.HEAD: State Survey Finds 7 Percent of Delivering Mothers on Drugs
DOC.TEXT: Drug testing in Rhode Island showed that 7.5 percent of 465 women had used cocaine, marijuana, speed or opiates two days before giving birth, federal health officials said Thursday. While Rhode Island is an urban state, and perhaps more prone to drug use than more rural ones, the report probably has underestimated illicit drug use among women giving birth, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control said. ``It's probably important for any state ... to keep in mind the same thing we discovered,'' said Dr. William Hollinshead of the Rhode Island Division of Family Health. ``There are almost always a number of different substances being used (by pregnant women), probably much more commonly than we realize. And this doesn't even touch on our old standard poisons of alcohol and tobacco.'' The testing was performed on urine samples from 465 women in labor at eight hospitals across the state in October and November. The women were not informed the program was taking place, and only samples headed for discarding were analyzed, Hollinshead said. Demographic data about the patients were recorded, but names were not used. Thirty-five samples, or 7.5 percent, tested positive for drugs. Cocaine was detected in 2.6 percent, marijuana was detected in 3 percent, opiates were detected in 1.7 percent and amphetamines were detected in 0.2 percent, according to program results reported Thursday by the Atlanta-based CDC. Drug use rates were higher among non-whites than whites _ 10.2 percent to 7 percent. Rates were also higher among women under age 25 than older women _ 9.1 percent to 7 percent. Rates were lower among women having their first child _ 5.7 percent, compared with 9.2 percent for women having their second or more. Hollinshead said he would be hesitant to project Rhode Island statistics to other states, in part because urban and coastal areas tend to have higher incidence of drug use than more rural areas. Still, the CDC's report noted, ``These rates are probably underestimated ... because they reflect drug use only within 48 hours of labor and delivery, and because only a limited number of drugs were assessed.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Moving to Restore Relations With Democratic Chile
DOC.TEXT: The United States is moving to quickly normalize relations with Chile's new democratic government, the State Department said Thursday. This could include the lifting of economic sanctions and the end of restrictions on military aid and arms sales. ``The United States applauds the return to democracy in Chile,'' the State Department said in a statement. ``We hope to normalize quickly all of our relations with the new government in Chile, including economic, political and defense relations.'' The department's statement comes one month after the inauguration of President Patricio Aylwin to replace dictator Gen. Augusto Pinochet. Pinochet ruled Chile with an iron hand after the coup that ousted Socialist President Salvador Allende Gossens in September 1973. Thousands of Allende's supporters were rounded up and many were tortured or killed. Pinochet remains head of the Chilean armed forces. But Vice President Dan Quayle, who attended Aylwin's March 11 inauguration in Santiago, said Pinochet assured him he would follow the policies of the new civilian government. The State Department said a review will open soon on Chile's petition for the restoration of easier tariff treatment of its exports and its request for renewed participation in the programs of the Overseas Private Investment Corp. Chile was suspended from participation in these programs in 1987 due to workers' rights issues, the department said. Organized labor in Chile now strongly supports the ending of the sanctions, the department said. Military aid and arms sales to Chile have been restricted since 1976. The department noted U.S. law bars their restoration until the Chilean government meets these two conditions: _Restores respect for human rights. _Cooperates with the United States in bringing to justice those Chilean intelligence officials suspected of complicity in the 1976 murders in Washington of former Chilean diplomat Orlando Letelier and an American colleague, Ronni K. Moffitt. ``We are confident that the new government of Patricio Aylwin will make every effort to meet those conditions,'' the department statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Harvard President Criticizes Higher Education's Critics
DOC.TEXT: Critics have attacked higher education ``more savagely during the past 10 years than at any time in my memory,'' the president of Harvard University charged Thursday. In his 19th annual report, Derek Bok warns that the current trend toward assailing the state of U.S. education threatens to weaken the system even more. ``Most of the charges are flawed because they ignore basic conflicts and contradictions in the demands society makes on universities,'' Bok wrote. ``Continued criticism of this kind ... threatens to do needless damage to the public confidence so important to maintaining a strong system of colleges and universities.'' Bok blames the swelling federal deficit and tax cuts of the 1980s for the decline in higher education and the tendency to bash it. ``The political climate of the 1980s gave prominence to public figures and intellectuals of a conservative bent who saw universities as liberal strongholds populated by cocksure, opinionated professors,'' Bok wrote. While criticism is always a valid outlet for opinion and change, Bok believes the attacks on higher education have been unfounded or made without all the facts. ``What is needed ... is not an end to criticism but a criticism that is less given to rhetorical excess, more careful with its criteria for judgment,'' Bok wrote. Bok addressed several controversial issues, including the conflict between teaching and research, increasing tuition costs, curriculum quality and calls from the public to curtail university spending. The teaching-versus-research debate has been especially heated at Harvard. Last month, the faculty of Harvard Medical School approved a set of guidelines governing outside work for faculty members. ``One signal comes from all the critics who deplore the neglect of teaching and the stress that universities place on published work,'' Bok said. ``The other makes the opposite point through a system of powerful incentives and rewards that offers fame, fortune and ample funding to successful scientists and scholars.'' Bok said that teachers are not always motivated by private gain when undertaking outside pursuits and that research usually benefits a university. But he said that schools need to delineate how much time can be spent on outside pursuits and that restrictions are inadequate at many institutions. Bok also decried what he called ``hostile publicity'' about rising tuition costs. He most news reports about expensive tuition are focused on a few high-powered universities such as Harvard, Stanford, Yale or Princeton when in fact the majority of undergraduates attend public universities where tuition is less than $2,000 per year.

DOC.HEAD: East German Parliament Accepts Agenda for Unification
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 21 grafs to UPDATE with de Maiziere comments. Picks up 19th pvs, `The accord...' Edits thereafter to trim
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BER2, BER7
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's parliament chose Lothar de Maiziere as prime minister on Thursday and embraced his sweeping agenda for quickly uniting the foundering nation with West Germany. The former Communist nation's first freely elected legislature also apologized to Jews for Nazi atrocities and promised to make reparations to Israel and seek diplomatic ties. By putting de Maiziere's broad coalition government in power, the parliament sets up a transitional government whose prime goal will be to negotiate the terms of creating a single Germany. Before parliament met, members of the coalition agreed that a united Germany should remain part of NATO and that East Germany should merge its weak currency with West Germany's strong deutschmark by July 1. The coalition also backed a rapid process for unification. However, it demanded too that East Germans retain some social benefits, including housing and job guarantees, as the nation of 16 million residents sheds four decades of socialism for the competitive free market. The historic decisions on Thursday will be followed in the coming weeks by unification talks with West Germany and the four World War II allies that divided the countries: the Soviet Union, United States, Britain and France. De Maiziere, closely aligned to Helmut Kohl, appeared to distance himself from the West German chancellor after the parliamentary session. He said final unification may not come late next year, as Kohl has said. ``It can be realistic, but it doesn't have to be realistic,'' he said of Kohl's prediction. De Maiziere said merging the nations will depend less on timing than on the conditions. He said on West Germany's ZDF television network ``that we must create compatible structures.'' The 400-member parliament put de Maiziere and his 24-member Cabinet in power by a vote of 265-108, with nine abstentions. Eighteen lawmakers were absent. With the vote, the new government replaces the Communist caretaker government that has been running the economically troubled country since East Germans overthrew the hard-line regime of Erich Honecker in October. In a remarkable string of conciliatory gestures, the Parliament recognized the legitimacy of Poland's post-war borders, which include former German lands, and apologized for East Germany's role in the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968. It apologized for the deaths of 20 million Soviets during World War II, and ended four decades of denials that East Germany's former Stalinist leaders played any role in the deaths of 6 million Jews. ``Persecuted Jews should be granted asylum in the future in East Germany,'' the parliament declaration said. Israel has long demanded reparations and an East German apology for Nazi crimes as a condition for diplomatic relations. Yossi Ahimeir, a spokesman for Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, said that ``at first glance, it looks like a positive announcement.'' But Parliament Speaker Dov Shilansky, a survivor of the Dachau concentration camp, said he would never grant forgiveness for the killing of 6 million Jews during World War II. De Maiziere, a bearded, 50-year-old lawyer whose conservative coalition won in the nation's first free elections on March 18, rose to power by promising Western prosperity through quick unification. His compromises with the left-leaning Social Democrats, who finished second in the elections and agreed to join his government, indicates East Germany will demand some sort of social safety net for its citizens when it negotiates with West Germany. The coalition accord calls for a retention of current unemployment benefits, retirement insurance and aid to the disadvantaged. It calls for East Germans to be guaranteed a place to live and for rent increases to be tied to wages. The accord on terms of reunification contained several compromises that could put de Maiziere at odds with his mentor, West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. The accord calls for a 1-1 conversion of East German marks for West German marks when the nations merge their currencies. West Germany's central bank has proposed a 2-1 rate for all but small savings accounts. The coalition agreement follows Kohl's demand that a united Germany be part of NATO. The agreement said ``it can be assumed that a unified Germany, during a transition period and until the creation of a collective European security system, should be a member of a NATO that itself is transforming its military functions.'' The Soviet Union wants a new Germany to be neutral. West Germany now is in NATO and East Germany is part of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. The strategic future of a unified Germany will be the main negotiating point when the superpowers take part in the unification talks, perhaps next month. The coalition agreement also said the merger of the two countries should be based on a West German constitutional provision that permits direct incorporation of East German territory into West Germany. The Social Democrats had demanded a more gradual system of unification, with East German states voting separately on unification. Kohl and de Maiziere both favor the faster process. Kohl congratulated de Maiziere on his election and offered ``close and friendly'' cooperation in bringing together the German states after ``decades of forced separation.'' Although de Maiziere's conservative alliance finished first in the elections, he formed a coalition with the Social Democrats to get the two-thirds majority in Parliament needed to win constitutional changes needed for unification. The coalition has proven politically expedient as East Germans, first enamored of the idea of quick Western prosperity, now are beginning to fear the loss of their subsidizied homes, jobs and food.

DOC.HEAD: Appeal Filed in Divorce Battle Over Seven Frozen Embryos
DOC.TEXT: A judge's decision to give legal protection to seven frozen human embryos went far beyond his authority and should be overturned, a lawyer said in an appeal filed Thursday. The ruling was made last September in the divorce case of Junior Lewis Davis and Mary Sue Davis. The only issue was what to do with the eggs that resulted from in-vitro fertilization in December 1988. Mrs. Davis testified that she wanted control of the embryos in an attempt to have children. Davis said he did not want the embryos used in any fashion without his consent, especially by his ex-wife. Blount County Circuit Court Judge Dale Young last September ruled that ``life begins at conception'' and accorded the embryos the same legal status as children would have in a custody dispute between their parents. He granted temporary custody to Mrs. Davis, who has since remarried, but continued an order preventing her from using them while appeals are pending. The appeal filed by Junior Lewis Davis said the judge's decision was inconsistent with existing laws. ``Forty-eight-hour, fertilized embryos kept frozen will enjoy enhanced protection, while first trimester fetuses will continue to be legally aborted,'' the appeal said. The ruling elevates ``these tenuous, and as yet undeveloped, laboratory embryos to a legal status that exceeds any in federal constitutional law or the Tennessee criminal, abortion, or probate laws,'' according to the appeal. The appeal says Young erred by attempting to set a policy, which is supposed to be reserved for the Legislature. Moreover, the appeal says, the decision does an injustice to the rights of Davis to avoid becoming a parent. Attorneys for Mrs. Davis, who is remarried and living in Florida, have 30 days to respond to the appeal.

DOC.HEAD: Cold Temperatures From Kansas To Kentucky
DOC.TEXT: Temperatures fell to record lows Thursday in the heart of the nation, snow fell in the Appalachians and around some of the Great Lakes, and rain fell along the Rockies and western Plains. Lincoln, Neb., hit a record low of 17 degrees and Paducah, Ky., dropped to a record 26. Des Moines, Iowa, tied its record of 15 and Springfield, Ill., tied its record of 23. Thursday's low for the Lower 48 states was 14 at Bismarck, N.D., and Philip, S.D. The northerly wind pushing the cold air into the center of the nation picked up moisture from the Great Lakes and produced snow squalls that left almost 3 inches of snow overnight around Rochester, N.Y. At midday, snow showers were scattered from eastern West Virginia into southwestern Pennsylvania, over eastern Lower Michigan and eastern Upper Michigan, and along Lake Ontario in northwestern New York state. Farther west, showers extended over northeastern Montana, and from north-central Wyoming into south-central Montana. Rain and occasional thundershowers reached from eastern New Mexico across the Texas Panhandle, northern Oklahoma, southern Kansas, and from north-central Colorado into southeastern Wyoming and the Nebraska Panhandle. Snow fell over northeastern Kansas. Unseasonably low temperatures were expected overnight into Friday for the central Atlantic states and part of the Ohio Valley. An advisory for freezing temperatures through the night into Friday was posted over northern Kentucky, and warnings of freezing temperatures were posted over sections of inland Virginia and Maryland, and the Eastern Panhandle of West Virginia. An overnight frost and freeze warning was issued over much of South Carolina. But there were no reports of measurable snowfall or significant rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 26 at Saranac Lake, N.Y., to 100 at Palm Springs, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Calling for No Timetable on Global Warming
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration will call for broader research into the economic effects of global warming but propose no timetable for dealing with the the issue at upcoming international talks, senior officials said Thursday. The two-day conference will bring together ministers from 17 countries as well as the European community for a discussion of the economic impact of global warming and what additional scientific data is needed. ``We want to raise the level of debate ... on the science and economics of global change,'' Michael Boskin, chairman of the president's Council of Economic Advisers. told a White House briefing. William Reilly, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, said the conference ``is not about targets and timetables'' but aimed at ``forming priorities'' for further research and evaluating the economic problems posed by the warming of the earth. President Bush in February called for the White House conference and invited senior ministers to attend. The top economic, environmental and scientific advisers to the heads of state of the 17 countries will participate in the conference which begins Tuesday. With the conference focusing on more research, environmentalists have renewed criticism of the Bush administration. They urge a more active response to concerns that the globe will become significantly warmer by the middle of the next century because of manmade pollution. ``They're just saying no again to taking any steps to deal with global warming,'' said Daniel Becker of the Sierra Club. Bush had steadfastly maintained that not enough is known about the severity of the problem to warrant dramatic moves to reduce the emissions that are causing the earth to become warmer. Some European countries have argued for a stabelization of carbon dioxide emissions, primarily from the burning of fossil fuels, by the year 2000. Many environmentalists have said such emissions should be cut by as much as one-fifth by the turn of the century if significant warming is to be averted. The adminstration has argued that such moves, which would require a dramatic shift toward energy conservation and away from the burning of fossil fuels, could have severe economic repercussions and should not be imposed until more is known about the so-called greenhouse problem. Allan Bromley, the president's science adviser, who has been among those advocating the go-slow approach, said Thursday that the United States plans to push during the upcoming meeting for agreement among the participants to expand international research on both the science of global warming and the economic implications. Both Reilly anbd Bromley maintained that some who advocate stabelization of carbon dioxide emissions have not examined sufficiently the economic consequences of such a move.

DOC.HEAD: Government Settles Overcharges for $3.95 Million
DOC.TEXT: A British company's American subsidiary and one of its divisions agreed to pay $3.95 million to settle charges that the division overbilled the Defense Department, the Justice Department announced Thursday. The false claims for electric devices made for military aircraft flight control and fuel management systems were submitted from 1983 through 1986, the department said. The settlement was with the American subsidiary of Smiths Industries of Great Britain and one of its divisions, SLI Avionic Systems Division, Grand Rapids, Mich. The false claims were submitted by the Instruments Division of Lear Siegler Inc., SLI's forerunner, and it reported the mischarges to the Pentagon in December 1986, the Justice Department said. SLI continued to provide information to the government after it took over Lear Sieger. The division overbilled the government when it shifted costs between accounts that were established for a specific project and accounts for general research and development, the department said. ``This settlement represents precisely the type of voluntary cooperation that we encourage among all the contractors who discover billing irregularities,'' Stuart M. Gerson, assistant attorney general in charge of the civil division, said in a statement. The False Claims Act allows for civil damages to be reduced from three to two times the government's loss when the company reports the problem and cooperates during the investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Task Force Says Patients Should Be Able To Refuse Treatment
DOC.TEXT: Patients have the right to refuse life-sustaining medical treatment but active euthanasia is wrong, said a report released Thursday, nearly a year after a gun-wielding father disconnected his comatose baby's life support. ``The time has come to return control over the dying process to patients and their families,'' said the report. The report was written by a task force formed by Cook County State's Attorney Cecil Partee after the April 26 incident at Rush-Presbyterian-St. Luke's Medical Center. Rudy Linares, holding hospital workers at bay with a gun, turned off his 15-month-old son's respirator and cradled the baby in his arms until he died. Officials at the hospital had refused family requests to halt life support. A grand jury refused to charge Linares with murder. He pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge of unlawful possession of a weapon, and was ordered to seek psychological counseling. The report ``should have been done long before, so this wouldn't have occurred,'' Linares said in a telephone interview Thursday, adding that he had no regrets over his actions. Illinois law allows people to decline life support through living wills or by assigning power of attorney to a third party. Model legislation drafted by the task force would allow people to refuse life support without taking such actions. Partee wrote legislation similar to the model bill. It was introduced last week in the Illinois Senate. The task force said a person should be judged capable of making the decision to end life support before medical officials take such action. The task force said surrogates could make the decision for those judged not capable and that parents could decide for children. A judicial ruling would be needed only in cases of a dispute, the task force said, noting that doctors and surrogates should be immune from criminal prosecution for decisions made in good faith. The task force said its report was ``in no way intended to endorse the practice of active euthanasia or mercy killing.'' At the time the task force was formed, there were no state court rulings on the issue. Earlier this year, the Illinois Supreme Court ruled that life support could be withheld from terminally ill patients when they are diagnosed as irreversibly comatose and when a doctor's diagnosis was confirmed by two other physicians. The task force's work was praised by Fenella Rouse, director of the New York-based Concern for Dying and the Society for the Right to Die. ``You don't want to have outsiders who have never been involved in the person's life making the decision for them,'' she said. Linares' dilemma began after his infant son, Sam, swallowed a balloon in August 1988, blocking his air passage. Paramedics failed to revive Sam, and he never regained consciousness. When hospital personnel refused family requests to withdraw life support, Linares said he decided to take things into his own hands. Although he escaped prosecution and prison, Linares was fired from his job as a painter. About a week after his son died, he was hospitalized for taking a mixture of cocaine and the drug PCP. He later pleaded guilty to a drunken driving charge. ``The pressure and the realization that I wasn't going to go to jail after all got to me,'' Linares said. ``I felt like the drugs were a way out.'' Hired as a forklift driver in September, Linares was fired the day after he started when management learned of his past. Linares has a new job fixing machines at an assembly plant, and attends Alcoholics Anonymous and Narcotics Anonymous meetings. ``I had two other kids and a good-looking wife,'' he said. ``I thought, if I fold under now, if I got too depressed, what will happen to them?''

DOC.HEAD: For Oscar Hijuelos, the Nicest Surprise
DOC.TEXT: This was supposed to be a day of rest for Pulitzer Prize-winner Oscar Hijuelos. Staying at a friend's house in the country, the author had spent the morning shopping for antiques and browsing in bookstores, and was looking forward to getting some reading done in the afternoon. Then, the phone rang. It was Roger Straus, president of Farrar, Straus & Giroux, which published Hijuelos' novel, ``The Mambo Kings Play Songs of Love.'' ``He doesn't call you very often, but when he does it's good news,'' Hijuelos said in a telephone interview from Ulster County. The news couldn't have been better: ``Mambo Kings'' had won the Pulitzer Prize for fiction. ``This is so unexpected,'' said Hijuelos, the son of Cuban immigrants and a resident of Manhattan. ``I've just been in England and I was spending the week here to chill out. I didn't even know when they were going to announce this thing. My mother will be happy.'' Mambo Kings Cesar and Nestor Castillo would have understood. They're the Cuban brothers who immigrated to the United States, and through their friendship with Desi Arnaz wound up on stage at the Tropicana and in the living room of Ricky and Lucy Ricardo in Hijuelos' own special episode of ``I Love Lucy.'' ``It really started out as a novel about a superintendent who had a past life,'' Hijuelos said of his second novel. ``His past life was about music, and then the music took over. It ties into my Cuban roots and also into my interest in the culture in general. ``You always get that second novel-itis,'' said Hijuelos, whose first novel, ``Our House in the Last World,'' was published in 1985. ``So what happened was simply amazing to me.'' Hijuelos, born in New York in 1951, originally wanted to be a rock 'n' roll star, but was turned off by the drug scene. He nearly quit writing as well, attending a conference in 1978 and finding it ``the most sexist, hierarchal, opinionated, prejudical place I've ever been on Earth.'' Fortunately, Hijuelos became friendly with author Donald Barthelme, who encouraged the young writer to develop his own style and even offered tips on the secrets of success. ``He said if you're good, you eventually get recognized sooner or later,'' Hijuelos said of Barthelme, who died of cancer last year. ``I figured I had 20 years to go to get these kinds of breaks. He always spoke about awards as an important kind of thing. I think it's a way for writers' investing into their future. It helps people, it helps writers and the readers they identify with.'' Hijuelos gets letters from people all over the country, telling him they can relate to the experiences of the Castillo brothers and expressing curiosity about the world he evokes. ``The United States is a country of immigrants and I think people who are still in touch with feelings of displacement could tap into the characters in the novel,'' he said. ``I guess on another level, people are tired of the `A fits into B' kind of formulaic novels. I wanted to do something different. I tried to structure the book musically. I also hope it means that people feel differently about the kind of people I wrote about.'' Hijuelos, working on a new novel tentatively titled ``14 Sisters,'' says winning the Pulitzer is just the ``tip of the iceberg'' for him, and so many others ready to tell their stories. ``I think, culturally, the `establishment' has in home-grown Latin writers a potential source of great literature. Most writing from ``minorities'' is on small presses and university presses. Maybe this will encourage publishers to move over a little bit.''

DOC.HEAD: Second-in-Command Says Doomed Ferry Should Never Have Left Port
DOC.TEXT: Combustible materials were left in the passageways of a ferry before it caught fire and the vessel was in such poor shape that it should never have left port, the ship's second-in-command said Thursday. Karsten Hansen, staff captain of the Scandinavian Star, made his comments before a maritime commission investigating the blaze Saturday on the 10,500-ton ferry, which was sailing from Norway to Denmark. On Thursday, Norwegian police lowered their estimate to 166 people killed in the disaster. They earlier estimated the toll at 168, but police have said they have no final figure. Police said they believe the fire was deliberate. The Danish shipowner, VR Da-No, posted a $39,000 reward for information leading to the identity of the arsonist. In Larvik, Norway, police said Thursday that 1,639 passengers and 130 crew members were evacuated from a Norwegian ferry following a bomb threat. The ferry Peter Wessel, which had left 90 minutes earlier for Denmark, returned to the Norwegian port Wednesday night after the threat, which proved false, said police inspector Paal Aartun. Hansen told the maritime inquiry that inflammable refuse was left in corridors while the the ship underwent renovations. ``Work was going on all over the ship,'' he said. Carpenters and painters were finishing renovations of cabins, the bar and other areas of the ship, which the new Danish owner took over March 30. Service personnel often left bundles of bedding outside the passenger cabins they cleaned, creating a fire hazard, he said. ``The authorities should never have allowed that ship to leave port,'' Hansen said. Hansen said some of the catering staff complained of exhaustion from overwork. He added that he'd heard of friction between crew members. Rescued passengers complained that the crew, mostly Filipino and Portuguese sailors, appeared untrained to handle a crisis and could not communicate with passengers. A fire inspector testified earlier that serious faults were found with fire-containing devices, and fire fighting equipment was unused. According to the ship's emergency roster, Hansen was the ship's fire chief and was responsible for organizing the crew in an emergency. But during questioning, Hansen said he was unaware of the regulation, and added he wasn't hired in that capacity. Hansen said he and another crewman donned fire suits to rescue trapped passengers. The two rescued three unconscious passengers before being taken off the stricken ship by rescue helicopters. Hansen said at one point during a search below decks he found a dead woman clutching an infant, also dead, to her breast. The Norwegian captain of the vessel, Hugo Larsen, denied in testimony Wednesday the safety devices were faulty, but admitted the crew had not undergone a fire drill, which had been scheduled for the day after the fire. Eighty of the 97 crewmen had been hired within the week before the disaster, according to witnesses who appeared at the inquiry.

DOC.HEAD: `The Piano Lesson' `A Joyful Play' to Write
With AM-Pulitzers-Arts
DOC.TEXT: August Wilson says ``The Piano Lesson,'' winner of the 1990 Pulitzer Prize for drama, was a ``a joyful play to write.'' ``I wrote the play in several months, and when it went around the country for two years, I continued to work on it,'' said the man who won his first Pulitzer three years ago for ``Fences.'' Wilson said the idea for ``The Piano Lesson,'' which opens Monday at Broadway's Walter Kerr Theater, came to him from a painting by black artist Romare Bearden. The painter's work inspired another Wilson play, ``Joe Turner's Come and Gone.'' ``Bearden is a tremendous artist, and I always wanted to make my plays worthy of his canvasses,'' Wilson said. ``I would be doing a good thing if I could make them as rich and as full as the life he expressed in his paintings.'' The playwright was taken by a Bearden painting of a young girl sitting at a piano with her teacher standing over her. From it, he fashioned a family drama of a brother and a sister in Pittsburgh in 1936. The brother wants to buy the land his grandfather worked on as a slave and is willing to sell the family heirloom, a piano, to pay for it. The sister wants to keep it. Wilson says he was haunted by the question, ``Can you acquire a sense of self-worth by denying your past?'' ``nd when I began to work on the play, it began to take on a larger question: `What do you do with your legacy and how do you put it to work for you?''' ``The Piano Lesson'' is a better play for having had the opportunity to tour for so long before coming to New York, the playwright said. ``When it started, I never said what happened to the piano,'' the playwright said. ``And I found that the audiences wanted to know. Now I do answer the question. I found I did not want to make a choice, but I discovered the choice was built into the play.'' Wilson was in a Manhattan hotel giving an interview when he learned he had won the Pulitzer. ``I was very surprised,'' he said. ``I wasn't expecting it. I thought `Wow. This is No. 2.' It made me want to go right to my typewriter and start another one.'' ``The Piano Lesson'' is part of a cycle of plays about black American life during the decades of this century. It's also the fourth collaboration between Wilson and director Lloyd Richards, who also directed ``Fences.'' Their relationship started with ``Ma Rainey's Black Bottom,'' which opened on Broadway in 1984. It was followed to New York by ``Fences'' in 1987 and ``Joe Turner's Come and Gone'' in 1988. Wilson's newest play, ``Two Trains Running,'' recently opened at the Yale Repertory Theater in New Haven, Conn., and eventually is expected to make its way to Broadway. When he returns to his home in St. Paul, Minn., after the opening of ``The Piano Lesson,'' Wilson said he would begin work on ``Moon Going Down,'' set in the 1940s. Wilson is the first playwright since Edward Albee to win two Pulitzer Prizes for drama. Other two-time winners include Robert Sherwood, George S. Kaufman and Tennessee Williams. Eugene O'Neill won four Pulitzers, including a posthumous award in 1957 for ``Long Day's Journey into Night.''

DOC.HEAD: Washington (N.C.) Daily News Wins Pulitzer Prize
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf, ``I feel...'' with one graf to fix quote, ``in a little town'' sted ``on''; subs 5th graf, `The Daily...' with one graf to fix spelling of `hollers.'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Pulitzers, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: It's not uncommon for foreign correspondents to move to Washington after their tours abroad. But it's usually Washington, D.C., not N.C. Bill Coughlin did it a little differently, much to his delight Thursday when the Washington Daily News won a Pulitzer Prize for public service journalism. ``I feel it's a little ironic after having worked in Moscow and Vietnam and Beirut _ to find my Pulitzer in a little town on the Pamlico in North Carolina,'' said Coughlin, 67, a former foreign correspondent for the Los Angeles Times who was hired as executive editor of the Daily News a year ago. ``It says if you set your standards high enough, you can be just as good as big town newspapers.'' The Daily News, whose circulation is 10,700, won the award for breaking town officials' long silence about the cancer-causing chemicals tainting the drinking water. The announcement brought whoops, hollers, marching music and champagne into the newsroom of the eastern North Carolina paper. ``This is quite a moment,'' Coughlin said. ``I will say we haven't had this much excitement in this town since the Union cavalry and the Confederate cavalry chased each other up Main Street in 1862, and there's been nothing like that since.'' Daily News Reporters Betty Gray and Mike Voss, who wrote the series about the town's contaminated water supply and the failure of town officials to notify the 9,000 residents, said the award made their efforts worthwhile. ``All through covering the story, there was a great deal of pressure,'' said Ms. Gray, 36. ``I'm a native of Washington. I grew up with the people that were running the city. It was all worthwhile anyway.'' The afternoon newspaper, published by former state Sen. Ashley Futrell Sr., 78, and his son, Ashley Jr., has won statewide awards. The paper averages 16 pages and is written and edited in three rooms, ``It shows (small-town newspapers) that they have just as good a chance as anybody else,'' Voss said. It all started when Coughlin was at City Hall paying his water bill last summer. He noticed a message on the back of the bill saying the water was being tested for a variety of chemicals. He suggested that Ms. Gray, a former insurance agent with three years' journalism experience, look into it. In September, when the newspaper first reported that the drinking water contained nine times the safe level of trihalomethanes, which are known to cause cancer, town officials said Ms. Gray's article exaggerated the danger. But 10 days after the stories began, state officials told residents to stop drinking water from the Pamlico River. The Marine Corps set up 24-hour-a-day water wagons. A second chemical, even more deadly, was found by state officials who warned that the risk of cancer for lifelong water drinkers could be 1 in 250. A month later, state officials found similar contaminants exceeding federal standards in 13 other small communities. Voss, 35, said he joined Ms. Gray on the series ``when we saw what we had.'' ``I'm ecstatic,'' he said. ``This is a dream come true. It's the pinnacle of the profession. For a small town newspaper to compete and take home the biggest and the best is unbelieveable.'' The two-month water ban was lifted after the city began spending $14,000 per month on a temporary treatment system using chemicals besides chlorine. The water now meets federal standards, and state officials are working with the other towns to clean up their water. State Health Director Ron Levine credits the Daily News with the regulatory changes that perhaps saved hundreds of lives. Some town officials disagree with the honor and remain bitter about the stories that divided this quiet waterfront town. As part of their stories, Ms. Gray and Voss reported that town officials had known about the problem for eight years and hadn't told anyone. Washington's elected officials have since been voted out.

DOC.HEAD: World War II Fighter Planes Go To Auction For $1 Million and Up
DOC.TEXT: Apollo astronauts Wally Schirra and Buzz Aldrin lent their support Thursday to a museum auction that aviation buffs hope will do for old airplanes what Sotheby's does for Rembrandts and Van Goghs. ``These planes are works of art in their own right,'' said Donald Douglas Jr., whose father built the DC-3 and countless other planes made famous in war and peace. ``We hope this auction does very well by them.'' The auction will be held May 19 and 20 at the grounds of the Museum of Flying, located where Douglas Sr. once ran his aircraft works. Aircraft offered for sale include classic ``war birds'' of World War II vintage _ Spitfires that gained fame in the Battle of Britain and P-51 Mustangs that escorted American bombers to targets over Nazi Germany. Bidding on a P-38 twin-boom Lightning fighter built by Lockheed begins at $1.1 million in the auction catalog. A reproduction of a bright red Fokker of the type flown by the Red Baron's squadron during World War I lists for a modest $25,000. The museum, sitting next to the Santa Monica Airport's runways, is on the site where Army Air Corps planes built by Douglas departed in 1924 on a historic round-the-world flight. One of the biplanes from that flight hangs in the museum. Another is at the Smithsonian Institution's Air & Space Museum in Washington. Aldrin, whose 1969 moon walk electrified the globe, joined Douglas and Schirra at the museum preview and joked about space and flight, nicknames and missions in the clouds and beyond. ``You gave me a bit of boost,'' Schirra quipped to Douglas. The auction's purpose is to raise funds for the Museum of Flying and to support scholarships for students who pursue aviation careers, said David Price, president of the 18-month-old facility. ``We believe this will be the most historic auction of antique aircraft ever,'' said Price. ``It's like mounting a Broadway show. You don't know if it's going to work until opening night.'' A few years after the war, Price noted that a shrewd bargainer could pick up a surplus P-51 Mustang at a country air field for as little as $2,000. The same plane now commands a $500,000 pricetag. A rich history has flamed the passion for planes, Price said. Hundreds of thousands of people attend air shows every year and the Air & Space Museum in Washington is the best attended of all the Smithsonian displays. ``The fighter planes hark back to chivalry and knighthood,'' said Price, who operates golf courses when he isn't flying one of his two Spitfires over the Santa Monica Mountains. Volunteers at the museum in Santa Monica point out with pride that most of the aircraft on display there can be flown. ``The kids can smell the gasoline, and they can see that these airplanes are not relics,'' Price said. ``They are something that works.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Senators Ask Iraqi Leader to Halt Arms Efforts
With AM-Britain-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Five U.S. senators urged President Saddam Hussein of Iraq on Thursday to halt efforts to develop nuclear, chemical and biological weapons, which they said created ``dangerous tensions'' in the Middle East. Senate Republican leader Bob Dole said Saddam was seriously worried that Israel planned to launch a pre-emptive strike similar to the one in June 1981, when Israeli warplanes bombed an Iraqi nuclear reactor. ``They still remember the 1981 Israeli strike, and I think there is some fear that that might recur,'' Dole told reporters after arriving from Iraq. His delegation met with Saddam in the Iraqi city of Mosul for 2{ hours. The others in the U.S. delegation were James McClure, R-Idaho; Alan Simpson, R-Wyoming; Frank Murkowski, R-Alaska; and Howrd Metzenbaum, D-Ohio. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel called for international pressure on Iraq to end such weapon programs, and he declared that Israel would use ``all the necessary means'' if attacked. Western fears over Iraq's arms programs have grown in recent weeks, and British officials said Thursday they had seized an Iraqi-bound gun that would be capable of launching nuclear or chemical warheads hundreds of miles. Dole said Saddam was upset by negative press reports about Iraq, including British revelations two weeks ago that Baghdad had tried to acquire U.S.-made triggering devices for nuclear weapons. ``I think Saddam Hussein believes there is this capability by America, the British and Israel to tarnish the image of his country and to send out false statements,'' Dole said. In a letter to the Iraqi president, the U.S. senators said Iraq's arms programs are creating ``dangerous tensions'' in the Middle East. Dole said Saddam denied either possessing or developing nuclear weapons and insisted he was not trying to make a biological weapon. However, NBC News quoted intelligence reports saying Iraq had developed germ warfare in research at the Salman Pak facility south of Baghdad. Israeli sources said Iraq was trying to make a weapon that could spread anthrax, typhoid and cholera but lacked the technology to package it in a missile warhead. Speaking to reporters earlier, Shamir called for international support in eliminating the threat posed by Iraq's reported chemical and biological warfare capabilities. Shamir, speaking at a park near Jerusalem, said in view of improving peace prospects in many parts of the world, ``it is very disagreeable and frightening to hear such voices coming from Iraq.'' ``These threats have to be eliminated by the pressure of the whole international community,'' Shamir said in response to a question. Simpson said Saddam had made it clear to the U.S. delegation that he would launch a full-scale retaliatory strike against Israel, using chemical weapons, if Israel struck first with nuclear weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Police in Jerusalem Break up Christian Protest, Fight Arabs
LaserPhoto JRL4
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Arab report that army killed activist without provocation, 10 wounded. Pickup 5th pvs, `The founding...' Edits to trim.
DOC.TEXT: Police fired tear gas Thursday to end a Christian protest over a Jewish settlement and fought Palestinian stone-throwers as foreign tourists visiting the city for Easter tried to avoid the violence. The street battles with young Arabs occurred in Jerusalem's Old City near the Church of the Holy Sepulcher as thousands of tourists were visiting this Biblical setting for Easter celebrations. The protest by Christian clerics focused on a nearby settlement of 150 Jews in the Arab Christian quarter. The Jerusalem magistrate's court, responding to a lawsuit by the Greek Orthodox Church, ruled late Thursday the settlers must leave. However, a spokesman for the settlers, David Ben-Ami, said they would appeal, and police agreed for now not to expel them. Also Thursday, the Palestinian Al-Haq-Law in the Service of Man human rights group said a Palestine activist killed last week by soldiers in the West Bank was shot in the back of the head without provocation. The group said the death of Mustafa Ali Tal Shrakeh from the West Bank's Jalazoun refugee camp was the 19th case in which it suspected Israeli forces of carrying out a ``willful killing'' during the 28-month-old uprising. The army said the youth was killed when soldiers opened fire with rubber-bullets on stone-throwers. The army has repeatedly denied it intentionally shoots Palestinians. Throughout the occupied territories Thursday 10 Palestinians were wounded in stone-throwing clashes with troops, Arab reports said. The army confirmed one of the wounded and said it was investigating the other incidents. At least 673 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers and civilians during the uprising and 206 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most as suspected collaborators with Israel. Forty-three Israelis have also died in the violence. The founding of the new settlement during Easter week particularly angered the Palestinian Christian community, which perceives it as a threat to their small neighborhood within the walled city. The new Jewish enclave also set off a dispute between Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek and the Israeli government. ``There is no question that the timing of their move lacks wisdom and sensitivity,'' Kollek said in a statement. Thursday's clash in the Old City began when police fired tear gas and pushed about 200 demonstrating clerics and supporters away from the Jewish settlement. Witnesses said police charged after a priest tore down a poster picturing an Israeli Star of David that had been pasted over a cross on the door. Greek Orthodox Patriarch Diodorus I was overcome by the gas and collapsed, witnesses said. Several other clerics were also sickened by gas, the witnesses said. Later Thursday, Arab youths raised an outlawed Palestinian flag on the roof of the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, and police chased after the youths to the Greek Orthodox patriarchate. Witnesses said stone-throwing broke out, and police fired tear gas and rubber bullets, filling the building with gas and breaking windows. The standoff ended when Kollek, who came to the patriarchate to extend Easter greetings, intervened with police. Tourists wandered through the narrow streets of the city seemed bewildered, wondering which way to go to avoid trouble. Kollek criticized the Israeli government for not intervening, saying the dispute ``has international repercussions.'' But Yossi Achimeir, spokesman for Prime Minister Yizhak Shamir, said Arab Christians were being unreasonable. ``Jews are entitled to live everywhere, especially in our eternal capital,'' Achimeir told The Associated Press. Shamir's government has consistently championed the right of Jews to settle anywhere in Jerusalem, including the Old City and Arab east Jerusalem, which were captured from Jordan in the 1967 war and annexed. President Bush last month raised a controversy in Israel by repeating that U.S. policy considers the Arab sector of Jerusalem to be disputed land. Jerusalem's Old City, divided into ethnic quarters, is home to 50,000 Moslems, about 7,000 Christians and 4,000 Jews. The latest religious dispute began Wednesday when ultra-Orthodox Jewish families moved into the four-building complex in the heart of the Christian neighborhood. The group that set up the enclave of Naot David, Hebrew for Dwellings of David, says it bought the building from a Christian. In its suit, the Greek Orthodox Church says it owns the 72-room complex where the Jews moved in under police guard. The church says the four buildings were sold illegally by a former tenant. Ben-Ami said the group was trying to re-establish the Jewish community that was driven from the area by Arab riots in 1936.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Found Guilty of Ax Attack in So-called Jack the Ripper Trial
DOC.TEXT: A judge ruled Thursday that a woman was insane when she tried to kill a man in what was portrayed as a ritual honoring Jack the Ripper. Deborah Kazuck, 27, was ordered sent to a psychiatric hospital by Circuit Judge William D. Gardner after he found her innocent by reason of insanity of attempted first-degree intentional homicide. A jury earlier Thursday convicted her of the charge; the judge decided whether she should be sent to prison or a psychiatric hospital. ``I honestly feel the judge did the right thing here,'' defense attorney Alan A. Olshan said, adding he didn't think Ms. Kazuck understood either decision in the trial. Her mother, Marilyn Kazuck, left the courtroom crying after the jury's verdict, telling a reporter her daughter was upset and suffered from psychological problems that needed attention. ``If I was crying, she was probably crying too,'' Mrs. Kazuck said. ``She needs help. Now most of all she needs help. What they have done to her _ oh.'' Mrs. Kazuck said she believed her daughter was the victim of an unfair police investigation. ``She's innocent completely. She got a raw deal all the way around.'' Deborah Kazuck testified Wednesday she never plotted the May 29 attack and only struck the man with the ax when he tried to sexually assault her. But two co-defendants, Ramona Barry and Catherine Lipsham, testified Ms. Kazuck had asked them to lure the victim, Jeffrey Meka, 27, to an apartment where they planned to kill him. Ms. Barry and Ms. Lipsham, who pleaded guilty to attempted murder last week under a plea bargain, said they and Ms. Kazuck regularly looked for victims to ``kack'' _ their code word for killing. Prosecutors told jurors Ms. Kazuck sprang from behind a shower curtain and slugged the man in the head with a hatchet, intending to kill him. Prosecutors alleged Ms. Kazuck planned to dismember Meka's body, drain his blood and eat his kidneys in a ritual she believed would resurrect Jack the Ripper, the 19th century British serial killer. Meka testified Ms. Kazuck was chanting ``redrum'' _ or ``murder'' backwards _ when she lurched at him with the ax. The blow, he said, opened a gash over his eye that required 50 stitches. Ms. Kazuck disputed those claims, but admitted she was fascinated with Jack the Ripper, and regularly carried a backpack containing a hatchet, a drill and knives. During the second phase of the trial, a defense psychiatrist testified Ms. Kazuck suffered from a mental disease and could not understand her acts were wrong. A state psychiatrist said she suffered from a personality disorder, but could be held responsible for the crime.

DOC.HEAD: August Wilson Wins Second Pulitzer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For those wishing it, this optional lead emphasizes the arts awards. Moves up last graf dealing with other arts Pulitzers to follow 8th graf, `All together...' Picks up 18th graf pvs, `Announcement of...
DOC.TEXT: Playwright August Wilson won his second Pulitzer in four years on Thursday, and the author of ``The Piano Lesson'' said he's raring to go for a third. ``I was very surprised,'' said Wilson. ``I thought, `Wow. This is No. 2.' It made me want to go right to my typewriter and start another one.'' Wilson's play won in the drama category. The Pulitzer for fiction went to ``The Mambo Kings Play Songs of Love,'' Oscar Hijuelos's novel about two Cuban brothers who find some fame in New York's nightclubs. ``In Our Image: America's Empire in the Philippines,'' by Stanley Karnow, won the award for history. ``And Their Children After Them,'' by Dale Maharidge and Michael Williamson _ which revisits the poor Alabamans who were profiled 50 years ago by James Agee and Walker Evans in their classic book, ``Let Us Now Praise Famous Men'' _ won for general non-fiction. ``The Piano Lesson'' _ the story of a sharecropper who wants to buy the land his grandfather worked as a slave, and is willing to sell the family piano to pay for it _ opens Monday on Broadway. It has played in regional theaters around the country for more than a year, and had been a Pulitzer finalist in an early form last year _ the first time a play has been a finalist for two consecutive years. The version submitted for consideration this year ``was significantly changed'' from the 1989 finalist, said Pulitzer Administrator Robert Christopher. Wilson won the 1987 Pulitzer in drama for ``Fences.'' All together, Columbia University awarded 14 prizes in journalism and seven in the arts. Each award carried with it a $3,000 prize, except the award for public service in journalism, which is a gold medal. The other arts Pulitzers went to ``Machiavelli in Hell'' by Sebastian de Grazia, for biography; ``The World Doesn't End,'' by Charles Simic, for poetry; and ``Duplicates,'' a concerto for two pianos and orchestra by Mel Powell, for music. The award for public service in journalism was given to two newspapers that exposed health menaces _ the Washington (N.C.) Daily News for an expose of carcinogens in the city water supply, and The Philadelphia Inquirer for its probe of the blood industry. Reporting on a third health threat _ the link between the dietary supplement L-tryptophan, and a rare blood disorder _ won the Pulitzer for specialized reporting for Tamar Stieber of the Albuquerque (N.M.) Journal. Ultimately, the supplement was recalled nationally. Two San Francisco Bay area newspapers won Pulitzers for their coverage of the northern California earthquake. The staff of the San Jose (Calif.) Mercury News, which published with the aid of emergency generators in the aftermath of last Oct. 17's quake, won the general news award for its coverage of the disaster. The spot news photography award went to the photo staff of The Tribune of Oakland, Calif., for pictures of the earthquake's devastation. The award unleashed ``an earthquake of happiness,'' said Tribune Publisher Robert Maynard. Other prizes honored coverage of the world's upheavals in 1989. The award for international reporting went to Nicholas D. Kristof and Sheryl WuDunn of The New York Times, a husband-and-wife team that covered the mass movement for democracy in China and its suppression. It was the Times' 61st Pulitzer, and ``a great victory for the institution of marriage,'' said Allan M. Siegal, Times assistant managing editor. David C. Turnley of the Detroit Free Press won the feature photography prize for his coverage of political uprising in China and Eastern Europe. Announcement of the awards set off celebrations around the country. ``I will say we haven't had this much excitement in this town since the Union cavalry and the Confederate cavalry chased each other up Main Street in 1862, and there's been nothing like that since,'' said Bill Coughlin, the Washington Daily News' executive editor. The Daily News revealed that carcinogens had been in the water supply for eight years, and that the local government had neither disclosed the problem nor corrected it. They broke out the champagne at the Inquirer, which won for reporter Gilbert M. Gaul's series. It was the Philadelphia newspaper's 17th Pulitzer _ and the 11th in the past six years. ``I feel great. It is a terrific honor,'' said Gaul. ``The paper showed an incredible amount of courage to allow me to spend a year and a half on the story and to report on a subject that is of great importance to everyone that we don't often think about _ blood.'' Gaul, 38, had previously won the Pulitzer Prize for investigative reporting in 1979. The blood series, which found that the industry is little regulated, was inspired by his questions about what happened to the blood he donated four times a year. It was the first time in 23 years that two newspapers were cited in the public service category. The investigative reporting award went to Lou Kilzer and Chris Ison of the Star Tribune of Minneapolis-St. Paul, for their revelation of a network of local citizens who were linked to members of the St. Paul fire department and who profited from fires. The explanatory journalism award went to David A. Vise and Steve Coll of The Washington Post for stories examining the workings of the Securities and Exchange Commission and its former chairman, John Shad. Four reporters for The Seattle Times _ Ross Anderson, Bill Dietrich, Mary Ann Gwinn and Eric Nalder _ received the national reporting award for their coverage of the Exxon Valdez oil spill and its aftermath. ``When we first heard we might have won I was on pins and needles and sick to my stomach and everything, and now I'm just covered with champagne and feeling great,'' said Nalder. For his feature writing award, Dave Curtin of the Colorado Springs (Colo.) Gazette Telegraph profiled a family that was struggling to recover from an explosion that devastated their home and left them severely burned. Other awards included: _For commentary, sports columnist Jim Murray of the Los Angeles Times. _For criticism, Allan Temko of the San Francisco Chronicle. ``Did I win?'' said the architecture critic. ``Is it true? How extraordinary. I've always been a bridesmaid.'' _For editorial writing, Thomas J. Hylton of The Mercury of Pottstown, Pa., who wrote editorials about a local bond issue for the preservation of farmland and other open space in rural Pennsylvania. _For editorial cartooning, Tom Toles of The Buffalo (N.Y.) News.

DOC.HEAD: Greenpeace Accuses U.S., British Companies of Poisoning Zulus
DOC.TEXT: The environmental group Greenpeace on Thursday accused a British company of contaminating drinking and bathing water in South Africa's KwaZulu homeland by improperly reprocessing mercury wastes. The company, Thor Chemical, denied it contaminated a river that provides the drinking supply for the KwaZulu homeland or exposed workers to poisonous fumes. Thor Chemical's mercury reclamation plant, the world's largest, receives wastes from companies in the United States, Britain, Italy, West Germany, France and Australia. Greenpeace said American Cyanamid Co. of Wayne, N.J., is one of the largest users of the plant and has shipped nearly 10 tons of toxic waste a year to the plant the past four years. There was no comment from American Cyanamid, which did not return repeated telephone calls. In a statement released in London, Greenpeace said workers at the plant are regularly exposed to mercury fumes and have suffered a variety of mental disorders. Mercury attacks the central nervous system and can cause brain damage. In a statement carried in the Greenpeace press release, the South African environmental group Earthlife said black workers at Thor Chemicals have been sent home from the plant after suffering from bouts of ``madness'' associated with mercury poisoning. Bill Garrard, managing director of Thor Chemicals, was quoted as telling the British newspaper the Guardian that workers are tested weekly for contamination and are taken off the job if they show high mercury levels. The Greenpeace statement also said sediment taken from the nearby Umgeni River showed mercury levels of 1,000 parts per million. Villagers in the government-designated homeland of KwaZulu use the water for bathing, washing and drinking. ``This is an astonishing level of contamination, among the highest ever recorded,'' Dr. Paul Johnston, an aquatic toxicologist at Queen Mary College in London, was quoted as saying in the Greenpeace statement. Johnston was quoted by the Guardian as saying the mercury contamination was ``extensive and serious,'' and that levels were hundreds of times above the World Health Organization's maximum acceptable levels for drinking water. The KwaZulu homeland in the southeastern part of South Africa is home to 7 million blacks. South Africa is the only nation that recognizes the area as independent. Greenpeace said the toxic waste has been introduced into the water supply when heavy rains carry contaminated soil into the river. Chris Priestley, a spokesman for Thor Chemicals, accused Greenpeace of ``sensationalism.'' He said if his company was contaminating water, high mercury levels would also be present in drinking water in Durban, about 50 miles downstream. Priestley said the high levels of mercury in the soil samples was due to a form of gold mining called mercury leaching, used in a nearby mine a few years ago. He said excess mercury seaped into the river from the abandoned mine, and contaminated the nearby Zulu areas, but not Durban, which is too far downstream for the contamination to affect. ``I have no evidence that leads me to believe that any contamination that is arising is coming from Thor Chemicals itself. We must now investigate and find out why this is happening,'' Priestley said. In the last two years, the growing trade in hazardous waste has prompted a number of agreements on dumping in Africa. In December 1989, the European Community signed a waste trade ban with 68 African, Caribbean and Pacific states. In May 1988 and July 1989, the Organization of African Unity adopted resolutions calling for a toxic waste import ban for Africa. South Africa is banned from membership in these groups due to the government's practice of racial discrimination.

DOC.HEAD: Former Sen. Chiles Enters Florida Gubernatorial Race
DOC.TEXT: Former Sen. Lawton Chiles, one of Florida's most popular politicians, came out of retirement Thursday to enter the Democratic gubernatorial race. Chiles, who resigned from the Senate in January 1989 saying he was ``burned out'' by big-money politics and the grind of the federal bureaucracy, said he wanted to keep Florida from going down the same path. His running mate will be former Rep. Kenneth ``Buddy'' MacKay. ``We're going to ask the people of Florida to walk with us, to walk with us to try to make this state ... what they would like it to be,'' said Chiles, who literally walked across the state in his first successful senate campaign. The 60-year-old Chiles said he looked forward to a contest against his Democratic opponents, Rep. Bill Nelson and state Sen. George Stuart, who each said Thursday they were in the race to stay. The primary is Sept. 4. ``I think George and Bill Nelson are excellent men,'' said Chiles. ``I look forward to campaigning with them. I think we can go out and talk about the issues.'' Republican Gov. Bob Martinez, who is winding up a tumultous first term in office, said Chiles' candidacy only boosts his re-election bid. ``They have some difficulty figuring out how they're going to beat me,'' said Martinez, who is expected to defeat his GOP challengers. ``The tide is going against them. They just don't have the leadership for the future.'' Nelson, 47, who was considered the front-runner prior to Chiles' candidacy, was already toughening his rhetoric. ``I can assure you that I'm not burned out. I'm ready to govern this state,'' said Nelson. ``We Democrats lost an important U.S. Senate seat two years ago when Lawton Chiles decided he was suddenly burned out with public service. ... Which job is the more mentally and physically and emotionally demanding, governor or U.S. senator?'' MacKay, a former three-term congressman, was beaten by Republican Connie Mack for Chiles' seat. In 1970, Chiles was a little-known state legislator whose populist campaign led to an upset Senate victory and endeared him to many Floridians. He was re-elected by a landslide in 1976 and 1982 and became chairman of the influential Senate Budget Committee. After leaving the Senate, Chiles became director of the LeRoy Collins Center for Public Policy, a think tank at Florida State University in Tallahassee. He resigned that position late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Five Choose To Remain In Jail After Arrests For Violating Court Order
DOC.TEXT: Five blacks protesting the ouster of the city's first black school superintendent chose to remain in jail Thursday, a day after police armed with a court order restricting protests arrested seven people. ``They're free to go at any time,'' said Police Chief Melvin Summerlin. ``They apparently don't want to leave.'' Summerlin described the situation as quiet after protesters rallied outside the jail Wednesday night in a show of support for the seven people arrested earlier in the day. Two people did post bond and were released. The protests have continued since mid-December, when the white-controlled school board refused to extend the contract of Norward Roussell, the system's first black superintendent. The arrests came after Lauderdale County Circuit Judge Leslie Johnson issued an order restricting demonstrators to the sidewalk in front of City Hall. The order also prohibits demonstrators from encouraging car drivers to honk horns, marching around the building and holding picnics in the lobby. Four of the protesters were arrested outside City Hall at noon Wednesday on charges of obstructing governmental operations for setting up chairs on the sidewalk. Three others were arrested later in the day after a scuffle involving three policemen outside a restaurant. They were charged with disorderly conduct. Summerlin said he ordered the group outside City Hall to disperse but was ignored. ``I gave them sufficient time, but it didn't appear as though they planned to listen or abide by the court order,'' he said. ``We had no choice but to make arrests.'' The incident at the restaurant Wednesday apparently was sparked when a driver was cited for blowing his horn about a block away from City Hall. Police reports said the three who were arrested were to blame for the skirmish, but a spectator, Eliza Manuel, said police chased the three for no apparent reason. In addition to the arrests, several black motorists were given tickets for blowing their car horns as they drove by City Hall, which Mayor Joe Smitherman said were deliberate acts to test the injunction. Among those arrested was lawyer Carlos Williams, 41. It was his second arrest during protests against the the city's white-controlled school board. In February, Williams and three others were arrested when they tried to force their way into the mayor's office during a protest.

DOC.HEAD: Legislator: 70 Percent of State Economy Could Be Private by 1991
DOC.TEXT: A senior legislator said Thursday that up to 70 percent of the Soviet state economy could be turned over to private hands in radical economic reforms likely to begin next year. But Pavel Bunich, deputy chairman of a Supreme Soviet committee on economic reform, was unsure whether the government would be bold enough to press that hard for such large-scale reforms. ``If we want to take small steps, we will get nowhere but to a general collapse,'' Bunich told a news conference. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said earlier this week that he will meet Saturday with his Presidential Council and the Council of the Federation to hear the government's proposals for radical economic changes. He said that reforms previously scheduled to take effect in 1992-93 _ in a plan presented by Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov four months ago _ should be moved up to this year and next. Bunich predicted that opponents of such radical reform _ a fundamental change in the state-based Soviet economy _ will complain loudly at the Supreme Soviet. But he said the reforms are likely to be approved, permitting them to go into effect in 1991. ``If we are talking about de-nationalization, about 70 percent of the public sector will cease to exist,'' Bunich said. ``There are many people who want to buy shops, workshops and small enterprises.'' Such a shift would mean not only putting business in private hands, but freeing up prices of goods produced and sold by the private sector, Bunich said.
