It also would cut drastically into the work of government ministries and the agencies that handle economic planning, pricing and supply, he said. Bunich told reporters that he did not favor a Polish-style ``shock therapy'' approach to economic reform, including a sudden freeing of prices, devaluation of the currency and rapid increases in unemployment. Public opposition and danger of social upheavals ``is the main danger we are facing here,'' he said. Instead, he said economists are looking at an approach closer to Yugoslavia's, based on wage controls. That approach has cut the rate of inflation drastically in Yugoslavia this year, he said. ``Prices are beginning to stabilize in Yugoslavia. We are studying the Yugoslav option,'' he said. Asked whether Ryzhkov's government agrees on the need to return the majority of the economy to private hands, Bunich said government ministers have ``some exact formulas, but some of them are so porous that it's just impossible to tell whether the government agrees or not.'' After Ryzhkov's government makes its proposals to Gorbachev, he is likely to address the Supreme Soviet legislature at the end of the month with a final blueprint of economic reform that will require new laws and directives.

DOC.HEAD: Firefighters Battle Blaze on Yorkshire Moors
DOC.TEXT: More than 100 firefighters worked around the clock Thursday battling a blaze that swept across about 1,000 acres of the dry, heather-covered moors of a national park. The fire threatens some of Britain's most valuable grouse moors and one of the loveliest valleys in the North Yorkshire Dales, a region known to the world from James Herriot's descriptions in ``All Creatures Great and Small.'' Additional firefighters were called in late Thursday to reinforce those who had been trying to contain the blaze that began Wednesday. Firefighters and officials of Dales National Park urged people to stay out of the area over the Easter holiday. They said they were hoping for rain. The blaze, which firefighters believe was ignited by a discarded burning cigarette, is being fanned by winds sweeping across the countryside near Leyburn, northern England. The blaze comes at the height of the grouse-breeding season, and grouse are fleeing the area and abandoning their eggs, which could mean a shortage of the birds when hunting season opens in August.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan Library Gets Chunk of Berlin Wall as Reminder of Oppression
LaserPhoto LA7
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan accepted a 3-ton chunk of the Berlin Wall on Thursday, saying the ``unnatural, ugly, unwelcome'' symbol will remind presidential library visitors of communist oppression. ``It shattered dreams and crushed hopes,'' Reagan told more than 1,000 guests gathered at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library, which is still under construction, to witness the unveiling of the 9{-foot tall, 3{-feet wide concrete slab. Moments after a white tarp was pulled away, revealing 1960s-style graffiti of a brilliantly-colored butterfly and flower design, Reagan and his wife, Nancy, walked up to the wall and touched it. Thirty-four months earlier, on June 12, 1987, the nation's 40th president stood at the Berlin Wall's Brandenberg Gate and challenged Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev: ``Mr. Gorbachev, tear down this wall!'' ``For more than 28 years, the Berlin Wall stood as an unnatural, ugly, unwelcome, undeniable symbol of the oppression of communism,'' Reagan told guests, mostly GOP faithful and contributors to the $40 million library. ``It stood as a grim reminder of what happens when dictators strip the people of their freedom,'' he said in a six-minute speech. On hand for the presentation were Leopold Siefker, the West German consul general in Los Angeles, and Norbert Reemer, minister counselor for the German Democratic Republic. The chunk to be installed in the library was supplied by the Berlin Wall Commemorative Group, an East German organization. During the 38-minute ceremony the UCLA marching band played tunes such as ``Surf City'' and ``Tequila,'' and the Bavarian Beer Garden Band played accordion ditties. Guests included Lew Wasserman, the MCA Inc. chairman who was Reagan's Hollywood agent during his movie days, former U.S. Information Agency Charles Wick and fast food burger magnate Carl Karcher. Mel Torme sang the national anthem. The 153,000-square-foot presidential library 40 miles northwest of Los Angeles is carved into a Ventura County hilltop. The concrete and steel superstructure overlooking green grass hills and beyond to the Pacific Ocean is due for completion Feb. 6, Reagan's 80th birthday.

DOC.HEAD: New York Rabbi Emerges as Key in Effort to Form Israeli Gov't
DOC.TEXT: A New York-based Hasidic rabbi who has never been to Israel emerged Thursday as a pivotal figure in deciding whether Labor Party leader Shimon Peres will be the new prime minister. A lawmaker of the Agudat Israel Party said the ultra-Orthodox faction would appeal to Brooklyn-based Rabbi Menachem Schneerson to change the minds of two Agudat members who at the last minute backed out of the party's pledge to join a Labor-led coalition. The two legislators, Avraham Verdiger and Eliezer Mizrahi, cited loyalty to Schneerson's teachings in explaining why they refused to vote for Labor on Wednesday. This blocked Peres from forming a new government. Schneerson is known as the Lubavitcher Rabbi and is revered by hundreds of thousands of Hasidic Jews. He opposes Labor's proposal to exchange parts of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip for peace with the Palestinians. He has written that the biblical land of Israel, which includes the occupied territories, was given to the Israelis by God and must never be surrendered. The involvement of Schneerson and other ultra-Orthodox religious leaders in Israeli politics has caused concern among the country's overwhelmingly secular public. ``The whole political situation depends on rabbis, not only the Lubavitcher Rabbi, but also others,'' Moshe Shahal, a senior Labor Party official, said on Israel radio. ``We are facing a new phenomenon ... the involvement of ultra-Orthodox streams of Judaism which are taking part for the first time in secular politics,'' Shahal said. Berke Wolff, a spokesman for Schneerson's Habad Movement in Israel, denied the rabbi had persuaded the two lawmakers to defect. But Israel army radio reported that at least one of the legislators was instructed by Schneerson to refuse to vote for Peres' coalition. Agudat legislator Rabbi Menachem Porusch, who negotiated the agreement with Labor, said Schneerson did not give direct instructions to the two defectors to defy the party line. ``No doubt there is a misunderstanding here,'' he said. ``I'm sure he (Schneerson) would not tell Verdiger and Mizrahi to go against the wishes of the Council of Torah Sages.'' The council's rabbis are the spiritual leaders of the Agudat Israel party and had approved the party's coalition agreement with Labor. Verdiger resigned from Parliament on Wednesday to avoid casting a vote, and Mizrahi said he would create his own faction and vote against Labor. With the defections, Labor's backing in the 120-seat Parliament fell from 61 to 59. Prior to the changes the Agudat party held five seats in parliament. In Brooklyn, a spokesmam for the Lubavitcher Hasidim, Rabbi Yehuda Krinsky, said Verdiger called the Lubavitcher Rabbi's office before the Passover holiday and asked if there had been any change in Schneerson's opposition to the land-for-peace arrangement. He was told no, and decided on his own to oppose a Labor government, Krinsky said. ``It was on his own, it was his own initiative,'' Krinsky said. He said the Lubavitvcher movement has ``not been in any of the political horse-trading that's going on.'' Israel's previous Labor-Likud coalition government collapsed March 15 over the party's differences on Middle East peace moves. Likud's leader, Yitzhak Shamir, refused to accept U.S. compromises intended to clear the way for Israeli-Palestinian talks in Cairo. He lost a vote of confidence in Parliament, leading to the government's collapse.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Opens Higher in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The dollar opened at 158.27 yen on the Tokyo foreign exchange market Friday, up from Thursday's close of 158 yen.

DOC.HEAD: Iowa Says FmHA and Elevator Operator Equally Responsible for Cleanup
DOC.TEXT: State environmental officials on Thursday held a federal agency and a grain elevator operator equally responsible for cleaning up 12,755 bushels of corn heavily tainted by a natural cancer-causing toxin. The order from the Iowa Division of Environmental Protection gave the Farmers Home Administration and the Pruess Elevator Co. of Lowden, which purchased the corn, until next Friday to remove it. But a lawyer representing the FmHA, which sold the corn from a foreclosed farm at Chouteau, Okla., and knew it was tainted, insisted the agency has no responsibility. The owner of the elevator, Harlan Pruess, continued to decline to comment Thursday. The grain is believed to have the highest concentration of aflatoxin ever found in this country, as much as 1,600 times the maximum allowable limit for human consumption, said Dale Cochran, Iowa's secretary of agriculture. Regional officials of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration in Kansas City, Mo., also said the aflatoxin level is the highest they've ever come across. Aflatoxins are cancer-causing and toxic substances produced by certain soil fuingi. The Food and Drug Administration says aflatoxin concentrations above 20 parts per billion are unsuitable for human consumption and concentrations above 300 parts per billion are unsuitable for animal feed. FDA tests of the corn found concentrations as high as 32,300 parts per billion in one sample. In its bill of sale, the FmHA disclosed that the corn contained aflatoxin concentrations greater than 5,000 parts per billion and assigned any liability to the purchaser. ``It shouldn't be fed to anything,'' said Gary Osweiler, a veterinary toxicologist at Iowa State University. An animal fed such tainted corn ``probably would become ill within a day or so. You'd probably kill animals,'' he said. An FMhA lawyer declined to say why the agency had sold the grain, except to say that the sale had not been banned by federal or state authorities. Speedy action by the Iowa Department of Agriculture prevented the corn from being fed to animals or winding up in milk or meat products, state and federal officials said. Oklahoma officials notified counterparts in Iowa once tests disclosed the aflatoxin concentrations in the early March shipment, and Iowa inspectors were on hand to quarantine the corn when it arrived. Dust from the tainted corn could be a health risk, but fortunately the corn is covered with a protective crust, in part because of the high moisture content that also enabled the fungi to grow, said Allan Stokes, director of the environmental protection division within Iowa's Department of Natural Resources. ``It's kind of like a scab. It's best not to pick on it till you know what to do,'' Stokes said. The corn is quarantined, piled on a concrete slab, surrounded by concrete retaining walls, next to the elevator in a sparsely settled area three miles outside Lowden, in eastern Iowa, Stokes said. Iowa environmental authorities set a deadline of April 20 for implementing ``an acceptable plan to get the corn out of the state or remove the threat from the corn,'' Stokes said. Stokes estimated the cleanup cost at around $100,000, while Cochran has placed it as high as $1.5 million. The grain was sold for $9,566. Robert Bird, an attorney in the U.S. Department of Agriculture's office of general counsel in Stillwater, Okla., represents the FmHA. ``I don't see how the state of Iowa could hold the FmHA co-responsible because the FmHA has no ownership interest,'' Bird said in a telephone interview. He said the FDA and the Oklahoma Department of Agriculture both knew in advance of the intended sale and if either had ``told the FmHA to destroy the corn the FmHA would do it.'' But he said aside from informing the FmHA of the maximum allowable limits of aflatoxin in animal feed or for human consumption, there was no directive banning the sale.

DOC.HEAD: Group Says It Will Unify Soviet Greens into a Party
DOC.TEXT: A group closely tied to the Communist Party and the Soviet government has organized an environmental movement and plans to transform it into a political party in the fall, members announced Thursday. Non-Communist political parties were legalized last month. There are many local environmental, or Greens, movements in the country, including one in Leningrad that has already registered as a political party. The new group, called the ``Movement for the Restoration of the Environment and Morality,'' says it will try to unite them into a single political force. The more radical environmentalists, however, may be unwilling to affiliate with such an established group. The Soviet Union is severely polluted as a result of years when any questioning of official stands, including environmental activism, could bring a prison sentence. Three officials of the new movement said it is affiliated with a group of 50 Soviet state-owned enterprises and scientific institutes that are developing environmentally sound technologies. All three men said they were Communist Party members, and the movement is modeled on the party. The organization's founding was announced in a news conference at the Foreign Ministry, giving it an official air. The group's director, Soviet legislator Alim I. Chabanov, said the movement will have its own newspaper and broadcast programs. He said it will propose anti-pollution legislation and government funding for non-polluting equipment.

DOC.HEAD: China Condemns U.S. Order to Protect Chinese Students
DOC.TEXT: China on Thursday denounced an order by President Bush to protect Chinese students in the United States from being deported. Bush's executive order, issued Wednesday, is designed to help the students avoid reprisals for supporting the pro-democracy movement crushed by Chinese forces in June. The Chinese also criticized Britain on Thursday for its plan to offer citizenship to Hong Kong residents. It reiterated that it considers all Chinese in the British colony to be citizens of China. China is to take over control of Hong Kong in 1997, but it has pledged to allow the capitalist system to remain there for 50 years and permit local autonomy. However, about 1,000 Hong Kong residents are emigrating each week, including many of the territory's best-educated people. Bush's order Wednesday followed his veto of a congressional act with the same goals in November. He said at the time he would instead issue an executive order. However, he initially put out a directive containing guidelines for immigration officials _ rather than an executive order. The action brought a rash of published reports and congressional criticism. ``At the end of last year, the Chinese government made clear its principal position on the administrative measures announced by the U.S. government,'' Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Li Jinhua said at a weekly news briefing Thursday. ``The position of the Chinese side on this issue is consistent and unequivocal.'' In criticizing the U.S. plan last year, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said, ``The sending of Chinese personnel abroad, their management, and assignment upon return are all China's internal affairs in which no foreign government or parliament has the right to interfere.'' He added, ``The allegation that Chinese personnel studying abroad might be persecuted upon their return to China is utterly groundless.'' Bush's order Wednesday allows Chinese students to remain in the United States until Jan. 1, 1994, even if their visas expire. In the complaints about the British proposal, Ms. Li said, ``The Chinese government has time and again made clear its solemn stand against the unilateral decision of Britain to change the nationality of some of the Hong Kong Chinese citizens.'' Britain plans to give passports to 50,000 Hong Kong residents to prevent a crippling brain drain in the territory before it reverts to Chinese rule. British officials hope the guarantee of citizenship will keep those residents in the colony for now. The measure was introduced in the House of Commons on Wednesday. However, it faces stiff opposition from opponents of mass immigration.

DOC.HEAD: Pulitzer Winners Whoop It Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after the 11th, ``This is a ...,'' to UPDATE with reax from Los Angeles Times.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Pulitzers, Bjt
LaserPhoto FX5
DOC.TEXT: Pulitzer Prize winners and their co-workers whooped it up, sprayed each other with champagne and cheered Thursday from Washington, N.C., to Oakland, Calif. ``I will say we haven't had this much excitement in this town since the Union cavalry and the Confederate cavalry chased each other up Main Street in 1862, and there's been nothing like that since,'' said Bill Coughlin, executive editor of the Washington Daily News, which has a circulation of 10,700. The Daily News and The Philadelphia Inquirer won Pulitzers for public service journalism; the Inquirer won for reporting on the blood industry, and the Daily News for revealing that the city water supply was contaminated with carcinogens. ``We've got a great team here _ a real bunch of pros operating at this level,'' said Coughlin, covered with champagne and speaking over shouts and marching music. ``All through covering the story, there was a great deal of pressure,'' said reporter Betty Gray. ``I'm a native of Washington. I grew up with the people that were running the city.'' Gray and Mike Voss reported the story. ``I'm ecstatic,'' Voss said. ``This is a dream come true. ... For a small town newspaper to compete and take home the biggest and the best is unbelievable.'' The Inquirer's public service prize marked the sixth straight year the newspaper has won a Pulitzer. Champagne is a tradition there: the paper has won 17 Pulitzers in 16 years. Gilbert Gaul wrote the prize-winning series on the blood industry. In 1979, Gaul and Elliot Jaspen won a Pulitzer for investigative reporting at the Pottsville (Pa.) Republican. Family was a big part of the Pulitzer picture for Nicholas D. Kristof and Sheryl WuDunn of The New York Times, who won the international reporting prize for covering political turmoil in China. They were married shortly before going overseas in March 1989. ``I can't think of any journalists who did a more superb job during those incredible days in China last year,'' said Bernard Gwertzman, the Times' foreign editor. ``This is a great victory for the institution of marriage,'' said Allan M. Siegal, Times assistant managing editor. Jim Murray, 70, widely respected sports columnist for the Los Angeles Times, won the prize for commentary. ``All the years I was in the business, I always thought Pulitzers were for overturning a government or exposing a scandal in the stock market,'' Murray said. ``I thought Walter Lippmann got Pulitzers, not us guys.'' Allan Temko of the San Francisco Chronicle, the criticism winner, was hauled away by applauding co-workers for a celebration. ``Did I win?'' he said. ``Is it true? How extraordinary. I've always been a bridesmaid.'' ``When we first heard we might have won I was on pins and needles and sick to my stomach and everything, and now I'm just covered with champagne and feeling great,'' said Eric Nalder, one of four reporters at The Seattle Times who won for national reporting. ``I'm literally speechless,'' said Tamar Stieber, 34, of the Albuquerque Journal, who won for specialized reporting for her reports linking the dietary supplement L-tryptophan to a rare blood disorder. ``It's wonderful of course _ kind of like a lifelong dream,'' said Dave Curtin, 34, winning feature writer, at the Colorado Springs Gazette Telegraph. Curtin wrote about a family's struggle to recover after its members were severely burned in an explosion that leveled the family home. Red, white and green balloons went up in The Washington Post newsroom. The explanatory journalism prize went to the Post's David A. Vise and Steve Coll, who scrutinized the Securities and Exchange Commission and its former chairman, John Shad. ``I think it's a terrific honor,'' said Vise. ``It's a proud day for me and my family and my partner, Steve Coll, who is in New Delhi, India; for the business section of The Washington Post, and for the newspaper.'' An elated, cheering staff at The Tribune of Oakland, Calif., which won the spot news photos category, spritzed newspaper executives and editors with champagne. ``The work of this staff prevailed over all of the other entries because of its incredible clarity, the intensity, the closeness to the action, the way our staff really got in close, and the compassion for the victims _ that too came through,'' said Robert Maynard, publisher. In Pottstown, about 30 miles northwest of Philadelphia, editorial writer Thomas J. Hylton was returning from the drug store to The Mercury office when he got the news. ``I'm kind of in shock,'' he said after getting a hug from editor and publisher Joe Zlomek and a round of applause from the staff of the morning newspaper with a circulation of 30,000. Hylton, 41, earned the prize for his editorials about a bond issue to preserve farmland and open space in Chester County, where suburban development is quickly changing its rural character. David C. Turnley's images of world upheavals won him a photography prize. The winning portfolio by the Paris-based photographer for the Detroit Free Press _ ``The Year in Revolution'' _ contained eight pictures from China, two from the Berlin Wall, two from Czechoslovakia and eight from Romania. Turnley, 34, got the word in Johannesburg, South Africa, in a conference call his editors set up, supposedly to talk about pending assignments. Not everyone was surprised. ``Everybody has been saying every year, `You're going to win,' '' Tom Toles, 38, the winning cartoonist, told colleagues who poured into his cubicle adjoining The Buffalo (N.Y.) News newsroom. ``All I can say is I really wanted to win it in Buffalo and now I have,'' said Toles. ``Buffalo has had its hard times and I have a special feeling for the city.'' ``I can't say it was unexpected. Everybody who saw our coverage from the outside and the inside said it was extraordinary,'' said Executive Editor Robert Ingle of the San Jose Mercury News, winner for general news reporting. In Minneapolis, Executive Editor Joel Kramer of the Star Tribune of Minneapolis-St. Paul, which won the investigative award, told a newsroom crowd that the story, ``Fire in St. Paul,'' resulted from ``old-fashioned gumshoe reporting.'' Then, after a 1{-hour celebration, Kramer announced: ``This party's almost over. We've got to put a paper out tomorrow.'' And not everyone breathlessly awaited the news. ``I had no idea it was even being announced this week,'' Oscar Hijuelos said in a telephone interview in New York. His book, ``The Mambo Kings Play Songs of Love,'' won the Pulitzer for fiction. Poetry winner Charles Simic was in Delaware on a reading tour when his wife called. ``I always hate to get these calls from my wife,'' he said. ``I always think something happened, like the car got wrecked or the basement is overflooded. But I could hear by her voice there was something special, and she told me right away. It astonished me.'' Two-time Pulitzer winner August Wilson, whose ``The Piano Lesson'' earned him the drama award, was in a hotel coffee shop when he got the news: ``I thought, `Wow, this is No. 2.' It made me want to go right to my typewriter and start another one.''

DOC.HEAD: Former W.Va. Governor Agrees to Plead Guilty to Five Counts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 20 grafs to UPDATE with comment from Moore, agreement to help investigators, details on charges; picks up 10th graf, ``Moore also ...''
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CN2
DOC.TEXT: Three-time Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. agreed Thursday to plead guilty to extorting $573,000 from a coal company, as well as mail fraud, tax fraud and obstruction of justice, a prosecutor said. The former Republican governor could be sentenced to 36 years in prison and fined $1.2 million, U.S. Attorney Michael Carey said in announcing the plea agreement and a five-count indictment at a news conference. By signing the agreement, Moore admitted committing illegal acts in his 1984 campaign, his term as governor from 1984 to 1988, and his 1988 re-election campaign. ``It's tragic for the state of West Virginia that an official of this stature was involved,'' Carey said. ``This news will be greeted with a great joy by some in the state of West Virginia,'' Moore said in a statement. ``There will be others who will be sincerely grieved by reason of their devotion to me and my family. I know I have their understanding and love. For that, I shall be ever grateful.'' Moore's Democratic successor, Gov. Gaston Caperton, said he hoped West Virginians now realize that he inherited a government that was morally bankrupt as well as financially. ``The back-room, slipshod politics of the past must forever remain in the past,'' he said. It was the second time Moore was indicted for alleged improprieties in office. He and his 1972 campaign manager were indicted in December 1975 on a charge of extorting $25,000 from the president of a shaky financial holding company trying to get a state charter for a new bank. He was acquitted in 1976. Moore is the latest West Virginia politician in recent years to either become involved in a corruption scandal or resign. Since December 1988, a state attorney general, a state treasurer, two state Senate presidents, a Senate majority leader, a top aide to a Senate president, a House member and two lobbyists have lost their jobs. Under the plea arrangement, Moore agreed to help federal prosecutors in their investigation of political corruption in West Virginia. Carey declined to provide specific cases for which Moore would provide information. The U.S. attorney said his office would make no recommendation to the federal judge who sentences Moore. He said, however, the judge would be given details of other crimes Moore allegedly committed that are not included in Thursday's indictment. Moore is accused of blocking a federal grand jury's investigation of him last year and this year, Carey said. The obstruction of justice charges allege he falsified documents and tried to persuade witnesses to commit perjury, Carey said. He also lied in an interview with federal investigators, the indictment alleged. In early January 1990, Moore met with former aide John Leaberry, who was Moore's 1988 campaign manager, the indictment said. ``Unknown to Moore, his meeting with Leaberry was recorded,'' the indictment said. ``In the meeting, Moore discussed the fact that he had received and used illegal cash in the 1988 campaign and then told Leaberry how they would both falsely deny to investigators and to the grand jury that there had been any such cash in the campaign.'' The indictment also alleged Moore used his office to extort approximately $573,000 in 1985 from H. Paul Kizer and Maben Energy Corp., a coal mining and processing company, Carey said. Moore agreed to assist Kizer and Maben Energy with receiving a refund of more than $2 million from the state's black lung fund, which provides benefits to coal miners with the respiratory disease, the indictment said. In return, Moore received about 25 percent of that refund, it said. The indictment said Kizer was responsible for a Maben Energy check being mailed to an unidentified attorney, who took $50,000 as his share and sent the remainder to Moore. Carey declined to identify the lawyer involved. Kizer is cooperating with federal prosecutors, said his attorney, James Lees. The indictment said Moore created fake, backdated documents purporting to be legitimate ``contingent fee'' legal agreements to cover up the extortion. The indictment also accused Moore of filing false income tax returns in 1984 and 1985, Carey said. It said he failed to report $40,000 in income in 1984 and $105,000 in 1985. Moore also was charged with scheming to defraud the state of his salary and benefits by funneling approximately $100,000 in cash into his 1984 campaign fund, Carey said. Carey said he did not know when Moore would be arraigned, but said it probably would be within 10 to 14 days. Moore, whose 67th birthday is Monday, was the first West Virginia governor elected to two four-year terms and the first elected to three, serving from 1969 to 1977 and from 1985 to 1989. Moore survived three decades of West Virginia's rough-and-tumble politics despite a 2-to-1 registration edge for the Democrats and almost constant controversy. He served one term in the state House of Delegates from 1953 to 1954 and was elected to Congress in 1956. At 33, Moore was the youngest freshman in the 85th Congress and represented the state's Northern Panhandle for six terms. In 1968, Moore gave up his House seat to run for governor. He was prevented from seeking a third consecutive term by a provision of the state Constitution and was succeeded by Democrat Jay Rockefeller in January 1977. Moore was dogged by controversy even out of office. In August 1979, his former state liquor commissioner, J. Richard Barber, was convicted of racketeering, extortion and mail fraud involving charges that Barber received cash and free liquor from distillers. The trial included testimony that some of the cash was used for campaign contributions, and some of the liquor was passed on to the governor's office. Barber was sentenced to three years in prison. Moore won the governorship for the third time in 1984. However, in that term Moore presided over a state government in extreme financial difficulty, unable to pay its bills and forced to borrow heavily. His tenure ended in dramatic defeat when Democratic newcomer Gaston Caperton routed him in the 1988 election.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Stagehands' Union Goes On Strike
DOC.TEXT: About 200 members of a stagehands' union local went on strike against CBS on Thursday after ``last-ditch'' contract talks ended in failure, a union spokeswoman said. The strike by members of Local One of the International Alliance of Theatrical and Stage Employees is only against CBS' New York facilities. The network's Los Angeles studios have separate contracts with the union. The walkout, called after negotiations broke down Wednesday, was the first against CBS since about 300 Writers Guild members struck CBS News for seven weeks in 1987. Members of the union had been working without a contract since Dec. 31, said union spokeswoman Deborah Friedman. She said the strike also was against CBS-owned WCBS-TV here. ``We don't expect that it's going to affect our day-to-day operations,'' said CBS spokeswoman Ann Morfogen. ``There are contingency plans that can be put into effect as necessary.'' No new talks with the union are scheduled, she said.

DOC.HEAD: East German Holocaust Apology Welcomed in Israel
With AM-East Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Israel welcomed East Germany's apology Thursday for the atrocities of the Holocaust, but one senior official, a survivor of the Nazi camps, said he could never grant forgiveness for the murder of 6 million Jews. The declaration by East Germany's first freely elected Parliament marked the first time the country formally accepted responsibility for Nazi crimes against Jews and said it was prepared to pay reparations to victims. Israeli officials said the declaration could ease the way toward establishing ties between the two countries. But Parliament Speaker Dov Shilansky, a survivor of the Dachau concentration camp, said he would never forgive the killing of 6 million Jews during World War II. ``I, who have been there and have seen with my own eyes what happened there, say that even in a thousand years, the shame of Germany will not be erased,'' Shilansky told The Associated Press. Yossi Ahimeir, a spokesman for Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, said that ``at first glance, it looks like a positive announcement.'' Asked to decribe the view of the Polish-born Shamir, who lost most of his family in the Holocaust, Ahimeir said: ``The prime minister knows to put a line between the past and the future, even though the memories are very strong at the bottom of his heart.'' East Germany's hard-line Communist rulers, whose 40-year-rule was ended last fall in a popular revolt, refused to accept responsibility for the Holocaust, arguing that they themselves were persecuted by the Nazis. West Germany apologized many years ago for Nazi atrocities and has paid hundreds of millions of dollars in reparations to Jewish victims. Parliament also suggested East Germany was willing to pay reparations, saying it would ``do everything in its power to contribute to the healing of emotional and physical suffering of the survivors, and to fight for a just compensation for material losses.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Attends Comedy About Widows and Death
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, with his wife Barbara and daughter Dorothy LeBlond went to the theater Thursday night to see a new comedy about three widows. The nearly full house at the Kennedy Center for ``The Cemetery Club'' by Ivan Menchell gave Bush a standing ovation before the curtain went up as he waved from his seat and shook hands with a couple in a box adjacent to his center presidential box. The play, starring Eileen Heckart, Elizabeth Franz and Doris Belack, is about three women who get together monthly to visit the graves of their husbands. It features a set that transforms ingeniously from a living room to a cemetery and back again in a few seconds. One line might appeal to grandmothers, including Mrs. Bush, on pointers for grandparents: ``You don't need any. You just sit back and enjoy them and watch them do to your children what your children did to you.'' With the president were his campaign press secretary, Shiela Tate, and her husband Bill; Transportation Department official Julie Andrews; Susy Peake, who worked for Bush when he was vice president and Greg Petersmeyer, head of the Office of National Service and Points of Light.

DOC.HEAD: Exiled Romanian King Barred From Returning to Homeland
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf, `In Romania...' with 2 grafs to CORRECT that Michael has five daughters, ADD details. Pickup 15th graf pvs, `Michael was...'
DOC.TEXT: Exiled King Michael of Romania was barred from returning to his homeland Thursday when the Romanian government canceled his visa and said the monarch's first visit in 43 years might promote unrest. The 68-year-old ex-king told an airport news conference in Zurich, Switzerland, his visit would have been ``strictly private.'' ``I don't understand the decision to rescind the visas. I don't know what concerns there could have been,'' he declared. He was to have been accompanied by his wife, Queen Anne, and his eldest daughter, Princess Margarita. Their visas were also rescinded. Romania's provisional, post-revolutionary government had appealed to Michael to postpone his visit until after May 20 elections to prevent possible disturbances. In Bucharest, several hundred Romanians who had gathered to welcome the ex-king broke into chants of ``Shame, shame!'' and ``Down with the Communists!'' when they heard he was not coming. The king was booked on a Swissair flight from Zurich to Bucharest Thursday at noon, but the airline management decided not to let him board the plane. He learned of the cancellation of the visas only after leaving his home near Geneva. In an interview with France's state-run Antenne 2 television channel Thursday, Romanian Prime Minister Petre Roman said Michael had planned to attend a demonstration in the western city of Timisoara, where the December revolution began. He said the visit would have been covered by about 80 journalists flown in especially by chartered plane. ``Thus it was not at all a private visit, which we would not have objected to, but a visit of a political character which was opposed by practically all political factions and by public opinion,'' Roman said. Silviu Brucan, chief ideologue of the National Salvation Front, the dominant power in Romania's provisional government, called the visit ``a very controversial political issue.'' ``We are striving to calm down public opinion,'' Brucan said, referring to the ethnic violence in Transylvania last month that left at least six people dead. On Wednesday, the Bucharest government warned in a statement that ``there is the possibility of some violent manifestations'' if the visit took place. It said Michael's visit before the elections could ``exacerbate existing conflicts, while also endangering his personal security.'' When asked at the airport to speculate on Bucharest's motives, Michael said he had ``no idea at this moment.'' But he said he was still planning a visit ``as soon as possible.'' In Romania, Princess Helen, one of Michael's five daughters, said ``no words can express the sorrow of my father'' at being barred from Romania during Easter celebrations. She and her sister Sophie arrived in the country a few days ago with aid shipments. Michael's other daughters _ Margarita, Anne and Marie _ live in exile. Michael was forced to abdicate by a Soviet-installed government Dec. 30, 1947. He had intended to stay no longer than 10 days in Romania. Michael, who has been living near Geneva for the past 30 years, denounced his abdication shortly after he arrived in exile, saying he signed the act after being told a refusal would set off a massacre of his supporters. After the overthrow of Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu in December, Michael said he was prepared to return to Romania as head of a constitutional monarchy. But he indicated that this would have to be subject to a referendum.

DOC.HEAD: Racial Unrest Shatters Calm in Suburb Proud of Its Integration Record
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 19th graf, `But people...,' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with black minister saying problems had existed between blacks and police.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NR2,4,5,8, LaserColor 6
DOC.TEXT: Street violence over the fatal shooting of a black teen-ager by a white policeman strained racial relations Thursday in this tightly knit suburb, which has prided itself on racial harmony for decades. Teen-agers, mostly blacks, roamed city streets after a night of smashing windows and overturning cars. The Wednesday night violence broke out after a peaceful candlelight protest over Tuesday's death of 15-year-old Phillip Pannell of River Edge. The crowd of about 1,000 protesters called for a special prosecutor to investigate the shooting. Gov. Jim Florio asked for calm, but said he saw no reason to appoint a special prosecutor because the county prosecutor is a deputy attorney general. Florio also said he would not put the National Guard on alert. ``I am being kept informed of events there, and I will await further investigation before determining what other action by state officials may be required,'' he said at a Statehouse news conference in Trenton. City police Chief Bryan Burke held a news conference outside police headquarters and warned against further violence. ``It's stopped as far as I'm concerned,'' Burke said. ``We're not going to tolerate any more unlawfulness. There will be arrests.'' The chief promised a large contingent of local, county and state police would remain in the New York City suburb for about a week. He declined to estimate property damage from Wednesday night's violence but said six police cars were destroyed. Many store windows were shattered. Witnesses said police pushed the protesters into the parking lot of police headquarters and some women and children were trampled. The crowd retaliated by turning over cars, and throwing rocks and other debris through the windows of the municipal building. Four police officers and at least three civilians were injured. None of the injuries appeared serious. An attorney for the boy's family, Franklin Wilks, said he had notified the borough, county and state that a lawsuit was planned. Pannell's mother, Thelma Pannell, told a news conference Thursday that the lawsuit would help keep the case open. ``They can kill all the black kids until people realize that it could be their sons who get killed,'' Ms. Pannell said. ``It's not going to stop here. My son will not die like this, shot in the back.'' Others, however, both black and white, readily spoke about the predominantly positive racial relations in this town of 37,000 people eight miles from New York. State Sen. Matthew Feldman, a former mayor, said this community has prided itself on its ability for people of all races to live in harmony. ``This is the first town in America to integrate, and we did it ourselves, not by order of the Supreme Court,'' Feldman said, referring to the city's voluntary integration of its schools in the 1960s. On April 1, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and the B'nai B'rith honored Feldman, who is white, and Municipal Judge Isaac McNatt, who is black, for their efforts in achieving racial harmony between Jews and blacks in Teaneck. But people also talked about the shooting, and some said it had been preceded by ill will between the police department and black men in town. The Rev. Glenn Wilson, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church and a speaker at the vigil Wednesday, said that he and other blacks often are pulled over by police. ``It may not be Camelot, but there is a nice climate here,'' he said. ``Unfortunately the problem is between the black community and the police. They stop blacks on a routine basis. Certain police officers single out youths for selective law enforcement.'' ``Things won't go back to normal, not until the cop goes on trial for murder,'' said Maurice Jones, 17, a black Teaneck High School student. Adults on both sides of racial lines in this town, where 64 percent of the residents are white and 24 percent are black, talked about Pannell's shooting. ``It's not black against white. It's a matter of a policeman who made a terrible mistake. We need to put a cap on this right now,'' said resident Robert Robinson, who is black. Officer Gary Spath, 29, who fired the fatal shot, reported to the prosecutor's office to answer questions on the shooting of Pannell, who died from a single gunshot in the back. Spath was suspended with pay, and his gun was impounded as evidence, officials said. Burke said Spath was responding to an anonymous telephone tip that a teen-ager had drawn a gun on another youth. Acting Bergen County Prosecutor John Holl said police told him a gun was found on the youth's body, a contention that some of Pannell's friends denied. Spath last month received his fifth commendation from the Teaneck Policeman's Benevolent Association since he joined the department in 1982. Mayor Frank Hall, a white who has been on borough council for 24 years and said he was involved in the 1960s integration of the schools, said the violence may have been caused by ``outside agitators'' who wore red hats or scarves and broke away from Wednesday's vigil. ``There were many cars with New York plates. You could say they came to help their brothers. And that's fine, but they don't have a stake in Teaneck like we do,'' Hall said.

The Bush administration is preparing a proposal to ease restrictions on sales of high-technology items to the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe, but the changes likely will not go far enough to satisfy Western allies. Commerce Undersecretary Dennis Kloske, who supervises export control activities, said Wednesday there was growing agreement in the administration over the actions needed to provide Western technology to the struggling economies of Poland, Hungary and other former communist bloc countries. The administration is conducting a review, and recommendations on what changes can be made without jeopardizing national security should be presented to President Bush by the end of this month, Kloske said. ``There is an emerging consensus inside the administration that the changing developments in Eastern Europe will allow for a significant level of streamlining'' of export controls, Kloske told business executives attending a U.S. Chamber of Commerce trade seminar.

British news reports today linked a murdered American ballistics expert with an alleged plot by Iraq to construct a huge gun capable of firing nuclear or chemical shells hundreds of miles. Eight crates awaiting shipment to Iraq when they were seized by customs agents at the northeast English port of Middlesbrough included what were believed to be parts for a 131-foot gun barrel, the British news agency Press Association said. This would be the largest gun barrel ever made. A spokesman for Britain's Customs and Excise Department said Wednesday: ``Last night we intercepted a consignment of goods being loaded upon a ship that was destined for Iraq, a ship that had been chartered by the Iraqi Maritime Services. The goods appear to be of a military nature.'' Iraq denied this. The official Iraqi news agency said the consignment was steel pipes for a petrochemical project.

Doctors' decisions to give tests or take X-rays depend in part on how much money they make on them, a study today says. The research supports the widely held but hard to document idea that doctors' own financial interests play a role in determining the kind and amount of care they give their patients. ``As in most professions, money matters,'' said David Hemenway, a Harvard School of Public Health economist who directed the study. The report, in today's New England Journal of Medicine, measured what happened when a chain of walk-in clinics changed the way it paid its doctors. Instead of a flat hourly wage, doctors could earn a percentage of all the fees they generated. With this financial incentive, they boosted the number of tests and X-rays they performed by about 20 percent. The study was conducted in 1984 and 1985 at Boston-area offices of Health Stop, the nation's biggest chain of walk-in clinics with 80 centers in six states.

An experimental AIDS drug injected into two pregnant monkeys reached their fetuses, raising hope that it might block AIDS virus infection of human babies by their mothers, scientists said today. If used early enough in pregnancy, it might ward off perinatal AIDS infection, said study co-author Daniel Capon of Genentech Inc. of South San Francisco. The drug reached the fetuses about as easily as a human mother's natural proteins do as they build up disease resistance within babies, researchers said. The drug, called a CD4 immunoadhesin, has shown promise against the AIDS virus in the test tube, but its effectiveness in people is not yet known.

With the pomp and circumstance usually reserved for state funerals, the rich and famous joined in paying final respects to Ryan White, who fought prejudice against AIDS sufferers during his long battle with the disease. The funeral, attended by 1,500 people and broadcast live on CNN, showed how the articulate, poised 18-year-old had touched the nation's heart with his pleas for understanding. First lady Barbara Bush led the ceremony, also attended by pop stars Michael Jackson and Elton John. The Rev. Raymond Probasco encouraged the mourners to continue to seek a cure for acquired immune deficiency syndrome. ``With God's help, and each of yours, we'll make AIDS a disease and not a dirty word,'' said Probasco, pastor at Center Chapel United Methodist Church in Muncie.

DOC.HEAD: NBC's Folksy ``Down Home'' Has Goshdurn Lame Scripts
DOC.TEXT: As a rule, any sitcom that needs more than two executive producers tends to be lame. NBC's new ``Down Home'' has three, including ``Cheers'' star Ted Danson. On the bright side, it's not about teen-age mutant ninja turtles. That should count for something. Premiering Saturday after what NBC called a ``special preview'' on Thursday, ``Down Home'' stars Judith Ivey, a fine Broadway actress who has Tony awards for her work in ``Steaming'' and ``Hurlyburly.'' But here, she seems like a fish out of water. This is not good, since ``Down Home'' is set in a Texas seacoast fishing village. Thursday's preview established that she plays Kate McCrorey, a successful New York management consultant who returns home on vacation to the little village to find her dad's cafe and bait shop business failing. Worse, a developer represented by her old boyfriend (Ray Baker) of 15 years ago wants to demolish the village and turn it into one of those resorts that have hotels, time-share condos, minimalls and probably cable TV. Well, by neddies, she decides to forgo Fun City and her career there and help her daddy (Dakin Matthews) fight what passes for progress. That's pretty much it, although it took a while for her to reach that decision, not to mention be kissed by and fight with her old flambee. In between, the preview presented the other regulars, among them her hulking brother (Eric Allen Kramer) and a young, optimistic Vietnamese refugee (Gedde Watanabe), the cook and dishwasher at the cafe. Although strained, Thursday's premiere did have a few good moments, the first when the town's laconic mayor, a fisherman, drifted into the cafe and was greeted with a jovial, ``How the fish treatin' you?'' His off-hand reply: ``Aw, better than the missus. They ain't bitin'.'' (It should be noted that Tim Scott is a standout in his deadpan mayoral role. He seems a keen student of good ol' boy Texas ways, even to the point of wearing a faded Vietnam-era Marine camouflage jacket in one scene.) But Saturday's premiere, about fishing, football and daring to dream, is so thin on plot and dialogue it wouldn't even get a coveted Emmy award for Best Lame Episode of a Comedy Series With Three Executive Producers. Ivey gives both episodes her best shot. But she often seems to be pressing, as if hoping her vitality will hide the fact that the scripts basically are a case of nobody home. Incidental note: The closing credits of Thursday's preview had 10 people listed as ``assistants.'' In Saturday's show, the number rises to 12. If it goes up to 14 assistants next time, we're asking Geraldo Rivera to fly to Hollywood and see what gives.

Elsewhere in television ... TUNE-IN TIME: If you get cable's Home Box Office, don't miss Carly Simon's ``Carly in Concert: My Romance'' on Sunday. It's a classy show, the fine old romantic kind of concert that even has a string orchestra. Generous in sharing the spotlight with visitor Harry Connick Jr., whom she puckishly describes as ``at 22, the grand old man of standards,'' Simon gives lovely readings to a good collection of standards, among ``My Funny Valentine'' and ``By Myself.'' She also includes a few Simon standards, of course, and does a wonderful, exuberant bossa nova version of ``We Have No Secrets.'' If you miss Sunday's show, not to worry. It'll be rerun five more times. If you're not among the 17.3 million cable viewers who pay extra for HBO, get her new ``My Romance'' album. It features many of the same songs and the same tasty Marty Paich string arrangements. THE THRILL OF VICTORY, THE AGONY OF THIRD: This TV season ends Sunday, and while this week's Nielsens for prime time won't be available until Tuesday, ratings analysts say NBC easily will win its fifth consecutive season and that ABC will be No. 2 again. CBS, which once led the pack, will be third for the third consecutive season. That's costly, both in image and advertising revenue.

DOC.HEAD: Galway Embarks on Another Musical Adventure
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: James Galway loves to travel with his audiences on musical adventures that make different tunes dance from his flute. He plays Beethoven with a smile, and Irish ballads with The Chieftains. Last year he toured with 30 children and the Baltimore Symphony as the ``Pied Piper of Hamelin'' in a musical fantasy written especially for him by composer John Corigliano. Now he's coming out with a new LP ``The Enchanted Forest.'' Galway teamed up with a roomful of synthesizers to make the album, and then topped it off with an MTV video. But Galway doesn't know how to describe the new work, because he dislikes labels. ``So don't call it new wave,'' he said. ``Just call it a unique type of which there is no other like it.'' Galway loves music and his temper can flare up at anyone or anything that tries to complicate it. Even the contracts he must sign for all of his ventures must be straightforward. ``We have a rule in our office. If we can't read it. We don't sign it,'' he says. Last year he turned 50, and Classical magazine calls this period ``the golden days of Galway'' as the flutist allows himself to pick and choose his schedule. ``I can think of a lot of things I want to do and what I can't think of, somebody else does,'' he says with a laugh. ``I sure don't need the money, so I do the ones I want to do.'' He makes his opera debut April 16 in a new production of Rossini's ``The Thieving Magpie.'' The next evening, he begins a tour in California that ends May 9 in New York, with a stop at ``The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson.'' ``He has a performance schedule that goes from here to there and back,'' interjects his wife, Jeanne, who travels with him. She performs with him in chamber groups, and will play the part of the magpie in the second and final Philadelphia performance on April 20. The idea to play the title role in Rossini's ``The Thieving Magpie'' was not Galway's. ``I had never thought of it before and no one else did it before. So I decided to do it,'' Galway says. The opera had its American debut in 1827 in Philadelphia. But no flutist has ever been cast as the magpie. During rehearsals in Philadelphia, Galway's impish side surfaced from time to time. At one point he put a ``boom box'' on his shoulder and said: ``James Galway and the 20 best hits from the street. How's that for my new album?'' Underneath the wit, the blunt charm and the bantering nature that has endeared him to audiences, Galway is very serious about his craft and is devoted to practice sessions. He's also fiercely independent about his way, whatever way that may be at the moment, of playing. ``I wouldn't play in an orchestra now,'' he says. ``I wouldn't want to narrow my music down.'' However, Galway did branch into serious acting once. ``I needed money while I was between Guildhall (School in London) and the Paris Conservatory. So I took a year off and did Shakespeare at Stratford-on-Avon,'' he said. But he said he was never serious about a switch. ``I've always thought of music. Nothing else.'' It was the combination of acting and music, complete with a costume and intricate staging while playing his magic flute, that appealed to Galway in doing the opera. Rossini originally wrote the work using an actor as the magpie who stole the silver spoon and caused a young servant girl to be sentenced to death. The Opera Company of Philadelphia decided in the first American production of the work in this century to create a special role for someone such as Galway. The rolling notes that Galway plays as he flits about the stage were borrowed from passages Rossini wrote for the violin and flute as parts of the orchestra. For his motions on stage, Galway draws on his own observations of the bird, an outgrowth of his interest in the animal kingdom. He talked about the latest television program he had enjoyed on animals in the wild, then with a burst of Galway directness denied that his performance was to be a statement on anything but music. ``I didn't study birds for years to do this. I studied music,'' he says. ``It just so happens that I would know a dead magpie in the road if I saw one.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Army Despised in Poland, but Will Stay for Now
DOC.TEXT: Last year, Poles showered Soviet soldiers with rocks and bottles 21 times during a 210-mile training march. This year, Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki opposes a speedy Red Army withdrawal. They have disdained Soviet soldiers for decades, but Poles seem to understand Mazowiecki's point. Poland has not joined Czechoslovakia and Hungary in the rush to be free of the Red Army _ not because it loathes the ``occupiers'' less, but because it fears the army of a reunited Germany at least as much. The Solidarity prime minister, leader of the first non-Communist government to take office in the former Soviet bloc, envisions a Soviet withdrawal only within an overall security arrangement for Europe. A survey by television's Center for Public Opinion Research in March indicated 47 percent of Poles felt the Red Army should go, but the date should depend on events in Germany. ``Maybe a year ago, people would say the Soviet troops shouldn't be here, that their presence was more like a political presence,'' said Franciszek Grzywacz, a magazine editor in the garrison town of Legnica. ``Now people are saying it is a kind of a shield against Germany.'' Poland's predicament is as old as its geographical position between Germany and Russia, and has led new voices to utter a version of the old regime's argument. For decades, the Communists used the danger from Germany, combined with the general threat from the West, to support Poland's alliance with Moscow and the Red Army presence. Most estimates put the number of Soviet soldiers in Poland at 40,000 to 45,000, well below the 380,000 in East Germany, 80,000 in Czechoslovakia and 65,000 in Hungary. Those in Poland, however, form the supply link from the Soviet Union to the East German frontier of the Warsaw Pact. One of the most important Soviet military headquarters, the Western Theater of Military Operations, is in Legnica, in southwestern Poland, 55 miles from East Germany. The headquarters would coordinate a Warsaw Pact offensive, using the Baltic fleet, air force support and troops from across Eastern Europe. Legnica, 250 miles southeast of Warsaw, is one of the few places in Poland where the Red Army is visible. The well-preserved painted brick architecture is a reminder of the town's place in the swath of Silesian territory taken from Germany after World War II. Most of its 100,000 people, however, are Poles uprooted from eastern territories annexed by the Soviet Union under Josef Stalin. That adds emotion to the atmosphere as Soviet officers stroll the streets and black Russian limousines rush commanders to and from prewar mansions in a vast Red Army compound enclosed by by a 7-foot concrete wall. Tales of Soviet army abuses are legion: secret installations in the forest, bombs gone astray, ditches running black with leaking fuel from military airports, low-flying planes buzzing farms. Russian-bashing is a popular sport: Soviet soldiers live rent-free and make slums of the scarce apartments denied to Poles, cover windows with copies of Pravda instead of curtains, throw garbage out the windows, favor strip shows, are above Polish law when they commit crimes or cause traffic accidents. ``If the Soviets go home, people in this town will have nothing to talk about,'' said Grzywacz, the magazine editor. Teacher Jolanta Tochinecka does not see the Red Army as a safeguard. ``Poles know they can rely only on themselves,'' he said. ``That was shown in 1939,'' when the German invasion of Poland started World War II. Scrawled slogans may say ``Tanks to the Volga,'' and one roughly translates to ``Soviets go back to your garbage,'' but the soldiers are an economic benefit to Legnica. There is a brisk trade in Soviet gold and television sets outside the elegant turn-of-the-century officers' center. Shopkeepers rely on the well-paid soldiers and their families, who relish the relatively comfortable five-year tours in Poland. Residents speak gratefully of access to sophisticated hospitals and some other facilities _ the Soviets have their own schools, police force, book stores and work crews _ but the communities are largely separate. ``There are not two sides of town,'' Grzywacz said. ``There are two cities.'' Soviet troops came to Poland ``temporarily'' under a 1956 agreement that contains assurances of Polish sovereignty and provisions that the Kremlin will pay for their upkeep. In Czechoslovakia and Hungary, negotiations already have turned Soviet soldiers toward home. The Red Army has been in those countries since it crushed Hungary's anti-Stalinist uprising of 1956 and the Czechoslovak ``Prague spring'' liberalization of 1968. It was Moscow that proposed talks on leaving Poland. Mazowiecki's government announced in March that discussions would begin on finances and the ``inconveniences'' suffered by communities where Soviet soldiers are stationed. The Polish subsidy for the troops amounted to 26 billion zlotys ($2.7 million) in 1989, according to statistics compiled by Radio Free Europe. Solidarity leader Lech Walesa has demanded the Soviets withdraw this year, but government spokeswoman Malgorzata Niezabitowska said in mid-March: ``Poland is at work on the proposals to be presented during the Vienna negotiations regarding the overall withdrawal of Soviet troops in the context of a new European security system.''

DOC.HEAD: Candidates See Smart Politics in Death Penalty
DOC.TEXT: The boos drowned out Dianne Feinstein when she told California Democrats, ``Yes, I support the death penalty.'' But the former San Francisco mayor was betting that her stand would draw cheers from voters worried about drugs and crime. Her judgment is echoed in campaigns from California to the Eastern seaboard, from the Sun Belt to the Rust Belt. It is an election year in which death and politics are locked in a rhetorical embrace and candidates engage in macabre numbers games. In a campaign ad, Republican Gov. Bob Martinez of Florida proclaims he has signed ``some 90 death warrants.'' But only five people have been executed since Martinez took office in 1987. ``As district attorney and attorney general he's put or kept 277 murderers on death row,'' said an ad for John Van de Kamp, who says he personally opposes capital punishment. Nobody's been executed in 23 years in California, where Van de Kamp and Feinstein are battling for the Democratic nomination for governor. ``There's a very clear consensus all over the electorate that the death penalty is a good thing,'' said Republican political consultant Charles Black. Lynn Cutler, a vice chair of the Democratic National Committee, lamented the fact that so many candidates ``glory'' about their roles in executions. But she conceded that the majority of the people strongly support the death penalty. ``The death penalty has become this sort of simplistic litmus test or symbolic test of whether you're tough on crime,'' said Frank Greer, a Democratic consultant who questions whether voters will be satisfied with ringing endorsements of capital punishment. ``You can make a case that a lot of people will wake up to find voters expect more,'' said Greer. He found support for his case in Texas, where state Treasurer Ann Richards won a vicious contest for the Democratic nomination for governor. Richards' two opponents _ former Gov. Mark White and Attorney General Jim Mattox _ competed for the right to claim they had executed the most criminals, prompting a Richards aide to quip: ``Maybe the next step will be scratch-and-sniff ads so voters can sample the smell of the death chamber.'' ``My view on the death penalty is that it's the law and that the law should be carried out,'' said Richards, who rarely mentioned the issue. She once referred to White's ads _ which showed him walking past giant mug shots of criminals executed while he was governor _ and said: ``I think perhaps they are contrasting me with a guy who goes on TV and struts up and down in front of pictures of people who have been executed. It's macabre and strange.'' Time may prove Greer right. But the consensus among politicians, including Greer client Andrew Young, is that the place to be is in support of capital punishment. ``The state has got to have the right to put mad dogs to death,'' said Young, the former mayor of Atlanta who is campaigning for governor of Georgia. Long an opponent of capital punishment, Young said his view began to change after he ``went to a half dozen policemen's funerals'' while mayor. Van de Kamp, the early favorite to win California's Democratic gubernatorial primary, suddenly found himself scrambling after polls showed Feinstein soaring into the lead. Analysts were divided on whether her surge was attributable to a particular issue like capital punishment or the result of a large television buy during a period when Van de Kamp was not running commercials. But it was clear that Van de Kamp and his strategists thought he'd better edge away from his opposition to the death penalty. As state attorney general, Van de Kamp took a prominent role in asking the U.S. Supreme Court to end a stay of execution granted Robert Alton Harris, a prisoner on death row in San Quentin prison. ``This is a man who said he didn't believe in the death penalty up until the time he began running for governor,'' said Feinstein. ``I am running the law office responsible for handling the case,'' Van de Kamp responded angrily. The most prominent exception to the rhetorical rush to the execution chamber is Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York. Cuomo is expected to run for a third term this year and his name is always high on lists of presidential prospects. Lee Miringoff of the Marist College Institute of Public Opinion, said his polls of New York voters have found little evidence Cuomo is hurt by his opposition to the death penalty despite polls showing overwhelming public support for capital punishment. ``No one's going to accuse Mario Cuomo of making policy by public opinion polls,'' said Miringoff. ``The fact that Mario Cuomo opposes the death penalty and has a proposal for life imprisonment without parole comes as no news to New Yorkers. He's able to make in New York the case that he's a man of strong convictions so that even if you disagree with him on this issue it doesn't affect your overall view of him.''

DOC.HEAD: Crimes Over Clothing Prompt Schools' Return to Dress Codes, Uniforms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, ``In Chicago ... the back,'' to INSERT dropped word ``than,'' and 11th graf, ``In a ... citywide statistics,'' to fix style on ``acknowledgment''; PICKS UP 12th graf, ``We are ...''
DOC.TEXT: It is a modern urban phenomenon: kids robbing _ and sometimes killing _ other kids over the hottest designer sneakers, sunglasses or athletic jackets. In Chicago alone, four young men have died in little more than a year over multi-colored, satiny jackets with splashy team logos across the back. Those not dying for their clothing might instead be robbed. On an icy day this winter, an 11-year-old boy was forced to hand over his $61 gym shoes to four youths, then walk the several blocks to his home barefoot, one of scores of incidents that occur each month, police say. ``Kids who try to keep their jackets are beaten or killed,'' said Sollie Vincent, commander of the Gang Crimes Section of the Chicago police. ``It's a very cold, callous frame of mind.'' To combat the problem, schools from Baltimore to Miami to Los Angeles are falling back on an old idea: dress codes. Some public schools even have instituted uniforms, traditionally associated with parochial schools. ``It's a definite trend,'' said Tim Callahan, a spokesman for the National Association of State Boards of Education. ``Kids are going to learn best in an environment free of undue, inappropriate pressures, and certainly one that's free of violence. ``If clothing becomes a disruption to education, then we certainly are supportive of removing that barrier,'' he said. ``Starter'' jackets _ athletic jackets named for their manufacturer, Starter Sportswear Inc. of New Haven, Conn. _ have sparked numerous crimes in Chicago, including four murders, police say. In a grim acknowledgment of the garment's popularity, the police department last year created a separate category for ``Starter jacket murders'' in its citywide statistics. ``We are hoping these are isolated situations that are not long-term,'' said Thomas McAuliffe, human resources director for Starter. ``We have a responsible attitude towards the communities in which we have operations.'' Educators say dress codes that eliminate some popular items and, in some cases, gang colors, not only help stem violence but allow students to concentrate on learning. ``We try to discourage children from buying hot items,'' says Jim Murray, assistant principal at a middle school in Chicago's troubled Englewood neighborhood. ``When they don't wear those items to school, they don't have problems.'' ``We have found that, subtly, it is changing attitudes,'' Alberta Mitchell, counselor at Hendricks Academy, said of the Chicago public elementary school's new uniform policy. ``The children are not supposed to wear gym shoes, so that eliminates the problem of buying brand-name gym shoes symbolizing status,'' Miss Mitchell said. ``We are trying to eliminate the problem of children feeling like they have to have designer-type clothes. It seems to have a calming effect.'' In Chicago, as in many of the nation's largest school districts, dress codes are the prerogative of individual schools. In Baltimore, uniforms are recommended, although not mandatory, for elementary school students, and a dress code is suggested for secondary schools. Educators say uniforms now are the norm at 74 of the city's 118 elementary schools. School officials can't recall any crimes over clothing since the policy was instituted last fall, and Baltimore police say the problem virtually has disappeared. ``It still happens, but not with any frequency,'' said police spokesman Dennis Hill. Next fall, high schools in Detroit will have the option of adopting a dress code. The new policy by Detroit's Board of Education was prompted in part by the December shooting of a student over his $135 goose-down jacket. Detroit police say crimes over clothing are on the decline. ``It's not like the old days 10 years ago,'' said Sgt. Christopher Buck. In New York's Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood, a high school principal earlier this year barred students from wearing removable gold caps on their teeth, saying the faddish caps were robberies waiting to happen. But the new policies have not been cheered in all quarters. In March, high school students in Palmdale, Calif., enraged by a new anti-gang dress code, boycotted classes and pelted a sheriff's patrol car with rocks. And there is some support for student resistance to the dress-code trend. Laws allowing schools to require uniforms are ``a way of trying to see that all students look alike, act alike and think alike,'' said Jane Whicher, an attorney for the American Civil Liberties Union in Illinois. ``It's important for children to have an appreciation of their own individuality as well as the constitutional values that protect that individuality,'' she said. ``Orthodoxy in apparel is not something a school board should be involved in.'' Requiring uniforms might also pose a financial hurdle for the poor, Whicher said, but some families are applauding the trend. ``Parents seem to really like the idea,'' said Shel Erlich, a spokesman for the Los Angeles Unified School District, the nation's second-largest public school system. ``It certainly cuts down the amount of arguing in the morning over what the kids should wear to school.'' And some parents are instituting their own dress codes when the schools are not. ``I have two daughters, one a senior in high school,'' said Charles Hill, who heads security for 40 Chicago schools. ``We don't entertain the thought of a Starter jacket. ``We want our kids to have everything,'' he said, ``but we don't want our kids to have something that endangers their lives.'' Law enforcement officials welcome the move toward dress codes. ``Any way that a kid can avoid the problem seems rational to me,'' said Vincent, of the gang crime unit. ``Parents would be a little kinder to their kids if they deprived them of the things they beg for.''

DOC.HEAD: IOUs from Hurricane Looters Persuade Shop Owners to Stay
DOC.TEXT: When looters plundered their candy and tobacco shop in the chaos that accompanied Hurricane Hugo seven months ago, Hal and Mary Longer decided to return to the States. Now they've decided to stay, touched by the unexpected honesty of some of the looters. While cleaning up their ransacked shop, the Longers were astonished to find a dozen IOUs from people who took part in a three-day looting rampage on St. Croix Island after Hugo struck Sept. 17. Then other fellow residents _ realtors, business people, a lawyer, even a territorial senator _ began stopping by to confess they, too, had taken things from the store and would pay for them. ``It makes me feel great that there are some honest people in the world,'' Longer, 63, said recently in his refurbished store. ``It restores your faith,'' his wife, 49, said from behind the candy counter. Of the three main U.S. Virgin Islands, east of Puerto Rico, the hurricane hit St. Croix by far the hardest. About 90 percent of the houses were destroyed or damaged, and reconstruction continues on the island, which has 55,000 permanent residents. St. Croix's image as a Caribbean tourist haven was tarnished by the looting. Scores of businesses were plundered. About 100 people were arrested, and even some police officers and National Guardsmen were accused of taking part in the looting. President Bush sent 1,100 military police, who remained for two months. The Longers, who moved to St. Croix from Davenport, Iowa, in 1987, were visiting Philadelphia when the hurricane struck. They returned two weeks later to find their shop, called Steele's Smokes & Sweets for a previous owner, in ruins. ``The place was a mess,'' Longer said. ``The inventory was trashed and even the scales were gone. Cleaning up was the worst, because they threw stuff all over the walls. There was no need for that.'' Their house also was heavily damaged. The Longers said they were ready to move back to the mainland. That was before they found IOUs for stolen goods that had been left for them in their own shop and the one next door. One scribbled on an envelope said: ``I took four boxes of cigars. I am one of your regular customers. I will pay you when I see you _ Bill.'' ``On the back of the envelope, someone else wrote: `I took some too _ Don,''' Longer said. Bill and Don later paid their total debt of $100, he said, and added, ``Every one of the people but one has voluntarily come in to pay, and I know the one will.'' Longer said a man walked in one day, wandered around as if looking for something to buy, then handed him $27 for six tins of stolen pipe tobacco, and ``the guy's had a smile on his face every time he's come back in the shop.'' Other St. Croix shopkeepers had similar experiences. Jeff Seroogy, 39, owns the Solitude Country Store, a grocery in the island's affluent East End. After he reopened, Seroogy said, people approached him wanting to make amends. ``When I was first told of some of the people who were in the store and what they were doing, I was really mad, just very angry and disappointed,'' he said. ``But when they started coming back and, indeed, came forth and paid, I wasn't angry.'' Hal and Mary Longer said their rebuilding costs were $136,000, including $37,000 in damaged or stolen inventory, and insurance covered all but $14,000 of the loss. The main reason they decided to stay, they said, is the way their customers have treated them since the hurricane. Lt. Gov. Derek Hodge said the IOUs showed many looters were ordinary people panicked by the ferocious storm. ``In the darkest days of our despair, there were those who recognized being a good citizen still had a value,'' he said.
