DOC.HEAD: Actor Says the Jim and Tammy Bakker Story Not a Caricature
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Actor Kevin Spacey says care was taken to see that the story of Jim and Tammy Bakker in NBC's ``Fall From Grace'' didn't lapse into caricature. ``You have to play a real person,'' said Spacey, who stars as the convicted television evangelist in the Sunday movie. Bernadette Peters co-stars as Bakker's wife, Tammy. ``You have to have a respect for that human being, regardless of what's happened to him,'' Spacey said. ``We're all familiar with the ridicule and criticism. Once you get past the fact that I don't really look like Jim Bakker, you get into their life and problems as a married couple. We never got into a cartoon. No one wanted to make this a joke. I tried to play him as a man, not so much an imitation as a suggestion.'' The movie tells the personal story behind the rise and fall of Bakker's empire, built upon his success as a television minister. It begins in 1980 with his dream of Heritage Village and ends with his ouster from the PTL ministry in May 1987. NBC paid the Bakkers for the rights to their story, but said it did not give them any control over the story. Bakker currently is serving a 45-year prison sentence for bilking money out of his followers to support his lavish lifestyle. Spacey, perhaps best known for his role as Mel Proffit on CBS' ``Wiseguy,'' turned down the role when it first was offered. ``I was reluctant to do it, but changed my mind after talking to the director, Karen Arthur,'' he said. ``When it was offered to me, I had the same reaction as other people. They laughed and said, `Another trashy TV movie rehashing headlines.' Karen showed me that it was going to be much more complex than the headlines. ``When Bakker first came to notice, he was a beaten man. He was clawing at air. I think that's why people had a pathetic view of him. We look at him when he was at the peak of his career and energy. We also stay away from the caricature of Tammy as a crying woman with mascara running down her face. It may have happened in real life, but not to the extent of all the ridicule and gags.'' The only concessions to making Spacey look like Bakker were a hairpiece and a dental appliance to change the shape of his mouth. The movie, written by Ken Trevey, also stars Beth Grant as Tammy's confidant, Richard Herd as Bakker assistant Richard Dortch, and Richard Paul as the Rev. Jerry Falwell. Jean Kasem makes a cameo appearance as a real estate saleswoman. After completing the movie in Los Angeles, Spacey returned to New York for a new stage play called ``National Anthems,'' which he had done at the Long Wharf Theatre in New Haven, Conn., with Tom Berenger. Another actor will be cast in Berenger's role for the Broadway version. Spacey also stars in the upcoming theatrical movie ``Show of Force,'' along with Robert Duvall and Andy Garcia. ``Show of Force'' is based on a true story about the killing of young pro-independence students in Puerto Rico, based on the book ``Murder Under Two Flags'' by Ann Nelson. He plays the head of the FBI office in San Juan. He's also been in such movies as ``Dad,'' ``The Right Stuff,'' ``The Unbearable Lightness of Being,'' ``Heartburn,'' ``Working Girl'' and ``Henry and June,'' which hasn't yet been released. Spacey has appeared three times with Jack Lemmon, playing his son in the Broadway production of ``Long Day's Journey Into Night,'' his son-in-law in the movie ``Dad,'' and a reporter in ``The Murder of Mary Phagan,'' a 1987 NBC miniseries based on the lynching of Leo Frank, in which Lemmon played the governor of Georgia. He looks back fondly on his ``Wiseguy'' role. ``Proffit was a man who, on the surface, was an entrepreneur,'' Spacey said. ``He was well known for giving to charities, but his actual business was gun-running and drugs. He had an illicit relationship with his sister. It was pretty racy for television. ``That's a terrific show for actors,'' he said. ``You know you're going to create a terrific character. You also know it's only for a limited time. You get the feel of television without having to commit to a series.''

DOC.HEAD: Moynihan Mixes Politics and Ideas in Senate
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Daniel Patrick Moynihan's career hasn't fit the traditional pattern; while most senators work to change votes, he works to change minds. So there's no Moynihan Act or Moynihan Amendment to mark the pinnacle of his Senate tenure. His is a different approach, wholesale instead of retail. ``What Moynihan loves to do is take an idea, pluck it out of the heavens, set it on the table and let it influence events,'' says Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y. The former professor, diplomat and White House official has done it time and again. He puts forward an idea that at first goes against common wisdom but stays alive despite efforts by others to proclaim it dead. In the 1960s, as an official first in Democratic and then Republican administrations, Moynihan wrote about the instability of black family life and its harmful effects on blacks' chance of success. Controversial at first, his ideas two decades later drove the 1988 welfare reform act. After President Ford made him United Nations ambassador in 1975, Moynihan rocked the diplomatic corps by bluntly asserting U.S. positions. He was particularly sharp-tongued in opposing a resolution labeling Zionism as a form of racism. He stayed only eight months before returning to Harvard, but he established the model for his U.S. successors at the world body. In 1976, he was elected to the Senate, giving up his professorship. But he has clung to the image of an academician. Tall, gray-haired and tweed-clothed, he seems able to lecture his colleagues on an infinite range of topics. ``He's never had an unspoken thought,'' quipped one colleague. His occasional meetings with Washington reporters are called ``tutorials'' by the attendees, who sit in chairs arranged classroom-like in his office. He doesn't just answer questions, he expounds on most anything. At one recent session, he described the life cycle of the sea lamprey, a parasitic fish whose control he supports, noting that it was ``really a nice piece of biology.'' Unlike many lawmakers, the burden of elected office has not dampened Moynihan's taste for the controversial. His latest idea on Social Security has revitalized that penchant. Back in 1983, Moynihan was the intellectual force behind an increase in Social Security payroll taxes so that the system could build up a surplus for when the baby boom generation retires. The surplus is now building at a rate of $1 billion a week, but instead of being saved for the future as Moynihan intended, it's being frittered away to cover day-to-day government operating expenses and make the federal deficit appear smaller. Washington's leaders promise to make the surplus ``off-budget'' and thus more sacrosanct. But in reality, that answer is nothing more than ``how you display your books,'' Moynihan says. His solution: Roll back the payroll tax. Simple, but the political implications are immense. The White House and even some fellow Democrats, such as House Ways and Means Chairman Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., label the idea as dangerous. The politicians don't like to admit that Social Security taxes are being misused, but nobody seems willing to cut spending or raise other taxes enough to take their place. Some fretted, with prodding from President Bush, that the plan was somehow ``messing with'' Social Security, a political no-no. One official even called it goofy. But the biggest White House worry was that a Democrat was treading on turf the Republicans thought they owned _ tax cuts. Unlike Bush's cherished capital gains tax cut, Moynihan's benefits would be tilted to the working poor and middle class. ``Political genius,'' is what Democratic National Committee Chairman Ronald Brown called it. Last month, just when Congress seemed to be putting it on the backmost burner, the DNC endorsed the plan. ``The DNC can do exactly what it wants,'' responded House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo. ``They are not in the Congress and they don't have the responsibility to actually produce a budget. We don't have a consensus in the Congress today to do Moynihan.'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell said Moynihan's idea will be put up for a vote in his chamber. But the opposition including Finance Committee Chairman Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, says chances for passage this year are dim. Moynihan said if the people he meets outside of Washington had their way, his proposal would already be enacted. But the capital's bureaucracy takes time to turn around, so for now he may have to settle for less, he said. ``If I have one minimum ambition it's that before this is over the first paragraph of stories about the federal budget and federal revenues ... would include that they're using $72 billion in trust fund monies,'' Moynihan said. There's no telling when or if his Social Security plan will fly. But Moynihan, reveling in the spotlight, has found plenty else to talk about. For example, he used a speech before the National Press Club to press his ideas about Lithuania, pushing the almost quaint suggestion that the World Court at the Hague could serve as the mechanism to defuse the dispute between the Soviet Union and its Baltic republics. He also is continuing his lonely effort to promote U.S. development of technologically advanced trains that ride on magnetic fields instead of regular tracks. ``Could you have a Senate of 100 Moynihans? No. But is it great to have a few? Sure,'' says Rep. Schumer, who is rumored to be eyeing a 1992 race against Moynihan's junior Republican colleague, Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y. The juxtaposition with D'Amato, widely known as ``senator pothole'' for his attention to local issues, sometimes makes Moynihan look as though he pays little attention to the home folks. But one of Moynihan's favorite topics is a local one, taking the tolls off the New York Thruway. The idea of removing the tolls started in 1956, when Moynihan was an aide to the governor of New York and the free system of federal interstate highways was being started. ``I was a member of the New York delegation to the 1960 Democratic National Convention. I went to Los Angeles with one platform plank in my pocket: Tolls off the Thruway,'' he wrote in a letter to voters in 1982 from his schoolhouse hideaway near Pindars Corners in upstate New York. ``Sixteen years later, I was a candidate for the Senate. I promised that I would press to take the tolls off the Thruway,'' he said. ``Finally, in 1982 ... we signed the agreement'' to take tolls off in 1996 _ 40 years after the effort began. ``No business for the short-winded,'' Moynihan concluded.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Leader Says Results Will Vindicate Low-Key Style
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Political leadership, according to the Democrat who wields it in the House, means governing rather than incessant campaigning, even if the style looks bashful. And Speaker of the House Thomas S. Foley said he won't change his ways, despite the dissatisfaction of some Democrats who argue that leaders should be more confrontational, posting clear themes and alternatives to challenge the Republican in the White House. ``We're unwilling to simply be an opposition party and probe every weak spot,'' Foley said, adding that people who advocate that course view the Democrats as a party out of power despite their command of Congress. ``That's not the case,'' the speaker said. ``We are in control here. ... Part of the time we have to worry, between elections, about the country's government. ... ``Maybe we're not doing it well enough, but it's not because we're bashful,'' Foley said. Foley has been speaker for 10 months, since the resignation of Jim Wright. After the ethics investigation that marked Wright's final days, the Washington congressman was promoted as a skilled legislator with a television style that would help the new team of Democratic congressional leaders present the party message in counterpoint to President Bush. Now some Democrats are complaining that the party's House and Senate hierarchy isn't making the case, that there is no real alternative program or theme, and that Rep. Richard A. Gephardt, D-Mo., the majority leader, is the only person in the lineup willing to tackle Bush. In the audience as President Bush addressed the American Society of Newspaper Editors, Gov. James J. Blanchard of Michigan remarked that Democrats aren't presenting an alternative vision of where the country should be heading, especially in domestic policies and programs. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts complained last week that the party seems muted, timid and befuddled, when it should be seizing the opportunities presented by the easing of East-West tensions. ``With a few notable exceptions, there has been a kind of unnatural quiet coming from our party, a sense of yielding ground to the president, of kowtowing to his veto threats, of confining our own Democratic efforts to merely marginal improvements in Republican programs, or almost conceding a second term to President Bush,'' Kennedy said in a speech at Georgetown University. Over a spartan breakfast in the House restaurant _ he's dieted away 40 pounds _ Foley said his natural inclination is to seek solutions first and have political arguments later. He said there will be plenty to argue about before the session ends. Foley said Democratic pressure has pushed Bush from timid proposals into more ambitious ones on some fronts. ``He's doing more on Eastern Europe now because we demanded it,'' the speaker said. He said the same thing happened on drug control, on clean air and on child care legislation, although the Democratic majority is still pushing farther than Bush wanted. ``We may have some tough disagreements in front of the country on some of these issues,'' Foley said. ``I'm not going to roll over and drop dead because the president says veto. ... So threaten veto, go ahead. ...'' The next line, of course, is make my day, but that's not Foley's style. He said Democratic leaders are not shying from confrontation because of Bush's still lofty popularity ratings. ``The popularity is very personal,'' he said. ``But it has a limited political consequence. ... His popularity doesn't translate to legislative influence or party preference.'' Foley said there is no voter pressure to support Bush programs, nothing like the message from home when Ronald Reagan was pushing his first-term tax cut. ``There isn't any Bush revolution,'' he said, adding that the administration is drifting when it should be leading. Then, reflecting on the point, he added that nobody has an agenda challenging the country to confront real problems, and both parties share the blame. ``That's my complaint against all of us,'' Foley said. Again, the conciliatory ring that bothers some Democrats. It doesn't bother Foley. He looks back to the days of Sam Rayburn, the legendary Mr. Speaker, and of Lyndon B. Johnson as Senate majority leader, recalling their private visits to Dwight D. Eisenhower's White House to work out legislation. ``If anything, the government was less confrontational then than it is now,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Attorneys Challenging Reliability of DNA Testing
DOC.TEXT: The use of DNA identification to link suspects to crimes is being successfully challenged by defense attorneys in a small but growing number of cases. At issue are the reliability of the tests and the way they are conducted. ``In the last year, I am aware of at least seven or eight cases where after the defense got an expert involved, the prosecution has withdrawn the evidence,'' says lawyer Peter Neufeld, who successfully challenged DNA test results in a New York City murder case last summer. The judge in the case cited problems with the laboratory analysis. Since it was first introduced in a U.S. criminal court in 1987, DNA testing has been presented in 200 cases in at least 36 states. The FBI opened its own DNA lab in late 1988 to test samples for state and local police departments. Since then bureau experts have presented evidence that has helped convict 44 people. ``With everything we have seen so far, we are gaining confidence in the DNA identification's utility in serving the criminal justice community,'' said John Hicks, head of the FBI's laboratory division. The tests compare genetic material extracted from tissue or body fluids found at crime scenes with DNA from a suspect's blood. While law enforcement authorities hail DNA identification, defense lawyers have won several victories by exposing what courts found to be flaws in testing procedures. Among them: _ The Minnesota Supreme Court refused in November to admit DNA test results in a murder case, saying the laboratory of Cellmark Diagnostics in Germantown, Md., did not meet standards for scientific reliability. _ In December, prosecutors in Maine were forced to withdraw DNA evidence in a sexual assault case and drop charges. Defense experts testified there were flaws in procedures used by Lifecodes Corp. of Valhalla, N.Y., to match DNA in the defendant's blood with that extracted from a semen sample taken at the crime scene. _ On March 8, a judge presiding over an Oregon rape case refused to admit DNA test results from the FBI lab, ruling there was too much scientific controversy over the tests' reliability and too much danger of confusing jurors with technical details. Spokesmen at the two commercial DNA laboratories defended their procedures, as did Hicks. Hicks said computer imaging at the FBI lab ensures that a match is properly read by the tester. In addition, two examiners must find that the DNA patterns match before positive results are declared, he said. Michael Baird, director of forensic testing at Lifecodes, said the court decisions have not discredited the technique or the procedures' track record. ``We are talking about whether the approach itself is correct as opposed to what's being done in a particular case,'' Baird said. ``There have been situations where portions of the evidence were not ruled admissible, but the technology itself has been admissible.'' ``The issue is not so much should it be accepted as evidence but how and under what circumstances,'' said Janlori Goldman, a staff attorney for the American Civil Liberties Union's privacy project. DNA testing isn't exclusively a weapon for prosecutors. Of more than 500 tests completed by the FBI, 36 percent excluded the suspect in question, Hicks said. Public defenders in Washington commissioned DNA tests that recently exonerated a man whose rape conviction was overturned because his DNA did not match that taken from a semen stain found on the woman's clothing. Thousands of other tests performed by Cellmark and Lifecodes have exonerated defendants or encouraged them to plead guilty, said Mark Storolow, a spokesman for Cellmark. ``As a form of evidence it must be very, very powerful because it results in a lot of plea bargaining,'' he said. Rape cases are the most common application of DNA testing in criminal investigations because hospitals routinely take semen samples from victims. The test can also be useful in solving murders, enabling police to determine, for example, that blood on a suspect's clothing was from the victim. It also is used for paternity tests. ``When it goes to the identity of the person, that's when it's particularly relevant,'' said Jay B. Stephens, the U.S. attorney in Washington. To check for a match, scientists use enzymes to ``cut'' DNA strands into small pieces and place them on laboratory gelatin. The fragments move along the gelatin and form patterns similar to the price-code bars on supermarket merchandise. Each person, except for identical twins, has a singular genetic makeup so the pattern should be unique. Based on the size of the test sample and data taken from DNA tests drawn from samplings of the population, scientists calculate the odds against a pattern being repeated. Neufeld and other lawyers argue that laboratories use less-than-objective criteria for deciding that two DNA patterns match. In the Maine case, expert witnesses questioned the procedures Lifecodes used to adjust for a phenomenon called ``bandshifting'' _ in which the fragments do not move evenly along the gelatin. Thomas Caskey, a medical professor who is starting a DNA lab at Baylor University in Houston, dismisses those who question the reliability of tests. ``It is extremely easy to determine whether one has a match between the suspect and the forensic specimen,'' he said. But Neufeld argues that like other scientific evidence, DNA should be subject to rigorous court scrutiny, particularly if it's used to determine if a person is going to prison.

DOC.HEAD: Therapists Fleecing Public with Self-Help Books, Psychologist Says
DOC.TEXT: Enter any bookstore and you'll find walls of self-help manuals. They'll save your marriage, cure your phobia, release the ``inner you,'' or enable you to stick to the only diet you'll ever need. Many of them make claims on the covers or jackets that the contents don't deliver, and some use theories that have not been proved, said psychologist Gerald Rosen, who wants his fellow professionals to do something about that. He suggests a kind of Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval from the American Psychological Association. Books would be required to state how methods had been tested, on whom, and how effective they were. And now the market includes cassette tapes, too. ``We have to have these products marketed with accurate claims and not take advantage of the public,'' said Rosen, who is in private practice in Seattle and has written a self-help book of his own, about phobias. Rosen had hoped to present a ``Golden Fleece Award'' for self-help psychotherapies at the APA's convention last August in New Orleans to embarrass therapists who made exaggerated claims about untested programs. He had planned to pass out noisemakers, and make awards based on the level of honks and boos each book received. But the APA nixed the idea. ``Very bad taste,'' said Charles Spielberger, APA president. ``It's not scientific evaluation, people booing.'' If an APA member writes a book that violates the organization's ethical principles and if someone files a claim, the APA would investigate, said Spielberger, a psychology professor at the University of South Florida, Tampa. ``We don't shrink for a minute from expelling or censuring a member who doesn't follow APA code,'' said Raymond Fowler, a psychologist and APA chief executive officer, but ``you can't just let one member speak for the association and say, `Here's a bad guy doing a bad job.''' But APA may consider regulating member authors. ``We will start a serious consideration of APA's role in looking at self-help books and ... (whether) we need to develop a task force to draw up guidelines or inform our members of general standards,'' Fowler said recently. ``The truth is, I wouldn't want to underestimate some of these books. They are very sound and very sensitively thought out,'' said Fowler, ``and for some individuals it may be the only psychological help they'll obtain.'' And evaluating every self-help book would be an enormous undertaking. Rosen's book, ``Don't Be Afraid,'' had its share of exaggerated claims, he said, and the experience taught him it would be possible for the APA to set up a standard contract for psychologists to negotiate control of book promotion. One way to deal with book jacket hyperbole, Rosen said, is for authors to take a tough stand with publishers. But Herbert Holtje, a literary agent, said it is nearly impossible for writers to maintain that kind of control. It is unrealistic that self-help books ``should be marketed without consideration of the competitive climate created by publishers,'' Holtje wrote in the journal American Psychologist. Albert Ellis, president of the Institute for Rational-Emotive Therapy and a psychologist in New York City, has written more than 50 self-help books. ``I'm critical of some self-help books but definitely in favor of others,'' said Ellis, who would approve of a program to test a book for effectiveness. But he said he doubts publishers would wait around for that. ``I must say there's something frustrating about the hard work of research day in and day out just to get a little way and someone reels out a pot-boiler and makes thousands,'' said Patricia Keith-Spiegel, a professor of psychology at California State University at Northridge who teaches a course in ethics. She was on the APA's ethics committee at a time when a psychologist couldn't give out professional advice except in a client-patient relationship. ``Then everything exploded,'' she said, and psychologists were on radio and television, they were writing columns, they were writing books. She is writing her own how-to book, how to get into graduate school. ``I've been a vocal critic of self-help books,'' Keith-Spiegel said. ``I'm going to have to research and check out everything I say.'' Rosen cites a number of books he feels exaggerate their claims. One is ``The Doctors Guide to Instant Stress Relief: A Psychological and Medical System,'' by psychologists Ronald G. Nathan and Thomas E. Staats, and Dr. Paul J. Rosch. ``I don't believe there's any such thing as instant stress relief,'' Rosen said. ``It could have been called the `Doctors Guide to Stress Relief You Can Learn in a Few Weeks.''' But Nathan said the title was suggested by the publisher and agreed upon only after much discussion among the authors. While it may take six months to learn the technique of instant relaxation, it then can be applied in seconds, he said. One danger in self-help books is that people can misdiagnose themselves and fail to seek help, Rosen contends. But Nathan said he and his co-authors provided a test for the reader to determine if professional help is needed. ``My pitch has been trying to convince psychology professionals that it's time to take self-help books seriously because they've set up an alternate therapy system, and the books reach many more consumers than we will,'' said Steven Starker, chief of psychological services and professor of medical psychology at Oregon Health Sciences University in Portland, Ore. He also made that point in an article debating the topic in the magazine American Psychologist. ``I have talked to a lot of people over the years who have found a great deal of help in self-help books,'' said Bernie Zilbergeld, a psychologist in private practice in Oakland, Calif., and co-author of ``Mind Power: Getting What You Want Through Mental Training.'' ``If they can go out and pay $5 for a paperback book and get help from it without seeing me, why not?'' Zilbergeld said. Rosen admits he sounds self-serving: He charges $95 for an hour of therapy. But, he said, professionals should not promise the public more than they can deliver.

DOC.HEAD: Study Backs Link Between Diet, Heart Disease
DOC.TEXT: A study of more than 12,800 men bolsters research arguing that quitting smoking and eating low-fat foods can help lower the risk of heart disease. The study, published in the April 6 Journal of the American Medical Association, found that men at high risk for heart disease who were given dietary advice and other special treatment had a 24 percent lower death rate from heart attacks than those who received ordinary care. The death rate from heart disease was 10.6 percent lower and the overall death rate was 7.7 percent lower in the first group, researchers found. Treatment consisted of advice to lower cholesterol levels, counseling on quitting smoking and improved drug therapy to control high blood pressure. About half the 12,860 men studied at 22 clinics nationwide received the special treatment several times a year, while the other half were examined annually and received additional treatment only if needed. The study of men aged 35 to 57 began in late 1973 and ended in 1982. The results reported in JAMA occurred between 1982 and a December 1985 follow-up review, said Marcus O. Kjelsberg, a statistician at the University of Minnesota's School of Public Health, where the data was analyzed. Initial examinations in 1982 showed no significant differences between the groups, which surprised researchers and prompted the follow-up, Kjelsberg said in a telephone interview. The ultimate results were not surprising, given the multitude of data showing a link between diet, smoking and heart disease, said Jeremiah Stamler, a cardiovascular epidemiologist at Northwestern University and a principal investigator in the study. Researchers expected to see the results earlier, at the end of the study, but they failed to anticipate several factors that may account for the delay, Stamler said. One reason may have been that all the volunteers were relatively healthy, despite facing a higher than normal risk for heart disease because they smoked, had high blood pressure or high cholesterol levels or a combination of the three, Stamler said. Another reason for the delayed results may have been a change in drug treatment for high blood pressure that occurred toward the end of the study. The later treatment was considered more effective, Kjelsberg said. Researchers did not determine how many of the men who had received special treatment continued to seek it after the study ended, he said, but they asssumed that many stuck to their healthier lifestyles. The study was funded by the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute in Bethesda, Md.
DOC.NOTE: End advance for April 16

DOC.TEXT: The nation's businesses significantly increased their plans for modernization and expansion this year, shrugging off economists' gloomy recession predictions, the government said. The Commerce Department said Wednesday that a survey completed in March found businesses planning a record $503.4 billion in plant and equipment spending in 1990, up 7.6 percent from last year.

To justify seizing Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, regulators arbitrarily wrote down the value of its $1.4 billion loan portfolio by 50 percent and slashed the worth of its extensive land, hotel and stock holdings by 75 percent, the thrift's former owner said. Phoenix financier Charles H. Keating Jr. testified Wednesday in his suit seeking to recover the Irvine, Calif., S&L that ``without any analysis, they took the entire loan portfolio and said it was non-performing.''

CBS Inc. said its broadcasts of the Super Bowl and the NCAA basketball tournament fueled a 52 percent increase in its first-quarter profit despite disappointing ratings for its prime time entertainment lineup. CBS, which operates the CBS Television Network and owns five TV stations, said Wednesday it earned $85.3 million, or $3.31 per share, in the three months ended March 31 compared with $56.1 million, or $2.18 a share, a year earlier. Laurence A. Tisch, the CBS president and chief executive, said the company's second-half outlook was uncertain due to a sluggish national economy, heightened competition for television viewers and higher sports rights costs.

A flood of OPEC crude oil and weak demand for gasoline and home heating oil are responsible for the recent sharp slide in oil prices, analysts said as the energy futures market gyrated widly. Oil futures veered lower Wednesday as trading opened, but by late afternoon had recovered the day's lost ground and rose above Tuesday's close. Oil prices have fallen about 25 percent since January.

OPEC nations have held ``intense discussions'' about the recent sharp fall in oil prices, with some ministers considering whether to call an emergency meeting, analysts said. ``There has been some contact among the ministers about the possibility of meeting to discuss the problem,'' a source close to the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, who demanded anonymity, said Wednesday. OPEC spokesmen in Vienna, the group's headquarters, said no meeting had been planned.

Shell Oil Co. unveiled its own version of a reformulated gasoline that reduces certain exhaust pollutants and said the gas will be sold in nine U.S. metropolitan areas where air quality is a problem. The SU 2000E gasoline reduces hydrocarbon vapor emissions, a component in smog formation, and carbon monoxide emissions from automobile tailpipes, Shell officials said Wednesday.

Standard & Poor's Corp. is taking a closer look at its ratings on about $7.1 billion in long-term public debt and preferred stock of Time Warner Inc. because of the media and entertainment giant's new financial agreement with Pathe Communications Corp. Standard & Poor's, one of the nation's leading credit rating services, said it was placing $1.5 billion in Time Warner debt and $5.6 billion of its preferred stock on its CreditWatch listing with negative implications. The move is not an actual credit downgrade, which if undertaken would increase Time Warner's borrowing costs.

The student loan default rate has dipped slightly and Education Department officials said they will study the statistics to see if a trend may be emerging. Officials said Wednesday that the department data show an overall default rate reduction from 17.3 percent in 1987 to 15.6 percent in fiscal year 1988. In fiscal year 1986, the default rate was 21 percent.

One in eight Americans has no health insurance, the Census Bureau reported. A study concluded that 26.5 percent of Hispanic Americans weren't covered in 1988, while the figure was 20.2 percent for blacks and 11.7 percent for whites. The report Wednesday comes as the Senate is considering a proposal to assure that all Americans have private or public health coverage.

Energy issues posted broad losses Wednesday while the rest of the stock market drifted aimlessly in a quiet session. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 1.35 to 2,729.73, marking the sixth consecutive session in which it rose or fell less than 10 points. The dollar ended narrowly mixed in thin trading. Bond prices rose in response to a temporary drop in oil prices. Orange juice futures prices leaped; livestock and meat futures were mixed; grains and soybeans were mixed and precious metals were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Fraud Blamed For Much Of S&L Problems
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Hearing scheduled to convene at 10 a.m. CDT
DOC.TEXT: ``Pervasive'' fraud played a major role in the collapse of many savings and loans, FBI Director William Sessions says, but tracking down crime is difficult because of the complex nature of the institutions' deals. ``The types of cases we are seeing in Texas frequently involve the looting of institutions for the direct financial benefit of officers, directors or major stockholders,'' he said. Sessions testified Wednesday at a House Banking Committee hearing in Dallas, leading a parade of witnesses who blamed fraud for much of the thrift industry's problems. ``Although it was the general economic downturn in Texas that surfaced the problem, it appears to the FBI as if a pervasive pattern of fraudulent lending activity began much earlier,'' he said. ``Experience demonstrates that insider abuse is a major factor in almost all of our investigations involving failed financial institutions,'' Sessions said. The committee, chaired by Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, is holding two days of hearings in Dallas to examine investigations of fraud in the industry. The hearing was scheduled to continue today, although at least three of the listed witnesses indicated they wouldn't show. The committee has asked key figures at some of the most notorious failed thrifts to testify, but only one, Thomas Gaubert, has indicated he will appear. Gaubert, who has been acquitted once on fraud charges, was chairman of Independent American Savings Association. The three others asked to testify were Edwin T. McBirney, former chairman at Sunbelt Savings Association of Texas; Don R. Dixon former owner of Vernon Savings and Loan Association; and Jarrett Woods, of Western Savings Association. All four institutions were recipients of multimillion dollar bailouts and have been targets of federal investigations. ``This is not a problem that is limited to Texas, or even to the Southwest,'' Sessions said. ``More incidents of insider abuse have been identified in Texas, however, because the Texas institutions are coming under closer scrutiny as they are being declared insolvent.'' In North Texas alone, Sessions said regulators have ``38 separate savings and loans institutions identified wherein major conspiratorial fraud is alleged. Over 500 subjects have been identified for investigation and possible prosecution. ``Potential financial loss exposure is $10.5 billion,'' he said. Gonzalez criticized the Bush administration for being slow to implement regulations and safeguards adopted last year in bailout legislation. ``We gave the regulatory and the law enforcement agencies unprecedented power to deal with the crisis and the cleanup,'' Gonzalez said, but the administration left key jobs unfilled and failed to develop a ``sense of urgency.'' ``The recovery machinery at the Resolution Trust Corp. creaks along like some old Model T with many of its parts missing. The biggest evidence of life and vigor has been the outlandish bureaucratic infighting that has paralyzed and driven away the better people,'' Gonzalez said. The RTC is the agency charged with rescuing failed thrifts. ``The American people _ judging from my mail and my telephone calls _ are angry about what they see as `business as usual' approach to a disaster that is costing them dearly,'' Gonzalez said. Sessions defended his agency's efforts, recalling bank fraud investigations as far back as 1982. He said a shortage of resources and the complexity of the frauds had hampered the agency's work. ``It is often difficult to distinguish failures that involve fraud from failures resulting from poor management and poor business decisions,'' Sessions said. Sessions said the FBI is investigating 530 failed institutions, including 276 banks, 234 savings and loans and 20 credit unions; 198 of the institutions, including one-third of the thrift cases, are in Texas. In addition, Sessions said the FBI has more than 3,000 pending cases of traditional bank fraud and embezzlement involving $100,000 or more. Other witnesses, who included former federal and state regulators and other officials, testified about the regulatory climate in Texas and in Washington and said top officials and some congressmen refused to recognize the industry's problems in the mid 1980s.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Holds `Intense Discussions' on Falling Prices, Possible Meeting
With PM-Oil Prices Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The recent sharp fall in oil prices has prompted ``intense discussions'' among OPEC nations, including the possibility of an emergency meeting by ministers, analysts said. ``There has been some contact among the ministers about the possibility of meeting to discuss the problem,'' a source close to the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said Wednesday. The source spoke on condition of anonymity. OPEC spokesmen in Vienna, the group's headquarters, said no meeting had been planned. Some doubted the ministers would gather so soon before their scheduled meeting in late May. At that time, all 13 ministers will set their production and pricing guidelines for the last half of the year. But the source close to OPEC said the organization's eight-member monitoring panel could meet in a special session to discuss the price declines, or that an even smaller group could hold informal talks. ``There are intense discussions,'' he said. A fall in prices had been expected in the often-weak second quarter, but the sharpness in recent days has been startling. West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, fell by some 25 percent in the past 11 weeks. On Wednesday the near-month contract dropped below $17 a barrel at one point on the New York Mercantile Exchange before rebounding strongly to finish up 38 cents at $18.06 a barrel. The average price of a basket of seven crudes monitored by OPEC was $17.12 a barrel in the first week of April, off from $17.26 in the last week of March and below the cartel's $18 a barrel target price. Analysts blamed the price drop on overproduction by some OPEC members and seasonally lower demand by the United States and other consuming nations in the April-June quarter. Peter Gignoux, director of the international energy department at Shearson Lehman Hutton in London, estimated the cartel's production last week at just over 24.5 million barrels a day, well over OPEC's cap of 22.1 million barrels a day for the January-June period. Peter Bogin, associate director for oil markets at Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Paris, said, ``It's the spring weakness everybody has been talking about. ... Demand is down because it's always down at this time of year.'' He predicted prices could fall further in the near-term before firming in June when demand for gasoline picks up with the summer driving season in the United States and elsewhere. In a report last week, the International Energy Agency said OPEC pumped about 23.7 million barrels a day in March, the same as in the previous month.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Putting on the Gloves in Truck Advertising
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. is throwing in the towel in its truck advertising battle with Chevrolet, but there's a string attached. Ford, which has dominated truck sales for more than a dozen years, will stop using comparison advertising in its new round of truck ads, advertising manager John Vanderzee said Wednesday. But the new series of ads, which debut this month, can be changed easily to insert a Chevrolet or two if the company feels it has to, he said. ``It is a major new direction for us resulting from customer research,'' Vanderzee said. ``We are not interested in advertising wars anymore. ``We're not going to take on Chevrolet anymore.'' Chevrolet has no immediate plans to drop its current run of comparison ads, said Dave Hudgens, a spokesman for the General Motors Corp. division. ``I do know that the truck advertising people in particular, felt that they were very effective,'' Hudgens said. ``If you have something that's very effective it makes sense to continue with it.'' Ford and Chevrolet have taken each other on with pointed and sometimes snippy advertisements. Chevy's ``Ditch of Doom'' ad showed a Chevrolet pickup plowing through a muddy trench while occupants of a Ford truck jumped into the muck to manually lock front wheels and make their truck a four-wheel-drive vehicle. Chevrolet claimed in a later advertisement that its trucks outsold Ford trucks in Ford County, Ill. Ford fired back with an ad acknowledging that Chevrolet outsold it _ in one month by one truck. The ad said Ford outsold Chevrolet for the entire year in Ford County and, for extra measure, in Chevy Chase, Md. Through March 31 this year, Ford sold 10.8 percent more light trucks than Chevrolet, 352,469 to 318,247. And for the first half of the 1990 model year, Ford's trucks sold at a pace 13.1 percent faster than Chevy's. ``We're gaining ground on them, they're not gaining ground on us,'' Vanderzee said. Ford's ads responding to Chevy's were endorsed by dealers, Vanderzee said. Ford officials have been on a 33-city dealer tour during the past month telling dealers, among other things, about the new truck advertising. Cecil Davis, general sales manager at Coliseum Ford in Portland, Ore., said he liked the comparison ads. ``I always thought it was a good case they were making,'' he said. ``If it was one way or another I would wish they would keep the comparison ads.'' While telling dealers that the corporation's ads won't show comparisons with Chevrolet, Vanderzee said some dealers may not be able to resist it in local advertising. ``If they want to take on Chevrolet or Toyota in their market, they are going to do it,'' Vanderzee said. ``We may say that we don't like it.''

DOC.HEAD: Shell Unveils New Gas Officials Say is Better For Environment
DOC.TEXT: Shell Oil Co. is joining other oil companies in pumping a new gasoline that reduces hydrocarbon and carbon monoxide emissions. Shell's gas, called SU 2000E, was put on the market in the nine metropolitan areas the Bush administration has identified as having the most severe air quality problems, said Frank H. Richardson, Shell's president and chief executive officer. ``We think this new product from Shell represents an important step toward improving the nation's air quality,'' Richardson said Wednesday. The gas is being sold in the areas of New York City, Chicago, Houston, Los Angeles, Philadelphia, Baltimore, Milwaukee, San Diego and Hartford, Conn. It also is available in the Washington D.C. area, which was targeted as having a serious, not a severe, air quality problem. Houston-based Shell said it may expand production in the future. Other oil companies that have introduced reformulated gasolines include Arco, Phillips Petroleum, Marathon, Exxon, Amoco, Mobil, Citgo and Sun Oil. Those companies generally are selling the new gasoline in limited test markets. More than 2,000 Shell stations are selling the gas, which can be used in virtually any car. The new gas has the same octane number and additive package as Shell's SU 2000 premium gas, which it has replaced in the 10 targeted areas. ``We obviously do not view our introduction of SU 2000E as a total solution to the nation's air quality problems. We do believe that it is an important step in the right direction,'' Richardson said. The new gasoline reduces hydrocarbon vapor emissions, a component in smog formation, and carbon monoxide emissions from automobile tailpipes, Shell officials said. Steven L. Miller, president of Shell Refining and Marketing Co., said the carbon monoxide emissions are reduced because the gas contains methyl Tertiary-butyl ether, or MTBE. MTBE replaces butane, which results in a gasoline with a lower vapor pressure that evaporates less quickly. ``By reducing the vapor pressure of gasoline, we reduce the pounds of hydrocarbons that escape into the atmosphere through evaporation,'' he said. Richardson said if all of Shell's premium gas customers in the targeted areas used the new gas, there will be about 80 fewer tons of emissions to the air during a typical summer day. About 3.7 million gallons of premium gas are sold on an average summer day in the 10 areas. The gas costs about 2 cents more per gallon to produce than other premium gasolines. Shell officials said the new gas is priced the same as SU 2000, but they added the future price will be determined by competitive conditions in the marketplace.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Trade Surplus Rises for First Time in 11 Months
DOC.TEXT: An 11-month declining trend in Japan's trade surplus halted in March, but economists said it was because the month's imports were being compared with an unusually large amount of imports in March 1989. The Finance Ministry on Thursday reported a surplus of $7.09 billion in March, up from $6.61 billion in March a year earlier. In each of the 11 previous months, the surplus had been smaller than the ones the prior year. In February, the surplus had fallen to $5.01 billion from $7.23 billion in February 1989. For Japan's fiscal year, which ended March 31, the surplus, measured when goods pass through customs, fell to $59.7 billion from $78.9 billion the prior year, the ministry reported. In trade with the United States, which has been pressing Japan in a series of talks to narrow the imbalance, the March surplus contracted to $3.77 billion from $4.01 billion in March 1989. For the fiscal year, Japan's sales to the United States exceeded U.S. sales here by $42.8 billion, down 12.7 percent from the $49 billion surplus the year before. On a global basis, Japan's exports in March fell 1.8 percent from the previous year to $26 billion, but imports declined 4.8 percent to $18.9 billion. In March 1989, imports had climbed nearly 30 percent from the previous year, said Toshiaki Kakimoto, chief economist with Sumitomo Bank. There was a surge of buying before Japan imposed a new 3 percent sales tax last April 1, he said. Meanwhile, the U.S. dollar's recent increase against the yen makes Japan's exports, measured in dollars, appear bigger. In March, the Finance Ministry used exchange rates of about 148 yen to one dollar to calculate exports and imports, up from about 128 yen a year earlier. ``There's no big change in the downward trend'' of the Japanese surplus, said Jan VanDenBerg, an economist with Merrill Lynch in Tokyo. But she said that in coming months a combination of weaker demand in Japan, stronger demand abroad and the weak yen will cause Japan's trade surplus to begin expanding again. Kakimoto predicted a surplus of about $60 billion in the current fiscal year, compared with $59.7 billion in fiscal 1989.

DOC.HEAD: State Moves Closer To Nation's Toughest Anti-Takeover Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS typo in creeping in 17th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Pennsylvania is ready to adopt the nation's toughest anti-takeover law despite an outcry from the nation's investment community and securities regulators. Lawmakers and Gov. Robert P. Casey are standing behind the measure despite claims by fund managers that it will cut off Pennsylvania companies from investment and that hostile takeovers are dying out for lack of financing. ``The bill is an overreaction to a problem that is pretty much in its final stages,'' said Charles M. LaLoggia, editor of LaLoggia's Special Situation Report, a newsletter on takeover stocks. ``It's sort of like the Keystone Kops arriving at the scene of a crime about a month late,'' he added. The measure is supported by a labor-business coalition that says it will protect the state's business and jobs from corporate raiders. The bill likely will come to a final vote in the state Senate by the end of April. It cleared the House April 3 by a 182-10 vote, and the Senate approved an earlier version in December by 45-4. Casey says he backs the bill. ``He is very strong in his support of legislation that would prevent raids on Pennsylvania companies and jobs,'' said Casey's spokesman, Vincent Carocci. Fund managers have lobbied against the bill since its introduction last year, and they won a key ally last week in Richard C. Breeden, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Breeden denounced the bill in an April 2 speech, saying it would deny shareholders their rights and allow bad managers ``to run a company into the ground.'' He said Pennsylvania, Indiana and other states are trying to ``tilt the balance of corporate power in favor of corporate management and against shareholders.'' Hostile takeovers have cost Pennsylvania thousands of jobs and the loss of such corporate mainstays as Gulf Oil Co., which closed its Pittsburgh headquarters after it was merged with Chevron Oil. The state ranks ranks fourth in the number of Fortune 500 company headquarters. The AFL-CIO estimates about 90,000 jobs were lost around the nation over the last decade because of mergers, takeovers and leveraged buyouts. But LaLoggia said the market already is correcting past abuses. The excesses of corporate raiders have made it ``almost impossible to raise money in the junk bond market and the banking system for the type of leveraged buyout that caused companies to get into trouble,'' he said. Those arguments hold little sway with the bill's sponsor, Sen. Noah Wenger. ``This is precisely the time to move ahead,'' he said. The law also will be a model for other states, Wenger adds. Pennsylvania already has some of the nation's toughest anti-takeover laws. In 1983 and 1988, the state adopted measures to block creeping tender offers, two-tiered offers and efforts to squeeze out minority shareholders in order to finance takeovers with corporation assets. The push for even stronger sanctions started after the Belzberg family of Canada started buying into Armstrong World Industries Inc., a Lancaster, Pa.-based building products manufacturer. The Belzbergs now own a 10.68 percent stake in the $2.5 billion-a-year company and are waging a proxy fight to elect four candidates to the 14-member board at the company's April 30 annual meeting. A key plank of the bill that has sent opponents into a frenzy is a so-called disgorgement section. For the first time in the nation, the measure would require corporate raiders to surrender profits earned by selling shares within 18 months of making a takeover bid. Supporters say the section will prevent the payment of greenmail, the practice of buying back stock from a raider at an above-market price. Also under the bill, raiders who gain 20 percent or more of a company would not get voting rights until approved by other shareholders. Opponents contend this stipulation will make it virtually impossible to wage proxy fights. The bill also would allow company directors to act in the interest of the entire corporation and to consider interests other than those of shareholders in assessing takeover offers. Such interests could include a takeover's impact on employees, customers or the community. Opponents say that would violate management's fiduciary duty to stockholders. In provisions supported by organized labor, the bill spells out that employees must be paid severance and that labor contracts must be honored when corporate ownership changes hands. More than half the states have enacted takeover laws, but Indiana is the only other state that allows managers to play down shareholders' interests, said James E. Heard, managing director of The Analysis Group, a Massachusetts-based financial consultant retained by the Belzbergs. About half the states also have limited restrictions on voting rights for acquisitions of large stakes, but they are not as broad as those proposed for Pennsylvania, Heard added.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Slightly Lower at Midday
DOC.TEXT: Stocks were slightly lower at midday Thursday in very light trading ahead of the four-day Easter holiday break. The thin volume exaggerated price changes, dealers said. They said they expected the market to drift for the rest of the day as traders left for the long weekend. The market will be closed for Good Friday and Easter Monday. There was little reaction to British economic data released during the morning. Britain's annual inflation rate, as expected, jumped to 8.1 percent in March from 7.5 percent in February, largely because of increases in mortgage rates, the government said. The unemployment rate, meanwhile, held steady at 5.6 percent in March, it said. Shortly after midday in London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 1.1 points, or 0.05 percent, at 2,214.2. Volume at noontime was 211.1 million shares at midday, compared with 190.9 million shares at the same time Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Mellon Acquiring Automatic Tellers From Cleveland Bank
DOC.TEXT: Mellon Bank completed its second automated teller machine acquisition in the last five weeks by purchasing a regional ATM network from Ameritrust Corp. Mellon's Network Services Division will perform automatic teller processing for 19 financial institutions and their 171 machines in the InstaNet network. The deal adds 650,000 to 700,000 transactions a month to its current total of more than 11 million at about 350 institutions nationwide. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Mellon ranks sixth among processors of electronic fund transfers, according to Bank Network News, a Chicago-based newsletter that monitors the industry. Ameritrust, one of Cleveland's largest banks, will continue to own and process the transactions for its 270 machines, which it calls the Asset network. Mellon also will serve as a link between Asset and InstaNet. A. Jay Meyerson, executive vice president at Ameritrust, said the bank decided to leave the regional automatic teller business and concentrate on building its retail banking operations. Mellon decided to expand its automatic teller processing business after selling its CashStream network of automatic tellers two years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Conditions in Central America Impairing Results
DOC.TEXT: Johnson & Johnson says deteriorating business conditions in Latin America are responsible for a $125 million charge against its first quarter earnings. The health care company Wednesday blamed the charge, being taken to cover a number of separate actions, on severe economic turmoil, inflation and high interest rates in certain Latin American countries. Johnson & Johnson said the loss includes the write-off and restructuring of several subsidiaries, principally in Argentina. It also provides for additional interest from the company's liquidated Argentine debt. The charge also recognizes the impact of recent monetary restrictions in Brazil, the company said. The new government of President Fernando Collor de Mello last month imposed a package of economic measures designed to combat hyperinflation. The plan's centerpiece _ a freeze on 80 percent of the country's savings _ has dried up money in circulation and left the country on the brink of recession. Johnson & Johnson had revenue of $9.76 billion and net income of $1.08 billion last year. The company said the charge will reduce earnings by 38 cents per share. In the first quarter of 1989, the company earned $317 million or 95 cents a share on sales of $2.45 billion. Johnson & Johnson said it will announce first-quarter results April 26.

DOC.HEAD: Smithkline Reaches Deal to Sell Yardley Cosmetics
DOC.TEXT: Smithkline Beecham PLC said Thursday it has agreed to sell its British-based Yardley-Lentheric Cosmetics business to Old Bond Street Corp. of the United States for $180 million. Smithkline, the Anglo-American pharmaceutical group, said it has obtained shareholder approval for the deal. But the agreement still requires both U.S. and British regulatory approval, as well proof of financing by Old Bond Street, a Smithkline spokesman said. Proceeds from the sale will go toward reducing Smithkline's debt, the company said. The sale is part of Smithkline's strategy of focusing on its core healthcare business following its creation last year through the merger of Beecham Group PLC and Smithkline Beckman Corp. It is the first disposal of a cosmetics unit since the merger. Negotiations are underway with possible buyers of the remaining cosmetics divisions, which include Yardley-Lentheric operations in South Africa and the Smithkline Beecham Astor-Lancaster businesses in continental Europe, the spokesman said. He wasn't identified, in keeping with British practice. Old Bond Street, a holding company, plans to pay for the cosmetics unit with a combination of cash and debt, Smithkline said. Smithkline said it will hold a 10 percent stake in Old Bond Street. Smithkline's spokesman said he didn't know when the deal might be completed.

The stock market staged a moderate advance in quiet preholiday trading today. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 11.94 to 2,741.67 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 574 up, 362 down and 462 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 20.24 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Analysts said traders came into the session with low expectations, given the market's recent sluggish behavior and the approach of a long holiday weekend. The markets will be closed for Good Friday. In that kind of environment, observers said, an absence of selling pressure helped produce some pleasant surprises in the price fluctuations of individual stocks. The government reported that retail sales dropped .06 percent in March, in contrast to advance estimates of a small increase. That served as a new suggestion of continued sluggish, erratic economic growth, along with possibly less upward pressure on interest rates than has been feared of late. Ames Department Stores led the active list, down } at 1} on reports that some manufacturers had stopped shipping merchandise to the troubled retailer. Intel rose 1 to 43} in the over-the-counter market. The company reported earnings for the quarter ended March 31 of 73 cents a share, up from 52 cents in the like period a year earlier. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained .52 to 188.09. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .10 at 357.44. On Wednesday the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 1.35 to 2,729.73. Declining issues slightly outnumbered advances on the NYSE, with 725 up, 747 down and 492 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 141.08 million shares, against 136.02 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Says Easter Weekend Could Put It Over The Top
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf pvs, `Greyhound spokesmen...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with explosion aboard bus in Pittsburgh, no injuries. Picks up 12th graf `Two striking...' A version also moved on financial wire.
DOC.TEXT: Officials at Greyhound Lines Inc. say traffic during the five-day Easter travel period will solidify the company's financial position despite a 5-week-old, violence-marred strike by bus drivers. Greyhound President Frank Schmieder said in an interview this week that company projections indicate revenue will reach 70 percent to 73 percent of last year's Easter holiday travel period. He added that 73 percent of revenue is the break-even mark, ``and when we do that, we figure we've turned the corner.'' ``They've been claiming they turned corners for the last six weeks,'' said Jeffrey Nelson, spokesman for the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions. The company's 6,300 drivers and about 3,000 of its office and maintenance workers walked out Marc 2 in an argument over wages and job security. Greyhound has been operating a reduced schedule, using permanent replacements and drivers willing to cross picket lines. Greyhound has increased service in stages. Today, when the company plans to add more than 100,000 miles, putting it at 459,685 miles, or 71.9 percent of pre-strike levels. Union officials claim Greyhound is operating only about 20 percent of its pre-strike routes. Negotiations to end the strike have been stalled since last month. The company has refused to bargain until seven days have passed without major violence. More than 30 shooting attacks have been reported since the strike began. The company filed a $30 million federal lawsuit earlier this week charging the union was behind the violence. The union claims the company is using the violence as an excuse to avoid negotiations. Authorities stopped three buses in northern Ohio on Wednesday after a man called Greyhound's toll-free phone line claiming a bomb was planted on a bus heading east from Chicago. No explosives were found on the buses, said Thomas Johnston of the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms office in Toledo. In Pittsburgh, a driver and passengers reported an explosion aboard a bus bound for Washington, D.C. about 20 minutes after a firecracker shattered a window at the Pittsburgh terminal. No one was injured in either incident, said Kevin Fry, a Greyhound spokesman in Dallas. The bus, carrying 31 passengers, was on Interstate 376 when ``both the driver and passengers heard and felt a vibration which they took to be an explosion,'' Greyhound spokeswoman Bernadette Barney said today. She said the bus returned to the station and neither police nor the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms could immediately determine what caused the explosion, which caused no damage to the bus. Two striking Greyhound drivers were ordered held without bond on charges they fired shots at a bus last month just east of St. Louis. Through Easter, Greyhound is offering free tickets if its buses are late in the busy Northeast, where service has been hardest hit. Schmieder said the promotion had been taken up by 800 passengers during the first five days of the offer. Passenger volumes nationwide totaled more than 56 percent of last year's level, according to company figures. P. Anthony Lannie, Greyhound's executive vice president, said the company should be serving 95 percent of its routes by summer. Greyhound will have 3,200 drivers by May 1, but will need at least 1,000 more to meet summer demand, he said. While passenger traffic may be growing, the company is missing out on money from its small package express business, which accounted for about $92 million of Greyhound's $1.04 billion in revenue last year. Schmieder said the package business is at about 45 percent of year-earlier levels. Greyhound's charter operation, which last year brought in $90 million, has been almost non-existent during the strike. Despite the reductions in service, Greyhound is meeting its bill payments, Schmieder said.

DOC.HEAD: Lincoln Portfolio Was Undervalued to Justify Seizure, Keating Says
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Recasts lead with 4 grafs to raise testimony; picks up 6th graf pvs, He contended ...
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators arbitrarily devalued the assests of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association by 50 percent to 100 percent to justify their takeover of the institution, the thrift's former owner contends. ``Without any analysis, they took the entire loan portfolio and said it was non-performing,'' Phoenix financier Charles H. Keating Jr. testified Wednesday in his suit to regain ownership of the Irvine, Calif., S&L. The devaluation of Lincoln's loans and extensive land, hotel and stock holdings was ``absurd,'' Keating said in his fifth day on the witness stand. A government document dated April 21, 1989, and introduced Wednesday, lists ``assumptions used in the liquidating costing'' to come up with a cost to taxpayers of $1.8 billion to $2.2 billion. He contended the document from regional regulators to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board supports his claim that regulators arbitrarily devalued Lincoln's assets to make it appear insolvent to justify their seizing it. On Tuesday, Keating testified that, in his opinion, Lincoln had a net worth of $500 million to $700 million when the government seized it. The April 21 document was written one week after regulators seized control of the $5.2 billion thrift under a conservatorship, claiming that Keating was operating it in an unsafe and unsound manner. It wasn't until five months later that regulators declared Lincoln insolvent _ with liabilities to federally insured depositors exceeding its assets by $153 million _ and took ownership away from Keating under a receivership. Government attorneys repeatedly objected to Keating's comparison of figures in the regulators' April 21 analysis with those provided by the chief financial officer of his American Continental Corp., Lincoln's parent holding company. The objections were overruled by U.S. District Judge Stanley Sporkin, who previously instructed the government attorneys to call witnesses from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. _ Lincoln's receiver _ to explain their reasoning behind the writedowns. ``This is something that has some meaning,'' said Sporkin, a former accountant and once the top enforcement officer at the Securities and Exchange Commission. ``The testimony here is that it (the April 21 analysis) is pretty shoddy work. You don't write down 50 percent on a mortgage portfolio.'' Robert Wurzelbacher, Keating's son-in-law who headed Lincoln's real estate investments, likened the analysis to a family buying a $100,000 home with a $20,000 down payment and an $80,000 loan. Then a regulator comes in and says the value of the loan and the home is only $40,000, even though the monthly payments are still being made, he said. The April 21 document estimated that the government could recover only $2.1 billion to $2.5 billion from the sale of assets that Lincoln was listing on its books as worth $5.2 billion when regulators seized control. Assuring no losses to depositors would cost the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp., which has since been merged into the FDIC, $1.8 billion to $2.2 billion, according to the analysis. Among the ``assumptions'' listed were that Lincoln's entire $1.4 billion portfolio of mortgage-backed real estate loans was non-performing and in reality was worth only $703 million. It also estimated that $148 million in property that Lincoln had repossessed under foreclosure could be sold for only $74 million and that only $35.5 million of $71.1 million in non-mortgage commercial loans could ever be recovered. In addition, the government said 75 percent or $533 million of the $710 million that Lincoln invested through subsidiaries in stock, hotels and various land holdings could never be recovered. Some assets were devalued by 100 percent, including long-term leases and property improvements on Lincoln in Southern California and some office equipment and furniture. Keating testified that 3 percent of the $1.4 billion in land and real estate loans and less than 3 percent of the commercial loans were more than 60 days in default when regulators seized Lincoln. All of the land and real estate loans, he said, were fully secured with borrowers putting up an average 20 percent down payment on the property. Lincoln's 20 percent ownership in the timber rights on 1.9 million acres of timberland in the Pacific Northwest and Louisiana alone were valued at about $270 million, according to an analysis by Merrill Lynch, Keating said.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Slip In Pre-Easter Selling
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were slightly lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, partly due to position-squaring by traders ahead of the three-day Easter weekend beginning Friday. Analysts linked further selling to prospects for increased soybean meal exports from Brazil, the world's second largest soybean producer, as the South American soybean harvest approaches 50 percent. Another bearish factor was the Brazilian legislature's approval of certain inflation-fighting measures that are expected to prompt Brazilian farmers to sell more soybeans, analysts said. Brazil's government hopes to hold inflation to 5 percent this month compared with more than 80 percent in March, which ``leaves very little incentive for producers to hold onto inventory,'' said William Biedermann, director of research at the commodities brokerage Allendale Inc. in Crystal Lake, Ill. Weakness in the wheat market partly reflected reports of minimal frost damage overnight to the winter wheat crop. In early trading, wheat futures were } cent to 1{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in May at $3.63\ a bushel; corn was { cent to 1\ cents lower with May at $2.70 a bushel; oats were unchanged to } cent lower with May at $1.51 a bushel; soybeans were } cent to 1} cents lower with May at $5.91\ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange with live cattle futures scaling back after failing to surpass Wednesday's record high of 80.40 cents a pound. Live cattle were .05 cent to .12 cent lower with April at 80.32 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .12 cent lower to .10 cent higher with April at 83.90 cents a pound; live hogs were .15 cent lower to .28 cent higher with April at 55.90 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .15 cent to .55 cent higher with May at 58.20 cents a pound. Cattle futures settled mixed on Wednesday while pork futures were sharply higher.

DOC.HEAD: With BC-Couples and Money
DOC.TEXT: You've just come home from work and find a check for $50,000 after taxes in the mailbox. What will you do with it? That's the dream quiz posed by Victoria Felton-Collins, author of ``Couples & Money,'' to help determine whether you see money as a source of security, freedom, power or love. She gives these possible choices for answers: A) Make a safe investment, i.e. a certificate of deposit or Treasury bond, to be used towards your children's college education. B) Take a leave of absence from work and travel to Europe or some other exotic destination. C) Buy gifts for all your family and friends. D) Buy a BMW or Mercedes to impress your neighbors. Felton-Collins says that if you answered ``A'' you would be considered a Hedger, someone who is security conscious and afraid to spend money. ``B'' means you're a Freewheeler, using money for freedom, to buy choices and options. ``C'' means you're a Relator and tend to use money to enhance a relationship. ``D'' means you're a Driver, someone who is power conscious and interested in using money to influence others or make a statement. Felton-Collins says couples may possess a combination of these traits, although she finds more women fall into the Hedger category and men in the Driver. ``I'm finding more and more women, though, that are becoming both hedgers and drivers,'' she says. ``Men tend to move from driver to hedger as they get older...and then into freedom.''
