DOC.HEAD: Car and Driver Lists Best Buys
DOC.TEXT: The Mazda Miata, a two-seat sports car that captured widespread attention when it was introduced last year, failed to make the favorite car list of Car and Driver magazine's editors. In its May issue, the magazine listed the favorite cars of its editors in seven categories, ranging from small sports cars to minivans. The only requirement was that the vehicle had to cost less than $20,000. The magazine's choices, along with their category and base price, were: _Sports cars: Honda CRX Si, $12,784. _GT (or sports cars with a rear seat): Eagle Talon TSi AWD, $19,077. _Family sedan: Ford Taurus L, $15,787. _Sports sedan: Nissan Maxima SE, $18,949. _Sport-utility: Mitsubishi Montero, $16,683. _Minivan: Mazda MPV 3.0i, $19,715. _Convertible: Volkswagen Cabriolet, $16,630.

DOC.HEAD: Eli Lilly Discontinues Manufacture of 60 Products
DOC.TEXT: Eli Lilly and Co. has discontinued manufacturing 60 products and versions of products, according to a notification letter sent to drug wholesalers around the country. Representatives of several pharmaceutical wholesaling companies said the products involved were either old or slow-selling and that the manufacturing halts would have little or no financial impact on them. ``It shouldn't cause an problems. Our buyers reacted to it as a routine maintenance'' of Lilly's product line, said a spokesman for Bergen Brunswig Corp., a California-based drug wholesaler. In the letter, dated March 26, Lilly told wholesalers to continue to fill orders from their inventories and then, after inventories were depleted, to classify them as ``manufacturer discontinued.'' Lilly said it knew of no other manufacturers for 10 of the products, including two package sizes of 32 milligram Darvon capsules. However, other dosage sizes of Darvon are available. In additions, some packaging formats of Axid, Lilly's anti-ulcer drug, and of Keflex, an antibiotic, were discontinued, but Lilly continues to manufacture those products in other formats. Several of the products discontinued were among those cited in the U.S. Food and Drug Administration's highly critical inspection report on Lilly's manufacturing practices issued last year. Also discontinued two versions of Bacitracin ointment, an over-the-counter antibiotic. According to the FDA, Lilly recalled about 6,000 tubes of Bacitracin in February after testing showed that the product might not retain its potency through its expiration date.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Mostly Higher at Midday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 9 new grafs to UPDATE with early afternoon prices. Picks up 9th graf pvs, Analysts said ...
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices mostly were higher in see-saw trading today after breaking a weeklong slump with some modest gains in the previous session. Prices had declined early in the session but recovered the day's lost ground and more by midday. The erratic performance came in the wake of official confirmation that OPEC oil ministers were considering calling an emergency meeting to deal with conditions that have seen crude oil futures prices fall 25 percent since January. Wednesday's gains came in one of the wildest sessions of the year, as prices rocketed higher in the afternoon on speculation that OPEC nations were considering calling an emergency meeting. Prices had fallen sharply to start Wednesday's session in what analysts said reflected concerns about the huge supply of crude and weak demand. In London today, OPEC's acting president, Sadek Boussena, said OPEC oil ministers are considering various options, including calling an emergency meeting, to try and stop the recent slide in world oil prices. On the New York Mercantile Exchange at midday, the May contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, was up 9 cents at $18.15 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. It had been down 44 cents at midmorning after rising 38 cents on Wednesday. Among refined products traded on the Merc, the contract for May delivery of unleaded gasoline was off 0.08 cent at 59.50 cents a gallon, after rising 1.15 cents on Wednesday. May home heating oil was up 0.47 cent to 54.10 cents a gallon in early trading, after rising 1.23 cents on Wednesday. Meanwhile, natural gas for June delivery was trading at $1.597 per million British thermal units, down from $1.605 on Wednesday. Analysts said the early price declines on Wednesday reflected the American Petroleum Institute's report, released after the market closed Tuesday, that U.S. crude oil inventories rose by a larger-than-expected 8.1 million barrels last week. But prices rebounded sharply later in the session after rumors circulated that OPEC nations were consulting by telephone and considering calling an emergency meeting about the decline. Spokesmen for the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries at the group's headquarters in Vienna said no meeting had been planned. Analysts say OPEC has been producing more crude oil than the market can absorb in recent weeks, causing prices to decline since late January. It has been estimated that the OPEC nations have been producing between 23.5 million and 24.1 million barrels a day of crude oil, topping its self-imposed cap of 22.1 million barrels. ``The only thing that can turn this market around would be OPEC,'' said James R. Fiedler, a vice president at E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc. Crude oil prices have plunged 25 percent since the near-month contract for West Texas Intermediate reached $24.20 a barrel on Jan. 22. The decline had accelerated in recent days, with the May crude oil contract losing $1.47 a barrel in this week's first two sessions alone, sinking to the lowest level for a near-month contract since February 1989. Despite the big decline in crude futures, motorists haven't seen lower prices at the pump. The national average price for a gallon of gasoline was $1.1331 a gallon on April 6, according to the latest Lundberg Survey of 13,000 gasoline stations nationwide. That compared with an average $1.1306 on Jan. 19. Analysts say there often is a lag of a month to 45 days for refined products to reflect movements in futures prices. In addition, they say gasoline prices normally rise as the spring driving season approaches, and refiners this year are incurring extra costs in meeting tougher anti-smog regulations for their products. Demand for crude oil normally falls off in the early spring, and refineries often take the opportunity to close their plants for maintenance. But this spring, inventories already were high because of an unusually mild winter in Europe and the United States, according to Bob Baker, who tracks the oil markets for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Demand also appears to be weaker than a year ago. Peter Beutel, assistant director of the energy group at Elders Futures Inc., estimated demand for gasoline is down 1.2 percent from a year ago while demand for heating oil fell 8.5 percent. Part of the decline, Beutel said, may stem from a general weakening in economic activity.

For Release PMs Friday April 13
DOC.HEAD: Is The Old Economic Buggy Breaking Down?
DOC.TEXT: In one form or another you can perceive a growing hope among Americans that whatever power it is that pushes the economic pedals and levers knows what it is doing. The mutual concern, arising from consumers and producers, employers and workers, academics and the man and woman about town is that the economy is beginning to sound like an old, poorly maintained car. There's a lot of coughing and sputtering to be heard, a good deal of deterioration to be seen, and a sense that there isn't enough wherewithal to replace the old buggy. Who's in charge? Theoretically, at least, economic policy is made up of fiscal and monetary actions, the first being the responsibility of Congress and the White House, the latter mainly being a function of the Federal Reserve. Of the two, the impact of fiscal policy tends to be slower-acting than monetary policy. It involves taxing, public spending and budgets, for example, while monetary policy involves money supply and interest rates. Interest rates remain fairly high by standards in comparable times of the past three or four decades. Action by the Fed to lower them could spur activity, but so far that body has not deemed such action appropriate. Still, manufacturing is sluggish. The economic index by the nation's purchasing managers association rose slightly in February, but it remained below 50 for the 11th month in a row. Below 50 generally is seen as negative and portending contraction. Similarly, the jobless rate essentially was unchanged in March, with the civilian unemployment rate remaining around 5.2 percent of the labor force. It might have looked good in headlines, but finer print didn't read well. Why did the jobless rate remain steady? Good weather, rather than improving business, resulted in fewer layoffs. Federal government hiring of census workers helped. It will help in April too, when 200,000 will be added. But a disturbing story was contained in the March data. The number of factory jobs declined by 30,000, bringing the manufacturing job loss to about 100,000 since last November. Over a year, such jobs are down by 250,000. Single-family home sales rose 3 percent in February, but that report also wasn't as good as hoped for. The National Association of Home Builders had expected mild weather and some mortgage rate declines to produce better news. ``The year 1990 is stacking up as a weaker year than we expected only a few months ago,'' said NAHB president Martin Perlman. Over the 12 months ended in February, the index of leading economic indicators was down 1 percent, one of the worst year-to-year reports since the mid-1980s. Consumer spending is weak. Production readings too. Not easily measured, but certainly not adding to economic confidence, are various news items, including the ever-worsening savings and loan losses, poor real estate markets in some areas, and the problems with junk bonds. Once upon a time _ many times _ the Federal government would step in and throw money around like confetti to fuel greater growth. But governments at all levels are hurting these days, and they have little money to give. An apparently positive signal flashed a few days ago with reports that U.S. companies would maintain their capital spending programs for new plants and equipment, but that report is being questioned because profits are falling. With effort, it often is possible to assemble a handbasket of bad economic news like this and attempt to convince people that things are going to Hades. But to do so in recent weeks takes no effort at all. Perhaps the most optimistic aspect of the situation is that it isn't new. Several times in the past few years the long economic expansion seemed to be at an end. The old buggy coughed and sputtered, but then it didn't expire. And now, with springtime here, maybe it can find a few more miles in its worn machinery, especially if the Federal Reserve greases the gears with a shot of lower interest rates.

DOC.HEAD: Intel First-Quarter Income Jumps 48 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Intel Corp. said Thursday its first-quarter profit jumped 48 percent, due in part to increased demand for the company's 32-bit computer microprocessors. Profit for the quarter ended March 31 totaled $144 million, or 73 cents a share, compared with $97 million, or 52 cents a share, in the same period a year ago. Revenue for the quarter totaled $894 million, up 25 percent from $713 million in the same quarter last year. ``The transition to 32-bit (computer) architectures has picked up momentum in the past six months,'' said Andrew S. Grove, president and chief executive officer of the Santa Clara-based company. Intel's new 386 and 486 microprocessors process information 32 bits at a time, rather than 16 bits under their original design. A bit is the smallest piece of information used by a computer. The increase expands microprocessor power, capabilities and speed, said Intel spokeswoman Karen Nalley. Grove predicted continued market demand and growth for Intel products in the current quarter. Intel has announced plans to upgrade or expand manufacturing capacity at several of its plants, with capital expenditures for the year estimated at $600 million. In December, the company announced it was phasing out its last chip plant in Silicon Valley and moving production operations to other locations such as Arizona, Oregon and New Mexico, where there is more affordable housing. Intel also said last year it is spending $400 million to build a plant near Dublin, Ireland. The company in January announced a joint venture with NMB Semiconductor Ltd. of Japan to sell NMB's dynamic random-access memory, or DRAM, chips worldwide on an exclusive basis. Intel used to manufacture DRAMs, a vital ingredient in many electronic products, but quit in 1985 when Japanese companies started making them in large quantities and selling them at low prices.

DOC.HEAD: Annual Meetings: Chance for Institutional Investors to Rock the Boat
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: The decline of hostile takeovers may have restored a measure of calm to the boardrooms of U.S. corporations, but that doesn't mean directors and managers are enjoying peace and quiet. Their biggest shareholders, institutional investors such as public-employee pension funds that once endorsed nearly everything corporate executives said or did, have become increasingly vocal and more demanding. They are increasingly sponsoring resolutions at annual meetings, for example, on subjects ranging from shareholder proxy-voting rights to policies on the environment and South Africa. Much to the chagrin of top executives, some big investors have muscled their way into corporate decision-making. ``We're seeing companies voluntarily agreeing to institute confidentiality in proxy votes...(and) Occidental Petroleum agreed to meet with institutional investors on an informal basis,'' Gray Davis, California's comptroller and a trustee of the state's public employee pension funds, said in citing examples of the institutions' evolving power. Perhaps the biggest coup scored by institutional investors came last month at Lockheed Corp.'s annual meeting, when the big stockholders forced management to make some substantial concessions or risk losing their support in a proxy vote instigated by dissident investor Harold Simmons. Lockheed Chairman Daniel Tellep met with 70 institutions in his defense against Simmons' campaign to unseat his company's board. Among the concessions Tellep made was an agreement to name up to three Lockheed directors to represent institutional shareholders. ``He convinced me that he has finally got religion,'' Davis said of Tellep. ``He said the last three months of his life have been the most educational of his career.'' Davis said the institutions' victory with Lockheed will open doors at other corporations that sell stock to the public. ``Management is increasingly affording institutional investors an opportunity to make constructive suggestions,'' he said. Institutional investors are trying to do what any investor wants to do, make a profit. The price of the stock they hold must be at or above a certain level, or the value of assets needed to fund thousands of pensions will fall. For example, if a pension fund held 1 million shares of a company's stock and the stock fell $10 million over the course of a year, the fund's assets would be worth $10 million less than a year earlier. That means there's less money to fund retirees' pensions. Lockheed's stock reached a high of $54.75 a share during the last 12 months, but fell to $36.62{ by March 29, the day of the company's annual meeting. For California Public Employees' Retirement System _ one of the funds of which Davis is a trustee _ the $18-a-share drop meant a decline of more than $9 million in its assets. The stocks of other defense contractors also have fallen recently, but the institutions and other shareholders _ including Simmons _ have been dissatisfied with the company's management and linked its policies directly to the decline in Lockheed's stock price. If they're so unhappy, why don't they just sell their stock? They can't _ at least, not in one fell swoop. With their massive holdings, institutions can't unload an underperforming stock without affecting the rest of the market. Recently, the California, New York City and Massachusetts pension funds jointly sought assurances from Exxon Corp. that the oil giant would protect its earnings _ and therefore its stock price _ by taking steps to prevent another disaster like last year's Exxon Valdez spill. The funds said they approached the company because they couldn't just dump their combined holdings of 14 million Exxon shares. Todd Lang, a partner with the law firm Weil, Gotshal & Manges, said institutions are more active because they are forced to hold onto their shares. Institutional investors have ``a responsibility to their beneficiaries to seek changes or to vote independently...so they develop voting positions on everything,'' Lang said. Many big companies have resisted institutions' attempts to take a larger role in corporate governance. When the California public employees fund and the New York State and Local Retirement System recently asked General Motors Corp. for updates on the search for a successor to retiring chairman Roger Smith, for example, they were told to butt out. ``Corporate governance, which includes the selection of officers, is the board's responsibility,'' GM said in a statement. Last year, Exxon named an environmentalist to its board in response to a request by New York City's employee pension fund. But the request came less than two months after the Exxon Valdez accident. The oil company, fighting criticism about its environmental record, was in no position to refuse. Despite the institutions' recent gains, some pension fund executives say there is still much work to be done. Roland M. Machold, director of New Jersey's Investment Division, sees institutional holders as largely powerless although they hold 40 percent to 50 percent of all outstanding stock. He attributed much of the successes institutional holders had with Lockheed to the threat generated by Simmons, one of the few takeover strategists who has remained relatively active in recent months. ``Certainly we have made our presence known, but companies have tried to close the door on shareholder activity,'' he said. Nonetheless, investor relations consultants are warning management that institutional investors will be rocking the boat harder, and told them this will be increasingly evident at annual meetings. Dale Gerboth, a partner at the accounting and consulting firm Ernst & Young told companies recently, ``Institutional investors are acting more like owners.'' Machold and Davis are two of three co-chairmen of the Council of Institutional Investors, an association of employee benefit plans; state and local agencies that oversee such plans; and not-for-profit foundations and endowments. The council has become an advocate for shareholder rights in the belief that more powerful investors can help effect changes that will benefit all stockholders. The council backs a set of proposals known as the Shareholders Bill of Rights, which among other things includes the principle of one-share, one-vote and calls for shareholders to have a voice in matters that would have significant financial impact on a company. Institutional investors are also opposing some classic takeover defenses, including anti-takeover laws and ``poison pill'' plans, which could limit their ability to receive a higher price for their shares in a buyout. Some have actively pressured companies to rescind corporate policies that award multimillion dollar ``golden parachute'' severance packages to executives if they're dismissed. California's funds have also been active on their own, submitting to the Securities and Exchange Commission proposed revisions on proxy solicitation rules. ``We believe shareholders and employees should be afforded the opportunity to make constructive suggestions to management. The proxy rules as presently constituted don't really afford shareholders that opportunity,'' Davis said. ``Our goal is a more level playing field,'' he said. ``Under current law, management has the upper hand.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Income in 1989 Approaches Half-Million Dollars
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs graf 4, The joint, to CORRECT contributions to deductions.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and his wife, Barbara, reported $208,274 last year from business holdings kept in a blind trust and paid total federal income taxes of $101,382, according to a copy of the first family's tax return released today. The Bushes reported a total gross adjusted income of $456,780 for the year, which includes the income from the blind trust and Bush's government salary of $189,167. The job of president pays $200,000 a year, but Bush was only president for just over 11 months and vice president for 20 days in 1989. The joint tax return filed by the president and his wife listed $94,702 in itemized deductions. Among the contributions was $3,000 in cash for relief organizations to help victims of Hurricane Hugo in the Virgin Island and another $1,500 for similar efforts in the aftermath of the San Francisco-area earthquake. Bush also reported profits of $14,282 in 1989 on his campaign biography, ``Looking Forward.'' He divided all the proceeds between two charities: the United Negro College Fund in New York and the M.D. Anderson Cancer Center of Houston. The Bush's paid taxes equivalent to 22.2 percent of their total income. In addition to his rise in slary in going from the job of vice president to the presidency, the blind trust Bush set up in 1981 when he became vice president showed a profitable year. The $208,274 in interest and dividend earnings through partnerships and other ventures, masked by the blind trust, was up from $155,662 reported in the previous year. Meanwhile, Vice President Dan Quayle and his wife, Marilyn, reported that they paid total taxes of $25,479 on adjusted gross income of $133,696. Most of the income consisted of Quayle's government salary _ $106,528 as vice president and $3,715 in January 1989 during the governmental transition period. The Quayles reported $14,572 in dividend earnings in 1989 on stock holdings in Central Newspapers Inc. Bush, who has lobbied long and hard for a reduction on the capital gains tax, wound up paying taxes on a long-term capital gain of $36,068. In his income bracket the capital gains tax is 28 percent; under his proposal it would be just under 20 percent. The gain was reported by the blind trust, therefore the nature of it was not revealed. The capital gains tax applies to profits from the sale of stock, real estate or other assets. Overall, the Bushes claimed $94,702 in itemized deductions, including the $37,272 they gave in contributions to 39 charities. The blind trust also gave $594 to unspecified charities. Like many Americans, the amount withheld from Bush's paycheck _ and quarterly payments to the Internal Revenue Service _ didn't quite cover the tax bill. So the Bushes had to send off a check to the IRS regional office in Philadelphia of $3,228.

DOC.HEAD: Women Still Subservient in the Family Finances, But Influence is Growing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs next-to-last graf to CORRECT consciousness to conscience in quote.
DOC.TEXT: Matt Fisher is the family risk taker, known to delay paying the electric bill until the ``disconnect notice'' comes, while his wife Barbara is a virtuoso at balancing the checkbook. Fisher, 34, feels reasonably comfortable with things like corporate bonds or growth stocks. Mrs. Fisher, 42, gets uneasy at the mention of those words. Still, the Jacksonville, Fla., couple, who recently opened a hair-replacement business, mix love and money successfully. They keep half their $200,000 investment portfolio in stocks and bonds and the rest in short-term certificates of deposit or money market accounts. Neither makes an investment decision without the other, they say. For every couple like the Fishers, however, there are several more that fail to jointly plan or even discuss important personal financial matters. Experts say part of the problem is that a large number of women have been slow in gaining equality in the home when it comes to money. Even though women have emerged from the Money Decade of the '80s as the fastest growing part of the work force, their role in shaping the family's financial future remains stuck in a bygone world, some investment planners say. ``Women are still in a very transitional role in which a man makes the investment decisions,'' said Marilyn Cohen, a principal of Capital Insight Inc. of Beverly Hills, Calif. ``I don't find the young urban professional woman any more interested in money and investing than her mother who had a traditional housewife role. I find it very distressing.'' Michael Stein, a financial planner with Brownson Rehmus & Foxworth in Chicago, said he also has encountered apathy in many of the working women among his married clients, largely comprised of wealthy, middle-aged executives. While the wives may be more likely to manage day-to-day family finances, like balancing the checkbook and paying household bills, the husbands usually have the upper hand in making the major financial decisions, he said. ``Often where you have two executive units...the husband still tends to be the dominant one,'' Stein said. ``A dominating woman is the exception more than the rule.'' Not surprisingly, couples' financial concerns vary with age. Investment counselors say a younger couple likely will be more concerned with making house payments and accumulating wealth than a middle-aged pair, which is starting to think about retirement or paying off a child's college loan. Victoria Felton-Collins, a financial planner and psychologist with offices in California, said money values start between the ages of 4 and 12. Many Americans, she said, have trouble shedding the traditional male-female roles ingrained in their past regardless of economic changes. ``Both men and women are, in fact, perpetuating this,'' said Felton-Collins, who wrote the recently published book ``Couples & Money.'' ``I've seen very successful women who go home and turn their paychecks over to their husbands. They may manage millions of dollars for their companies but when they get home it's a different story.'' That relationship, however, is slowly changing as women continue to enter the work force and gain greater financial confidence. Felton-Collins said she expects that to continue through the '90s. ``Maybe it's going to take another generation _ the daughters of these young urban professional women,'' said Cohen.``They see their working mothers bringing home paychecks.'' About 60 percent of all women of working age are employed outside the home, and by the year 2000 women are expected to comprise about half of the nation's total work force. Full-time women workers are making more than they once did and some nearly bring home as much as their spouses. Still, only one in six married women working full-time brings home more money than her husband, a figure that has remained constant for a decade. Census Bureau figures show that on average, women still only earn about 65 percent of their husband's income. Eileen Sharkey, who runs the Denver financial planning service Sharkey & Associates Inc., said that in her practice she has seen more women taking an active role in finances over the past 10 years. But she said, ``I don't think there's ever going to be equality in terms of interest. There will always be men who won't give up the checkbook and women who won't give up tennis ... and the other way around.'' Often, it's not until death or divorce that women take a more active role in their financial future, said Jan Warner, a Columbia, S.C., lawyer who runs SoloSource Inc., a service that counsels divorced women on financial options. Warner estimates that three-quarters of his female clients, most of whom are age 40 or older, come to him without the financial know-how needed to make it alone comfortably. ``The average person that comes to us has been the victim of the demise of a 15-to 20-year-old marriage with no business acumen because she has relied on someone else to do it,'' he said. ``And we deal with some pretty good business women.'' Mary Lynn, 47, a real estate broker from Cleveland, fits into that category. Recently divorced from her husband of 24 years, she has crammed to learn enough about investment matters to make it on her own. The woman, who asked not to be identified by her full married name, said she expected to receive between $50,000 and $60,000 once the family house is sold. She's looking for investments. ``He (the ex-husband) just basically did all the decision making where money was concerned,'' she said. ``I guess that was one of the sore spots. He never really asked or consulted me.'' Stein, the financial planner, said that wives of breadwinners, no matter how stable their marriages might seem, should try to garner some financial independence. He suggested they establish credit and accummulate assets solely in their own name, since their husbands likely are doing just that through their own company retirement plans. ``Money and the inability to discuss it openly and honestly causes more damn problems than anything else,'' said Hank Madden, a financial planner with IDS Financial Services Inc.'s Jacksonville, Fla., office, who has been advising the Fishers. He said the hair-replacement entrepreneurs stand out among his clients because each would be prepared to make an investment decision individually. Still, he said, the financial philosophies of the Fishers appear to reflect some sexual stereotypes. Men, for example, are more likely to be risk-takers, while women tend to be a bit more conservative and accountable. ``Barbara is my conscience. She is more frugal,'' Fisher said of his wife. ``I'm concerned with losing money; that's my biggest fear,'' said Mrs. Fisher. ``He has a more in-depth grip on what's happening. He would come home and tell me about whatever he's interested in and we would make a decision together.''

DOC.HEAD: Group Plans Takeover Effort for Close-out Retail Chain
DOC.TEXT: A former lieutenant of T. Boone Pickens is leading an investment group that has bought 6.6 percent of the stock of Pic `N' Save Corp. and plans a takeover bid for the close-out retail chain. The investment group, Girard Partners, disclosed in a filing Wednesday with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it paid $25 million for the stock. The filing said the group will seek control of Pic `N' Save's board. William M. Jacobs Jr., Pic `N' Save's senior vice president and chief financial officer, said company officials would have no comment until studying the SEC filing. Girard Partners is led by David H. Batchelder, who served as Pickens' chief strategist until 1988. Another member of the group is Robert H. McNulty, president and chief executive of the HQ Office Supplies Warehouse retail chain and a founder of the Home Club chain. There is speculation that the investors may plan to overhaul Pic `N' Save, which faces tough competition and has little attractive real estate or other assets, according to Sarah Stack, a retail analyst with the Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards Inc. brokerage in Los Angeles. ``Management is at risk,'' Ms. Stack said. She note that institutional investors hold about 69 percent of Pic `N' Save's stock while just 3 percent is held by management. Pic `N' Save, based in the Dominguez suburb of Los Angeles, had about $400 million in sales last year and employs about 5,000 people. It buys manufacturers' close-out merchandise and sells it at discounts to customers.

DOC.HEAD: March Sales at Chain Stores Fair to Poor; Improvement Seen for April
With BC-Retail Sales-Table
DOC.TEXT: This year's later Easter and lackluster business conditions made March a mediocre month for many of the nation's major chain stores, retailers reported Thursday. Store executives and retail economists said April should turn out to be a better month for business as holiday promotions capitalize on a seasonal upsurge in demand for spring clothing and other merchandise. The retailers' March results varied. Some big chains had stronger-than-expected sales. Management at some companies asserted that sales actually were quite good considering they missed out on pre-Easter business. Rosalind Wells, chief economist at the National Retail Federation in New York, said, ``stores are looking forward to a successful Easter sales period in April'' after an encouraging March. Last month's sales were compared with March 1989, when stores drew customers because of holiday promotions pushing everything from spring clothing to candy. Easter fell on March 26 last year. The largest chain reporting Thursday was K mart Corp., which blamed the calendar shift for its so-so showing. The Troy, Mich.-based discounter, which ranked second in nationwide sales volume last year behind Sears, Roebuck and Co., said its total sales for the five weeks ended April 4 rose 8.6 percent. But sales fell 1.1 percent at stores open at least a year. Results from stores open a year or longer give a more accurate reading on a retailer's performance. These same-store, or comparable-store, results exclude sales at new outlets, which sometimes are inflated temporarily by the hoopla of store openings. ``Sales were strong in the first two weeks of March but, because of the later date for Easter in 1990 than in 1989, sales weakened in line with expectations in the latter part of the month,'' said K mart Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Joseph E. Antonini. Several major mass merchandisers, such as Sears, Wal-Mart Stores Inc., J.C. Penney Co. Inc. and others, already posted their March sales a week ago. Overall, those results were sluggish. The exceptions were the perennial star performer Wal-Mart and stores concentrating on apparel, including Penney. Apparel-oriented retailers have almost consistently outpaced general merchandise chains that devote much of their business to costly durable goods for more than a year. Subpar economic growth _ with workers in some industries worried about layoffs _ have made consumers cautious about spending heavily or going into debt to finance expensive purchases. The government's more comprehensive retail sales report, also issued Thursday, illustrated how a weak economy has flashed warning signals to consumers. Outlays have been curbed by the Federal Reserve Board's high interest rate policy aimed at diffusing inflationary pressures. The Commerce Department said retail sales fell a seasonally adjusted 0.6 percent in March from February. The report covered sales at a wide range of establishments including stores, auto dealerships, restaurants and elsewhere. Still, some stores have managed to prosper. ``I think overall the companies that have been doing well in the past continue to improve market share in a very challenging environment,'' said retail analyst Richard Pyle at Piper Jaffrey & Hopwood in Minneapolis. ``It does appear that the shoppers are willing to spend if the merchants have the right merchandise.'' Dayton Hudson Corp., the Minneapolis-based owner of the Target discount chain and Mervyn's department stores, did well in March. Companywide sales rose 14.9 percent in the five weeks ended April 7 while sales at stores open at least a year gained 8.2 percent. May Department Stores Co. posted a 7.5 percent increase in sales over a year earlier. The St. Louis-based chain, which operates Lord & Taylor and numerous other well-known retail names, reported the results from continuing operations only. Its same-store sales were up only 2.7 percent. Los Angeles-based Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. said weakness in women's and children's apparel as well as in shoes contributed to a 1.9 percent sales drop overall and a 2.4 percent on a comparable store basis. Among stores selling exclusively apparel, The Limited Inc. said its sales rose 8 percent but rose a more modest 4 percent on a comparable store basis. Analysts said the sales gains for the Limited, which has its headquarters in Columbus, Ohio, were lower than in many past months because sales were compared with March 1989's robust results. Another apparel specialty chain, The Gap Inc., posted a 20 percent jump in March sales. Same-store sales rose 12 percent.

The stock market gained ground in quiet preholiday trading today. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 23.20 to 2,752.93 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 851 up, 564 down and 534 unchanged. Analysts said traders came into the session with low expectations, given the market's recent sluggish behavior and the approach of a long holiday weekend. The markets will be closed for Good Friday. In that kind of environment, observers said, an absence of selling pressure helped produce some pleasant surprises in the price fluctuations of individual stocks. The government reported that retail sales dropped .06 percent in March, in contrast to advance estimates of a small increase. That served as a new suggestion of continued sluggish, erratic economic growth, along with possibly less upward pressure on interest rates than has been feared of late. Ames Department Stores led the active list, down } at 1} on reports that some manufacturers had stopped shipping merchandise to the troubled retailer. Intel, one of the volume leaders in the over-the-counter market, rose \ to 43. The company reported earnings for the quarter ended March 31 of 73 cents a share, up from 52 cents in the like period a year earlier. Chemical Banking, which also posted higher quarterly profits, gained 1 to 24]. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks climbed 1.14 to 188.71. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was off .04 at 357.50. Volume on the Big Board came to 117.07 million shares with an hour to go.
Stock prices broke out of their recent holding pattern with a rally today. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 21.85 at 2,751.58.

DOC.HEAD: Hilton Hits Jackpot as Casino Take Pushes Quarterly Profit Up 92 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Record casino gambling profits pushed quarterly earnings up 92 percent at Hilton Hotels Corp., which took itself off the auction block in March because of disappointing low offers. ``The Las Vegas Hilton results last year were abnormally low, but the improvement there and at the Flamingo Hilton-Las Vegas are positive considering the recent capacity expansion along the Las Vegas Strip,'' said Hilton's chairman, Barron Hilton. During its first quarter, which ended March 31, Hilton had net income of $25.1 million, or 52 cents per share, compared with $13.1 million, or 27 cents per share, in the same period a year earlier. Revenue rose by 18 percent, from $225.1 million to $265.5 million. Hotel income was up 8 percent at $22.8 million, Hilton said. But it was in the gaming segment where profits rocketedby 119 percent to $33.8 million, the highest level in the company's history, Hilton said. The company had held discussions with nearly a dozen potential buyers before its board of directors voted to take down the ``for sale'' sign after rejecting two final bids worth nearly $3.8 billion each.

DOC.HEAD: NY Times Co. Posts 1st-Qtr Profit Decline
DOC.TEXT: The New York Times Co. said Thursday its first-quarter profit fell 50.4 percent, citing lower advertising linage at its flagship newspaper, an operating loss at its magazine group, costs associated with a new printing plant and weaker results from its forest products investment. The company said it earned $16.6 million, or 22 cents a share, in the three months ended March 31 compared with $33.5 million, or 42 cents a share, a year earlier. The 1989 results included $2 million from cable operations that have since been sold. First-quarter revenue rose 1.9 percent to $431.2 million from $423.1 million a year earlier. Operating profit at the company's newspaper group, which includes The New York Times, 35 regional newspapers and a one-third interest in The International Herald Tribune, fell to $38.4 million from $55.9 million a year earlier. The company said the main reason was an 11.8 percent decline in ad linage at The New York Times because of the continuing weakeness in the New York region's economy. About 75 percent of the decline in linage was in the help-wanted and real estate classifications, which are sensitive to economic conditions. ``Our strong business franchises and our recent investments position us for renewed growth when the economy of the New York region improves,'' said Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman and chief executive. The company's magazine group posted an operating loss of $3.8 million in contrast to an operating profit of $700,000 in first quarter 1989. The loss resulted primarily from costs associated with the July 1989 acquisition of McCall's magazine. The company said increased depreciation and interest expense associated with completion of a new automated color production and distribution facility in Edison, N.J., and a new facility for the Gwinnett (Ga.) Daily News also depressed its latest results. The company's equity in earnings after taxes from its forest products group fell to $30,000 from $3.6 million a year ago as a result of price discounting in the newsprint market. Operating profit from its broadcasting and information services operations was steady.

DOC.HEAD: KKR, Nabisco Mull Bonds Due In 2007
DOC.TEXT: Most of the junk bonds that financed the megatakeover of RJR Nabisco Inc. are due in 2007, but recent gyrations in prices of the volatile bonds indicate how speculators are betting on the company's chances of paying them off. Earlier this week some high-yield Nabisco issues rose as much as 4{ points, or about $45 per $1,000 in face value, before easing Thursday as investors cashed in gains. Although Nabisco is considered one of the less risky issues in the market for high-yield debt, its bonds have been volatile for months. Traders recently have focused on rumors that Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., which bought Nabisco last year for a record $24.53 billion, might be buying up an issue of bonds to avoid having to pay sharply higher interest on them next year. But others say the bond price jump reflects anticipation of a favorable first-quarter earnings report for the tobacco and consumer products giant. Nabsico's first quarter earnings, due out later this month, are expected to show a marked improvement over the previous quarter, when the company lost $144 million. Nabisco lost $1.15 billion for all of 1989, but had positive cash flow of $647 million after all interest payments were made. ``If the market gets some feeling that the company is doing a great job, then the bonds will go up and react more like stocks'' to the news, said Jack Maxwell, an analyst at Wheat First Securities in Richmond, Va. Both Nabisco and KKR have a keen interest in seeing the bonds trade at high prices. Although the bulk of bonds _ about $4.5 billion worth _ don't mature until 2007, their interest rate must be ``reset'' in April 1991, or adjusted to restore the bond price to face value. Bond prices move inversely to their interest rates, so the lower the price of the RJR Nabisco bonds, the higher the interest rate the company must offer at the reset. Some market watchers speculate, for example, that the rate on RJR's 13.71 percent convertible bonds due in 2007 might have to be reset at 20 percent or more. Rumors circulating in the marketplace indicate KKR might be in the process of buying back $2 billion of bonds due in 2009 that are convertible to stock. Analysts say such a move not only would increase KKR's stake in Nabisco, but also likely would help boost the value of other outstanding Nabisco junk bonds _ helping cut the potential reset interest rate. Spokespeople for both KKR and Nabisco had no comment Thursday on the rumors. ``It's not the first time KKR has been rumored to be buying the bonds,'' said Joan Greenberg, senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. But ``we saw greater (price) movement this time,'' she said. Despite the recent upturn in prices, some believe it hasn't been enough to allay Nabisco's and KKR's concerns. ``When you face a reset, the main problem is ... the interest expense might be too much for a company to bear,'' said Robert Waill, a vice president at the Stamford Co., a Manhattan-based investment management firm. ``You can be assured that the KKR people are thinking about his problem.'' But Wheat First's Maxwell believes the time ahead of the reset date will help Nabisco. If positive fundamental data emerges on the company and the bond prices rise, ``the less you have to worry about them and the more people (there will be) buying them,'' he said. Maxwell said the Nabisco bonds suffered from the demise of junk-bond pioneer Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the once-powerful investment house that collapsed in February and has been in liquidation. Plunging prices forced managers of junk bond portfolios to sell some better-quality, marketable securities such as RJR Nabisco after Drexel left the scene as the sole market-maker in a number of low-quality junk bonds. ``The couldn't sell the real junk because there was no market, but there's an actual market in RJR junk,'' Maxwell said.

DOC.HEAD: Chemical Posts 1st Qtr Gain On Asset Sales; Bank of NY Income Flat
DOC.TEXT: Chemical Banking Corp. on Thursday posted a 29 percent rise in its first quarter profit from a year earlier due largely to the sale of its interest in Florida National Banks, while Bank of New York Corp. reported flat earnings. Both of the major banking companies said problem loans, led by debt to Third World countries, continued pressuring their results. Analysts said the results generally were in line with expectations. Meanwhile, Chemical continued to downplay criticism of its credit position, calling ``inappropriate'' the slight downgrading Thursday of some of its debt and preferred stock by the rating service Fitch Investors Service of New York. Chemical said its first quarter profit totaled $151.7 million, or $1.55 per share, compared with earnings of $117.9 million, or $1.49 a share, in 1989. This year's results included a pre-tax charge of $52 million for a previously announced restructuring and a pre-tax gain of $115 million from the recent sale of its investment in Florida National Banks of Florida Inc. Bank of New York, which merged with Irving Bank Corp. in a $1 billion deal a year ago, said it netted $102.3 million during the period, up 1 percent from $101.05 million a year ago. Earnings per share remained unchanged at $1.37. The company said earnings were hurt by a $17.5 million addition to its loan-loss allowance. The provision for the quarter rose to $63 million from $46 million. During the quarter, Bank of New York reduced its medium-term loans to less developed countries to $552 million, resulting in charge-offs of $207 million. Most of Bank of New York's Third World debt portfolio was inherited from Irving. Chemical said lower interest income on medium- and long-term loans to Brazil and Mexico helped depress its net interest income for the quarter, to $482.4 million from $549.2 million last year. Total non-performing assets declined by $265 million to $3.24 billion for the entire company. At Chemical's Texas Commerce Bancshare Inc. subsidiary non-performing assets, including problem real estate loans, fell by $222 million from a year earlier. Chemical's provision for loan losses was $70 million, compared with $90.7 million in the year-earlier quarter. ``Their asset quality is getting better,'' said James J. McDermott Jr., a banking analyst with Keefe Bruyette & Woods in New York. Other analysts took a dimmer view. ``They look weak to me when you take out the unusual items,'' Stephen Berman, an analyst with County Securities USA, said of Chemical's net results. Chemical said non-interest income rose to $445.7 million from $330.8 million. But without a $114.7 million pre-tax gain on the sale of its holdings of common stock warrants of Florida National Banks, income in that category would have been flat, it said. Chemical also said its non-interest expense rose, to $688 million from $642 million, largely due to a $52.3 million charge for restructuring to reduce operating expenses. Without the charge, non-interest expenses would have declined 8.7 percent, the company said. Chemical's earnings report coincided with Fitch's announcement that it lowered its rating on about $540 million of the company's debt, including its senior notes, debentures, floating rate notes, and $200 million of preferred stock. The ratings, which affect the company's borrowing costs, still are considered investment grade. Furthermore, Fitch is only one of several debt rating services, which include industry giants Moody's Investors Service Inc. and Standard & Poor's Corp. Fitch said its downgradings reflecting a weakening real estate market in the Northeast, Chemical's primary lending market. Chemical Chief Financial Officer Joseph G. Sponholz called the action ``inappropriate ... given the steps taken to strengthen our balance sheet and the pattern of continuing improvement in the corporation's credit quality. Bank of New York, which released its results at its annual shareholders meeting, said its net interest income rose 8 percent to $351 million. Non-interest income was $233 million, unchanged from a year ago, while non-interest expense declined to $335.5 million from $342.7 million, due to savings realized from the Irving merger. Chairman J. Carter Bacot told shareholders, ``We're very delighted with the way the merger has gone.'' The merger expected to be completed by year's end.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Slide On Brazil Harvest Pressure
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT that Brazil is second-largest soybean exporter sted largest, by DELETING word `largest'; picks up 4th graf: ``They could ...
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices closed moderately lower Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting increasing harvest pressure from Brazil, while grain futures ended mixed in subdued, pre-holiday trading. The grain markets will be closed on Good Friday. The soybean harvest in Brazil, the world's second-largest soybean producer and exporter, was 37 percent complete at the end of last week and is expected to advance more rapidly due to clearing weather, analysts said. ``They could very easily be at the halfway point by the middle of next week,'' said Joel Karlin, a grain analyst in Chicago with Research Department Inc., a brokers' advisory service. Exports of Brazilian soybeans and soybean meal are also expected to rise now that the Brazilian government has clarifed some of the inflation-fighting measures that had held up shipments of goods from the South American nation since last month. Sales of corn futures Thursday by commercial grain dealers could indicate the Soviet Union has filled its needs for the present with purchases of more than 1.5 million metric tons of U.S. corn during the past week, Karlin said. At the close, wheat futures were 1 cent lower to 2\ cents higher with May at $3.67 a bushel; corn was 1 cent to 2 cents lower with May at $2.69} a bushel; oats were } cent to 1{ cents lower with May at $1.50 a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents to 6\ cents lower with May at $5.87{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Still Under Selling Pressure
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures closed mostly lower Thursday as the oil markets finished a hectic holiday-shortened week dominated by selling. The contract for May delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, pulled back by 28 cents to settle at $17.78 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The loss wiped out much of Wednesday's 38 cent-gain that came after a wild session of ups and downs. Later crude oil contracts also declined Thursday, but by smaller amounts. Among refined products traded on the Merc, the contract for May delivery of unleaded gasoline dropped 1.03 cents to 58.55 cents a gallon, erasing most of Wednesday's increase of 1.15 cents. Other contract months also fell. May home heating oil, however, rose 0.20 cent to 53.83 cents a gallon, after advancing 1.23 cents on Wednesday. Contracts for delivery during June, July and August posted losses ranging from 0.67 cent to 0.98 cent. Meanwhile, natural gas for June delivery settled at $1.598 per million British thermal units, down from $1.605 on Wednesday. Contracts for late delivery were mixed. Energy analysts said trading was heavy. Commercial operators, such as oil companies, as well as smaller traders were said to be active in the market. U.S. and European markets will be closed Friday ahead of Easter Sunday. Markets in Europe will remain closed on Easter Monday and reopen Tuesday, while U.S. markets will be open Monday. Oil futures came under strong selling pressure this week as concern about abundant supplies overhanging world markets intensified. ``The overall trend is still down,'' said a trader at Merrill Lynch Energy Futures who spoke on condition that his name not be used. ``Today we didn't have nearly as much reaction as Wednesday _ that was a wild and crazy day.'' The catalyst for the selloff this week was a report from the American Petroleum Institute, released after the market closed Tuesday, that U.S. crude oil inventories rose by an unexpectedly large 8.1 million barrels last week, bringing stocks significantly higher than a year earlier. Lingering worries about oversupply by OPEC members also depressed prices. Responding to the price weakness, OPEC's acting president Sadek Boussena on Thursday said the cartel ministers were weighing various steps, including an emergency meeting, to try to halt the slide in world oil prices. Market rumors that OPEC was considering such a meeting to deal with the price declines, which have trimmed $3 a barrel in recent weeks, had helped arrest a plunge in prices Wednesday.

The Russell 3000 index of companies with the largest market value closed at 191.18 Friday, up 1.83, or 0.97 percent, from a week ago and down 6.10, or 3.09 percent, this year to date. The Russell 1000 index of the largest companies, closed at 179.43 Friday, up 1.86, or 1.05 percent, from a week ago and down 5.73, or 3.40 percent, this year to date. The Russell 2000 index of smaller companies, closed at 162.58 Friday, down 0.20, or 0.12 percent, from a week ago and down 5.73, or 3.40 percent, this year to date.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Narrowly Mixed, Trading Quiet
Precede LONDON-BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished narrowly mixed Thursday in quiet trading ahead of the Easter holiday weekend. Gold prices rose worldwide. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $375.90 a troy ounce, up $1.60 from late Wednesday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $375.25 an ounce, up 50 cents. Activity finished early in Europe, where traders have a four-day weekend. In domestic dealings, traders spent a dull session squaring accounts ahead of what will be a short trading session on Friday. ``There's not much interest out there at all,'' said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. The most notable activity came from Japanese investors, who sold dollars for yen. Flanagan said there was some speculation among traders that the Bank of Japan might move to raise interest rates over the weekend in an attempt to bolster the weak Japanese currency. Still, the dollar maintained its strength against the yen, relinquishing ground only in Asian trading. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell 0.50 yen to a closing 158.00 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at 158.14 yen. In New York, the dollar closed at 158.18 yen, up from 157.95 yen on Wednesday. In London, the British pound fell to $1.6425 from $1.6432 late Wednesday. In New York, sterling fell to $1.6420 from Wednesday's $1.6425. DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Falls
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply fell in the week ended April 2, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 fell to a seasonally adjusted $3,269 billion from $3,273 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, fell to a seasonally adjusted $4,062.3 billion from $4,069.4 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose to a seasonally adjusted $808.3 billion from $804.9 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 6.4 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 is 2.9 percent, which is below the Fed's target range of 3.5 percent to 7.5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,251.5 billion, a 6.2 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,058.9 billion, up 3.0 percent, while M1 rose 4.9 percent to an average of $800.5 billion. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported commercial and industrial loans at major New York City banks rose $872 million. _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $116 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, down from $244 million the previous week. _The Federal Reserve said net free reserves averaged $880 million in the two weeks ended April 4, up from $572 million in the previous two-week period. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $302 billion in the two-week period ended April 4, down from $304.2 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Close Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing stock prices.
DOC.TEXT: Prices rose on London's Stock Exchange Thursday despite a lackluster session before the four-day Easter holiday weekend. The market will be closed for Good Friday and Easter Monday. Britain's annual inflation rate, as expected, jumped to 8.1 percent in March from 7.5 percent in February, largely because of increases in mortgage rates, the government said. The unemployment rate, meanwhile, held steady at 5.6 percent in March, it said. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-stock index closed 6.6 points, or 0.3 percent, higher, at 2,222.1, just below its session high of 2,222.2. The index's session low was 2,209.5. Volume amounted to a light 324.5 million shares, compared with 311.7 million shares Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Resume Downward Course In Nervous Trading
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil futures resumed their downward spiral Thursday, giving back most of Wednesday's gains in a day of roller-coaster trading that revolved around the prospects for an emergency OPEC meeting. Most futures prices of refined oil products also fell in trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange. On other commodity markets, live cattle futures posted new record highs; pork futures advanced; grains and soybeans were mixed; and precious metals were mixed. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 6 cents to 28 cents lower with the contract for delivery in May at $17.78 a barrel. Wholesale home heating oil was 1.06 cents lower to .20 cent higher with May at 53.83 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .35 cent to 1.03 cents lower with May at 58.55 cents a gallon. Crude oil for May delivery opened above Wednesday's settlement price, quickly turned sharply lower, then bounced within a 93-cent range amid reports that OPEC oil ministers were weighing various steps, including an emergency meeting, to halt the slide in world oil prices. Overproduction of crude by some members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has been blamed by some analysts for a $3-a-barrel plunge in oil prices over the past six weeks. Springtime is a period of seasonal weakness in the oil market as demand for heating oil tapers off. OPEC's 13 oil ministers have a full meeting scheduled for May 25 to set their output and prices for the second half of the year. But some traders speculated the cartel would meet sooner than that to discuss ways of propping up prices. ``I think a lot of people were very confused today,'' said Tom Bentz, director of trading for United Energy Inc. ``There were a lot of people below the market with buy orders and a lot above the market with sell orders,'' he said. Bentz said the final selloff, late in the session, may have reflected profit-taking ahead of the three-day Easter holiday weekend that begins Friday. Live cattle futures made record highs for the second straight day on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange amid perceptions of tight near-term supplies and reports of spot cattle prices as high as 82 cents a pound in the Texas panhandle. Analysts said the record prices reflect a seasonal peak in demand for beef and supply tightness stemming from delayed cattle marketings as a result of dry pasture conditions in the Southern Plains last fall and winter. Futures prices are lower than spot prices, prompting some packers to turn to the futures market for deliveries, which is also boosting prices, said Philip Stanley, a trader and consultant for DEC Futures Inc. in Lincoln, Neb. ``On any sign of weakness in the cash market you'll probably see some pretty active selling come into the futures even with the discounts on the board,'' tanley said. Live cattle futures settled .27 cent lower to .05 cent higher with the April contract, which traded up to a record 80.47 cents, ending at 80.42 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .13 cent lower to .22 cent higher with April at 84 cents a pound; live hogs were .15 cent to .50 cent higher with April at 56.17 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .25 cent lower to 1.25 cents higher with May at 59.02 cents a pound. Soybean futures fell moderately on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting increasing harvest pressure from Brazil, while grain futures ended mixed in subdued, pre-holiday trading. Wheat futures settled 1 cent lower to 2\ cents higher with May at $3.67 a bushel; corn was 1{ cents to 2 cents lower with May at $2.69{ a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 1{ cents lower with May at $1.49} a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents to 6 cents lower with May at $5.86} a bushel. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold settled $1.30 to $1.60 higher with April at $375.90 a troy ounce; silver was 4 cents lower across the board with May at $5.108 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: The decline, 2nd graf
Bond Prices Fall in Lackluster Trading
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices slipped Thursday in light, pre-holiday trading, with little economic news to affect the direction of the market, traders said. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond fell 7-32 point, or about $2.19 for every $1,000 in face amount. Its yield, which rises when the price declines, rose to 8.59 percent from 8.57 percent late Wednesday. Traders said a retail sales report released by the government Thursday morning initially boosted Treasury prices because the March sales figure was weaker than expected. An indication of economic sluggishness boosts bonds because it implies the Federal Reserve may act to ease interest rates. But news that the government revised the February retail sales figure upward, from an 0.8 percent decline to an 0.3 percent decline, caused bond prices to give up their gains. Tom Lanier, a Treasury bond trader for Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co., said there was little activity in the market. ``There's no buying going on and we keep getting hit by supply,'' he said, referring to the Treasury's scheduled announcements next week on upcoming bill and note auctions and an announcement Thursday from Resolution Trust Corp., the government's thrift bailout agency, on its bond auction plans. The RTC said it may sell up to $42.7 billion in bonds this quarter, about $20 billion more than Wall Street thought it would try to sell, Lanier said. News of an increased supply of bonds can send prices lower for fear of a temporary oversupply, but Lanier said the effect on prices Thursday was minimal. Traders said there was little economic news to affect the market all week. The important wholesale price index for March will be released Friday, when the market will be closed for the Good Friday holiday. Traders said the market virtually shut down about 2 p.m. EDT in advance of the day off. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term government issues fell from 1-16 point to 3-32 point, intermediate maturities dropped from 5-32 to 7-32 point, and long-term issues fell 7-32 point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 1.13 to 1,150.01. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds was unchanged at 91 7-16. The average yield to maturity rose to 7.72 percent from 7.51 percent last Wednesday. Yields on three-month Treasury bills remained at 8 percent as the discount held at 7.75 percent. Yields on six-month bills rose to 8.19 percent as the discount rose 2 basis points to 7.77 percent. Yields on one-year bills rose to 8.26 percent as the discount rose 1 basis point to 7.68 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8[ percent, unchanged from late Wednesday.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Udpates with morning Nikkei, comments
DOC.TEXT: Stocks reversed their opening gains and traded lower Thursday morning on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average fell 197.73 points, or 0.67 percent, ending the morning session at 29,242.55. The index, which shed 184.40 points Wednesday, had opened more than 230 points higher before falling. The dollar edged upward but remained slightly below Wednesday's levels. The U.S. currency closed the morning session at 158.37 yen, up from 158.17 yen at the opening but down from 158.50 at Wednesday's finish. The dollar closed at 157.95 yen in New York overnight, up from 157.60 yen late Tuesday. Estimated volume on the first section of the stock exchange was a light 230 million shares. ``Trading was inactive, and investors sold small amounts of stock intermittently,'' said Kazuyuki Suzuki, a trader with Daiwa Securities Co. He attributed the index's loss mainly to a lack of confidence stemming from repeated losses in recent weeks. ``Stock investors are also nervous about the yen's weakness against the West German mark, instead of the dollar, and this is adding to the market's pessimism,'' Suzuki added. The dollar inched up from its opening level as market players sold the yen against the West German mark, dealers said. ``As market players are having difficulties figuring out the direction of dollar-yen trading, their interest has shifted from the dollar to the mark,'' said Minori Takeuchi, a dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. Other dealers said market players generally avoided major moves ahead of the Easter holidays in many European nations beginning Friday. Prices of government bonds eased, pushing up interest rates slightly. The yield on the benchmark No. 119 government bond rose to 7.305 percent from 7.295 percent the previous day.

DOC.HEAD: Debt Holders Told Company Won't Be Profitable Until End of 1993
DOC.TEXT: Southland Corp. said it will continue to lose money until 1993 even if debt holders agree to forego $1.6 billion in interest payments as part of a complex debt restructuring. The owner of the 7-Eleven convenience store chain projected a small $38 million profit in 1993 if it can restructure its debts and use cash to revamp its stores. The forecast was contained in a preliminary prospectus on the restructuring that the company issued Wednesday. The plan involves the restructuring of $1.8 billion in bonds and preferred stock, and would require holders of those securities to forego $1.6 billion in interest payments due through 1997. It also calls for selling 75 percent of the company to Japanese business partners. The company is struggling because it took on about $4.9 billion in debt when the founding Thompson family took Southland private in 1987. The company lost $1.3 billion last year. The prospectus said Southland expects to lose $156 million this year, $61 million in 1991 and $9 million in 1992. Capital investments in new stores should bring the company a $38 million profit in 1993 and a $67 million gain in 1994. Southland late last month announced plans to sell 75 percent of the company to its Japanese partners, Ito-Yokado Co. Ltd. and 7-Eleven Japan Co. Ltd., in exchange for $400 million in badly needed cash. Bond holders are skeptical about the proposal, which would give them a stake of about 10 percent, the Thompson family about 10 percent and other common shareholders about 5 percent of the restructured company. Southland officials reiterated their belief that unless bondholders approve the restructuring, cash-flow problems would force the company to seek relief under the bankruptcy code. The preliminary filing stated that Southland plans to open 1,814 new stores and close 1,724 others by the end of 1997 to compete with convenience store rivals. Southland opened 60 stores and closed 340 others in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Some Suppliers Reportedly Shutting Off Ames
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf to RESTORE million to acquisition price.
DOC.TEXT: Some suppliers reportedly are refusing to ship goods to Ames Department Stores, putting further pressure on the loss-plagued discount chain which is seeking a new credit agreement from banks. Shipments of clothing, hardware, soft drinks and other products needed to fill Ames' shelves for spring have been suspended for the last month by some suppliers who say they haven't been paid for earlier deliveries, The Wall Street Journal reported Thursday. The report comes as Ames tries to dig itself out of a cash crunch by selling stores and cutting jobs. Ames announced Monday that it lost an estimated $288 million in the fiscal year ending Jan. 27 because of lower than anticipated sales at the former Zayre stores Ames bought in 1988. It also announced it was negotiating with banks for a credit agreement. The $788 million acquisition of the 392-store Zayre chain doubled Ames' size and transformed the company from a little-known New England-based chain into the nation's fourth-largest discounter. As part of the credit agreement it is seeking, Ames plans to close 74 unprofitable stores. The company is negotiating to sell the inventory of those stores to Jerome Schottentein, a Columbus, Ohio, merchandise liquidator. The retailer also said Monday it will slash 200 jobs at its corporate headquarters in Rocky Hill. Ames officials did not return telephone calls seeking comment on the Journal report. The newspaper reported that Gerber Childrenswear Inc., a unit of Gerber Products Co., said it will not ship $1 million worth of spring wear ordered by Ames until it is paid a portion of the $1.2 million owed by Ames for winter clothing shipped earlier. The Journal also reported that Pepsico Inc. said it will not make soft drink deliveries to Ames unless it is paid in cash. Retail analysts said the suppliers' actions could touch off a downward spiral for Ames if the company is unable to convince key vendors that it can turn itself around. ``Unfortunately, when these situations occur, they tend to have a snowball effect,'' said Alan Millstein, publisher of The Fashion Network, a monthly newsletter for retailers and manufacturers. ``This becomes and has a tendency to spread like wildfire,'' he said. Jeffrey Branman, managing director for Financo Inc., a New York investment bank that specializes in retail industry transactions, said the slowdown in deliveries from suppliers is particularly critical coming at the start of the spring season, when shoppers expect new clothing lines to come in. ``What can happen is that because vendors tend to act en masse, it can turn a modest cash shortage into a big cash shortage,'' said Branman. Analysts cited a similar problem experienced by two Campeau Corp. subsidiaries, Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. Earlier this year, a shutdown by suppliers helped force the subsidiaries into filing for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal Bankruptcy Code. Some analysts said they believe the company can bounce back from its current problems by moving quickly to convince suppliers they will be paid. ``Most of the people who are selling to them don't want to see Ames go away. ... If they can get their key vendors paid and in line, I think they'll be OK,'' said Joseph Ahearn, a retail industry analyst for GDL Management Inc., a New York-based crisis management consulting firm. Millstein said the most important thing for Ames to do now is to ``put a very positive spin'' on their operations with Ames. ``It becomes an issue of how quickly they can convince their suppliers that they are not a credit risk,'' he said.

DOC.TEXT: The stock market broke the stalemate of the past several sessions with a rally in quiet pre-holiday trading Thursday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 22.07 to 2,751.80, finishing the week with a net gain of 34.68 points. That snapped a streak of six consecutive trading days in which the Dow industrials neither rose nor fell by as much as 10 points. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 8 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 908 up, 573 down and 518 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came 142.47 million shares, against 141.08 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 173.70 million shares. Analysts said traders came into the session with low expectations, given the market's recent sluggish behavior and the approach of a long holiday weekend. The markets will be closed for Good Friday. In that kind of environment, observers said, an absence of selling pressure helped produce some pleasant surprises in the price fluctuations of individual stocks. The government reported that retail sales dropped 0.6 percent in March, in contrast to advance estimates of a small increase. That served as a new suggestion of continued sluggish, erratic economic growth, along with possibly less upward pressure on interest rates than has been feared of late. Brokers also noted that favorable earnings reports from several companies contributed to the upbeat mood. For example, Chemical Banking, which posted higher quarterly profits, gained 1[ to 24{. Most other money-center bank issues moved up in sympathy. Federal National Mortgage jumped 1} to 36}. On Wednesday the company, known as Fannie Mae, chalked up a 67 percent increase in its first-quarter profits. Fannie Mae warrants, which give their owners the right to buy the stock at $14.75 a share, rose 1{ to 21~. Gainers among the blue-chip industrials included General Electric, up 1[ at 66; International Business Machines, up } at 107[; McDonald's, up { at 32|; Procter & Gamble, up { at 71\, and Coca-Cola, up { at 80{. Ames Department Stores led the active list, down | at 1~ on reports that some manufacturers had stopped shipping merchandise to the troubled retailer. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $21.15 billion, or 0.64 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks added 1.23 to 188.80. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 2.84 to 399.96, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 2.42 at 344.34. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market gained 2.78 to 436.31. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 357.88, up .34.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Decline, Dollar Inches Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with morning Nikkei, dollar
DOC.TEXT: Share prices fell on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday morning and the dollar moved slightly higher against the yen. Trading was very quiet in Japan's financial markets ahead of the weekend, especially because many markets in Europe and the United States will be closed later in the day because of Good Friday. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues lost 302.96 points, or 1 percent, closing the morning session at 29,320.24. The index gained 182.92 points Thursday. The dollar was changing hands at 158.33 yen, up 0.33 yen from Thursday's close. After opening at 158.27 yen, the currency ranged between 158.22 yen and 158.40 yen. Shinji Tanaka, a currency dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank, said trading was ``very quiet'' with most players retreating to the sidelines. On the stock market, the Nikkei index initially fell on index-linked arbitrage selling and then on small-lot selling, securities dealers said. In arbitrage trading, investors seek to profit from differences between prices of actual stocks and stock index futures. Yoshihide Koyama, an equity analyst with Nikko Securites, attributed the fall in the index to speculation that Japan's central bank may raise its official discount rate once again in an attempt to stem the yen's downswing. The Bank of Japan raised its key rate last month by 1 percentage point to 5.25 percent. Higher interest rates tend to support a country's currency, but discourage stock investment. Government bond prices fell during the morning, boosting interest rates. The yield on the benchmark No. 119 government bond rose to 7.37 percent from 7.295 percent Thursday.
